node.author: TBY
node.title: Schools
node.sections01: The curriculum in Colombia is not typically designed for real-life skills. To be successful, skills such as speaking, listening, and teamwork are needed—things we encourage from pre-school and lower elementary onward. Here, we emphasize teamwork. In general, though, students are not exposed to real cooperative learning in the design of their classes or lesson plans. After 20 years of education, many have still not learned how to successfully and effectively work in teams with the skills needed to be successful in any company, or even neighborhood or larger country, for that matter. The huge curriculum challenges in Colombia's educational system cannot be assessed through a standardized test. Companies will not hire a manager or a CEO through a multiple-choice test, so we do not do that for teachers either. We also expose students to adversarial relationships so they learn how to communicate with other people from a young age rather than perpetuate conflicts that have been around for so many years.
node.sections11: CNG was an educational pioneer when the school started back in 1938. We were the first school in Colombia to provide bilingual and bicultural education. The major bottleneck to advancing more and better bilingual education programs in Colombia lies in producing enough high-quality bilingual teachers. We are one of the few educational institutions with a bilingual teacher education/training program. We train approximately 40-80 bilingual teachers in conjunction with íšNICA University every semester; however, the need in this country far outpaces the availability of bilingual educators. That is the major challenge. For those of us who are highly involved in bilingual teacher education, we are able to have highly fluent teachers making an impact on kids every day, but we are the exception to the rule. Although the Colombian government is focused on this bilingual education initiative, there is a great need for bilingual teachers, while supply falls short of what is necessary. We have to put together a systematic approach to teacher education in order to produce quality bilingual teachers to fill that need.
node.sections21: For the past 50 years, Colombia has worked hard to make education more accessible, which has been one of our main challenges. Today, education is geographically much more widely available, particularly in the main urban centers, but the question is now about the quality or level of education. Colombia needs to focus on training high-level teachers and educators. We need to increase our competitiveness on an international level. Gimnasio Moderno has shown that this is possible, as we have produced a number of notable alumni in many different sectors. There is also another more general issue about preparing excellent citizens for the country. Corruption has been a plague on Colombia for a long time, and this is a long-term issue about educating people, starting from when they are children, on how to be positive players in society. Our educational institutions also need to address our growing problem with polarization.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Colombia is entering a post-conflict era, which demands citizens capable of adding to a more just, peaceful, and sustainable society.
node.title: Universities
node.sections01: 2017 is important for the Universidad Nacional de Colombia. This is a public university, and we have a presence throughout Colombia. Universidad Nacional de Colombia is the only university with a nationwide presence. To celebrate our 150th anniversary we have arranged a seminar with a specially invited group of important professors and academics who will speak about various topics relevant to the university. The main goal of this event is to celebrate and explain the story of the university and the influence it has had in the development of Colombia. Education will play a major role in the post-conflict era because the reason for the conflict was inequality, which is related to a lack of access to education and opportunities. Furthermore, Universidad Nacional de Colombia is included in the actual peace accord itself; the university will have an active role in reintegrating former FARC fighters and afflicted communities into the education system. We are also tasked with undertaking a census to assess the level of engagement such communities and groups currently have with the education system and their needs moving forward.
node.sections11: After 40 years of working with the academic community of this university to bring the Colombian economy excellent professionals, especially in the healthcare sector, which is our main field, we decided in 2010 to obtain the highest quality accreditation in Colombia, a move that is optional for universities here and which many quality ones still do not have. After six years of work, last June we obtained recognition from the government as a high-quality university, which started off a new phase for us. We will have to work more, be more meaningful for the community, and produce more knowledge. We need to focus on health and the quality of life. We also want to show that although medicine is important, we have 120 programs. We seek to expand the university outside of this campus and hope to build a new building. We also want to develop our culture, which is why we have an art school, a design school, and what we call a creation school. This is another important area of focus. Right now, we are only in Bogotá but have another campus in Chí­a. We want to get our accreditation before we go into other cities.
node.sections21: Education is the basis of any philosophy of peace; it is a concept and idea that is transmitted and guaranteed through education. The Universidad Externado has many projects to this effect, mostly in collaboration with the Ministry of Post-Conflict, and with other universities and educational institutions, especially in areas that were most heavily affected by the conflict. The objective is to educate the general population on the importance and value of peace by supporting and creating new diplomas and programs in line with these goals. To do so, we are creating 100-hour degrees and organizing many academic events. There are 10 in 2017 alone that will talk about the post-conflict process and achieving permanent peace. This is not just of importance to Colombia; the Colombian peace process is an example for the rest of the world and a model and inspiration for similar conflicts in other countries and regions around the world. We can show them what is changing, how, and most importantly, that change for the better is possible.
node.sections31: There are some issues that we as a country are very much aware of; however, going out to the rural areas outside the main cities and having a much more thorough, meaningful, and important relationship with the different regions in the country will be paramount. Today, important things are happening, programs that are making private and expensive universities more accessible to lower-income sectors. Accessibility is one of the biggest higher educational challenges here. Another is financing, which for higher education is difficult; quality higher education is expensive. The peace process will require a great deal of resources, and we will need wise decisions to see where we allocate those resources, among which of course will be higher education. We are talking about more resources for higher education and more resources for financing the lower-income class that cannot afford the cost of universities. One thing that characterizes Latin America is that we have some excellent universities scattered among many lesser ones in every country in the region.
node.sections41: La Sabana has developed a curricular management model that seeks to develop the relevant competencies in students for them to go beyond the technical abilities and be able to transform specific situations, problems, or needs into positive solutions, with a sense of respect and service-oriented attitude, thus adding to the development of their country. We are also preparing our students to develop international competencies. We have 10,000 undergraduate students and around 3,500 graduate students and are committed to developing an international profile in each of them. We focus on the development of international competencies in our students and have a strong bilingual education where they have to achieve a certain English proficiency assessed by international examinations before they can graduate in order to be competent and have the skills to apply for international universities and jobs. We also have around 130 agreements with different international higher education partners to provide international experiences for our students, both in our campus and abroad.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Clinics & Hospitals
node.sections01: We have three ways to oversee our company and its growth: the first is the annual budget, the second one is a three-year strategic plan, and the third is our guide, which we call the Mega Plan, a 10-year plan the first year of which we have just begun. Our main target in this mega plan is to be in 12 countries, have around 30 million users, 80,000 employees, and 720 medical centers; not just hospitals, but what we call a one-stop clinic. 2016 is the first year of our grand plan, and in terms of countries to be developed we are now at seven out of 12. We are in Colombia, where we have our headquarters, and in Brazil, Peru, and Venezuela; these are our historical base. We are moving into Mexico, where we also now have a presence, and the US, where we have presence in Florida and Connecticut. We are also in the Philippines and have an expansion area in Indonesia, Vietnam, and probably some countries in Eastern Europe.
node.sections11: Our most important business is insurance, but our group operates in many different areas, including insurance, surgical supply, and laboratory operations. Two years ago, we started a joint venture with a Portuguese laboratory and developed a new brand, ALTADIS. Our most important project for 2017 is our new hospital, a huge facility we plan on opening in August 2017. This is important because we are the only group that has such a diverse portfolio of operations in such a wide variety of areas. Unlike many of our major competitors who operate in one area, we have businesses in many different parts of the industry. In 2015, we had a clinic and insurance company in Panama; however, now we are refocusing more specifically on the Colombian market and want to spend much of our energy expanding our medical insurance and medical services businesses in Colombia.
node.sections21: We are always thinking about expansion. Considering that we started with 65 beds and one facility in Bogotá and now have several buildings that complete the complex, we have a history of growth. We are always growing to provide the people in Bogotá excellent care because demand has been growing. We have developed a reputation for good quality, so people asked for us. We also started a new facility in the northwest part of the city, which is Clí­nica La Colina, one of our latest expansion attempts. We opened this new facility in 2013, since we were not allowed to grow as we wished in Clinica del Country's area due to regulations, we hope that in the near future we will be able to provide additional beds in the city to meet the increasing demand. We are always focused on private medicine, but that does not mean we do not get public patients.
node.sections31: We started our operation nine years ago with the same HR, staff, and people that were working for the main insurance company that was dissolved by the government at the time. One of our main goals was to keep the same team and the same people together, but at the same time to change the culture and recover the humanization through activities focused on the patients and their families. We seek for society to recognize our work as a new model of attention and heath management. We have three plans for the future in terms of investments. The first one points to additional investments of USD40 million infrastructure and new medical equipment by 2020. The second is related to gaining the High Quality accreditation both as a hospital and a teaching hospital. The third point is to develop a research program in order to design clinical trials and studies.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: With a rapidly growing economy and greater purchasing power, the pharma market is expected to develop by leaps and bounds.
node.title: Pharmaceuticals
node.sections01: For national producers of pharmaceutical products, especially in the institutional sectors, the effects of the peace process are great. Three major ones have been identified. First, we will have more consumers since more people will demobilize from the guerrillas and become part of society. Second, we will have more opportunities to reach areas once controlled by the guerrillas. The third is that we can finally focus on solving other problems afflicting our country such as corruption. We are planning for growth of 30% in units of production in Mexico in 2017 and 2018. That will lead to physical plant growth as well as human capital. In Colombia, we are also planning to grow by more than 25% new units. What is more, Grupo Ave produces 25% of the units that go into the institutional sector. Every year, we export half of the 150 million units we produce to the rest of Latin America and the Caribbean, excluding Argentina and Brazil.
node.sections11: Official healthcare coverage in Colombia is around 94%, which is a sizable number compared to developed countries. In addition, it is an evolving market where the rules are changing in order to provide more access to more Colombians. Even though the number of people covered is high, the government wants to raise the breadth and depth of coverage further. These are positive signs, although still a rocky path in the future to achieve the goals. We have complete faith in this market, and we plan to be the fastest-growing affiliate for three years. We have various strategies to bring this about. We want to make our products available for those 94% of Colombians, improve access, and work with the Colombian government to achieve that. We want more quality healthcare for more Colombians, and so does the government; therefore, we need to work together to achieve this common goal and see how we can keep expanding coverage to yet more Colombians.
node.sections21: Cipla has been present here in Colombia for over 20 years through a network of distributors. We were well known in the healthcare community, and were often asked why we were not in Colombia directly and operating with distributors instead. Colombia is a growing USD4-5 billion pharma market. The other factor that led to our direct entry into this market was the therapies we focus on. We are large globally on respiratory, HIV, and oncology therapies, and these fit very well with what was most in demand by patients here in the country. The country's location is central and relatively close to our US office in Miami. In addition, there is high quality of human capital and talent for pharma here. Thirdly, there is ease of doing business here. To incorporate a company here was quite simple and a smooth process. We set up our business here quickly and got great support from local entities.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Real Estate Companies
node.sections01: The office market in Bogotá is the center of operations. While Medellí­n is perhaps increasing the participation of offices, the average transaction in Bogotá is between 1,000 and 2,000sqm, while in Medellí­n it is closer to 200. The reality is that the office market is in Bogotá. It is possible to find some 50-60sqm office projects in Bucaramanga or Pereira for local lawyers or architects; however, that is it. From an industrial or logistics point of view, the strangest cities will turn out to be logistics hubs. For example, the town where the road from Medellí­n connects with that of Bucaramanga will turn into a logistic center because of its specific location. The 4G plan will have a special impact on roads that will completely change the logistics market. This will generate huge development opportunities in the next few years, causing the logistics of the country to change massively. This is what we are targeting: we need to understand where these roads are being planned and how they will go through. Nor should we forget the new hubs that will be created once the Magdalena River is traversed. Altogether, there will be huge opportunities for developers and investors who understand these new logistics.
node.sections11: Opportunities for the future will mostly come about in the cities. There will not be much going on in offices and office buildings as it is saturated, with a great deal of supply and low demand. Housing, on the other hand, will depend on the socioeconomic and demographic segment in question. There will be low demand at the highest level, but demand at the lower end will be considerable. Colombia has a housing deficit that needs to be met, and the government subsidizes the lower income segments. The same goes for hotels. Hotels had tax incentives until 2017; however, without the tax advantage, that industry will also slow down in 2018. We expect market conditions to remain the same in the malls and retail segment as well, with the concern that rental prices are not growing at the same rate as the value some of commercial real estate assets. In the last few years, foreign investment increased in Colombia. There were private individuals seeking to purchase in tourism destinations like Cartagena as well as investors who came here for business purposes. We also have certain foreign capital funds, both private and mixed, that come to purchase or rent land to develop in the country.
node.sections21: In 2015 and 2016, we focused on planting the seeds of the company, to put together the ideas and strategies we want to harvest in the long term. Last year was an important year because most of the projects we handled broke even. In 2017, we need to harvest all the effort and hard work we've been doing so far. We started construction on three of the projects where we broke even, and this year we will focus on making an excellent final product for those who believed in us. It is a year to focus and grow intelligently because one of the important things that young companies face is the internal growth of the company. They have to grow intelligently and in strategic areas so this is the year to focus on materializing the projects we have been working on. We also want to make a strategic plan for the next years, from 2018-2022. We are already covered through 2018 but want to look beyond that. It will be a busy year, and we have a great deal of work to do. We have many partners and colleagues to work for and materialize everything we have been working on.
node.sections31: The real estate market in Colombia is a dynamic one. In 2017, we expected it to be a little slower than it is now. The sector has been growing in housing, retail, industry and offices. Colombia is a country of cities. We have the major cities of Bogotá, Medellí­n, Barranquilla, Cali, and Bucaramanga. Every city behaves differently in the market. In Bogotá, there are so many people that housing is one of the most important sectors of real estate, especially for lower income housing. I am on the board of directors for a construction company and all we do is low-income housing because it sells well and there is a great demand. Prices in Bogotá are high compared to other cities in Colombia. In Medellí­n, there is a problem as there is not enough land to build housing spaces for low-income segment. So, they have built in towns around Medellí­n instead of inside the cities limits. For the high-income segment, they are building in El Poblado. Some of investors coming from abroad would rather be in Medellí­n than Bogotá. It is the only city in Colombia with a metro and the transportation system overall is good. Even though traffic is getting heavy, it is not as heavy as Bogotá.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Infrastructure
node.sections01: The PPP infrastructure projects are long term. Yet, at the same time, previously made errors need to be corrected. This is the fourth generation of projects. We had three generations before with different financial structures and responsibilities for constructors. All these projects need to have a clear structure, especially when determining who is in charge of what and who bears the risk. The financing is the most important element in the success of these projects; if the contract is clear on how risk is assigned, then the projects will be easily financed. Then, the challenge is to successfully raise financing for the projects. The main obstacle the sector is facing is the fact that sponsors face bottlenecks when it comes to getting bank guarantees for equity contributions. The bank guarantees the sponsor equity contributions, but the sponsors have to provide to bank with liquid collateral in order to receive that guarantee. Therefore, the main obstacle is the collateral for equity guarantees. Our pipeline is full for another five years, but then we have to start getting things moving on other fronts. We have to finance and prepare other projects. We have construction between today and the next four years in all of the projects, and we are already thinking about what our pipeline will be after 2019 and 2020.
node.sections11: The 4G concessions took so long because they had to qualify for many conditions. First, it took a great deal of time to gather the financial resources. The first concession consisted of 10 projects that should have started in April 2015 but, due to a lack of funds, actually started in June 2016. There is also the fact that the big concessions had to buy the land to build on and get the environmental licenses. These two processes take a long time. The industry itself cannot do anything to facilitate and speed up the process. Many companies need a great deal of resources; the first 4G projects have finally started but still need new financing partners. To get off the ground, 70% of the financing is on credit and 30% has to be equity in cash. We want all projects to start operating in the first half of 2017 so that we are ready to move aggressively into 2018, which should be our best year yet. In these specific 4G projects, it is both difficult and different, as the risks are now on the company whereas before they were mainly on the public. For this reason, it was hard to get insurance because everyone was worried about how the projects were developing.
node.sections21: About 70% of the productive centers in Colombia are divided between its two coasts. 4G infrastructure projects such as Alto Magdalena are making these productive centers available and connected internally and to the world. We have an outstanding reputation because we always finalize and reach the financial closing of our products. We do this in accordance with our commitment to society and the development of Colombia. We have a macro commitment to the 4G projects that will connect Colombia to the world. We also have a micro commitment to our communities to bring progress as well. The social responsibility we follow is not only internal as a company but is focused on the local communities as well as the rest of the country. It is difficult to finance all these large-scale 4G projects, but Colombia is committed and has smart people working to find the best way to finance them. Pavimentos has a history of social responsibility and being a committed company so this will definitely help. We are not the largest, but we have one of the best reputations in the country. The participation of foreign companies is important in this process, especially in terms of financing. We are looking for foreign companies that are transparent, that will create a win-win situation for us and the country.
node.sections31: We decided to come to Colombia because it was developing strong infrastructure and had a bright future. In these four years, we have changed perceptions about purchasing equipment. This new perception allowed us to sell 50 rigs in a market that traditionally purchased two or three rigs per year, 80% of which were used. The market continues to appreciate our work, despite the fact that this year was a difficult one, and we continue to provide excellent products. Economically speaking, I have many expectations because the government has been trying to bring investment through the peace deal. In the last three years, investment in the country has diminished. The only thing that can change the situation dramatically is a large influx of money and investment into the country. We have many projects that have been approved but that lack financing, and we need to find some way to correct this. FDI is the way to do this, but if other states and multinationals do not have a guarantee that the process will be transparent and business operations will be safe and smooth, they will not come. The impact of the deal will mostly come in terms of the perception and reputation of the country, and this is a vital aspect of attracting business and activity to Colombia.
node.sections41: In each of the 13 countries where VINCI Highways operates, we are strongly committed to supporting regional development and attractiveness. This is also our ambition in Colombia. With the 4G plan, Colombian authorities intend to close the country's infrastructure gap, and we are proud to support this national objective with the VÍA 40 EXPRESS project. On VIA 40 Express, our number one challenge is technical. To take on the challenges, we draw on all of the VINCI Group's expertise and have also entered into a strategic partnership with Constructora Conconcreto, a company the VINCI Group has been working with for many years. Together, under the leadership of the National Infrastructure Agency, we will play on our experience and expertise to meet the schedule and successfully deliver. Beyond those technical aspects, we are committed to ensure maximum satisfaction of our clients. And we also pay particular attention to local integration, ensuring VIA 40 Express will be a significant growth driver for local communities and the region. VIA 40 Express is already the fourth generation of PPP projects in Colombia. The National Infrastructure Agency has been achieving strong progress in terms of structuring contracts, adapting legislation, awarding, and following the implementation of PPP projects in Colombia. The peace agreement this year should reinforce even further this positive trend, enhancing the stability of the country.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Intermodal transport
node.sections01: Our biggest opportunity is our location in the Caribbean and Cartagena's extremely focal point at the geographical heart of the country's commercial life with the rest of the world. In this century of commerce, an activity that dominates 50% of our national economy, Cartagena will be key to Colombia's prosperity. With technology, everything has changed quickly over the past two years—not just the last 20 years. The older locks of the Panama Canal used to support ships up to 4,500 TEUs. With the new expansion that limit is now up to 18,000 TEU. In fact, only about 10 days after the new locks were opened did we see the first big vessel in these waters, which we accommodated with ease.
node.sections11: In the colonial days, Cartagena was one of the three most important cities in the Caribbean, and when the new airport is opened it will be an important player in the region once again. In addition to its industry, port, logistics, and tourism, the airport's connectivity will help it become one of the most important hubs in the Caribbean. The capacity of the current Cartagena Airport infrastructure is below what the city needs to fulfill current traffic demands. There is a bottleneck at the airport since it is behind the rate of growth of the rest of the city. Cartagena is a tourist hub that needs connectivity with the rest of the world; the total land of the airport expansion is about 100ha, and since it is so close to both the city and the sea, there is no room to grow the capacity of the actual airport. The actual infrastructure does not have a parallel runway for aircraft to taxi, and this is a big limitation on the number of operations per hour the airport can handle.
node.sections21: Transport in Colombia is a matter of national competitiveness. The country has at the moment more than 40 international trade agreements and our borders are open to the world markets; however, it is said that moving a container from Asia to any of the Colombian ports costs less than moving the same container from our ports to the major centers of production and consumption located inland. Holdtrade Atlantico fits into this vision by offering a bimodal more cost efficient alternative for linking the Port of Santa Marta, located on the Caribbean, and the interior of the country, where more than 70% of the GNP is generated. Our studies show that savings in the cost of transport for freight—depending on the volumes, products, and routes—could be as high as 20%.
node.sections31: From a geographical and logistics perspective, Barrancabermeja is the heart of the Colombian economy—today and the future. All of our roads and train infrastructure used to run parallel to the river because it is the natural way to develop and transform fluvial transportation. We are thus in the right location to move the largest amount of products that come in and out of the country and the right location for the future development of the country. Here we provide direct access to the Caribbean, Cartagena, and the port of Barranquilla. Barrancabermeja is equidistant from the Cundinamarca region, where Bogotá is the capital, and from the Antioquia region, where Medellí­n is the capital, and both regions, along with Santander, represent over 60% of the Colombian GDP. As a result, we are the best logistics solution for 60% of the current Colombian GDP. On the other side, we have developed our port to serve all of Colombia's transport needs. We have an infrastructure that can move bulks, liquids, solids, containers, and general cargo; we provide solutions to every range of products that exists on the Colombian market.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Developments in the automotive sector, such as more competitive car prices and better road infrastructure, leave international distributors optimistic about the future.
node.title: Distributors
node.sections01: Hyundai is a strong brand. We will have a network of dealers for the public service segment where Hyundai has been a leader for many years, having 62% of the total market in 2010-2011. Our intention is to return to being leaders in that segment of the market. We have a separate network for passenger cars and are improving all our facilities, including our showrooms and technical support. Our strategy is also to participate in more segments. For example, we now have a small SUV and will bring in two hybrid vehicles. We are also bringing in a new model to participate in the crossover segment. Covering more segments will help us reach our targets. We seek to have 6.7% of the total market in 2017. We are also bringing in commercial vehicles from small buses all the way through to trucks. Hyundai has a new design in the commercial vehicles area, which is a huge segment in the market. Currently, we are not considering high-end, although Hyundai does have high-end models. The mid-term plan is to bring some of our high-end vehicles into Colombia to reinforce the perception of the brand here. In the past Hyundai was attached to public service functions, such as taxis. We want to show that there is a great deal more to Hyundai than taxis.
node.sections11: The Colombian market is the second-largest market in South America behind Brazil. We have showrooms in Bogotá and Medellí­n, and in September we have plans to open another showroom in Cali to cover the three main cities of Colombia. We have 28 showrooms of dealers throughout the country and 21 workshops for maintenance and the warranty. JMC is a unique brand and has gone up 50% compared to last year. Although the market is 20% smaller than last year, this year our target is to double our sales in trucks, pick ups, and SUV; last year we sold just 328 units, and this year our target is 600 units. And we look forward to selling up to 2,000 units within three years. Over the last three years, more and more Chinese brands have come to Colombia because of the new visa policy. Previously, it was hard to get a visa from China; now that it is easier, many Chinese brands have built factories or offices here and have brought their knowledge, technology, and employees to the country. We are the first Chinese brand to build a headquarter office, direct showroom, spare parts storage, and workshop in Colombia. Chinese brands have huge opportunity in Colombia; however, we need help from the government and banks to offer more support for long-term relationship development, especially credit facility for final clients.
node.sections21: In 2010, SKBergé took over the Chrysler, Jeep Dodge operations in Colombia. The last brand that joined our Colombian operations was Fiat. We were able to take over Fiat in November of 2016 and began sales in May 2017. We are new to Colombia but familiar with its operations from our headquarters in Chile, where SKBergé also distributes both Chrysler brands and Fiat. The plan was to follow the same model of leveraging the Fiat brand within the Chrysler-Jeep-Dodge network, which we already have here. Until May 2017, our entry price vehicle was the Dodge Journey, at COP69 million, and now we are adding a wide portfolio to the same dealer network, with a number of Fiat models. It is a way to leverage our operations with the right investment; the infrastructure is already in place for this to succeed. In our dealer network, we have the infrastructure to sell 5,000-6,000 units a year, but we are only selling 2,000 units. With Fiat, we should be able to increase the volumes from 2,000 to 5,000 in the coming years. It is a way to take advantage of our current infrastructure with a low investment. For the short term, we are focused on strength. We are reinforcing our team here in Colombia and bringing our successful practices to Colombia.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Director General-Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Venezuela
node.previewsummary: Significant investment in Colombia's airports have been made in the last several years and with incomes and the number of airline passengers expected to increase in the future, there are many opportunities for airlines to grow.
node.title: Airlines
node.sections01: Copa Airlines Colombia has successfully served primary and secondary markets in Colombia through what have been three challenging years. We have a quality product that is well regarded by the market to withstand a difficult economic environment. Our quality product awards are perhaps one of the highlights for Copa because of the product delivery consistency we have maintained for decades throughout our network. We received Skytrax recognition as the Best Airline of Central America and the Caribbean, Best Airline Personnel in Central America, and Best Regional Airline of Central America. As for punctuality, Copa Airlines was recognized as the most punctual airline in Latin America by Flightstats and the second-most punctual airline in the world by OAG. On top of this we have grown significantly. Over the last seven years Copa has increased its available seat miles in 50%, nearly doubling the number of aircraft in our fleet. Our corporate focus in serving primary and secondary markets in Latin America with a well-thought-out network with the best schedule choices and shortest connecting times has enabled us to do all this in an orderly fashion while maintaining the quality of our product. Copa Airlines serves key regions in each country we fly to, which differentiates us from other airlines. In Colombia, we connect eight cities in the country: Bogotá, Cali, Medellí­n, Cartagena, Barranquilla, Pereira, Bucaramanga, and San Andrés.
node.sections11: We started in 1967 with the first flight to Bogotá, a multi-sector flight with several legs that included New York. Today, we operate a daily flight to Frankfurt with Airbus A340-300 in which we offer business, premium economy, and economy class. It connects not only Colombia to Germany, but also Colombia with the rest of the world through our main hub of Frankfurt. Through our operations in Bogotá, we offer our customers the entire Andean region. Our customers from Ecuador, Venezuela, Peru, Bolivia, and Colombia can reach the rest of the world through Bogotá. There will definitely be a positive impact on the aviation sector in the context of the post-conflict era. Significantly, Colombia has reached a visa-waiver agreement with the EU, allowing Colombians to travel to Europe for up to 90 days on tourist visas. Many Colombians also have family ties to Europe. This certainly brings Germany and Colombia closer together and has already shown itself in passenger numbers, which have posted positive growth. When bridges are built across countries rather than walls, the numbers grow. For Lufthansa Group, we have different kinds of customers. We transport Colombian businessmen and families traveling abroad on our flights, but we also have tourists and investors coming from the other side. We also have people coming to Colombia to start a business.
node.sections21: Satena is a different, alternative airline; we are the only airline flying to the most remote parts of the country to bring development to these areas regardless of whether it is profitable. Satena was created in 1962 with the help of the government to reach remote areas, though the focus has now shifted to bringing these places as much development as possible. Satena started a new initiative with El Dorado Airport to increase plane parking spaces to reduce waiting time on runways by 25 minutes. This is one of the main initiatives we have to make Satena and the entire system more efficient. At present, 90% of Satena's destinations have huge potential to become eco-tourism hubs. However, it is not just about transporting people to these places; we are also in partnership with local institutions to develop their whole infrastructure and craft a larger, richer experience. Remote areas are important for the post-conflict era, especially for tourism, because few people have had the chance to visit them. The challenge that Satena has in bringing in more people to these remote areas and following their development will contribute to their economic growth. We already plan to expand our number of flights and destinations. The key word is security, and this was brought by the post-conflict peace deal, which helps to shore up confidence in Colombia as a safe place to visit.
node.sections31: Copa felt there was an opportunity in Colombia to create a new airline, Wingo, firstly because Colombia is ranked third in Latin America, behind Mexico and Brazil, in terms of passenger traffic. Passenger numbers are also expected to grow further with Colombia's economic reforms and the peace treaty. Secondly, there has been an important shift in the low-, middle-, and high-income classes here. Around 50% of the Colombian population is predicted to be in the middle-income bracket by 2020. Again, this gives opportunities for more air travel. Third, we felt there was an important opportunity in the fact that Copa already had a subsidiary here with a permit to operate, which was a real asset. Colombia is a strategically located country with a large degree of internal and external air traffic. There are many important cities within Colombia compared to other Latin America countries that only have one major city. A low-cost carrier here is the perfect fit for a burgeoning middle class that desires to travel more as well as for a country that still has land transportation infrastructure problems due to its geography. Two out of every 10 Colombians travel abroad, which is a low rate. Copa's product mission was to encourage Colombians to travel more internationally, but it was not affordable. With Wingo, we want to make overseas travel affordable for Colombians and Latin Americans in general.
node.sections41: Colombia is the second-largest market in South America and LATAM Airlines has a share of around 22% of this market. Colombia has strong growth potential. The impact of the peace process will definitely be positive, though it will not be felt right away. Colombia needs to accompany the peace process with continued investments in infrastructure, not only in airports, but also in related services and hospitality infrastructure. Some regions are a long way behind with this. International tourism will increase, but only at the rate of investment in the sector. We are pleased with the tourism corridors that are being developed by the government; these are the types of initiatives the government needs to put in place. Today, we see certain positive signs in terms of the tourism offering, though not yet the demand. It will happen, though. The right environment has to be set up to receive those new tourists before they start coming in. We believe local tourism will increase as well. The airline industry has to drive this by providing more efficient and economic air travel options. In other markets, the number of airline passengers increases exponentially compared to the rate of growth in the economy when prices are lower. Over the next three or four years, one challenge will be allowing the industry to provide lower prices to stimulate an increase in consumer demand.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Digital Transformation
node.sections01: Informese has been in the analytics market for 25 years. This is an ever-changing environment and market. Getting analytics to be part of the decision-making process is an area where we have had many challenges and continue our hard work. It is constantly evolving as new technologies appear, new data sources arrive, and new ways of processing information enter the market. Our challenge is how to make use of the best technologies available and bring them to market in such a way that it is comprehensible for people not used to statistics and analytics. Getting people and organizations to realize how these help them to make better decisions is our key goal. We have the challenge of growing and adopting technologies at a much faster pace than developed countries.
node.sections11: There are two aspects of being here; one is the talent that we need to develop a product for a global audience. Colombia has smart people, and the vast majority of our development team is here in Bogotá—something we are proud of. Our product is developed here in Colombia. The other aspect in terms of opportunities is that, in any given year, there is always a large country in Latin America in a difficult situation but another in good shape. Right now, Peru is growing aggressively and the countries of Central America together with the Dominican Republic are showing healthy economic growth. That is something we are leveraging. We see healthy investments from specific industries. The same thing is going to happen everywhere, in every single industry. We help in the transformation toward becoming a digital company, and there are many ways to do that.
node.sections21: The Colombian government is working hard to facilitate the transformation of the country's industries, enterprises, and corporations; hence, there are huge opportunities. Colombia is currently the third market in the region after Brazil and Mexico. In most industries in Colombia, our clients are thinking about how to transform their businesses to remain competitive. We can help our clients not only with their strategy to embrace digital transformation, but also with implementing it in the field, which is something some players in our sector cannot do. One obstacle is the lack of implementation capability with some of the service providers. There is plenty of innovation and lots of new products, but rolling these out to scale is the challenge. That said, we are ready to start an aggressive growth period. Our goal is to grow our Colombian business threefold. We are investing a large amount in the country, and we are planning to build a digital hub in Colombia.
node.sections31: The government has nearly connected the entire country. On the downside, we really need to invest more in digital education, especially educating the ecosystem. This is why 100% of our marketing budget goes to the education of the ecosystem. We go to our partners, clients, and agencies, but we also have an open door for people such as Google entrepreneurs, Google developers, and many other initiatives to help people to take advantage of the digital world and all of Google's tools. Technology gives opportunities, and we will soon have 8,000 more people looking to make a new life, and technology is there to help them. Google also supports “A Window to Dream,“ a program for people affected by the conflicts embarking on a new life. We teach them how to use digital assets to create new enterprises and develop their abilities. This is a good example on how technology can be used to help in the peace process.
node.sections41: In the forthcoming era of peace in Colombia, society as a whole cannot successfully be reintegrated if the entire IT industry is not leveraged. This is a huge strength that we can leverage through technology, or lose the opportunity. Microsoft is working with the government to figure out how to draw the digital bridge for every community and citizen, but the government has to have a clear vision of how technology is going to drive the next generation of Colombians. One of the best opportunities for this is the emerging market for products that are built on top of the Microsoft cloud. This is where I believe we have a huge opportunity and where I would invite the industry and government to invest more and capitalize on these opportunities and the eagerness of many entrepreneurs, independent developers, and students in order to start new businesses around intellectual property and digital services.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Textiles
node.sections01: The advantages of Arturo Calle versus international companies is that it already has a presence; we no longer have 100-150sqm premises, but 1,500-2,000sqm, or larger. This makes our products more varied and widely offered. Another important factor is being up to date on the latest sector trends, not to mention the fact that our products often cost half or less than half of their international equivalent. In addition, it is important to have a nationwide presence, which international companies don't have the capacity to do. One only sees international brands with a strong presence in larger cities such as Bogotá, Medellí­n, Cali, and Barranquilla. Beyond physical factors, it is also important to have good customer service so people associate the brand with good people. A few international brands like Falabella and Zara have been successful due to their size and variety, but venturing into Colombia isn't easy. What these populations need is quality and design at extremely low prices, something that international companies cannot offer.
node.sections11: Textiles and fashion should bring more exports to the country and play a bigger role in diversifying its economy and exports. If we go back to 2008-2009, we used to export USD2 billion to the world. Half of this went to Venezuela, while an important percentage went to the US and the rest of the world. When Venezuela went down, it was difficult to export because we were expensive in Venezuela, our peso was strong due to oil, and our internal market was growing. Hence, what happened is that most merchandise that used to go to Venezuela moved and stayed within Colombia. The internal market has been growing 8-10% every year in the last five years but exports have not. In 2016, our exports, excluding to Venezuela, came to around USD750,000, below our figures in 2008 and 2009. First, we need to focus on customers in the US. Second, we need to explore more aggressively in Canada, Europe, and Mexico.
node.sections21: As the country becomes more open and more international products come in, the company needs to compete with the other brands that enter the country. That is why we are producing and trying to bring a new level of quality, as well as the manufacturing and know-how that we have, for leather and the artisans that are working with us. Having all of our manufacturing locally allows us to have greater control over the quality. We are also creating many jobs within the country. Before we start growing outside of the country we have to be very strong here in this growing market. We have been increasing the number of stores we have here in Colombia. We are increasing our options here in Colombia and settling in more to promote our brand.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Industrial Players
node.sections01: We are sure that the implementation of the peace process will generate many growth opportunities, especially in the two areas with the biggest limitations in Colombia today, infrastructure and agriculture. Of course, Dow is active in both sectors through agrochemicals and seeds in agriculture and additives, cement, and other solutions for infrastructure. Our merger with Dupont in 2017 is another opportunity to increase growth. Both Dow and DuPont have a presence in the region, but DuPont does not have assets on the ground whereas we do. Thus, we are not competitors in any of the lines we have in Colombia or anywhere in the Andean region; however, we are complementary. For example, in infrastructure it has some solutions that will be a great addition to what we already have. We are expecting to grow in Colombia between 8% and 10% this year.
node.sections11: One of our company's key focuses is on creating long-term relationships. Mitsubishi Electric de Colombia sold its first elevator in the Colombian market in 1964 and ever since we have focused on nurturing and developing a long-term relationship with the market. Though the country has faced difficult times over the last 50 years, we never left because we believed the market was an excellent long-term source of growth. We have a long history in Colombia and have contributed to the sustainability of its economy and society in important ways. The impact of business operations on society as a whole is one of Mitsubishi's core considerations, and we have transferred that type of thinking and strategizing to the Colombian market. Our 50-year presence in Colombia has shown the people that we are dedicated to the country in many different ways.
node.sections21: The Colombian market is important because our participation here is not as high as in other countries. On average, we have a market share of 30% in countries in which we operate, while in Colombia it is around 17-18%. The idea is to achieve similar levels of market participation by introducing new technology in the Colombian market. For example, we have industrial heaters that use 30% less energy than the rest of the market. But the problem is the price, which is important in the Colombian market. The biggest opportunity I see is in the hydraulic line because here we only have 4% of market share and the potential is high in mining and oil, among others. The oil industry is not so high-tech, and we can offer this technology here. It is high-tech in Europe, and we have a chance to introduce this technology here and upgrade the existing machinery accordingly.
node.sections31: Colombia has been one of the most strategic countries in Latin America for L'Oréal. Therefore, in 2013 the group decided to heavily invest in Colombia by buying a local company for the first time. We acquired Vogue, which is the number-one make-up company in Colombia, as part of our strategy to become the number-one beauty company in Colombia, as we already are in the world. Growing in market share in countries like Colombia is how we will meet our goal of finding 1 billion new consumers. We are launching international brands such as Urban Decay and NYX here and bringing the Garnier Fructis range into the Colombian market. There is a large currently unsatisfied appetite for these products in Colombia that we are looking to fill. We also made a USD30 million investment in a new factory to increase production in Colombia and exports throughout the region.
node.sections41: Colombia represents the second-largest country in South America and the second-largest market in the region for Michelin. In the last two years, we experienced a devaluation of the currency and deceleration of the major motor of growth of the economy that helped the previous growth from 2012-2014. In terms of business, this meant we had to reorganize our operation by looking for efficiencies, cost reduction, and focusing on customers' needs to really be consistent in our delivered value. Despite the last two years being difficult, we performed well and outperformed the market by growing in market share in every segment. We did this because we are focused on innovation and renewed approximately 80% of our portfolio. In every segment, we consistently innovate to be able to deliver great added value to customers for bikes, trucks, passenger cars, light trucks, and the mining sector.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Mining
node.sections01: When we started, we identified a large number of illegal mines. Our challenge was to have a model for our business that would formalize these mines by incorporating them in our operations. Our operating model incorporates formalized contract miners, which we call the Small Productive Production Chain Initiative. In this model, the company seeks to involve communities and artisanal miners within our operations, with the goal to improve the living and working conditions of the miners and contribute to the economic and social development of the region and the country. Much of our production today comes from this contract miner model. It is a win-win situation. This is also good because it helps protect the environment. This model includes the small contract miners in our environmental license, helping them improve their safety and reduce injuries, ensuring they pay royalties and taxes because they are in our operations and they are one of our operators. If the sector and government work together, we could obtain good results in the ongoing peace process.
node.sections11: The most direct benefit we bring to communities is employment. Furthermore, there is a tremendous amount of training that goes into this; hence, there is also a strong aspect of personal development. And it is not all about mining; it is also about investing in people. While I am investing USD3 million into a machine, the resources needed to train and develop an employee for two decades, not to mention payroll and taxes, is probably fairly equivalent. And the employee gets an indirect benefit through the significant amount of money from returns generated by the mine that is then re-invested in the business and its people. The second most important concept for the communities is to establish a community locally and regionally that can provide supplier-based networks and a number of goods and services to the mining enterprise. We estimate that some 40% of our purchases could probably be done on a local and regional basis.
node.sections21: Mineria Texas Colombia is the first foreign company to run a Colombian emerald line in recent decades. We are not the only foreign company here now, but in terms of running a major project in the last several decades, we certainly are the largest. We have a few companies; there is MTC, which operates the Muzo mine in Colombia, and most of the most valuable emeralds in the world have come from Muzo mine. MTC was a new company created to operate the mine. The emerald industry in Colombia unfortunately has a turbulent and violent history. It was difficult to gain the confidence of local financial institutions and other businesses. Eventually, we convinced the industry that we were a legitimate American company and we were able to carry on with the legal procedures to establish the company correctly. We began an intensive effort to modernize the mines and expand operations and have been a successful mine-to-market program.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Country Chairman of Colombia, Ecuador, Central America & Caribbean
node.previewsummary: With a new peace deal, government incentives, and large potential reserves, upstream and downstream companies in the oil sector are planning ambitious projects, but taking all efforts to mitigate risk, in Colombia.
node.title: Cautiously Optimistic
node.sections01: Equion operates an important asset in Colombia, the Piedmonte license. It is a large, but technologically challenging, prospective area in oil and gas, as it is in a mountainous and environmentally sensitive area. We are working with other companies that bring in leading technologies from around the world precisely for projects like this. Each new successful well can provide anywhere between 2,000 and 8,000 bpd. Those wells can take six to eight months to drill and cost around USD60-80 million. The Piedemonte license with Ecopetrol expiries in 2020, though we have plans to continue being productive in Colombia and working with and for our shareholders. We are still competitive in the region but need to progress and develop increasingly our exploration efforts. We need to be covered by a clear framework that will enable us to develop Colombia's industry. The peace process will be a large advantage in achieving this aim.
node.sections11: In an effort to focus our development, we have been going through a strict portfolio management process, which Colombia survived. We are one of the world leaders in the offshore industry, especially deepwater, which fits in well with our portfolio in Colombia. Petrobras will also be able to balance its portfolio with a little more gas on long term. In general, the offshore business has been positive in keeping the country competitive. Although the deep water offshore sub-phase of Colombia does not have the same potential as neighbors such as Mexico or Venezuela, Colombia has been making a large effort to motivate and incentivize initial investments through free trade zones that have been assigned to some companies. We will be drilling one deepwater offshore well in Colombia in 2017 and one onshore asset to help mitigate risk for exploration of what to drill in 2018.
node.sections21: We still have the two Technical Evaluation Agreement (TEA) blocks that we need to decide in 3Q2017 whether to convert to E&P contracts. We will also need to decide whether to go from Phase I to Phase II on the E&P contract for SIN OFF 7. Though challenging, the prospects look good from what we know so far. We decided we did not need to shoot 3D seismic for SIN OFF 7; therefore, we are transferring these commitments to COL-3 block, which is another benefit from the government that allows this kind of flexibility. We are transferring the commitments to COL-3 block where we need more geological information. Like any other major oil company, Shell has an active portfolio that we are constantly reviewing. Currently, we have three businesses here—upstream, lubricants, and some trading activities. I do not see us moving away from these current businesses in 2017.
node.sections31: As a leading company in the downstream sector in Colombia, we challenged the status quo in 2012 and decided to make a shift in our competitive strategy. We decided that Terpel should focus on the people that came to our service stations rather than only on their vehicles. Under the certainty that we were delivering the best quality in our products, we focused every decision related to innovation for the individual person that visits Terpel. We changed our logo and made substantial improvements in aspects related to service levels, infrastructure, and pricing to become the best choice for our final customers. We have a long way to go in Colombia. Many people thought we had expanded outside Colombia because the Colombian market was already mature, but we do not think so. Aside from service stations, where we are still developing a market, we also have industrial, aviation, and lubricants businesses; hence, we have a great deal still to do in Colombia.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Investors
node.sections01: Overall, 2016 was an active year for us. The investment climate in Colombia continues to be positive, despite everything. We managed to close several large transactions: one was the sale of a 58% equity stake in one of the largest energy generation companies, Isagen, which we had been working on for nearly six years. It ended up being sold to Brookfield from Canada, which now has a solid platform to continue growing in the Colombian energy market. We also did another large transaction by Colombian standards, the acquisition of CIFIN SA, a USD200 million transaction that we advised the US-based TransUnion on. While these two deals are the most visible, we have a few other transactions in our portfolio that grab less headlines but still prove there is a healthy appetite for investments in Colombia. As the third-largest market in Latin America, Colombia has a great structural relevance when investors approach it. And the political situation relative to the region continues to be positive. We have a growing middle class with greater purchasing power that has been the main driver behind growth. Despite the slowdown, this continues to hold true. Granted, the last two or three years have seen a transition from 5% or 6% annual growth to something closer to 2%. However, given what is happening around the world, this is still quite healthy.
node.sections11: We are showing the market that the private equity industry is becoming an engine of development not only with an economic but also a social impact. Now with a decade of experience, we are both a young, strong, and structured industry. And private equity funds are really showing results in the market. We now have 90 funds operating across Colombia managed by 55 fund managers, 55% of which are local and 45% international. This means we have a very interesting mix of international and local players, the former of which are important to the market since they generate more information, best practices, and are a key player in the sector. We have raised about USD12 billion in capital commitments in 10 years and invested USD 6.7 billion, significantly impacting the GDP of the country. However, 40% of these capital commitments come from pension funds, of which there are only four; having so few players causes a structural problem with the capital markets in general. Granted, the industry is trying to build an independent regulatory body for the private equity market based on our decade of experience in the industry. This is one of the issues we have to deal with in the coming months. We also need to identify more new investors for those vehicles, both local and international.
node.sections21: We have had an excellent year, not only in prices but also a recovery in volume, particularly in fixed income. In the equities market we still have very low volumes and the market has shifted. Initially it was an individual based market, where more than half of the investors were individuals. However, during the past four years these investors have exited the market and their volume has been replaced by international agents that represent today approximately 40% of the volume traded. This has had a special effect on the market because international institutional investors, the ones that participate the most in the local equity markets, are focused on operations on the closing of the market. We have also had a few issuers that have exited the market through private transactions. For example, the Isagen deal involved a private equity fund and the company is no longer public. This market has had difficult times and even though we are expecting an IPO boom soon, today we are not in the best moment for the market. We have had a liquidity drop. This year has been better but brokerage is still a business that has its challenges with low volumes and tight fees. As long as we do not see new agents and new issuers, Colombia's capital markets will not recover.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: For new players and those long dedicated to the Colombian market, the country has been an anomaly in its tenacity to withstand, and even surmount, perpetual instability, offering a huge promise of growth.
node.title: Why Colombia?
node.sections01: The Bogotá office is one of our oldest offices in the world outside our London headquarters; it was established and has been fully functional since 1985. Therefore, we have an extensive history with the country. A large portion of our work for the first 20 years was related to security issues and helping companies get out of some complicated situations. The difference over the last 10 years or so has been that with the influx of FDI as a result of the administrations of President Uribe and Santos, our business has become more of a management consultancy, and has far more to do with assisting new investment from multinational companies in the country and increasing the amount of work we do for large Colombian companies. For example, the oil, gas, and mining companies employ our services to become more reputable corporate citizens in this environment, better understand the communities in which they are working, the impacts of their actions, local politics, and understanding local business partners in order to not violate any compliance norms.
node.sections11: We have been in Colombia for 50 years and offer services not available anywhere else in the region. The secure transfer of valuables, physical protection, and a wide line of consulting are but three. Our portfolio is much wider than that of other countries. Naturally, we are proud of these achievements. We also have a great deal of potential to export talent from this office. The perception of security in the country has changed dramatically in the past years for the better. Therefore, I am proud and optimistic for the future. Of course, we are still far away from an ideal world in which there are no security issues. This gives us a great deal of space to grow, however. And at least we have seen great improvement over the past few years, which obviously improves international perceptions of Colombia. Another problem is that security issues have risen with fast rates of urbanization, which certainly slows this process. However, perceptions are improving. It also gives us many opportunities in this sector.
node.sections21: The drop in the price of crude led to some changes for ConocoPhillips, particularly with redesigning our exploration strategy. We are now focusing our explorations efforts on four business units and some key international new ventures in which we see potential. Colombia is one of the countries where we are implementing these strategies. The budget we currently have for global exploration is much smaller than what we had a few years ago, but we have made the conscious decision to take a piece of that exploration budget and invest it here in Colombia. Our focus in Colombia will be on unconventionals. The Ministry of Energy and other institutions are working on that because Colombia has only about five years of oil reserves left; therefore, the country urgently needs to make new discoveries. Our long-term strategy in the country also includes implementing a sustainable development model sustained by three pillars: one is economic, one is social, and one is environmental.
node.sections31: Even though it has had turmoil throughout its history, Colombia is now a country with proven high quality institutions, reliable financial policy, and a good draw for foreign investment. In general, it has had the best performance in these areas within Latin America. We have been in Colombia for 90 years, providing cutting-edge technologies for the development of a sustainable infrastructure for health, energy, water, ground transportation, and aviation. Transportation and energy are two sectors the country needs to improve to be a more competitive economy. For both Colombia and GE, the oil and gas industry is one of the pillars for development. We believe in the strategy that the industry in Colombia is performing at this point to go offshore. This is the opportunity for the sector to make a good turnaround in our reserves, in both oil and gas. A decade from now, we could be able to double the country's production with a good combination of gas and oil.
node.sections41: For Virgin Mobile within Latin America, Colombia was the second-easiest market to enter. When we were exploring the entire region, Chile was a safe bet, but the other economies in the region were not as attractive. Argentina was not in a good political environment, and Brazil and Mexico were too large to tackle from scratch. Therefore, Colombia made perfect sense. It was large enough economically to be relevant and stable enough, both politically and economically, to remain a safe bet. It was also like a laboratory for testing our value proposition in a bigger way that Virgin Latin America had done before. That is why Colombia came after Chile and preceded Mexico—because of the experience we gained. We thought we were better prepared to tackle a market as big as Mexico after accomplishing what we have accomplished in Colombia. There are some things we learned commercially and others we learned politically.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: State agencies are working to ensure the most vulnerable parts of the country and those within them have access to housing and capital.
node.title: Funds
node.sections01: Innovation initially lies in strategy. Colombia is confronting the largest PPP road program in Latin America, which at USD18.2 billion is a sizable amount for a country that had traditionally done little of that type of financing. Colombia has done more corporate than infrastructure finance, so it was a challenge to shift the focus of the system to approach infrastructure, especially because of each project's complexity, size, and time schedule. The latter is tight, as we are doing nearly 33 projects worth around the aforementioned USD18.2 billion in two years, which is ambitious for such a short period. At the beginning, it seemed completely unrealistic to many people, who were skeptical that we could finance a program of this size. One of the reasons was the capacity of the private sector to efficiently finance these capital investments. This is where we played a key role in the strategy; we are the institution responsible for designing the strategy and then helping to implement it. The strategy was to find out how to diversify sources of financing to guarantee that the program would have enough resources available. The first thing was to identify the main sources of local banks, international banks, multilateral entities, and local and international capital markets and see what were the main constraints for their participation.
node.sections11: In these last five months of management, we have focused on three goals: acquiring new businesses in what Fonade considers its four business lines; designing an austerity policy mostly on operational expenditure and bureaucracy; and optimizing internal processes such that our clients understand there is a new management focused on being more efficient and effective. In addition, Fonade has two international clients based on mutual cooperation. On the one hand, our Spanish client receives resources in relation to sewage and rural aqueducts in municipalities that have had violent actors, or departments such as La Guajira that have great difficulty with the supply of potable water. On the other hand, our French client receives resources in relation to health-related issues all across the country. Furthermore, Fonade has had new businesses with entities such as the School of Public Administration (ESAP), the Unit of Penitentiary and Prison Services (USPEC), the Ministry of Housing, and the National Road Agency, which have allowed Fonade to increase its income. We have done project management in more than 900 Colombian municipalities, including the Municipal Stadium of Sahagún in Córdoba and the Santa Bárbara houses behind the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. In addition to these works, Fonade is present in several other departments in health, education, and sports and recreation, among others.
node.sections21: The role the National Savings Fund plays is important for the entire economy of Colombia. Together with the Ministry of Housing, we are closing the quality and quantity deficit in housing. Many Colombians are now economically independent and have escaped informal situations, but they still need some sort of savings. The best way to do this is to buy a house, which is where we want to help. Our goal is to reach these people and bring them prosperity through home ownership. This is important for our country, which is fighting really hard against poverty and is the role the FNA plays in this fight. In the future our goal is to modernize and have a larger focus on people. Colombia is focusing on its less-developed regions and growing a lot as a result. Therefore, we need to include every region; each is an important national asset. Colombia has many large and important cities, but there are also many municipalities that are much less developed. The idea is that the municipalities will follow the housing patterns of larger cities to give Colombia the future it deserves. We have to be proactive in identifying the difficulties people have in securing adequate housing and teach people about the importance of savings and not merely give them a house. This is so important to the future of the family and its education, health, and prosperity.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Despite a global slowdown, car companies are optimistic given the popularity and quality of their vehicles.
node.title: Car Companies
node.sections01: Retail comprises the majority of our business because the nature of our products does not lend itself to larger fleet deals. In 2016, we saw a decline in volume in the motor vehicles market, but were still able to launch some new products in segments that we had not been competitive in before. One of our key drivers of growth is our ability to provide vehicles to relevant segments of the market while supporting that from a retail perspective. We engineer and design products that allow us to compete in segments where we could not before. Middle Eastern consumers are sophisticated and educated; they travel the world and understand design, technology, and brands. The Range Rover Sport appeals across the age spectrum because of its performance ability. Also, it is an extremely well-designed vehicle. With the Range Rover Sport, a driver can be in the desert on Saturday and then at the office on Monday. This car is perfectly equipped to do both. Range Rover all over the world, and particularly in the Middle East, is a hugely aspirational vehicle for a number of reasons. It has been around this region for many years, and it is both an extremely capable and comfortable vehicle.
node.sections11: AGMC is the BMW Group importer for Dubai, Sharjah, and the Northern Emirates. We have over 700 employees at AGMC and the widest network in terms of infrastructure for an automotive company, with 26 sales and service facilities. We have 187 display vehicles across our network as well as 229 work bays across our service facilities. It is of paramount importance to us to be where the customer is, and this drives our expansion decisions. Our latest investment was in a new facility in Fujairah in 2012. At the time, it was a state-of-the-art project with the latest BMW Group design for facilities. In the post-economic crisis period from 2010 to 2016, we have been pleased with our growth. On the BMW side, we have had 85% growth and over 600% growth on the MINI side. Over the last five years, AGMC has invested over USD27.2 million, not just in new facilities, but also in upgrading, updating, and continuously developing our existing facilities from a technology, BMW Group design, and customer experience perspective. To celebrate AGMC's 40th anniversary, we have upgraded our service facilities in Dubai by launching the all-new workshop for BMW and MINI with 20 work bays as well as a multistory car park accommodating 250 cars.
node.sections21: Mercedes-Benz is in a position of great strength around the world. The brand is among the top-10 most valuable brands globally and is the number-one premium automotive brand in the world, according to Interbrand 2016. On a regional level, as automotive brands in this part of the world do not disclose their sales data, it is difficult to provide precise figures. However, given our brand recognition, visibility on the roads, and the special connection the brand shares with people across the region, we are the top premium car brand in the region. We are extremely lucky that our portfolio has expanded at the right time with impressive sporty, sleek designs—this has supported our performance in the region and will help us maintain our position as the region's top premium car brand. We are introducing no less than eight new models this year. We launched the new E-Class Coupé, GLA FL, and E 63 models and by the end of the year we will have the E-Class Cabriolet. Other models to be launched this year include our ultimate sports cars, the Mercedes-AMG GT R, Mercedes-AMG GT Roadster, and the new Mercedes-Benz S-Class and Mercedes-Maybach S-Class. A strong core business begins with first-class products.
node.sections31: BMW has enjoyed fantastic growth since 2009, and for most of the years, we had double-digit growth. We are aware it is difficult to maintain such a rate. If we look into the UAE, the growth in 2015 was 25%, and in 2016 we had a further increase of 2%, which was a fantastic result considering that the market had declined in terms of the premium segment. The growth driver is that we are building upon two strong brands, BMW and MINI, and many customers in this region appreciate strong brands especially during a challenging time. They look for brands they can trust. Secondly, we have the right products for the region. We have the brand-new 7 Series, a strong range of X models, and several niche models that are highly appreciated in the region. The third factor that makes us strong is that we have built up a network of successful importers throughout the region. Here in the UAE, for example, we have worked with AGMC for over 40 years in Dubai and the northern Emirates, and these factors, brands, products, and partnerships on a retail level make us strong and contributed to our growth in 2016 in the UAE.
node.sections41: Internationally, Porsche continues to enjoy incredible success with records, year after year. In 2016, we enjoyed 6% growth worldwide.
