We tend to focus and concentrate on what our clients want; through that focus, we deliver our end goals, and the volumes naturally come as a side effect of those accomplishments. The core of our brand is still the same, and the 911 is still at the center of that brand. We enjoy greater penetration in the sports car segment, especially in the two-door sports car market. The Macan was the volume seller, with strong support from the Cayenne, and we have also just launched the Panamera. Of the 60 million new cars sold annually worldwide, 240,000 of those are Porsches. We measure and monitor our customer base diligently worldwide. In the UAE, the population is significantly younger than in the US and Europe, and they have strong purchasing power, 10 years younger than it would be for a person in Germany, for example. The demographics for senior management in this country are also younger than other places in the world. Here the average age is 36 whereas in the rest of the world it is 46; this again influences our target market.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0position: Managing Director — Restructuring Services Middle East Region
node.previewsummary: A range of best practices and revamping strategies are changing the expectations for doing business in Dubai.
node.title: Dubai’s business environment
node.sections01: We are seeing a bit of pressure in the restructuring market because the fundamental issue is that oil price was at USD100 just over a year ago and now it is between USD43 and USD45. A lot of expenditure here is driven by the government, which has meant that government has had to rethink balancing its budget. This pressure has been felt first by the infrastructure and contracting businesses since they have typically operated on narrow margins of 2-3%. They work on long-term contracts; therefore, it can be difficult to estimate the end cost, particularly if there are variations or delays in the projects. Furthermore, there is a structural problem that needs to be addressed in terms of keeping SMEs in the country during difficult times. The new bankruptcy law that comes into effect from the end of the year should help to encourage more of a rescue culture. In all parts of the world, SME lending is a challenge, as it requires due diligence and more information about how they are performing in real time. SMEs are really important to the Dubai economy. The free zones have attracted many entrepreneurs, which has been positive and progressive for the economy. More needs to be done to support and develop this important sector.
node.sections11: The issue with the banking sector is that it is still highly regulated, and it is still quite a challenging investment environment for international investors. The predominance and importance of local ownership is still a key part of investment in the banking market. International banks see it as locally dominated and potentially overbanked, so it is still quite challenging for foreign investors to come and try to take a stake. There are foreign ownership restrictions and while that may change over time, at this stage it is a market that is likely to be less open to foreign investment. The fact that governments have significant stakes in a number of the banks here gives a different element to the operation of banks. The UAE's success in M&A will continue, since people here are open to good opportunities. Because of the relatively liberal environment in Dubai, people who are looking to invest in the region generally come here as their first point of call. Investors feel most comfortable about the investment risk when they come to Dubai. There is a strong legal framework for such interest, which means foreign companies are more likely to invest and buy a stake in Dubai. There may also more acquisition opportunities in Dubai because there are more entrepreneurial businesses and more people looking for capital to grow their business.
node.sections21: During the 1980s, the government was primarily trying to develop the free zones and the warehousing industrial exports, and we were also active with IPOs. Since the IT boom there has been a lot more work in software and the production of brands, which drew a lot of companies here and energized the intellectual property space. Real estate work boomed from 2003 onwards, as did mergers and acquisitions and capital markets work. All of that has brought the UAE markets, and to some extent the GCC markets, maturity. As well as operating on a larger scale, with larger mergers and acquisitions, the style has also changed from individual to corporations, groups, funds, investments, and so on. Now, the move is largely toward the emergence of new sectors such as renewables and data. With those changes we had to change our style and focus closely on new hires, ensuring we were recruiting individuals specialized in intellectual property rights, something we previously did not have any experience with. Underpinning all of this is the drive to create a highly transparent and regulated society, a reality that has developed the UAE into an attractive place to do business. That is one advantage of VAT and one advantage for taxes, and a solid tax system means that every business must have well-kept accounts, which is an added benefit.
node.sections31: In this part of the world, Brexit is not of great interest. Generally, we expect the volume of trade between the UAE and the UK will increase as a result, and statements made by the British Prime Minister on how Britain is looking to the Gulf as a strategic trade partner for British companies fortify that expectation. The drop in the pound's value has also encouraged Gulf investors to invest more in the UK. ADNOC, for example, has just purchased 2% of BP, which was awarded a concession for an oil field in Abu Dhabi that will increase its share of Abu Dhabi oil from 95,000bpd to 295,000bpd. Brexit will encourage more British firms to secure deals in Gulf countries and the UAE. For a long time, in discussions on hydrocarbons and aluminum, the EU refused to deal with the GCC as a bloc, preferring to deal with them as individual countries for obvious commercial reasons. This does not mean that the Gulf does not wish to act as a bloc, and it has acted successfully as a bloc in areas like pharmaceuticals. That being said, with the new US administration, the relevancy of commercial blocs is under increased scrutiny, and we are waiting to see how that will affect global trade and treaties.
node.sections41: A company's articles of association or the contractual documentation set a prescribed profit share. Standard practice here is that the foreign party, if it is not a real joint venture, enters into a commercial arrangement that negates that 80-20 profit share. This entails an agreement on terms such as a fixed fee for an annual period. The local partner has to add value to the foreign company. We get involved in every aspect of their licensing legality compliance on the ground. When companies first enter the market, the first piece of advice they are given is to choose a local partner that can advance your business interests, if you have to have one. Companies should engage with the local Emirati community on a commercial basis, but should not confuse that with business ownership. We suggest that your local partner is not necessarily an individual or a company that will help you. Instead, it should be one that ensures you to be always in the best position from a legal perspective. Many private equity firms and venture capitalists are advocating more M&As, but the businesses involved are in need of consolidation of ownership beforehand. Our company was one of the pioneers of this as the first to bring a corporate nominee product to the market and was the only independent company in the country offering this service.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Centers of Excellence
node.sections01: We have over 100 nationalities represented on our Manchester Business School part-time MBA program, with around 45% of our 2,000 MBA students residing in the UAE. As part of the program, we encourage and facilitate student visits to at least one of our five other international centers during their studies. We cover the cost of accommodation in two locations in order to give them a more global perspective and network. We consistently have students coming from a core of industry sectors—consultancy, engineering, construction management, software management, oil and gas, as well as ICT backgrounds. There has been an increase in the number of entrepreneurs becoming successful business owners following an MBA. The MBA has been a real catalyst for entrepreneurs developing their own SMEs. Female participation has also increased significantly over the last few semesters, reaching 20% of the latest student intake.
node.sections11: Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) has its own courts and our master's degree in law (LLM) serves that sector, mainly in arbitration, money laundering, and financial crimes. This serves the needs specific to Dubai. In 2016, we signed an agreement with DIFC courts where our LLM graduates have a greater opportunity to work at DIFC. We also serve the police department with our telecommunications and IT program, which focuses on IT security. Moreover, we have an agreement with Dubai Customs to prepare and teach their qualified employees to graduate from UD with a customs and supply chain management degree. We hope that this degree will expand to other entities in the Emirates of Ras Al Khaimah and Fujairah. This is something we are going to work on with the World Customs Organization to ensure that the qualifications we provide meet international standards. Beyond that, we have plans to cater to the hospitality sector as well as the emerging digital media industry.
node.sections21: Our business school is the largest of our university with 38% of total enrolment. About 25% of the faculty comes to us as part-time instructors from the business world. AUD has placed a lot of emphasis on developing its full-time faculty of career academics. Many have professional experience, and the university has made an effort to ensure that they can continue their professional work whilst teaching. We are working to complete a five-year plan for the university. We will add liberal arts programs, such as a major in psychology or a literary program in-line with the UAE's year of reading. We will certainly see additional majors in business administration, like Islamic finance, and possibly small business management or human resource management. An institution like ours must create and maintain its relevance. I am lucky enough to be on the advisory council for a number of primary and secondary schools and therefore aware of how teaching is changing and what the student expectations are when they get to university.
node.sections31: As the campus was set up with a focus on media, we have students going into public relations, journalism, and television production. We also have a business school, and within business, we make a distinction between training for general management, marketing, and finance. Our marketing students are all over the UAE working for various companies. There are a number of opportunities, especially with media increasingly moving online. With this development, it does not really matter where in the world you are. We have a number of students who are already writing blogs that are well visited. Others are doing freelance writing for publications around the world. Dubai is located perfectly, being right in the heart of the GCC and with over 60% of the world's population within an eight-hour flight.
node.sections41: The university started as a small vocational training college owned by the Dubai Civil Aviation Authority (DCAA). It was dedicated to aerospace engineering training and air traffic control but has since grown to a university where we have introduced many academic programs, both undergraduate and postgraduate. We have now broadened our scope of courses and offer aeronautical engineering, aviation management, travel, and tourism, as well as an MBA in aviation management. We have expanded our programs into different areas, such as logistics and supply chain management, business studies, software engineering, and mechanical engineering. Emirates Airlines is now the owner of the university; therefore, we work together closely, and although the university does not guarantee employment for our graduates within the Emirates group, many of our graduates are working for the group. Our plan has grown in terms of expansion outside the UAE and the GCC, we are looking into Europe as well, especially in terms of partnerships with universities.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Hospitals
node.sections01: Canadian Specialist Hospital is a multi-specialty hospital covering all the major specialties in medicine. Its sub-specialties include cardiology, neurology, rheumatology, endocrinology, and so on. We perform general laparoscopic orthopedic surgery; otolaryngology for ear, nose, and throat; and obstetrics and gynecology. We also carry out an extensive range of dental services. All these areas of practice require supporting services such as laboratories, radiology, ICU, NICU, and emergency services. Each area of practice at a hospital like ours needs to have some extra investment to complete the range of services we can offer and to keep up-to-date with new medical technologies. For example, now we are investing in minimally invasive microscopic spine surgery. In January 2016, we launched a new rehabilitation center. There had been none in the private healthcare sector here, and patients were forced to seek rehabilitation services in European and Asian countries. We conducted thorough studies and decided to set up a rehabilitation center at the Canadian Specialist Hospital.
node.sections11: Our structure for getting into this market was to look at how this healthcare market is driven by insurance. There are a number of hospitals and clinics; however, there are not many day surgical centers or ambulatory surgical centers, as in the US or the UK. We are one of the largest day surgeries in Dubai at the moment, at 20,000sqft. We are also the only hospital with level-two operation theaters. The difference between hospitals and clinics is that we have been given permission by the Dubai Healthcare Authority (DHA) to do over 200 types of surgeries. We offer high-quality, cost-effective surgeries, procedures, and consultations and see ourselves as a bridge between the clinics and hospitals. Insurance companies seek to reduce their costs on healthcare provision, and we see the insurance sector maturing. As a company we are engaging with this situation in several ways. We have 18 insurance companies on board and are in discussion with another 10 to design packages that provide cost-effective solutions for their clients.
node.sections21: Our agenda and focus in terms of the care we offer revolves around the demands of our customers. The focus thus far has been on a variety of practices that can be seen in our specialized facilities and centers of excellence including: a bariatric center, a cardiac center, a gynecology center, and oncology services, which include both surgical oncology and medical oncology apart from all other disciplines. We are doubling the capacity of several of our facilities and expanding into new fields such as radiation therapy. Dialysis is another popular tertiary care. While there is a great deal of talk about offering preventative care and exciting new initiatives, a lot more needs to be done on what currently exists. Preventative healthcare is more complicated and the implementation of truly effective preventative care in the UAE must coincide with an overhaul of social norms and lifestyles. The UAE has a troubling prevalence of diabetes, cardiac, and cancer cases caused by lifestyle choices such as poor diet and lack of exercise. The only way forward is to continue with the consistent and strong reinforcement of these policies through educative wellness campaigns.
node.sections31: Aster DM started as a single-doctor clinic and over the last 30 years we have transformed ourselves into a multi-faceted healthcare service provider with our own hospitals, clinics, and pharmacies. Our care ranges from general to specialty hospitals and from 20 beds all the way to 250 beds in the GCC, and one hospital with over 700 beds in India. Another distinguishing factor of Aster DM is the variety of care we offer across our three lines: Medcare, Aster, and Access. Medcare is a premium brand where everything from the doctors to the facilities is high end. Aster is our main segment catering to a wider population. Access is a newly introduced brand, which is the most affordable care we offer. We have managed to grow both organically and inorganically, building our own facilities or acquiring hospitals. Many of our patients come to Dubai as a tourist destination, whether for medical reasons or leisure, thereby we place an importance on making the Aster brand highly visible in the GCC market and globally. The most rewarding aspect of this business comes from doing good work and providing the best quality of care.
node.sections41: We are a very young player, but with strong roots from being in the healthcare sector for the past 35 years. We have a very strong rate of YoY growth, and last year we grew 65% compared to 2015, which is a great result for us. These growth levels will enable us to meet our capacity. We are a 200-bed hospital, out of which almost 100 beds are running. So by 2017, we should reach almost 100% capacity, having 200 beds. In the short term, our aim is overall growth of 35% in 2017. We are currently developing an integrated oncology program. We have been trying to understand cancer from the patient's point of view, trying to find a way that they can get everything done under the same roof, because a cancer patient should not have to worry about navigating multiple different centers and doctors. We want to offer one place where they can get medical, surgical, and radiation oncology treatment. Along with counseling and psychological and medical and surgical oncology services, we will have the radiation oncology capabilities providing chemotherapy and advanced surgeries for different types of cancer.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Building for Tomorrow
node.sections01: Population growth is robust because Dubai is at the epicenter of 3.5 billion people, by which I mean the Indian subcontinent, the whole of Africa, the Middle East, and CIS countries. Dubai is renowned for its development, high-quality living, high-quality entertainment, plus great vision by one of the greatest leaders that the world has seen. It is an international city where more than 200 countries are represented and that provides a safe environment and quality infrastructure for its residents. The number of houses and the growth of the population dictate Dubai's real estate sector. The existing number of homes is about 500,000, and population growth will be roughly 4% for the next 20 years. I am optimistic about our work; beyond that, I am an Omani national with Indian origin, and I have never felt at any point in time that this is not a good place for me to live. The potential of real estate is defined by the happiness and comfort a country provides for those that live and work in it.
node.sections11: We have been transparent when it comes to doing business with our clients as well as with authorities, and this regulatory environment has decreased risk in the market. The creation and enforcement of escrow accounts has streamlined the process and provided an equal playing field for developers. Ethical developers are supported, and dishonest developers are pushed out of the market because the escrow account (or lack thereof) provides numerous obstacles for them. It will be a natural process of purging the marketplace. That is why we have had strong growth in 2015 and 2016, and why 2017 is projected to be a banner year. If developers focus on construction, remain transparent, and develop a product that has demand, then there is no reason why companies cannot be successful in this competitive market. These principles apply across a variety of sectors, not just in real estate. Today, people see transparency as a modern and progressive way to do business.
node.sections21: As a 150-year-old group that has built a formidable reputation in the contracting space, we are now pursuing our passion to emerge as real estate developers of choice in the international arena. We have been constructing prestigious and iconic projects in the Middle East for the last 45 years now—a journey that began by us building the Palace of the Sultan of Oman in 1971. In fact, currently, approximately 50% of our group turnover comes from international operations. Currently in over 45 different countries across the globe, the expansion to this region was part of our concerted internationalization growth plan. With our first real estate project outside India currently under construction in Downtown Dubai, Imperial Avenue is set to be completed in the last quarter of 2019. In addition, we have another project at Dubai Healthcare City, which will be launched soon. We are also exploring other opportunities, both within the UAE and across the GCC, as well as in Africa and Sri Lanka.
node.sections31: There will always be winners and losers in a volatile market. Speaking specifically about our business, it is about exhaustive planning, not overstretching, and not doing too much. In terms of longevity, when you hit a difficult period, you can be the benefactor of being able to negotiate better commercial terms if you buy land. On the supply chain, in relation to contractors, designers, and consultants you can set up a better supply chain with favorable commercial terms, or even better materials and finishes. It depends on how your business is set up and how nimble it is in terms of reacting to market change. We are quite fortunate that we keep a close eye on what is happening in the global economy to make sure we do not get caught out. We came out of the economic crisis, and we delivered everything we had to, even though it was tough. That enabled us to put this diversification strategy in place, and we have been successful at it.
node.sections41: Dubai is a city with booming retail, hospitality, and tourism; these areas need to be supported by developments with medium-range pricing and luxury finish that are affordable for investors. The challenge with developing for the middle-class range is that the know-how is connected to contractors, subcontractors, and materials. You need to work with your consultants and project team to find ways to fix your construction costs to suit the development and selling price. 2016 was our year to restructure our entire development strategy. When we were doing market research, we found that buyers in the age range of 20-45 prioritize lifestyle and prefer medium-range real estate rather than luxury. The world's population is increasing, and new generations have new technologies and new priorities, so we need to keep up to date with their needs. We are developing studios, one-bedroom and two-bedroom homes, and townhouses with three and four bedrooms. In Meydan, 40% of the developments are studios, 30% are one-bedroom, 20% two-bedrooms, and 10% are townhouses.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Maritime Logistics
node.sections01: For more than 150 years, ABS has been committed to setting standards for safety, quality, and excellence as one of the world's leading classification organizations. ABS maintains a regional workforce of more than 70 surveyors and engineers, the largest of any classification society. This network operates from eight offices within the UAE and GCC region. ABS also operates a full-service engineering office in Dubai to support regional growth, strengthen service delivery, and provide communication in the same time zone. The engineering department offers a full range of analysis and plan review services. Historically, the focus has been to assess the integrity and efficiency of hull structures, mechanical and electrical engineering, and hydrodynamics. Today, the range of technical support on offer has to be wider and deeper to support the sophisticated machinery and complex systems used in modern marine and offshore assets. While remaining firmly class-centric, the focus of ABS's technical services has transitioned to offer more predictive and preventative applications.
node.sections11: Chevron Shipping and its affiliates provide functional support across the Chevron enterprise. Our job is to deliver marine operational, commercial, and technical expertise that enhances the corporation's business results. The decrease in crude oil prices has created a challenging environment for the energy industry. If there is a silver lining, it is that the downturn caused Chevron to increase its focus on costs. We scrutinized our operations, increased efficiency, and reduced costs. We are well positioned to provide safe, reliable, and cost-competitive marine transportation to support Chevron's global operations. The business environment has never been so competitive. What makes us stand out as a shipping company is our steadfast commitment to operational excellence. The entire industry is going through a challenging period; however, we are not willing to compromise on our commitment to safe, reliable, and environmentally responsible operations. We have high expectations and we hold ourselves accountable for achieving the right results. When selecting vendors and contractors, we seek companies that are like-minded.
node.sections21: We are excited to continue to grow in the Middle East. We see many opportunities that suit our fleet profile, in particular for fast offshore passenger transport vessels, which prove to be cost effective in comparison to helicopter transfers. Additionally, our liftboats (Jack-Up barges) will play a major role in offshore field production enhancement and platform maintenance. Overall, we intend to be a part of the continued growth across the entire GCC region. 2016-2017 will prove to be tough, and I doubt there will be a serious upturn in activity before 2019, and possibly beyond. Offshore activity appears to be picking up, benefiting from reduced cost for working offshore and the higher price for oil. Some of our client spending is now finding its way back to offshore assets, and barring a collapse in the oil price for an extended duration, the outlook for our fleet is positive. There is still a tremendous oversupply of offshore support vessels in the market, which will be a drag on activity recovery.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Mutual Connections
node.sections01: Traditionally, Hitachi has been a manufacturer of all sorts of equipment. However, the changes that we are undergoing all revolve around digitalization. This means that our focus will not merely be supplying equipment or taking part in infrastructure projects but also providing end-to-end solutions to our customers by utilizing the IoT. Hitachi has established a group of very advanced experts based in Silicon Valley, and they are leading this process. We have also acquired a lot of companies with expertise in the field of big data analytics. Combining this with our experience in the infrastructure business and in providing equipment, we are aiming to provide customers with solutions that are relevant to the 21st Century. For example, in healthcare we are offering complete solutions to patients and operators of hospitals and medical institutions instead of just medical or diagnostics equipment. We are including the clinical analytics, informatics and IT services together to provide more encompassing solutions.
node.sections11: The ICT industry has become diversified, and communications have become a basic human right, like electricity and water.This evolution has had a dramatic impact on industries and economies. It has created enormous opportunities for business growth. In the UAE, Huawei has realigned its business to support the country's efforts in creating a knowledge-based economy; digital transformation is a main component of the UAE's national strategy. Huawei is committed to helping bridge the digital divide in UAE through four key areas: providing communications for all, broadband for all, nurturing ICT talent, and the application of ICT technologies to help different industries boost efficiency. Huawei believes in open, collaborative relationships with local companies and SMEs who have the right ideas and a potential market, which can provide value to the end users. We work closely with our customers and partners, in the public and private sectors, to build a better-connected world, connecting people, people and things, and things and things.
node.sections21: Governments and companies cannot handle digital transformation on their own, and vendors like us need to build the right ecosystem that will allow entrepreneurs to come up with the necessary applications that will disrupt the digital economy. We are moving towards a service-based, technology-oriented economy, and technology is changing the core business of companies. The new environment requires joint collaboration with pre-existing systems. That is why we launched the Co-Innovation Lab in Dubai, where ten lab people from SAP will work together with partners and customers to work on these co-innovation projects. Also, SAP is partnering with leading UAE organizations in the public sector to drive positive outcomes across key priority areas. We have identified seven key areas where this value can be created. One is engaging citizens, residents, and visitors. Another is improving government efficiency through a unified cloud government platform where it can make significant savings.
node.sections31: How many devices need to be connected to the Internet? Between phones, tablets, and laptops, one family may have 10 devices connected. In the future, smart homes will have TV, speakers, and so many other things that will need connectivity. The demand is increasing, and no matter how the economy looks or what the political solution is, people still need good quality Wi-Fi solutions. We try to make our products very cost effective so that as many users as possible can make a connection. Meanwhile, we are planning to have all TP-Link routers become cloud based so that they can be used to access their networks from anywhere. The UAE is the best place for the company to expand the business in this region. Dubai is a very international open market where people are willing to test new technology. Thanks to a smart government, the investment environment here is number one in the region.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Though a difficult market at times, insurance in Dubai is far from a saturated one. In combination with recent laws in Dubai and Abu Dhabi that mandate health insurance for individuals, the time has never been better to be in insurance.
node.title: Insurance companies
node.sections01: When the UAE came into being in the early 1970s, the insurance sector was primarily driven by trade imports. People insured their shipments, which were financed by banks; motor insurance was mandatory in Dubai and Ras Al Khaimah from 1960s. The insurance market has grown over the decades. However, compared to other developed markets the penetration and per capita spend is much lower. But much of that is because people are so transient here. They do not have any permanent residence status and this uncertainty affects the insurance industry as well. Only six years ago the government of Dubai started letting foreign individuals own property; until then, the only thing people really owned was the contents of their home and their cars. If you look at Europe or other markets, most insurance, apart from corporate, comes from personal lines such as homes, cars, and belongings. Similarly, life insurance is much lower here. There is still opportunity for further growth, but the nature of the demographics of GCC countries makes this difficult.
node.sections11: Over the years, the UAE and Dubai have witnessed rapid economic growth, which has meant a continued influx of people from around the world. Even today, with the relatively slower growth due to a fall in oil prices, the diversified economy has successfully allowed a fair degree of stable growth across different sectors, and that has continued to attract people to work, trade, start new businesses, and live in this country. As Dubai and the UAE continue to grow, the demand for personal and corporate insurance will rise. In fact, the Dubai and Abu Dhabi governments' mandatory health insurance policies have boosted demand for health insurance. At the moment, insurance and takaful companies provide corporations and traders with a comprehensive range of options for risk coverage. However, when individuals, typically expatriates, compare insurance and takaful coverage offered by their employers here with their home countries offers, the product range is limited.
node.sections21: Many new products are coming online in 1Q2017. We are targeting millennials by digitalizing points of sale, an initiative we kick-started at the beginning of 2016 with the launch of our online health insurance portal. We are now moving to the next phase of our development by creating a fully digital platform for the company. This is part of a wider drive to be more customer-centric, which will be a big factor differentiating us from other providers, whether domestic or regional. Overall, medical insurance has been a major driver behind the growth of our top line, which we grew from USD21.8-24.5 million to more than USD81.7 million. That jump is attributed in a large part to medical insurance and the rollout of mandatory health insurance by the DHA in 2016. We are the first domestic company to offer online services that allow people to purchase insurance from the comfort of their own homes.
node.sections31: The UAE insurance sector is not saturated. Insurance penetration in the Arabian Gulf in general and in the UAE in specific remains low and roughly around one-sixth of the global average. This rate indicates the level of development of the sector and is why Chedid Re strongly believes there is a substantial growth opportunity. So we need to differentiate between a challenging market and a saturated one. The region in general, and the UAE in particular, are challenging markets that make it attractive for serious players. The culture at Chedid Re completely fits these requirements. Our team is trained to handle pressure, respond to challenges, deliver solutions, and run the extra mile to make sure our services exceed our clients' expectations. When we encounter our competition in the market and at social events, they usually ask us what our secret recipe is. But there is no secret recipe! There is only a committed and devoted team that is ambitious and enthusiastic with a lot of fighting spirit.
node.sections41: We launched in April 2013 as a platform for financial services and in February 2014 launched our health insurance category. Within a month of launching that, the new Dubai Health Insurance Law was passed. What excites us is solving problems for our customers and giving them a better way to do things, and health insurance provided a good opportunity to do so. We pooled our resources to become a medical benefits platform that provides insurance and HR solutions through technology. BECO first invested in us in 2015 because they liked the fact that we were getting a lot of traction in a big sector with a lot of potential. We continued to execute the business plan through which they were willing to put in more capital. We will be diversifying the portfolio as well as expanding geographically. We have not announced anything about which countries we will be going into, but in terms of portfolio it is a very natural progression.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: Boeing, Middle East, North Africa, Turkey
node.previewsummary: Dubai's tactical importance as an emerging hub for African, Asian, and European ventures has won it a hard-fought economic dexterity.
node.title: Why Dubai?
node.sections01: Last November we hosted the South Africa and Ethiopia Investment Summit in Dubai, at which we had over 80 investors. Every year we select a theme or a country and host an investment forum to showcase opportunities in the region. This year we chose the country in which the bank has the oldest presence, South Africa, where we are celebrating 154 years of activity, and our newest footprint, Ethiopia. We recently opened an office in the latter, an economically very promising country with significant growth and just under 100 million people, not to mention the second largest after Nigeria on the African continent. We are very excited about the prospects of facilitating trade, business, and banking in the country. The bank operates within the guidelines and parameters of what the authorities have allowed under our license, facilitating foreign investments and interaction. It was a successful event with great attendance and interest shown.
node.sections11: We have been working in the Middle East since 1945 and since then have had fantastic relationships with every country in the region. Our relationship with the UAE goes back to 1977. On the commercial side, in the UAE we earned the largest order in commercial aviation history back at the 2013 Dubai Air Show, when the three main Gulf airlines,Emirates, Qatar, and Etihad, awarded us a contract to build the 777X, which came from the fact that they loved the 777. All three airlines use it very successfully and want more out of it, so they asked us to redesign the 777 to fly further with more people. To do this in such a hot climate certainly affects the aerodynamics of an airplane, but we are starting on the construction of that airplane very soon. It will start to be delivered in the region in 2020.
node.sections21: The first business we did here, aside from investing in various projects, was selling properties in Europe for Emaar. We focused on German-speaking areas and sold more than 5% of the units for some of their projects. We then started working as a developer in Dubai in 2007 and built the European Business Center, a 400,000sqft office building next to Green Community, and the Austria Business Center, a global network of state-of-the-art, professional business facilities covering every corporate requirement in some of the world's top locations, including Dubai. We have also developed various projects and sold the plans, rather than building them ourselves. One of our developments at the moment is the Heart of Europe project, for which we developed the first master plan in 2008. The project was ready for construction when the economic crisis hit, so we had to work hard in the following years to make the project much more attractive to investors that had lost their appetite.
node.sections31: In terms of performance, 2016 was the strongest year we have had in a while, although it was probably one of the toughest for many companies. Our success was driven by the expansion of our footprint in Saudi Arabia over the course of 2015, which gave us significant access to the market in 2016. So we were able to gain a lot of business that had not been there in the past, and this despite a downward trend in the public sector. In the GCC we have a 50-50 split between public and private business. As a result, the tender segment over the course of the last year went through a downward cycle driven by cost containment in the public sector. The price of oil is driving a large proportion of the budgetary constraints. We were able to grow in the private sector, which provided us with a decent overall growth level of 11-12% for 2016.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Dubai's largest holding companies are ensuring the viability of the Emirate's critical relevance in the global economy.
node.title: Holding Companies
node.sections01: Historically, Arabs, Middle Easterners, and Mediterranean people have always been content creators. This region was home to the most famous storytellers. That has not been the case for the past century, which does not mean that the talent does not exist, just that we have stopped documenting the stories using the available technology. We have taken on that responsibility of telling stories, and creating the 360-degree value chain, much like Disney did, developing a story based on how they can advertise it through merchandise, social media, exposure, downstream sales, licensing, and more.
node.sections11: The business was started in 1943, and we have always endeavored to be pioneers in serving the country. Our diversification has been driven by the needs of the various sectors of the economy. Once in those industries, you build expertise and networks, and continually invest in those industries to maintain your businesses footprint. We started in Dubai with the Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) before expanding into telecoms with Etisalat and the banking sector with NBD, for example. We have always looked for opportunities that would first help further serve the community. Currently, we are shareholders and board members primarily of majority state-owned enterprises such as Etisalat, DEWA, and PepsiCo, amongst others in the private sector. We have more than 40 different lines of businesses and are well diversified. Dubai is the driver of our business and development, and we have grown in parallel to Dubai and the UAE as a whole.
node.sections21: In our business model our food production and our F&B outlets are disconnected. We have a F&B outlet called Smoothie King, and that is separate from the manufacturing side. We are the largest private manufacturer of flour in the UAE, and produce roughly 30% of the flour consumed in the UAE and export some as well. 2016 was a challenging year but we are well diversified and have had a mixed performance across those segments. Overall the group's result was strong and we did better than 2015. From the outset 2017 looks somewhat similar to 2016 and in some businesses slightly more challenging but overall we are relatively optimistic about the second half of 2017.
node.sections31: We will still develop and expand within the region; we will not look further afield per se. If an opportunity pops up then we will look at it but our main concentration is in the region, where we already have expertise. Despite general anxiety about these economic headwinds, there is still a great deal of opportunity within the market. We live and die in this region, and in terms of fiscal spending the Emirates would like to argue that they are decreasing focus on oil and gas, but that is not true. It remains a significant majority of our income in the region. The reason the government has decided not to spend cannot be because of the price of oil, but the biggest question is whether it is a real pinch or an artificial pinch. The Far East is picking up; Japan is in a good place, and Africa has also picked up; if all these countries are picking up economically, why does it still feel like 2010? For that reason, when people say they see a slowdown, I think it is just in their heads.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Director General, The Executive Office and Acting CEO
node.previewsummary: TBY gathered some key thought leaders in Dubai to discuss the growth and development of the smart cities concept.
node.title: Smart Cities / Smart Solution
node.richbody1content:
What makes the start-up ecosystem in Dubai unique and what are the competitive advantages?

SAFDER NAZIR When I first came to Dubai from the UK 14 years ago, it was very difficult to understand the opportunities available here, but today it is far easier to access information. Thanks to technology, today people are enabled to come here, set up their lives, and start adding value to the economy. That is part of attracting people to come here; and it is a talent war to get people to come here in the first place and bring their skills with them. In December 2015, Huawei announced the opening of a regional innovations center with Dubai FDI. That center is letting us work with companies of all different sizes. SAP is one of our global partners and there are many small local enterprises that we are working with that are providing software and components for us. That is how we have started to access that ecosystem of people, and the ecosystem comes together as one thing builds on top of another.

HE ABDULLA BIN TOUQ One important part of Dubai's uniqueness and its competitiveness is its thought leadership, which has played an important part in building Dubai since the late 1980s. Dubai's development history is one of taking risks and designing the future. The first dredging of Jebel Ali Port was the first risk, i.e. designing a port for which the ships did not really exist. This ambition to push forward runs in the blood of our leadership, and today we are doing the same thing in the creation of an ecosystem for startups. One important part of that is Dubai Future Accelerators, whereby the government poses challenges and brings in startups from around the world to design solutions for them. The most important thing is our newly launched Dubai 10X, which is an initiative aimed at keeping Dubai 10 years ahead. HH Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum does not want to be number one in the region or world; he wants to be number one with a 10-year lead. This is important as these 10X units are going to create a disruptive innovation strategy and help take a lot of companies and organizations out of their comfort zone. Finally, there is the Dubai Future Academy, which focuses entirely on how to build the skillsets for candidates that come in from the private and public sector. All of this falls into one very important goal; to develop Dubai into a lab and test bed for new ideas, new technologies, and new ways of seeing the world.

AMMAR AL MALIK His Highness launched Dubai Internet City in 1999, and over the last 18 years we have attracted over 1,600 technology companies ranging from multinationals such as Huawei, Accenture, Visa, Snapchat, Uber & Amazon, and regional home-grown success stories such as souq.com and Careem, Propertyfinder, and many more. in5, which was launched in 2013, is our enabling platform for entrepreneurs and start-ups that are to be incubated and nurtured to their next phase of growth. Combined with Dubai's drive for innovation and disruptive technologies, Dubai Internet City is a conducive environment for ideation and exchange of knowledge.

How are SAP's investments in Dubai contributing to these goals?

HICHEM MAYA When we started here in 2008, we had 10 people. Now we have around 600 people covering the entire MENA region from our headquarters here in Dubai. We opened our headquarters here because we have the talent in the region and the vision of the leadership of Dubai, which is in line with SAP's vision of innovation. If you look at how SAP has evolved over 40 years, innovation has always been the driver. We always think 10 years ahead in terms of where the world will be and what we can do in order to prepare ourselves and our customers. One focus area is cloud technology, and we announced the opening of our new data center facilities here in the UAE, which will help government and local organizations in Dubai use the potential of cloud in a way that ensures privacy and data security. In terms of contributing to the start-up ecosystem, SAP has Startup Focus, which currently facilitates around 4,500 start-ups globally. We started a few years ago here in the UAE and already have around 450 start-ups registered. They are developing on our platform, but everything is oriented to meeting the needs of the country. This means developing solutions for Smart Dubai and of course Expo 2020. We are proud to be a premium partner for Expo 2020 and this helps us focus our innovation on solutions for the event, which will also fuel multiple legacy initiatives.

What areas of innovation will Dubai excel in to create globally competitive new technologies?

AT What is important is the type of innovation we are looking at. There are two different kinds of enterprises: SMEs and innovation-driven enterprises (IDE). Dubai has understood how to differentiate between the two and draw a line between what is an SME and what is an IDE. For IDEs, the important part is to look at enterprises that have technology, R&D budgets, and IP. They are the focus of Dubai Future Accelerator (DFA). By attracting and enabling these IDEs, we aim to make Dubai a laboratory for new technology, especially technologies important to the future of Dubai's economy. This includes technologies related to blockchain applications, energy efficiency, autonomous driving, consumer retail, and transport and logistics.

Where does the Internet of Things (IoT) fit into Dubai's future economy?

SN Part of the outcome of digital transformation is smarter cities and digitalized industries. IoT is an enabling technology and is born out of a vision of convergence between the real and digital worlds. It was in 1999 when the term IoT was first coined, when a gentleman working for Proctor & Gamble who was responsible for a line of lipstick that was selling out on the shelves faster than they could replace it came up with the idea of using microprocessors to signal when stocks needed to be added. The idea of being able to know what is happening in real time has become increasingly advantageous. Huawei is leading in new ways of being able to connect at lower price points to make this technology more accessible to people. 5G and other new technologies will be available by 2020, and we are working with the operators at the high end in terms of bandwidth capability and at the lower end of the spectrum we see things like Narrow Band IoT, which is bringing in a new form of technology to allow connectivity to more things at a lower price point. Once we do that it will allow us to connect the billions of devices. To make that a reality requires a new form of technology, and we have been working diligently for the last couple of years with the regulators, operators, and other industry partners to work on a standards-based approach for doing this. The IoT will give us the ability to connect to more things and what we do with that capability depends on how creative we can be. All the innovation and younger brains we manage to foster will envisage new use cases for this technology.

How is the procurement landscape changing with the technology here in Dubai?

HM The most interesting part of this technology paradigm is that it is possible to combine the public sector on one side and the private on the other in order to address joint business opportunities. There is a shift in the government's role in business, moving onward from the role of administering a country like we have seen in Europe over the centuries. We see, specifically in new markets like the UAE, that the government is stepping ahead and getting closer to a business rational, and this is very motivating for us. We are now able to combine both elements on one platform, with government on one side and private companies on the other using a common dataset in order to analyze data and make predictions. For example, data about the consumption of electricity can allow government to take appropriate actions, while other data analysis can help us to provide better living standards for citizens, and innovative projects like Expo 2020 can engage participants across the spectrum.

Dubai Internet City is somewhere between the public-private divide. What is your role in this paradigm?

AM Our efforts are closely aligned to the National Innovation Strategy and we work closely with our partners to enable innovation at all levels. In fact, some of our partners, namely Huawei, Samsung, Visa, Accenture, and SAP recently announced the new premises of their respective innovation centers. As we look forward to the next phase of growth and creating an ecosystem in which Smart Dubai will grow drastically, we are excited for the launch of the “Innovation Hub." Located in the heart of Dubai Internet City and cutting across industries and disciplines focused on bringing innovative solutions and ideas to market, the Innovation Hub will support 15,000 professionals. It will offer companies of all sizes, including multinational corporations, start-ups, and SMEs world-class facilities and services, robust and adaptable state-of-the-art infrastructure, and a vibrant working environment to support and encourage creative processes.

As the number of start-ups grows, will funding for them be able to keep pace?

AM in5 offers entrepreneurs and start-ups five key benefits: a robust start-up business framework, training and mentorship, opportunities to network, access to investors, and cutting-edge creative spaces that include offices, smart labs, and studios. Since the launch of in5, our members have raised approximately USD38.1 million in funding. With over 1,400 applications, in5 to date has supported more than 160 entrepreneurs and startups through more than 100 mentors and three dedicated Innovation Centres in Tech, Media, and Design, located in Dubai Internet City, Dubai Media City, and Dubai Design District (d3), which house smart labs, recording studios, and design workspaces among other facilities. We look forward to continue providing emerging entrepreneurs and start-ups with platforms to not only succeed in their own businesses but also yield transformational benefits for entire societies.

One goal is to see Dubai produce a “unicorn," a start-up valued more than USD1 billion. Where do you think your unicorn is going to come from?

AT The government's perspective is that we cannot create a unicorn; what we are good at doing is creating the kind of place where people can try things out, fail, succeed, and move forward. An important part is that government can help with fundraising and to set targets and strategies. For example, we want blockchain implemented in government 100% by 2020, we want 20 to 25% of driving to be autonomous by 2030, and we have similar targets for 3D printing in the construction of buildings in Dubai. His Highness wants these technologies to be put in place gradually, rather than shocking the industry. For example, we are slowly incorporating 3D printing technology into the construction industry, making projects faster and cheaper, and we expect Dubai to benefit accordingly.

Which dimensions of the Dubai Smart initiative are you most excited about?

SN Dubai has some of the best companies in the world located here all applying their best people to solve pressing problems, whether it's from the application, communications, or data perspectives. At Huawei, we have over 3,000 high-end scientists whose job is purely to do blue-sky thinking, and we invest somewhere between 10 and 15% of our revenue every year in R&D.
node.intervieweelist4position: Head of Industry, Digital Transformation & Value Engineering, MENA Region

node.author: TBY
node.title: Banks
node.sections01: FNB Zambia has signed a tier-two facility with the FMO, a Dutch development bank, for USD15 million. We had such a facility in place prior to this, but we were coming to the end and sought to replace it with a similar-sized one to safeguard our capital structure. Tier two caters to the two main currencies we use in the country: the dollar and the kwacha. It is important to have a certain portion of capital in foreign exchange to offset any possible local currency depreciation, as was seen in 2016, and we were happy to have FMO invest in us. In December 2016, we did a further restructuring of our balance sheet, with a credit link note back to South Africa, which created profit for us. Aside from this, we have been concentrating on focused marketing strategies, with specific client niches and a drive to innovate and digitalize. It took us a year or two to have substantial liquidity to lend and gain the necessary market understanding.
node.sections11: One of the markers of economic growth is a booming construction industry. Indeed, in Zambia we see more and more large constructions springing up, especially in large cities. Stanbic has financed some of the largest infrastructure projects here, such as shopping malls, as we believe this is necessary for long-term economic development. Roads and shopping malls provide the platform for trade, communication, transport, and logistics. For example, we have partnered with the government in holding a number of events, such as the Infrastructure Symposium, to be held at the end of March 2017, which will look at the growth prospects of infrastructure, what needs to be done to build infrastructure, and what should be the priorities to boost the sector in the future. That is part of our corporate vision to provide thought leadership for Zambia's infrastructure industry. Moreover, Zambia only uses 20% of its arable land, meaning there is huge potential in the agriculture sector.
node.sections21: For any business, clocking in a quarter of a century is a commendable achievement, especially considering the cyclical volatility, challenging operating environment, and rigorous regulatory pressures that frontier economies can present. These past 24 months have certainly been tough, primarily due to cash-flow constraints brought on by government arrears and resulting in a deterioration in business portfolios in terms of asset quality, increasing costs of funds, and high interest rates. A decade ago, the Namibian Capricorn Group made a strategic decision to invest in Cavmont Bank, and our recent achievements are a manifestation of its capital and commitment to this entity, which is now beginning to present a more attractive prospect for our shareholders, with two consecutive years of profitability, which is highly commendable given the challenging economic landscape, and are on course to deliver our third. Cavmont Bank also received Zambia's first unsolicited credit rating with an investment A-grade. Coupled with profitability, this enables us to pursue capital markets activities and consider long-term DFI funding.
node.sections31: Ecobank commenced operation in Zambia in August 2009 during the period of the group's geographical expansion across Sub-Saharan Africa. The parent company, Ecobank Transnational Incorporated (ETI), was incorporated in 1985 as a Pan-African movement. ETI, which was initially set up by the members of the West African Chambers of Commerce and Industry, has now transformed into a truly Pan-African Banking Institution. Our largest shareholder currently is Nedbank of South Africa, followed by Qatar National Bank, the Public Investment Corporation of South Africa, International Finance Corporation, the investment arm of the World Bank, and SSNIT. These entities own between them almost 70% of the bank. The bank has grown its network and now has the largest footprint in Africa. Ecobank Zambia was set up during the period of geographical expansion for the group. Today, we have grown to eight branches, including several in Lusaka and three branches in the Copperbelt. At YE2016, our assets stood at over ZMK1.5 billion, putting the bank in 11th place in terms of size.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0company: Livingston International University of Tourism Excellence and Business Management (LIUTEBM)
node.title: Universities
node.sections01: Since 2010, we have diversified our educational offerings, and now courses such as law, medicine, business, and IT are available to all our prospective students. We have diversified to match demand, specifically in medicine. Once we receive certification, LIUTEBM will proceed with the development of a medical school, which will have branches dealing in surgery, physiotherapy, and pharmacy. Public medical universities in Lusaka have not managed to keep up with increased admissions applications, which enabled us to edge into the market and target this growing sector of interest. We have seen an impressive increase in admissions since our establishment, growing from just four students in 2010 to more than 350 in 2015. This growth is something we attribute to the high performance of our graduates, who subsequently attract others to join the same system. Because of our rapid expansion, we need to develop facilities that can cope with this and have applied for approval from regulators, as well as extra financing from investors.
node.sections11: Our programs have been accredited not just in Zambia but also internationally, and are attracting more and more students from overseas. In 2014, our student numbers totaled 4,300, and now we have 6,500. Second, we have opened our Leopards Hill campus, which houses the law school and an examination hall. Third, we are branching out into the medical field and will offer medicine, pharmacy, and nursing programs. Fourth, we have been broadening our portfolio of post-graduate courses, with a new executive MBA program in leadership and wealth creation. The first group will graduate in March 2017. This year we also intend to commence construction of our student accommodation at our main campus, due to begin in April 2017. The project, which should take about a year to complete, will be done in phases. We also prioritize internships and work experience and training. We want to engage with industry a lot more as a university because this is where our products end up.
node.sections21: Everything we do at ZCAS is business related and our programs are related to accountancy, finance, business administration, entrepreneurship, ICT, and economics. At the end of 2016, we registered our private university, ZCAS University, which became active in 1Q2017. All our programs with UNZA are undergraduate but in our new ZCAS University we are starting off with 17 programs, of which 12 are undergraduate and five are post-graduate. We have cemented our partnership with the University of Greenwich in the UK, and it has worked well. However, with our partnership with the University of London, our students struggled with the program largely because of the differences in criteria for application. ZCAS also started a partnership with Lancaster University, offering a global MBA program, but we terminated the program because it was unaffordable for Zambian students. We are in the process of building new partnerships for ZCAS University that will be looking more toward research and exchange types of collaboration.
node.sections31: When Cavendish University was founded in 2004, it was the first private university in the country. It began with a School of Business, and later added the Institute of Education and Research Development, School of Law, and Medical School. In 2014, Cavendish University Zambia majority shareholding was acquired by Maarifa Education, which is based in Mauritius. The School of Medicine has been operating from a small campus with outsourced laboratory facilities but, in late 2016, Maarifa signed a long-term lease agreement to use modern purpose built-facilities that were initially meant to house University of Southern and East Africa (UNESA). The Medical School moved to UNESA facilities in January 2017 and the campus has been renamed Cavendish University Zambia Long Acres Campus. Construction of laboratories for Foundation and Pre-Clinical courses has commenced and occupation of the new labs is scheduled for August 2017.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: There has been a sea change in the requirements of real estate managers to match the country's changing demographics and economy structure.
node.title: Real Estate Management
node.sections01: Seeff started as a small family business, acting as an agency for Zambian entrepreneurs to be more competitive in the face of big players and property competitors. Eventually it outgrew itself and expanded to what it is today, an international company with branches in Mauritius, Swaziland, Botswana, South Africa, and Zimbabwe, with ongoing expansion in other countries as well. Our latest addition is property management and valuation, which is rapidly growing. Our client mix includes NGOs, companies, and ordinary individuals, and we want to expand even more to be as competitive as the large companies that have been in the market for 15 years or more. Since we diversified into the agriculture sector, adding land for farming to our property offering, we have received more and more inquiries and offers for sales. We started off with offers for 10ha here and there to properties of 100 or 200ha, and even up to 3,000ha. We see a great deal of interest in Kitwe, in the Copperbelt, and in other parts of Zambia, and are now considering adding offices in Solwezi and Livingston as well. There is a notable lack of attractive houses in Lusaka: Many old houses are being demolished to make way for apartments, which means there is great potential for those seeking to construct or refurbish large houses, and demand for it, too.
node.sections11: A large portion of industrial property demand is still driven by foreign companies. Our manufacturing sector has taken a hit in the last few years, owing to the power deficit and high cost of production. Demand for industrial space, therefore, has lagged behind. In fact, we have seen a high vacancy of industrial space in the last 18 months. For example, Pam Golding currently sits on over 25,000sqm of empty warehousing available for lease; a large amount by our standards. One of the biggest occupants of warehousing space on the local market was the Food Reserve Agency, which rented out large spaces to store grain, and since it has been enforcing cost-cutting measures, it has not been renting this year. Industrial demand now is largely being driven by international and regional players that are not taking up spaces. However, even here we have not seen much interest, with many foreign companies not entering new leasing contracts on warehouses in 2016/2017. On the whole, people are confident about the long-term outlook of the sector due to a renewed confidence in Zambia and the overall economic growth outlook; however, trade volumes are still too low for many firms to warrant opening up an industrial space here. We need to see a substantial increase in regional and international trade in order for this to happen.
node.sections21: In terms of real estate markets, we have noticed increased interest from the education and health sectors, with many universities and colleges looking to expand their campuses. One of the factors that could have played a part in this is the rapid population growth in Zambia, with the largest demographic now being under 21 years old. Zambia is almost 50% urbanized, and we see growth in Lusaka and other cities across the country. However, there is a fair amount of agricultural land as well, which is where we should focus our attentions for development. Land in the immediate suburbs of the city has become more valuable for development rather than for agricultural use. Our clients have found that their land is now closer to the center, and that has led to active inquiries about how to best subdivide and service that land. There has been more subdivision of farm holdings in city suburbs, and overall there is greater use and development of farmland around the country. Only 40% of the arable land in Zambia is being farmed, so there is massive potential. However, only 10% of the land is under title, meaning there remains a great amount of work to be done by the authorities in terms of administering and processing land.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Cars
node.sections01: There have been many new entrants coming into the market as infrastructure becomes more developed and roads improve as a result of government initiatives such as Project Link 8,000. This has made it easier to gain access to used car imports: in Zambia the used market remains dominant, comprising about 90% of the total market. Also, asset finance was more affordable in 2014-15, whereas in 2016 the currency was subject to instability and borrowing decreased as a result. The car market suffered because of this, declining 25% compared to 2015. We expect decreases of a further 10-15% in 2017. However, the vehicle market in Africa in general is developing and holds great future potential as one of the strong areas for Toyota in terms of future sales. The Zambian market is still hugely dominated by dual purpose and commercial vehicles. Many parts of the country do not have sealed roads, which means demand for single cabs, double cabs, land cruisers, and pick-up trucks still tops the list.
node.sections11: We have a new double cab model launching in June 2017, which should grant us a little bit more market share. Nissan Zambia has been reasonably successful, with about 15-20% of market share. We started trading in August 2014 and it has seen quite good growth in a short time. After-sales is basically the bread and butter of our business. If we did not have a good after-sales service, we would not sell another new car. It is commonly said in the new car business that the salesperson sells the first vehicle and the after-sales will sell the rest. If we can show the motoring public we are there to look after them and can provide a trustworthy service, then they will trust in the brand. We are market leaders in Zambia, and it is a profitable market. Zambia is a good place for the brand to be and we have plans to build a new facility.
node.sections21: Our aim is to spread our wings throughout Africa, and our sights are set on opening a dealership in Mauritius and in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) once things calm down there. Mauritius has a large vehicle market, with strict controls on second-hand imports, meaning the whole economy revolves around brand-new vehicle sales. Moreover, the government has made purchasing a new vehicle feasible and attractive by offering tax benefits for consumers purchasing new vehicles. Our local footprint is also growing with the planned expansion plans for our Kitwe office, which will also be a base to serve the existing Isuzu Customer base in the DRC. We are also developing mobile vehicle servicing that will reach rural areas of Zambia, in towns like Livingstone and Solwezi. As our customer base in Zambia keeps expanding, we see the need to cater to our customers based in rural areas who cannot travel all the time to us when the vehicle is due for service.
node.sections31: CFAO Automotive entered the Zambian market in 2001. The group's expansion initiatives originally focused on West Africa, but then we decided to move into other regions, beginning with Tanzania and Kenya, followed by Zambia. CFAO Automotive bought out the company that was operating the Nissan franchise here, and then later, in 2011, it purchased the company dealing with Ford motor vehicles. When Toyota Tsusho bought out CFAO, Nissan disassociated itself from the company, since it did not want to be grouped with other brands, and now functions as a separate business. After losing Nissan, CFAO changed its corporate strategy for the whole of East Africa, acquiring the VW franchise. Here in Zambia, therefore, CFAO runs both the VW and the Ford franchises, in addition to selling generators and Maxxis and Pirelli brands of tires. In March 2017 as part of our synergistic approach, we launched sales of Motul products, a French brand of lubricants and oils.

node.author: TBY
node.title: German Connection
node.sections01: Achelis is a German-based company with headquarters in Bremen and subsidiaries all over Eastern Africa. Our regional hubs include Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda, where we have workshops and distributorships for equipment and generators in stock. In Zambia, we are quite small, with our main focus in public procurement. We participate in government tenders and tenders by state-entities such as Zambia Railways and ZESCO. Since establishing here in 1996, although we are slightly on the small scale, we have done great business and experienced good turnover in the country. We benefited from the Zambian government's project to issue euro bonds, which is partly what led us to invest in the country and remain open to business here. Some of our biggest projects include working with ZESCO on XPLEcables and line material, working with the Ministry of Health, as well as on a EUR4 million deal with Zambia Railways for a rescue crane for rail accidents. In terms of latest developments, on the whole we are purely focused on working with governmental agencies. We seek to establish a business model financing medium-scale companies in Zambia.
node.sections11: When the company was initially founded in 1958 with an original branch in Ndola and one opening in Lusaka shortly after, we undertook a broad band of contracting services, including Heating Ventilation Air Conditioning & Refrigeration (HVAC-R), plumbing, and electrical. In the early 1990s, we decided to specialize and focus on heating ventilation air conditioning and refrigeration only. With our focus on HVAC-R we have now become the largest contractor and distributor in this sector in Zambia, offering services of the highest standard and quality. Drake & Gorham has always been an innovator and trendsetter. We were the first company in Zambia to manufacture display fridges in the early 1980s. We were the first company in Zambia to partner with the air conditioner manufacturer Samsung, roughly 20 years ago. Drake & Gorham is also the sole distributor for Daikin, the largest air conditioning manufacturer in the world, and also have our own in-house brand, Dragor, popular in the Zambian market. We are thus able to offer the most innovative air conditioning and refrigeration equipment globally available.
node.sections21: In Zambia, our main business segments are water supply, sanitation, and transportation. Elsewhere in the region, we are engaged in different projects for harbors, airports, and railways. In Zambia, however, these facilities, in particular railways, have not received much attention to date. It is our belief that rail could be the future solution to relieve the congestion of Zambia's roads, and Gauff could be a potential partner in revolutionizing Zambia's transportation make-up. In the consulting engineering industry, we see more and more companies coming into Zambia looking for business. Those firms come from nearby countries like South Africa, where perhaps the market situation has become more challenging. Zambia provides a wealth of opportunities for infrastructure-related projects. Indeed, in Lusaka and the Copperbelt Province, we are seeing a multitude of large-scale investments being made in the water sector: USD200 million provided by EIB for Mulonga Water and Sewerage Company, MCC's investment of USD355 million in Lusaka's water, sanitation, and drainage infrastructure, and over USD250 million for Lusaka Sanitation Program, financed by the World Bank, EIB, KfW, and the African Development Bank.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: With abundant resources, growing demand, and a skilled labor force, the steel sector remains an attractive prospect.
node.title: Steel
node.sections01: Good Time Steel is one of the largest steel producers in Zambia. In terms of range of products, we are the number one company in Zambia. We produce everything from tubes, deformed bars, and round bars, to angles, window frames, steel plates, and roof plates. Our sales grow every year as we see infrastructure building picking up incrementally YoY in Zambia. There is still a long way to go in terms of rolling out development here, with a lack of hospitals, roads, houses, and the like; however, we see an increased drive to improve this, which boosts demand for steel in the country. Every year we see 20-30% growth. In 2017, we are in the process of completely upgrading our furnace and equipment, with a new 6ha facility, a project cost about USD50 million. This will mean a new production process, new technology, and a new team. We imported our equipment—a steel furnace, ruling machines, and structures—from China. This is more environmentally friendly, of higher quality, and more efficient, reducing labor costs. When operational, our capacity will increase to 50,000 tons per year. When we started our business in 2008 we only produced rebar but now we cover everything including angle irons, roof sheets, and steel tubes, which are produced and manufactured here in the Zambian facility.
node.sections11: BSI Steel is widely known and well supported in Zambia, despite some turbulence in the market and shifts in management in the last few years. We have made progress and made some purchases in a few sectors where we had pulled back our investments in the past. For example, our business in the Copperbelt has grown significantly, with some interesting projects cropping up in the latter half of 2016. We are also involved in exciting projects within Lusaka, such as assistance with the construction of a waterway to help with flooding up near Roma. We have also expanded business northwards into the DRC, serviced by our operation in Lubumbashi and supported by extra resources from our Copperbelt operation. We have taken on many more “cut and bend“ projects lately, which are growing in parallel to the advancing construction industry in Zambia. Our customers are varied. We have walk-in customers who are building or renovating their homes, as well as large construction companies working on large-scale projects, such as shopping malls, airports and warehouses. The cash flow for BSI is generally healthy, probably around a 40-60 split, with 40% corresponding to credit and 60% cash. We would like to see even more growth in cash sales with more purchases from the man in the street.
node.sections21: We are the manufacturers of steel and plastic products. We then sell these to the Zambian market, with a focus on wholesale trade. We fabricate products for the local market only, and do not export to neighboring countries such as other steel producers. We manufacture building materials, for example, wire, nails, and roofing sheets and also trade steel products, such as beams, for which there is still no capacity manufacture domestically. We import these products mainly from South Africa and also have a supplier in Belgium. Our imported goods to in-house production ratio stands at 2:3—on average we import approximately 100 tons and produce 150 tons of material a month. We mainly focus on quality, since this is vital for any company to survive though we also have to consider the extra cost. Right now, we are only based in Lusaka but are building a branch of Oriental Steel in the Chambishi area, in the Copperbelt. We are involved indirectly with certain large projects all over the country, as we work with most of the large contracting companies. Generally, we do not undertake any construction projects directly but focus on manufacturing to supply our partners. We supply most of the construction companies, such as China Civil, as well as large hardware stores.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Insurance
node.sections01: Overall, 2016 was extremely successful. We do not have the official industry figures yet but can confirm that we remain the market leader, with our gross written premium increasing from ZMK313 million to 353 million.
