I attribute this success to the confidence that the market continues to place in PICZ, the number-one insurer in Zambia now for at least the last five years. We are number one in terms of the top line and bottom line, and in both the corporates and retail line. We also have the largest liquidity reserves in the market, and are the only primary insurance company in Zambia to receive a credit rating, which stands at A+. Insurance penetration levels in Zambia are low, and we want to help in the drive to raise awareness. As a company, PICZ works with the IAZ to aid in this transition. In 2015 we sponsored the publication of a book, Insurance Basics: The Zambian Experience, authored by one of our own staff members, and we continue to sponsor an insurance column in the Times of Zambia. Beyond that, in 2017 PICZ has set a goal to engage with the media on this agenda to raise insurance awareness levels.
node.sections11: Considering that many business areas have been impacted negatively by adverse economic conditions, 2016 was an unexpectedly great year for Hollard. We grew by about 30%, our staff numbers increased, and we started planning an expansion into two other geographical areas, either in the east, south, or northwest of the country. This is all something of an achievement, given the difficult market this year, and our success is a result of our well-distributed network of insurance brokers and the support we have received from them throughout. Our business is broken down into corporate, commercial, and individual sub-fields. We have witnessed a shift in the overall success of these markets, with the corporate space being our traditional biggest source of business. An increased number of SMEs as well as a more influential middle-income sector have filtered into that commercial space, and because of this we plan to focus our attentions there in the near future. That said, we also look to penetrate the life insurance market. Our sister company, Hollard Life Insurance, has plans to expand in Zambia. Microinsurance is also worth mentioning, though it needs an improved legislative landscape in order to become a viable option for many Zambian citizens.
node.sections21: Zambia is an attractive insurance market, with a combination of low insurance penetration levels, a young and growing population, and a rapidly expanding middle class. Life insurance penetration here is less than 1%, so there is plenty of scope for the market to develop rapidly. The size of the potential target market for mainstream insurance is roughly 600,000-700,000 people, but this does not include the informal sector, where the majority of Zambians are employed. We plan to reach out to the informal sector through several channels. One of these is microinsurance; Prudential was the first company in Zambia to introduce a microinsurance product in 2011. A key challenge for the industry remains education—we need to continue to work on educating young people on the benefits of insurance. Also, the take-up of technology in the insurance sector here is at a nascent stage. While it is a vital part of the insurance back-office, as a tool for interacting with potential customers, it tends to favor more standardised products over life insurance. We are supportive of technology that makes insurance more comprehensible and will continue to assess the Zambian market, evaluating the ways in which technology can be harnessed to improve customer relations.
node.sections31: Since 2002, we have grown to become market leaders in Zambia, with 35% market share by revenue in 2015. Sanlam remains the unrivalled market leader in Zambia and we have 16 branches in Zambia, with 106 full-time employees and more than 500 direct sales agents. Our provision of insurance solutions to the informal sector is not an endeavor to bring our insurance clients from the informal sector to the formal sector; rather, we seek to provide insurance solutions to them in their existing circumstances and geographical locations. Our distribution philosophy is anchored on the need to not only reach the customer to sell insurance but to also be able to service the customer cost-effectively during the subsistence of the insurance policy. Each channel we deploy must therefore provide solutions to the whole value chain from sales, premium collection, policy servicing, and claims management. In this regard, we view the informal sector as a customer segment that can be reached by way of aggregation. In this model, we bundle our insurance solutions to the primary economic activity of each aggregated group. Our premium collection frequency is aligned to the seasonality and income cycles of the affinity memberships.
node.sections41: We saw early on that we would need a targeted strategy in order to stay afloat. Over time, if a company pushes to underrate to retain market share, it starts absorbing bad risks, too. So we established a disciplined approach; instead of writing for top-line insurance only, we started writing for bottom line, driving for more profitable, quality premium paying business. In addition, unlike our competitors, which remained focused on large towns, we developed a larger distribution strategy, especially for our agricultural insurance and motor insurance products. By spreading ourselves across all districts, we have established business in areas that our competitors are not able to reach. We have also invested considerably in raising personnel capacity, so that no insurance solution is too complicated for our staff, and we are able to advise our clients on the best possible strategy, whatever their specific needs. We also implemented a credit management policy, whereby we oblige our clients to pay premiums that are underrating or else the policy is cancelled. We hope to improve our market share by working with government agencies under the IDC. We also look at branch and district profitability, perhaps with a view to franchise off those branches that are not performing as well as we would hope.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Asset Management
node.sections01: Our client base is extremely diverse, including small and large businesses, public entities, associations, professional services organizations, and private individuals. In terms of reaching out to new clients, we are mainly developing our other services on the back of our risk services clients. Furthermore, we are a global, well-known, and respected brand and are able to leverage on that. Most clients in Zambia, however, talk about reductions in spend. This has been the function of economic performance. The demand for insurance services will increase as the economy rebounds. The risk landscape has been flat. On the one hand, we have seen certain slight increments in risk. However, on the other, there have been no catastrophic losses or anything of that sort; therefore, the overall trend has been flat.
node.sections11: Aflife remains the largest private sector investment management firm. Our market share fluctuates between 56% and 62% at any time of the year depending on how the assets we manage perform. In the last three years, we have launched collective investment schemes to take advantage of new laws promulgated by the Pensions and Insurance Authority in 2011. We initially launched products for our institutional clients; however, in the last two years we have rolled out a plan to try and reach out to individual retail investors using the same platform. We acquired the requisite approvals to deal with individuals and have launched six products. Now, we are creating the infrastructural backbone to roll these products out as efficiently as possible. As the industry grows, we envisage business growth to come through products. Therefore, we initially focused on products for collective investment schemes to demonstrate our capacity, capability, and competence. These schemes are our flagship in terms of marketing and how we face our clients to showcase our offering and capabilities.
node.sections21: Aon Zambia is the leading insurance broking firm in Zambia. Currently, we operate two entities: Aon Zambia Risk Solutions and Aon Zambia Pension Fund administration. The former provides broking services to local entities as well as multinationals, and the latter offers a wide range of products in the pensions and administration space. The risk side focuses on both the short-term and long-term business, as well as risk management services. The market has not experienced much diversity in products and services and currently most of the services on the market are similar; rivalry among insurance providers is intense. Regarding long-term products, the most popular are life schemes, medical, and funeral products. Aon strives to break away from this set path by bringing in new services and products.
node.sections31: Madison Finance made a deliberate decision to shift operations toward a 50% MSME and 50% personal loans position because the MSME segment was seen as a major area for growth and development of the Zambian economy. Very few institutions focus on MSME lending primarily because of the risks associated with this segment. To counter this, one of the measures we have put in place for MSMEs is training in aspects such as bookkeeping, financial discipline, and general business management skills. We go beyond merely lending out money, but also building clients' capacity in terms of helping them understand the practicalities behind lending and borrowing. Additionally, we have in place guarantees to secure loan products under agriculture and sustainable energy products that provides further impetus for the company to pursue these sectors in business. The question of boosting MSMEs goes beyond the aspect of funding; it is about improving the status of customers in terms of their ability to produce more within the country and sustain their businesses.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Managing Director, BASF Zambia & Area Manager, Southern Africa
node.previewsummary: A combination of accessible land routes, free trade agreements, ample rainfall, high quality soil, and a rapidly growing population help Zambia play a leading role in carrying Africa's economic boom forward.
node.title: Why Zambia?
node.sections01: In May 2014, FedEx Express acquired the business portfolio of its former service provider, Supaswift, in seven southern African countries: South Africa, Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland, and Zambia. The acquisitions were a strategic move by the company to expand its network to the world's fastest-growing continent. We now offer a complete suite of export, import, and domestic solutions across southern Africa, connecting the region to more than 220 countries and territories worldwide, enhancing customers' business flexibility and speed to market. This region offers tremendous opportunities for local and international customers to access new markets, and Zambia in particular has a geographical advantage. Being landlocked, or rather, “land connected“ with eight neighboring countries, gives Zambia trade access to markets in central, eastern, and southern Africa. Zambia is also integrated within two free trade areas. Combined with the entrepreneurial boom underway in Africa, the country has the potential to become an attractive hub for manufacturing and export in the region.
node.sections11: Our focus remains on underground and surface equipment, including drilling consumables, loading, and hauling equipment. We source the equipment from our manufacturing plants in Sweden and other parts of the world. We also work on developing our service support side of the business and other aspects of aftermarket sales. The majority of our growth comes from the mining segment, the drop in copper prices notwithstanding. That said, 2016 was difficult for us as well as many other players in the mining industry. To mitigate the adverse effects of the slowdown, our objectives shifted to internally reducing our cost structure, while still maintaining the same level of support for our customers. Our customers were also making similar changes, with everyone taking the same approach of aligning cost structures and growth rates. Atlas Copco weathered the storm well by targeting inefficiencies in the system: we are now in a better position for growth. The focus is on trying to make the organization as agile as possible.
node.sections21: The agriculture sector in Zambia has considerable potential. The soil quality in the country surpasses most other regions on the continent, as well as many other countries. For example, as a result of the properties and richness of the soil here, sugarcane cultivation is able to flourish more than in countries where it has traditionally been a staple crop, for example, Brazil. The rainfall pattern in Zambia is also, overall, remarkably good for growing crops. BASF is committed to seeing Zambia fulfill this potential. We have been working tirelessly and successfully with Zambian farmers to meet their specific needs regarding crop protection products. BASF believes that modern agriculture, including the responsible and appropriate use of crop protection products, is vital to meeting Africa's fast growing demand for food. In Zambia, BASF is one of the leading companies in crop protection. BASF continuously provides new and innovative agricultural solutions to help farmers improve their yields and the quality of their crops.
node.sections31: Our guar business is the largest of all our projects. At the beginning of each planting season, we take our seeds to cooperatives and they grow them with the help of our technical specialists and economists. Later, we begin the collection process, with each cooperative nominating a collection point. Once collected, we store the seed in our warehouses before processing in the factory, using equipment imported from India. After processing, we are left with the guar split, which is exported, and the bi-product, which can be sold to livestock feed makers. Our project is in the southern province, though we are expanding. Guar has many uses, including as an adhesive agent, a gelling agent, and in confectionaries and cosmetics. In 2015, we harvested about 400 metric tons of guar seed. In 2016, capacity increased to 2,000 metric tons. At that time, we were working with 52 cooperatives. Expected outputs of guar are between 3,000 and 4,000 metric tons for the 2016-2017 season.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation
node.title: South-South Symbiosis
node.richbody0content:
How is Morocco strengthening its relations with Zambia?

Mohammed Boussaid The recent visit was the first official visit of His Majesty King Mohamed VI to Zambia. We are currently reinforcing our diplomatic relationship with Zambia, in line with our new approach of forging ties at both an economic and social level. The Zambian economy boasts huge potential for growth. The country's geography means investment in Zambia is also an investment in the eight countries that border it. Zambia is part of SADC and COMESA, which means it is well integrated into a network of cooperating states, all working together for a common goal. This is another asset for investors. What is more, there are many parallels that can be drawn between Morocco and Zambia, and, therefore, the relationship can also become an important one of knowledge sharing. The three priorities for Zambia's economy are also Morocco's priorities: agriculture, tourism, and energy. In these areas, Morocco has experience and expertise. As such, on this visit we have signed 19 agreements with the Zambian government, most of which are with the private sector, in all areas, from human development projects to renewable energy.

Salaheddine Mezouar There were six or seven agreements consolidating the legal relationship between the two countries, as well as agreements from private-to-private sectors and public-to-private. These were in a number of fields. For example, we know that the potential for agricultural development in Africa is tremendous. Morocco has a rich and successful history in agricultural development, and our neighbors acknowledge this and ask us to bring this experience to the table. We want to help structure the development of agriculture, contributing to the know-how, investment, and investment planning in agro-business. Regarding the issue of minerals, the African continent, and in particular Zambia, boasts significant resources. When we consider that currently 70% of the Zambian economy depends on such exports, it is obvious that structuring the industry effectively can be key to creating wealth and employment. However, at the moment, there is extraction and export but no transformation, and if there is no transformation, no value-addition to raw products, then there is a minimum cap on the amount of wealth and in-country employment that can be created. This was the motivation behind the signing of the memorandum of understanding between the Zambian Ministry of Mines and Morocco's office for hydrocarbons and mining (ONHYM).

What are you doing to encourage further integration across the continent?

MB In Morocco, we believe strongly in South-South cooperation. We also believe that through regional integration, we can cooperate with each other to solve many problems ourselves. We can share public policies and experiences. That is why, in the last 15 years, His Majesty has made around 45 visits to 26 different countries. In this time, His Majesty has put Africa on the top of the list of priorities for foreign relations, because of this strong conviction that the continent, which has for many years had negative connotations, can represent hope for humanity and the world. It is a dynamic continent, with many social and economic transformations taking place over the last decade. The growth rate on average has been at about 5%, many countries have stable governments, and democracy is widespread. All of these developments shed a positive light on the continent, in turn unveiling new opportunities to invest and collaborate. This is leading to mass job creation and sustained development.

SM Returning to the African Union after more than 30 years away is like a return to our institutional family. Morocco has always been involved in Africa. After South Africa, Morocco is the second-largest African investor on the continent. In 2020, we have ambitions to become the first not only in terms of economic development, but also in terms of human development and culture. Morocco also fully supports the process of spreading peace across the continent. Many parts of Africa face challenges of fighting extremism and to do so it is crucial to boost cooperation among nations. His Majesty Mohammed VI has a vision for Africa. Africa is a continent with great potential, a continent of the future, but one grappling with many obstacles. Thus, the continent has two alternatives: become a problematic continent for the rest of the world in terms of democracy and political stability, or become a driving force—as one of the landmasses with a rapidly growing population—behind ensuring global peace and security. Morocco entered the African Union with this vision in mind. We want to share with our neighbors all that we have acquired in terms of experience, know-how, and capacity, to add value to the continent. There is a new generation of Africans, with potential, ideas, and innovation. The problem is organization, cooperation, and learning to work together. The visit to Zambia was part of Morocco's commitment to strengthening our ties with all African countries.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: The customer is not only always right, but they are diverse, with a wide range of needs and demands that these retailers are keen to cater to.
node.title: Retail
node.sections01: Shopping malls became popular in Panama in the last 15 years or so; however, for many years there were only two or three to which people could go shopping and also enjoy free time. In the last two years, there has been a boom in shopping malls and the trend is to consolidate the size of malls and design something that is friendlier to the public. We are trying to attain the top and best brands in each retail segment. We also seek to create special family experiences through shopping, entertainment, and leisure time at the mall. In Panama, people visit shopping malls at least one day out of the weekend and they do not go to malls just to shop; they also want to enjoy other activities. Our main goal is to open 95% of the shops. Then, the goal is to create traffic for the mall. We are the new mall so we have to create this constant traffic that we do not have yet. Weekends are relatively busy; however, during the week people are not in the habit of coming here yet. We have to change their habits and encourage people. It is a process that takes time and the right approach. We have to offer what they want and then they will come.
node.sections11: Spirit Wine Group is a young company, having started in 2004. We started with just three brands, and now have more than 35 vendors with over 600 products. Our portfolio is extensive and covers the most important categories of spirits. For example, we have whiskey such as Chivas and vodkas such as Absolut. Our focus is to provide premium products in the spirits market such as Tequila Patron, which is recognized as one of the best tequila brands in the world. We are part of the Duty Free of Americas, which is a large group; however, we work independently. We also have a large portfolio of wines, comprising every region of the world, including France, Italy, and Spain as well as Australia, Argentina, and Chile. Chilean wines, in particular, are prominent in the Panamanian market. Wine consumers today are more demanding and want to taste new flavors. We also carry certain drinks that are inexpensive and in the “easy to drink“ category. Our strategy is to focus on providing high-quality customer services. In this market, companies often try to focus on one area; however, we aim to diversify our brands and always leave the door open to new opportunities.
node.sections21: I could have opened a fine restaurant years ago, where I would cook and have my audience with reservations and high prices, but I did not identify with that. Globally there has been a movement for 10 years now of fast casual, which is a healthy, good, fast, and affordable meal in a pleasant atmosphere. Around 10 years ago, there were few options and several brands in the US started to develop that sector. It was great, people embraced that idea, and in Panama there was nothing like it so we entered the Athanasiou business. We have done well, and now even better with Suvlas. We have a number of projects scheduled for 2017 despite being such a new brand; we are opening approximately 10 branches, and the idea is to expand in the region and other countries in the next two or three years. Basically, the agenda focuses on four categories: price, taste, innovation, and speed, because people have less money and time, and health is more relevant. Before, there was not much focus on health issues because of a lack of information. Studying the fast casual market, it is estimated that by 2020, 75% of the consumer base will be millennial or will share their mentality and prefer fast casual.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Research & Development
node.sections01: Investment needs to improve in terms of science and technology and innovation. Panama is not a large country so it is easy to start at the grassroots level and build a knowledge-based country. Like any university in the world, we need research-based and problem solving education in local universities. In Panama, we need more research in universities and to build top quality research institutes. Though a transformation is now underway at the University of Panama and UTP, our institution has already had one as leading research institute. In 2016, we had almost 60 publications; therefore, we think it fit to call Panama the science hub of Central America. We are mainly focusing on biomedicine and biodiversity and interdisciplinary sciences. We cross discipline with mathematics, physics, chemistry and even social sciences. One other important aspect is that it is not just a number, it is about the quality. They should be competing at the international level, with high-ranking scientific journals like Lancet and Nature Biotechnology. We are publishing in these kinds of places, which is difficult but gives confidence to our people when they are able to do so. We train under and postgraduates and school kids as interns. We have lot of foreign students visit our institute for internship. The institute does lot of innovations in Panama.
node.sections11: Since its inception, we have consolidated the presence of City of Knowledge as a place where important universities, research centers, high-tech companies as well as international organizations are part of an environment centered around innovation. We work on having a stronger presence in other parts of Panama besides Panama City. The leadership has always relied on the private business community and we have accompanied the creation of a competitiveness center for the western region. It is positive that the City of Knowledge can insert itself in a dynamic that is promising and includes research, application of knowledge, promoting entrepreneurship, and incorporating marginal groups. A similar movement is just beginning in Azuero. The City of Knowledge was the place where the entrepreneurship community started when we created the first business incubator 15 years ago. We then had a meeting with a group from Mexico that was linked to Silicon Valley. It came here to establish relationships and enhance entrepreneurship in the country. At the City of Knowledge, we want to create opportunities. In another field, we will activate a simulation health-training center here. It is an agreement signed by the Director of Social Security, the Minister of Health, and SENACYT with the technical support of the University of South Florida.
node.sections21: We have a great deal of dialog with the private sector; for example, there is a plan to build a liquefied natural gas terminal near Colón and we have been in talks about the scientific information that is needed. There is also interest in hiring interns or students to collect data. We have worked with Minera Panama, which invested heavily in helping us preserve the Rana, a national symbol of Panama that is now extinct in the wild. Fortunately, with Minera's support scientists were able to go out into the field about 10 years ago and collect enough of them to preserve the species. We receive donations from international companies as well. Regarding our internal capacity-building, 42% of our interns and fellows are from Latin American, and half of these are from Panama. We have in total about 900 students with another 600 university-level professors who come to our facility every year on average to work in the areas of forest ecology, ecology, marine biology, and so on. They come from over 50 countries around the world. Our impact and reach is much bigger than just our small cohort in Panama. Our 1,500 scientific visitors per year and our core staff produce about 400 scientific publications annually. Every 19 hours there is a new publication released, and a significant number of them are in the top scientific journals of the world.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0name: Yazmina Gisela Yunsán de la Torre
node.title: Universities
node.sections01: Our university focuses on the medical and healthcare aspect of activities. We seek to provide a qualified workforce to serve the medical sector. Demand for nurses and experts in radiology is growing in Panama. A huge problem here is that all the managers and heads in hospitals in the public sector are usually not well qualified. That is why we seek to address this issue with a solid program that addresses the student community here that is willing to be part of the healthcare sector. Future professionals in this field must be able to manage a hospital. That is why we have activated a master's program in healthcare management and another in medical auditing. It is a sector with a great deal of potential. My target is to develop a new master's program in physiotherapy, nutrition, and dentistry. I would also like to start a master's program in project evaluation and one in environmental management. All these segments are extremely important for the national economy, and we are perfectly aligned to promote the development of the country. In 2014, when I started, we had 20 students. Now, our university has reached more than 300 students. This has been solid development and growth in a few years. We seek to diversify our offerings with specific programs; it is fundamental to have collaboration between the public and private sectors.
node.sections11: The country has recently begun to develop itself as educational hub, attracting more and more business schools in the last few years. It recently opened its doors to higher education organizations and schools, now positioning the country as a great regional platform in the sector. Panama offers the possibility of gaining valuable working experience in high-class multinationals and regional organizations. Additionally, the professional market is wide and varied. Overall, this has made the country much more competitive and attractive to foreign investment. Our main challenge is to educate and train the country's workforce according to the speed and quality of development the country and its companies require. There is a certain gap between the needs of the companies and the educational sector. Currently, Panama is an important business center in Central America. As such, we understand the importance of the country, and ADEN's development strategy goes in that direction. We see Panama as a regional hub for business and higher education in business studies. We have been here for more than 12 years, and our educational offerings target mainly executive directors and directors of companies. Thanks to our regional presence across Latin America, our students can complete a portion of their studies in other countries. This is one of our main competitive advantages: our regional presence across Latin America.
node.sections21: We have to focus on manpower and are concentrating our efforts to prepare better people to work onboard vessels and within the maritime sector. There is a global lack of marine officers and technicians and we have a great opportunity to address that issue as we are a maritime country. The university is focused on preparing more professionals to work onboard vessels. For these professionals, this is the first career they will have and is a great opportunity to change their lives. There are great salaries in this industry; for example, a 22-year-old has the ability to earn USD3,500 a month, which is difficult to find not only here in Panama, but in the world. Their lives and the lives of others will change, and they will contribute to the national GDP. At the same time, those who choose this profession will become more confident. The focus is manpower; this is how we contribute to the country and the region. We have an academic curriculum that can truly enhance the quality of life here in Panama. Our goal is to be a first-class, first-world university; we need to reach that level. We need to ensure our students are well prepared in the academic area, as well as have the best ethics. Our men and women are ambassadors of our culture outside of Panamanian waters.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: With a rapidly changing market and stiff competition, developers have had to adjust to market demands and focus on their core strengths.
node.title: Developers
node.sections01: We want to continue consolidating our ground in Panama, where people know The Group and its strong reputation. We concentrate on developments for Panamanians and Panamanian residents with a focus on properties from USD60,000-150,000. We even look to enter the rentals market. We have focused on doing social and preferential housing in the USD60,000-120,000 bracket. For the other buildings we have been developing, we focus on prices from USD120,000 up to USD200,000. This is the reason for our success and is why we have an advantage. We have projects to put on the market and continue to sell to expatriates who come to Panama for work and will live in the country for one or two years. They get residency and with that they can apply for mortgages. Those developers building projects in the USD250,000-500,000 price bracket are the ones that have been affected. Developers with projects under construction have to react to changes in the market and reduce their costs, while those working in our price bracket have been the most successful in doing so. Certain developers, instead of continuing with their original project, modify part of their plan, for example by reducing the apartment sizes.
node.sections11: We want to generate value by creating social spaces, boosting the sense of community, improving human interaction and efficiency in the use of the urban spaces, and so on. Currently, the most eco-friendly places in the US are cities because the density of people sharing that space with fewer emissions makes it more efficient than having people live far apart and using a car for everyday life. We are currently focused on developing projects outside Panama City. There are two main reasons for this. The first is that when developing our first town center we did not have the resources, credibility, or track record to develop in a dense and expensive urban setting such as Panama City; therefore, it was easier to make an impact in suburbs, smaller cities, and towns rather than in Panama City. Also, the opportunities in these areas are as big or larger than the ones in Panama City; these communities have been historically underserved, have an identity that needs to be showcased, and no one has capitalized on the opportunity and the value to do so. For example, our project Market Plaza Las Tablas is a cultural platform to strengthen its identity, culture, and folklore, encouraging local and international tourism.
node.sections21: We now have five projects under construction and will start two to three projects within this year and the next. As a partner of Santa Maria we believe in the idea. It will be a unique project in Panama as it is the largest gated community, measuring 250ha; it is a huge project. There are many small projects that are gated, though not large communities like this. The idea of having green areas, a golf course, security, and a high quality of life in Santa Maria is something special that people will want to be a part of. When we design our projects, we take a great deal of time to sit down with our architects to determine the little details. That is how we differentiate ourselves from the competition; it is all in the details. We look for that unique factor that will set us apart. We work with architects like Eduardo, who is working on one of our projects, namely Santa Maria Park with VerdeAzul. It is a beautiful project with green roofs. We already have a silver LEED certification for Santa Maria Park. Eduardo is an architect who looks for innovative ideas and we make sure these are things that will set us apart from others.
node.sections31: The trend in the city center is for smaller apartments. The city has grown and people who currently live on the outskirts face transportation problems; they want to come back into the city center to live. That is our focus right now, and most of the competition is also starting to tackle this market. For example, we have the Bella Vista Residence project in the middle of the city. There are another eight projects being built around the same area in the same price range and size. That is where the market is moving toward currently. The unique aspect of the Bella Vista Residence is that it offers the amenities of a more exclusive building, within a smaller space of between 90sqm and 120sqm. This represents good value for the size and price. Residents get the amenities and features of a USD500,000-plus apartment for only USD200,000-230,000. The apartments are suitable for small families, couples, newcomers to Panama, young people who want to move into the city to be closer to work and save time, and local or foreign investors. It is an area that offers people nightlife, supermarkets, metro links, and is next to the financial district.
node.sections41: Grupo VerdeAzul today is a well-diversified group. We develop and manage real estate and hospitality assets and invest in other companies and industries via third-party managed funds, in addition to venturing more recently into logistics and agroindustry. We started out with the Bristol Hotel in Panama City and the beach development Buenaventura, as at the time the family's main business was banking. With the success of Buenaventura in the Panamanian market, real estate turned into our main business. With the growth of Buenaventura came the construction of our second hotel, the Bristol Buenaventura Resort—today the JW Marriott Panama Golf & Beach Resort—which served as a window for more visitors to discover Buenaventura. The group continued to invest in other real estate projects apart from Buenaventura not only on the Pacific Coast but in the country's capital as well. The Bristol Hotel positioned us as the reference for luxury, high quality, attention to detail, and understated elegance, and when we launched the beach community Buenaventura, our brand was associated automatically with good taste and excellence.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Nordic Players
node.sections01: Panama holds the most comprehensive maritime community in Latin America. This played an important role in our decision to establish ourselves here. Some of the other companies complain about the lack of a skilled workforce; however, Panama is one of the few places in Latin America where you can get people with a maritime background and education. The other is the geostrategic location, which is a common feature for all the companies here. Panama is a hub for both sea and air transport with ambitions to develop the logistic sector further. Höegh Autoliners has the same ambitions and this is also one of the reasons we are expanding our role in the supply chain here. Our presence in Panama and the region is a mix of serving and facilitating intra-regional trade and offering a global reach through our deep-sea network. Höegh Autoliners is today the only Ro-Ro shipping company that can offer 22 destinations in the Caribbean connecting to Mexico, Panama, South Florida and all the small Caribbean islands as well as the rest of the world. With an extensive global network, our customers experience a seamless high-quality product from load to final discharge port.
node.sections11: We came to Panama because we saw a great opportunity. We saw a country that was growing and needed more expertise, which we could provide, and a stable environment to invest in. We are in a niche market. Panama has been important for us because it has been easy to integrate in the region. 2017 is a year of change for us; we have the Canal expansion that the industry is trying to adapt to. Recently, the 1,000th vessel passed the Canal and the bunker sector has started to feel the effects since November and December. Certain bunker companies have purchased new equipment while others bring in new vessels just to better understand the needs of these vessels. We need larger ships with better pumping rates. The impact is real; the market is changing and volumes are growing. The number of ships is gradually slowing down and this forces companies to be much more professional in their work. This has a real and positive impact on the market. There are also certain opportunities for LNG carriers. We see ship-to-ship transfers taking place here and eventually Panama can become a hub for LNG just like we are for fuels.
node.sections21: This office oversees all the American countries in which we operate. We decided to keep our US office as the regional one for sales and move all HQ functions to Panama; finance, compliance, credit, HR, operations, and everything else with the exception of sales was moved to Panama. The location of Panama was a major part of that decision. We are focused on three markets, Mexico, Panama, and Colombia, and it made great sense to be in Panama because it connects well with the other two countries. We will do whatever it takes to make sure that everything with our customer goes well. We have this Scandinavian mindset of paying attention to details to ensure the excellence of our operations. We want to have the same service in all ports and that is a challenge in this part of the world because there is always a strong bureaucracy. We are successful in Panama in building relationships and partnerships that we could not do unless we were based in here. Some of the most challenging and largest shipping companies in the world refuel here and we are pleased to service many of them on a regular basis.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: With a saturated logistics market in Panama, companies are pulling out all the stops to stay ahead.
node.title: Logistics
node.sections01: Yobel SCM is supply chain management company with 50 years of experience in logistics and supply chain. We started our operations in Lima, Peru, and began expanding into Latin America by opening up operations in other countries like Mexico, Guatemala, Costa Rica, El Salvador, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Colombia, Ecuador, and Panama. In Panama, we have two facilities: Parque Sur, which is one of the leading logistics parks in the country for its level of infrastructure and service, and Panama Pacifico, a free trade economic zone. We use this facility for international clients that need to export their products. One of the main challenges that we face is to be more efficient than our competitors by providing the best services for our clients. We started in 2010 and have significantly expanded our physical capacity. In 2016, we received an award for Best Corporative Operation, as we are the fastest-growing company in the segment in which we operate. We have double-digit growth here in Panama. This accelerated growth has not been easy; however, it is a remarkable achievement considering that the logistics sector in Panama is extremely saturated, with a great deal of competition. We are constantly fighting to get new clients, and succeeding.
node.sections11: Our portfolio is about 30% airfreight and 70% ocean freight. The majority of our airfreight volume comes from Europe for Brazil. Because airfreight is expensive, it is only used for matters that must reach a place at a certain time. We manage a great deal of parts and other components for the offshore gas drilling rigs and they must have their parts as it costs them millions of dollars a day to be shut down and they, thus, ship it by air. We also started a document custody business in Venezuela about 25 years ago as no one else was doing it at that time. Many government offices started to reconsider the need to protect their documents after a large fire broke out in a tower in Caracas where the government infrastructure division lost a large amount of information. We worked with divisions of the government as well as other businesses such as oil companies like Schlumberger, Halliburton, and other companies that were our customers. Many banks, for example, must maintain certain sensitive documents such as deposits, checks, contracts, and account information for a certain amount of time and they need to be secure and regulated in terms of humidity and so on.
node.sections21: DB Schenker has been in Panama since 1981; our headquarters are in Germany and we have around 2,000 offices in 130 countries around the world. Ocean freight, mostly from Asia, is our main business in Panama; we are the market leader in ocean imports from Asia while airfreight is our second-largest product followed by land transportation. Land transportation is mostly exports from the Colón Free Zone to Central America and even though we only started it in 2016, it is a growing market. We saw great opportunities in airfreight and the market is supportive of our airfreight services. We currently transport perishables, pharmaceuticals, and spare parts from Panama, and business is great. There is also sea freight; every company in Panama conducts sea freight from somewhere but not everyone does airfreight or exports and it thus requires a more qualified and professional service. In addition, a pharmaceutical company requires a company to take care of its cargo on the other side; they need someone who will not only do the billing but also receive the cargo on the other, work with temperature control devices, and so on. This is where we can truly differentiate ourselves from the other local or regional players.

node.author: TBY
node.title: IT
node.sections01: When GLESEC was established, I wanted to do something different and seize other opportunities. Panama was not in fact on my radar; however, after I contacted certain people they invited me to the country, where I discovered a great opportunity. The country is growing rapidly, it has connectivity and communications infrastructure, it is close to the US, and it is easy to travel to all Latin American countries from there. There are two potential markets, domestic and international. The domestic market is changing quickly and growing rapidly; the maturity of the market is growing. In 2011, the banking regulatory entity signed an agreement with the banking association, outlining the requirements for the financial sector regarding information security and compliance. This involves both governance and infrastructure in order to protect clients' information. This is just an example of how the market is changing; when we started these regulations did not exist and we were “preaching“ to the market, whereas now it is more mature.
node.sections11: Intelsis belongs to the Inbursa Group and has been in Panama for 12 years. It was established in 1986. We have partnered with important customers in Panama such as the Chamber of Commerce, Tocumen Airport, Tropigas, and Ralph Lauren and have market share in both Panama City and the FTZ. Over the last five years, we have seen an impressive increase of investment in the industry. There used to be a certain resistance from many sectors and investors. However, we have managed to change that cultural understanding and, with the arrival of more companies, Panama has indeed become a technological hub. Many companies have understood the need to enhance the commercial experience of their customers, and technology plays a key role here. Many companies chose Panama due to the stability of its local and regional economy over the last few years, as well as the increasing number of foreign companies operating there. In this context, this also contributed to increasing investment in technology in the country, including in the public sector, which has boosted e-services in all tax and fiscal activities over the last few years.
node.sections21: We are the premier provider of leading-edge IT solutions throughout Central America and Ecuador. Born as a service company in the IT industry, we have developed into a robust business partner that offers hardware, software, and innovative, high-tech IT solutions—but service remains at our core. So it is not only about the hardware. We do not just provide a server; we provide an entire IT solution. We provide the hardware with the operating systems, the structured cabling, communications, security, and everything else that relates to the initial IT platform. On top of that, clients require particular applications that are specific to their industry. TECNASA is able to be a multi-industry service provider because we can offer every sector the IT platform. We are a B2B company and all of our clients are corporations. A small percentage comes from the government sector; however, the majority is large- to mid-sized corporations from the private sector. We also have certain smaller companies as clients. Our target market and clients are the corporations and businesses in all the countries we operate in.
node.sections31: Technology is an accelerating wheel, creating tools that themselves make the production of tools more productive as an enabler. That makes it hard for vertical sectors to keep up. The level of innovation in this sector is high. We position ourselves as the innovation arm of some of those sectors. We first select and recruit talent based on their performance and potential. Then we cultivate this talent to make it vertical in the market. We have been in operation since 2001 and have been through a few phases. We gained the trust of our clients by performing reliably and transparently. We cannot provide them with sophisticated solutions because we are not an R&D company, even though we do R&D. We do more development than R&D. What sets us apart from our competitors is the ability to detect an opportunity to assemble and integrate technology that provides an impactful solution that is still low risk for the client even though it is not available in the market the way the client is.
node.sections41: We currently target a whole range of sectors because with Smartbytes' growth we have gained customers from various sectors and countries, including Costa Rica, Puerto Rico, Guatemala, Nicaragua, and other South American countries such as Peru. In terms of penetrating the healthcare market, we have a partnership with a hospital. The customers in this sector are changing; however, the mentality of doctors is difficult to change as their views are old fashioned. The market has changed in the retail industry where shops are closing and there is a shift to e-commerce. Other IT companies, for example in Peru, that do not have the same implementation expertise as Smartbytes, are also hiring us. They call on us to help them implement projects; for example, together with a competitor, we helped implement some big projects in Panama. Smartbytes specializes in IT talent and we have to invest in our employees' talent. We have 26 employees but are able to compete with companies that have 2,000 employees.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Logistics and Distribution Director North Latin America
node.intervieweelist2company: Tetra Pak Central America and the Caribbean
node.intervieweelist3company: Endress+Hauser Instruments International AG Latin America Support Center (LASC)
node.title: Panama as a regional hub
node.sections01: The strategic importance of this market can only increase. Along with our head office in Germany we want to create a hub for innovation in this region. The exact location has yet to be confirmed, but we are looking into having multiple country locations because we have different focuses in different locations. Costa Rica is a good finance hub, and Peru has good universities and vocational schools. The City of Knowledge would be an interesting platform to establish a competitive research center in Panama. Our idea is to cooperate with leading universities from different countries to improve our innovation in this region. We are contributing to innovation as well as knowledge transfers. The lack of qualified people is the main obstacle to the company's expansion in Panama. When we started, it was difficult to work together with vocational schools.
node.sections11: One of the strengths of Unilever is that we are able to make decisions more quickly because of our location in Panama. We take care of the logistics volumes from Mexico to Ecuador, including Central America and the Caribbean. From here, we have a center of excellence from where we can make faster decisions regarding our customers, consumers, and these countries. As we are able to make decisions faster, we provide better service for our customers. For example, in 2016 we won excellence awards and we were recognized by the government with “Premio Nacional de Logistica 2016“ after successfully implementing projects with our key customers for our service and in Mexico. Having better communication helps us generate more knowledge for people, improve our service, and reduce costs. For the consumer goods business to grow in Panama, we need to take better care of our distribution and the country has to still work on simplifying and speeding up processes.
node.sections21: We are one of the first multinationals that decided to set up operations in Panama. The main reason was because of the central location of the company and the country's banking system. It started to be a logistic hub for the region, particularly with the construction of the canal and the rail and air connections. It also uses dollars, which offers us stability and makes it easy for us to operate outside of Panama. As soon as we started to grow, we moved to other countries, keeping Panama as the hub. We have a front office that essentially takes care of all the countries that we do not manage directly. We also have a back office that helps us operate in an international and multicultural environment here. We have operations that run 24 hours and are our financial hubs. We also have customer service centers that manage all our spare part services for the Americas.
node.sections31: The largest market in the region that we support is undeniably food and beverages. For example, in terms of levels of operation in the industry, Guatemala is the second-largest producer of sugar cane mills in America after Brazil. We have a great deal of business with the food and beverage industry there. The second is oil and gas because our largest businesses in countries such as Bolivia, Ecuador, Peru, and Trinidad are in this sector. However, when we talk about Central America, like Nicaragua, Guatemala, El Salvador, or Honduras, the levels of operation of the oil and gas industry are lower. In terms of mining, we consider countries such as the Dominican Republic, Peru, and Bolivia, where we have high mining activity. When we have cement, we consider most of the countries because we have a cement plant in each of them.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1name: Rolando J. de León de Alba
node.title: Banks
node.sections01: Banistmo had a positive performance aligned with the output of the financial sector of 2016. We managed to reconfirm ourselves as the second-largest bank in the country and have an aggressive consolidation strategy, both for commercial banking and the individual segment. It was a challenging year; however, we are a resilient bank and have the skills to continually reinvent ourselves with a tailor-made strategy. 2016 ended with a positive performance by the bank, in particular in two fundamental aspects. The first is the growth of deposits with Banistmo. The aim of every single financial institution is to grow its deposits, which are one of the main indicators of the performance of a bank, and we are no exception. Hypothecary credit grew as well, with a focus on single individuals. In Panama there are still many opportunities for companies to attract new clients. There is still a deficit as far as the availability of houses in the country. The bank's borrowing activity is currently quite active. Our solvency is close to USD1 billion, which is higher than the minimum requirement. Since 2016 we have been more market sensitive and are thus consolidating ourselves as the leading consumer bank in Panama. In terms of personal borrowing, lending, and credit cards, we started to better understand the behavior of our clients and how they buy and make repayments.
node.sections11: 2016 was a challenging year for Panama. First we had the Panama Papers, and later we had the Waked Group situation. There are two main things to remember. Panama just got off the FATF gray list, meaning we are in a great position to recover everything that had to do with our legislature in terms of money laundering and counter terrorism. We need to continue to work with our international partners to protect the integrity of the Panamanian system. Panama has taken many steps to promote transparency, fairness, and compliance with the standards set by GAFI and the OEC. That is where the country made the biggest improvement this year. Then, the Waked crisis came and had a negative impact on the country's image. When something like this happens, it threatens the stability of the system. Fortunately, we were able to come up with a solution in accordance with our partners in the US. The banking system in Panama is continuing to grow. Local banks had to establish stronger reserves in order to comply with current regulations from the Superintendence of Banks. That has forced financial institutions to be more responsible and prudent. We have no central bank here and do not have a discount window, which makes our banks very conservative in the way they conduct business.
node.sections21: Our acquisition of Citigroup was a successful transaction. We have always been a conservative bank and that will not change; however, there is a global strategy to be bigger and better with credit cards. This transaction was mainly a bet on the country, its growth, and the credit card portfolio that Citi had built. We had 28,000 clients before and now have over 100,000; therefore, it was also a customer base acquisition. This was a success because the acquisition involved a bank that was well placed and well recognized for unsecured lending mortgages, while another bank was mainly recognized and successful in placing secured products like credit cards. The cross-selling potential of those two products is fantastic. We now have the product, and our customer base grew correspondingly. We are currently going through the integration process, which is a challenge with every acquisition, and everything is on schedule. After everything, our bank was established as a corporate commercial bank funded by Canada in 1974; however, its business started to change in 2007 and 2008. Currently, 65% of our assets continue to be corporate commercial, while 35% is retail. With our acquisition of the Citibank portfolio, the retail increases significantly in terms of customers and employees, though the assets were not that large relative to what we had.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Green Energy
node.sections01: At this moment, the new trends in Panama are a move toward a more renewable energy matrix; the entry of gas with the next regasification plant will change the way energy is being generated. The third line from Chiriquí­ will also change the way energy is distributed and generated. Unlike other countries, Panama will not go for 100% renewable because gas is not completely renewable; however, it is cleaner than other fossil fuels. That is a change toward where the matrix is headed. This summer has been a barometer of what support for wind and solar energy will represent for Panama in the future. We have two clearly defined businesses that come from the company's new long-term strategy. We are in the traditional generation of power and in that traditional generation we also have renewable, particularly in Panama; we are in hydraulics. We also have Bahia de las Minas, which currently has coal and is in the process of transformation. The contracts are until 2018 and we are waiting for the start of new long-term bidding. That process of transformation includes the conversion toward gas.
node.sections11: trong demand growth continues to impact the sector. On the generation side, the supply mix is constantly evolving. This market will have a new coal-fired plant shortly and at least one, potentially three, new gas-fired projects in the next five years. Panama currently has a maximum demand of approximately 1,700MW and these gas projects are large, averaging around 500MW each, so if we have two or three of those projects, it significantly changes the profile of the sector with the majority of current oil-fired capacity becoming obsolete. On the hydro side, there have not been any medium-to-large scale hydro projects being actively developed in the last 12 months. The only large project being considered is Changuinola II, but with all the issues surrounding Odebrecht, that project will need to be restructured before advancing. Additional small-scale hydro, wind, solar, and biomass projects continue to be evaluated and developed. The price signals that we as developers have received over the last 12 months are not as strong as they were in the past. There has been significant investment in renewables, particularly on the hydro side, in the last five years.
node.sections21: GreenWood was motivated to move to Panama, as it could introduce new technologies in the market. What we are doing now in northern Central America is competing using advanced technologies. If we talk about solar, we know it needs net-measuring program for solar panels for homes and businesses. That is why we operate in Panama and the Dominican Republic: both countries have great regulations. For example, Panama has a maximum individual power-generating limit of 500kW and in 2016 this limit was lifted. This is a specific regulation for solar energy that may be part of the new framework that allows clients to install as much solar energy as they like. This is the most aggressive regulation in Central America. If a client consumes more than 10MW/hour/year we can design a solar farm over their roof or car park with the aim of covering their annual consumption. The government should help people with some task-specific regulations to make this investment more attractive for clients. In general, we see a great deal of potential from hospitals, industry and logistics, agriculture, and big chicken farms.
node.sections31: If you have a look at the latest tenders you will see that the government is focusing on the development of the LNG market, and taking advantage of the Panama Canal expansion. Indeed, it has already changed the distribution channels of LNG, which will give rise to many new opportunities. Then again, Panama has to take a piece of the cake or a share of the opportunities not only in logistics but also in the energy sector to reduce the price of electricity. Once they focus on that area, you will see that with the projects like the one from Martano and AES and even LNG Power, which still has a few issues to resolve, these are the main trends where the gas sector will leave its footprint on our market. The other important one is solar energy for self-consumption, which is giving clients the opportunity to reduce the impact of energy costs in their operations. Finally, it is active in Panamanians' initiatives to support energy efficiency and the use of clean energy like wind, which with latest forecast technologies has the opportunity to deliver a deal of great support to Panama's energy mix.
node.sections41: Our client base includes blue-chip companies such as Tropigas gas stations and Delta Petroleum gas stations; we have done six installations for it and our solar plant is the largest on earth with micro inverters. We also have residential customers for projects as small as 10 panels to projects involving 8,000 cell panels. We do the whole range based on different customer needs. We also focus on what our customers truly require, taking the time to ensure we determine exactly what each customer needs and then designing a system that fits those needs. Once the system is installed and finalized, if it has a net meter, we provide customers with post-sales support and the technical know-how to ensure they have a great experience. We take care of any issues that may arise with the electrical distributor. We also offer customers the O&M for each project's needs at cost, and this assures our customers that they will have a working system generating the energy that was projected at the start, that their financials will pan out and satisfy estimates, and that they will have a reliable system that will not break down or present technical problems.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Why Panama?
node.sections01: People not only have to perceive that the country is transparent; it also has to be transparent. There have been a lot of reforms in this regard, and the challenge now is to implement them and show the world they are working. Panama needs to reinforce its commitment to transparency regarding all the corporate scandals in the country by reviewing their operations, supervision, and regulations without compromising the privacy and confidentiality of people with a right to it—it is a fine balance and compromise that is needed. The FDI figures are still strong. Relative to GDP, FDI is still at about 10%. So there is a strong foreign investment presence in the country. When you look at FDI in terms of sources, most of it is reinvestment of profits: That shows that people are committed to the investments they are reaping here. Investors are also highly diversified, although still dominated by the US and Colombia. Panama has an open economy with no capital flow restrictions, and there are plenty of opportunities for investors in different sectors. The activities and sectors directly or indirectly related to the expanded canal are but one. Panama also offers all sorts of opportunities in other sectors like tourism, financial services, infrastructure, energy, education, and agriculture. I would encourage all sorts of investors to look into investing in the country.
node.sections11: Certain sectors in Panama are economic engines. One is construction, though this is slowing down. Another is tourism; however, we need to increase and improve training in that sector to realize its high potential. Energy is also a key issue, especially clean energy. Furthermore, we need to offer new and different services in shipping and logistics beyond just the ships crossing the canal. Then, there is food production and agriculture. That sector contributes only 2.5% of GDP but employs 15-20% of the workforce. We need to focus on agro-industry and ways to produce more with less, as well as boost productivity and efficiency. We have to focus our engines of growth on education and training for jobs, as well as health. Quality education is a must for a level playing field and a just society. In politics, we need a clear and consistent roadmap for the next 25-30 years that is adhered to no matter what government comes into power. There are five Panamas in my view: the modern Panama, the urban marginal Panama, the middle-class Panama that pays taxes for subsidies for other Panamanians, the rural-agricultural Panama, and the indigenous Panama of the comarcas. Therefore, we need to consider all these Panamas.
node.sections21: CIFI migrated to Panama for several reasons. First, since we operate in US dollars it was more consistent with our lending guidelines to be based in a dollarized country in the region; hence, Panama was chosen as the best option. Also, in addition to CIFI's own equity we borrow money from the market to accompany our growth. Panama is a regional financial center and offers CIFI a good opportunity to become known in the capital markets, with regional banks so we can expand our access to funding. In 2016 we strengthened CIFI's regional presence, relocating the team to Panama, which has proved to be a good strategy since we are much closer to our clients and are developing a strong pipeline of new projects, some of them in Panama. We are currently financing 45 projects and are structuring new projects for 2017. Since CIFI is a specialized niche player we have both simpler and more complex projects. This is part of the beauty of what CIFI can bring to the region. With our extensive experience, background, excellent relationships with international and institutional investors, and our shareholder mix, CIFI is a platform that can put together the different pieces of the puzzle for complex projects.
node.sections31: As we like to say, from Panama our operations make the heart of Philips beat throughout Latin America. The Philips Center of Excellence in Panama represents an essential element for the performance of our company as we provide support to all our offices and plants in Latin America. Everything is done right here in Panama by a talented and diverse team in an environment structured for innovation in operational excellence. Once we decided to relocate our headquarters, which were originally based in Brazil, we considered several locations, and Panama had a clear benefit over other countries in terms of its location, flight connections, IT infrastructure, logistics knowledge, the Panama Canal, and the government's initiatives for fostering foreign investment. For these reasons, our focus is on building competencies and capabilities in Panama to support the company's transformation and deliver the highest performance for our customers. Innovation is everything for our Center of Excellence in Panama to become a model of reference within Philips and for all of Latin America. When we look back to 2016, in addition to improving the lives of 178 million people in Latin America, it was clearly a year marked by transformation. We experienced double-digit growth and sizable profit improvement in the region.
node.sections41: In 2015, BDO Panama received approval from the global board to develop some territories in Central America that were not covered by our brand and this decision was based on the success of the BDO model in Panama. The development of our office in the last decade under the BDO brand gave the board the confidence it needed to allow us to develop in Nicaragua, Honduras, and Belize; Panama also invested in the existing firm in Costa Rica with the purpose of taking the lead in the development of this territory. Thus, this office, which has corporate development responsibilities, directs professional practice in Panama, Costa Rica, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Belize. Strategically, we must see Central America as a single territory and from an office like this lead the practice of several countries to generate economies of scale and efficiency, improve profitability, and manage the model that BDO seeks much more efficiently. This includes sharing products and specializations with small firms from other countries and exporting knowledge, technology, experience, and resources of all kinds. There are two axes on which BDO's strategy and vision focuses. One is our customers and the other is our people. Our people are our assets; for us people mean everything.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0position: Country Head Panama and Costa Rica
node.title: Women in Power
node.sections01: IFC was established in 1956 and during those 60 years has participated in many of Panama's most important projects. These include the Panama Canal expansion, the Manzanillo International Terminal in Colón, the Panama Canal Railroad Company, and the Corredor Sur toll road. Major investments in infrastructure are also expected, such as the two new metro lines, bridges over the canal, and all the other roads and bridges planned in the last few years, not to mention the Minera Panama mining project. We think that those infrastructure, energy, logistics, and mining projects will support macroeconomic growth in the coming four to five years. But most importantly for IFC is that these investments and growth are also accompanied by social inclusion and environmental sustainability. The most important factor for Panama will be investments in education, both in terms of quality and access. Without a strong educational foundation the county will never reach the levels of social development and poverty reduction that remain its primary goal.
node.sections11: When it comes to gender relations, we are much more advanced than other countries in the region. Through LatamLex and our clients, we have the opportunity to work in other countries in Central America, and Panama stands out as a country that has the most opportunities for women. If an individual is talented, he or she will prosper regardless of their gender. Most businesses understand that having more women involved in their boards, executive teams, and advisor teams ensures they will be more successful. Different points of view, background, and experiences in the leadership of any company are a vital ingredient to thrive in the modern business world. The number of women in politics and serving on boards in Panama is still low, but we are quickly making strides. Progress is rapid, and it motivates me to continuing promoting the professional development of women. The objective in my view is not to get the numbers to exact parity or achieve equivalent representation, but rather to give women choice and equal opportunity to succeed in any area.
node.sections21: There are several principle excuses for why women fail to excel at the top of the business world. Women are encouraged from kindergarten and early childhood to be ladies, thus well behaved and disciplined and to do several tasks at the same time, including homework, caring for siblings, cleaning, doing the dishes—all of which they are under pressure to perform well. Boys are encouraged to be active, mischievous, take risks, and go forward without much thought to what happened two minutes ago or whom they might have harmed. Guess who will be better prepared to perform well and stay in school, particularly when, as is often the case, you have a full-time job and have to attend university at night? Second is the question of family-controlled companies where men are the chosen successors. Third is the excuse that there are no women CEOs from which to choose board members—an obvious result of women having to deal with crooked ladders, putting their careers on the backburner, and the thick glass ceiling, among others. Fourth is the fear of change.
node.sections31: In Panama there is not enough public policy focused on the inclusion of women, though President Varela did make an important step in including women in his cabinet. For the first time ever, there is a female vice president. He has many female vice ministers and our ambassadors to France and Spain are women. In Meduca and in the Ministry of Economics and Finance, we have female vice ministers as well. There has been a visionary and concerted effort on the part of the president to include women in the government, especially the executive branch. Having said that, there is not a comprehensive public policy regarding the inclusion of women, nor are there any policies focused on children and young people. We also need to address violence against women because the rates are shocking. In order to curb this, we need to expedite punishment and ensure that offenders are not getting lenient treatment. The laws are there, but the law means nothing if it is not enforced. This a key issue in the country.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Healthcare Services
node.sections01: The GCC is globally competitive in three things: oil production, airlines, and obesity. What people do not understand is that when an individual is obese, they are extremely likely to get diabetes and subsequently are four times as likely to be hospitalized. The cost of treating diabetes can run up to USD1-2 million per patient a year. We train people about prevention through our platforms. Other than obesity and diabetes, which are closely related, the major challenge here in the healthcare system is that we do not really have a data-driven system; there is no single unified medical record today. This is something that we are working on together with the Ministry of Health. Eventually, we also hope to develop a unified payment system for the sector, whereby public and private healthcare providers can compete on quality and not access or price. The private sector remains an important stakeholder in the way healthcare is delivered, so it must be involved.
node.sections11: The idea for the Millennium Medical Project came from a desire to improve the standard of healthcare here and construct a comprehensive medical day surgery center that provides a fully integrated health service in the center of Kuwait. We will have the latest technology in the centers including a state-of-the-art rehabilitation center, physiotherapy, and all of the supporting units. We will also have bone marrow densities screening for osteoporosis, and screening imaging studies to detect instances of cancer early on. This will help to facilitate an early diagnosis of the medical problem and to treat it before it becomes a significant issue. We will have family doctors where patients first see general practitioners in order to be referred to a specialist. Having family doctors onboard to screen and refer patients to specialists helps to improve the outcome of the treatment. It will also reduce the waiting time to see a specialist and it will be a very competent referral. The complex will be a new center for excellence in Kuwait.
node.sections21: We are a healthcare benefits management company and manage the medical portfolios of a large number of insurance companies. In Kuwait, we have outstanding growth, more than what was projected in our business plan. This is because we have won the confidence of insurance companies so many insurance companies have moved to work with us from other TPAs. This has placed greater burden on us because we have to continue to provide outstanding services as well as enhance our technology. The same applies in the region, where we currently manage in excess of 3.5 million people. We are the leaders in terms of market share in most territories where we are present and have great growth rates everywhere. There is a need for our services to control costs due to inflation in the healthcare sector. There is also abuse from certain medical providers, so we need a strong robust system and a great deal of automation as well as a strong medical team to be able to achieve the necessary controls.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Telcoms firms have to contend with rapid advances in technology and ever-growing appetite for services.
node.title: Telecoms
node.sections01: The market is extremely saturated, and every telecommunications provider offers a similar range of services. However, we aim for innovative and customer-driven services, particularly in the cyber-security segment. We notably provide CCTV solutions and access-to-control security. We have diversified our income and try to think out of the box by selecting our projects in a unique way. In telecommunications, we have to differentiate in Kuwait. As a telecoms operator, our services and coverage can easily keep up with European or US standards. For fixed business, however, we relay our services based on the government's infrastructure; we cannot do our own. It is old and there is a rollout of fiber, which sees slow progress. This is what we are aiming for as Kuwait has been covered by fiber by only 12%. There is a great deal more to do to deliver the service in a better way. Technology-wise, we try hard to catch up. Companies and banks are now respecting and admitting this ascension and there is greater budget and spending. It will grow in the future and ICT infrastructure will play a big role in that process.
