Nigeria, being the biggest economy in Africa, is the preferred investment destination for everyone looking to maximize their return on investment.

Wale Tinubu We are an integrated energy company with investments across the entire energy value chain in downstream, midstream, and upstream operations. The ConocoPhillips transaction is one that sees Oando become the leading indigenous oil and gas producer in the country. It certainly puts us in the top 100 oil and gas companies globally in terms of reserves and production, and it is a transaction that makes us the first Nigerian company to become one of the partners in an onshore joint venture. We intend to do more transactions of this nature to expand our footprint within the sector.

Tony Elumelu From an economic perspective, I am very happy that the recent elections and transition in Nigeria were without incident. This is evidence of a growing political maturity. Business thrives in a secure and stable environment so peaceful elections and transitions are good for business. Governments and policy makers also need to focus more energy and attention on a consistent policy regime aimed at ensuring the right sort of incentives are created to make African economies more productive.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Healthcare providers are some of the most technologically advanced service providers in the country, and with lower operating costs, their international reputation is spreading.
node.subject: Medical Tourism
node.title: Where it Counts
node.sections01: Our Medical tourism team attend and participated in the World Wide Meeting of Medical Tourism in Washington DC last August and were part of the Colombian Health provider institutions supporting the ProExport Colombia organization that promotes the most important Clinics and hospitals from Colombia. We present our clinic by showcasing our specialist staff and diversity of programs addressing issues such as patient safety programs and protocols, and continuous improvement programs, as well as patient benefits and the outstanding comfort of our facilities, the congeniality of our personnel and the efficient operation in healthcare delivery and administrative processes. We also have a website featuring complete information for doctors, patients and family plus all information required by insurance companies. Motivated by certification from an international high quality healthcare delivery system enabling us to offer our services in the US and Europe we work determinedly to retain this status. We estimate having invested almost $68 million in our healthcare delivery complex, mostly in top of the range medical equipment for our operating suites, at the ICU, and in in communication technology facilitating academic exchange among doctors worldwide.
node.sections11: We are recognized as high definition dental surgeons for having the most talented professionals in all aspects of dentistry on our staff, and for the exacting standards of hygiene we insist on, and which today's patient expects. Our facilities feature computerized anesthesia, as well as CAT scan systems where digital prints are conveniently taken should a patient experience any symptom out of the ordinary. We are also currently working to receive additional accreditation, which is vital at the international patient level. We expect to have accreditation by the end of 2015, making us the first clinic such clinic in Colombia. We work with German multinational Sirona, whose annual technical updates on the latest equipment keep us in the loop. We also have a partnership with Bredent for implants, where we also receive any necessary training. We tend to offer more products and services from Germany than form any other part of the world. Equipment maintenance is done by a German technician, who works with is for three months, which is a true advantage for the clinic. Few other companies have access to such technology in Colombia. Our partnerships in the US are mainly for materials, such as aesthetic materials market leader Ultradent. Dentistry in Colombia is attracting considerable foreigner interest. First of all, documentation is swiftly available and insurance regulations are more convenient, whereby we are best placed to provide solutions to diverse problems.
node.sections21: Free healthcare zones bring a lot of benefits. Normally there is a 35% tax, and here it is only 15%. Duty-free healthcare zones provide stimulus for companies to grow and create more jobs. On the other hand it is challenging because there is currently a heavy bureaucratic culture characterized by meticulous formalities—we faced it while we were preparing our new building—and institutions do not have the freedom to make their own decisions, while the government is very slow at issuing authorizations. We faced many problems with this, as we had to stop the transfer to the new building until we got the permit. For the majority of specializations we have differentiated services. We have fostered a particular service culture, which we follow systematically. Our entire staff applies this culture to our services, the treatment of patients, and personal behavior. We have specialized groups in every area—in the treatment of spinal injuries, and orthopedics. We do not just offer general orthopedics, but differentiated groups with their own specialization: neurosurgery, cancer, cardiovascular surgery, pediatrics, and all specializations have their own program. Each institution does its best, and not merely in response to the presence of competing institutions.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: In Colombia, putting the right talent in the right position is what makes some companies work better than others, and competent management makes all the difference.
node.subject: Optimizing HE Resources
node.title: Sign Here
node.sections01: There are no specific sectors of higher demand—the Colombian economy grows steadily and in a comprehensive manner. However, there are certain companies that currently require more consultancy services, due to sudden or extensive growth. These companies mostly required advice on internal organization. This allows them to focus on their core business activities at critical junctures. We tell all our clients that Colombia will be the fastest growing economy in the region for the foreseeable future. The role of our company is to professionalize their internal processes, as well as develop solid strategies and increase competitiveness. Outsourcing will be a growing area of activity in the future. However, companies have to understand that they need qualified companies to outsource some of their operations; otherwise they run the risk of losing control of their business activities.
node.sections11: Five or six years ago international companies were coming to Colombia and undertaking everything themselves, by bringing in expatriates to run their operations. Yet over the past three or so years, it has become even more imperative for companies to optimize their resources, whereby outsourcing has become an ideal solution. They only have to send the people who are totally focused on the business. The back office support and everything else that they need is provided through outsourcing. And while this may not be a cheap undertaking, it expedites business processes. With a good outsourcing partner, an international company can start up operations in Colombia within a month, from setting up the company, to opening bank accounts, and be ready to invest within the same period of time.
node.sections21: In Colombia, the trends in human resources are focused on the welfare of employees, such as workers' compensation, personal development, development of competency-based skills, leadership and even happiness at work and emotional salary. In the technology arena, the trends include collaborative internal social networks and e-learning as a tool to disseminate knowledge. Outsourcing is viewed by our clients as an effective alternative to optimizing resources—i.e. saving time and money—while allowing them to focus on expansion and business growth. We began in the health sector and with SMEs, which tend to lack a proper HR department, thus motivating clients to outsource due to cost savings and headcount flexibility.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0name: Jaime Eduardo Bernal Villegas M.D. PhD
node.previewsummary: As research and education becomes a transnational endeavor, no school is an island, and Colombian schools are well on their way to establishing an international presence.
node.subject: Establishing Abroad
node.title: Alma Matters
node.sections01: We have worked with around 10 universities abroad, including the Tecnológico de Monterrey, El Politécnico de Turí­n in Italy, among others. We encourage our students to spend time abroad, which naturally is an expensive endeavor; we provide scholarships and loans wherever possible to enable this. Meanwhile, many students come from abroad to study here for a few months, especially from Mexico, Argentina, and the US. At this point we have 6,000 students altogether, and 1,000 of those are post-grads. We have one PhD program in engineering in association with the University of Cartagena. In the near future, we will also be setting up another PhD program with the University of Cartagena. We are setting up a program in naval architecture. Half of Colombia's territory is coastal. The country also boasts a richness of biological diversity that demands extraordinary solutions. I am working to train researchers to consider the sea in the context of naval architecture, technology, and offshore oil. Meanwhile, Cartagena is in need of well-trained medical doctors. Cartagena is becoming an address for medical tourism. Colombia has excellent doctors and also produces medicine, albeit not in Cartagena. Local medical facilities require overhauling, and encouragingly new and significant clinics are being opened locally.
node.sections11: At the graduate level, we have the Global MBA program, which is a program we run with Tulane University in New Orleans where we operate dual degree programs. They award a degree and we also award an MBA degree. Related students benefit from three international experiences. Some classes are taught by professors who are foreign nationals with international experience. At the end of the first year, the students go to New Orleans for two weeks and at the end of the second year they go to Paris for two weeks, and then Beijing for two weeks after that. We have another MBA, which is not global. Nonetheless, all the students on that program have international experience, too. This program is a shorter experience, and we have five or six opportunities for these students to study abroad, in the US, the Polití¨cnica in Valencia, Spain, the University of Chile, and in Peru. For undergraduates, we are members of the International Student Exchange Program, which allows our students to select from hundreds of destinations to visit. We also have additional agreements with schools in France, such as Sciences Po, Ecole Supérieure de Commerce, and Lyon. We have sent students to INAS for engineering training. I think France and Germany are the most important partners for exchange programs and we receive around 50 undergraduates a month from those two countries alone. Our university offers dual degrees with three schools in Europe, two in France and one in Spain. We also offer undergraduates international internships.
node.sections21: Our university has a strong partnership with France, as we have a large exchange program with French universities, including Sciences Po in Paris, in Bordeaux, and elsewhere. We have also been building relationships with institutions in the UK, such as University College, London, The University of Manchester, and Norwich University. We have seen a 30% rise in the number of postgraduate admissions. Moreover, our introduction of a number of new Master's programs has been highly successful, such as Development Management, in which students devise creative development projects for various regions of Colombia. We have also introduced Master's programs in Political Marketing and Political Communication; these garnered much attention with the presidential elections last year, and the local elections this year. We have been working on interdisciplinary models within the university, in conjunction with schools of Business Administration, Economics and Politics in order to combine our efforts and unite various disciplines. In terms of new faculty projects, we are focusing intensely on technology: how the University uses it and how students can professionally maximize its application. We are collaborating with other universities in Silicon Valley, the UK and France, and possibly India. We plan to begin offering graduate programs and executive seminars in this field, and eventually to introduce an undergraduate program.
node.sections31: Our university has a joint research project in social science, which is developed with professor Miguel Angel Campos at the Autonomous University of Mexico. In the area of health sciences a professor named Gladys Espinilla who undertook a sabbatical year at the University of Washington, is persuing specific practical issues related to genetics. Another research group, the Rema Group, participated in a call for Colciencias and just won a grant to develop a research project with them, financed and released in an international publication. We have a very good relationship with the scientist Manuel Delquin Patarrollo, who was a member of the university board of governors of the university for several years. He oversees an immunology center at the National University of Colombia. And we have a graduate of bacteriology and clinical laboratory at the National University of Colombia, who is currently a senior executive at Colciencias. Regardless of the budget of each of these research projects, they can take advantage of mobility, either nationally or internationally. We have conducted several shared projects in the US, Spain, Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, and Chile. And through these international conventions of mobility there has been a huge increase in movement of our students and professors to different countries. In 2011, 12 students were studying abroad, but by 2014, this number was up to 60.
node.sections41: We are mostly interested in developing the relationship between Colombia and Brazil. In addition to Brazil, we are also focused on developing agreements with universities in Argentina and Chile. We have close to 200 agreements worldwide—Australia, US, Europe, and so on. Such agreements afford the university worldwide relationships—different cultures, different education systems—facilitating the exchange of students, and the exploration of new alliances through research. For example, in our operations in Australia, we have the double degree with Queensland University and a second university. We also have degrees in universities in Switzerland in business administration and service or hospitality management. We are also focused on a school of psychology in Italy, which is a highly specific strategy. We have an international business office that is preparing to discover universities and countries we are interested in developing agreements with. We mainly promote the university through international meetings. We have workshops and we also encourage our professors to network when they are conducting their research internationally, working on theses, Ph.Ds., or Master's degrees. We put them in contact with these universities and develop their relationships. After that, we have the opportunity to explore the possibilities for exchange students or else joint research.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: Universidad de Antioquia — Faculty of Economic Sciences
node.previewsummary: Colombian universities are focusing on their research programs, with some contributing to business practices, while others pursue more esoteric ambitions.
node.subject: Research investments
node.title: In the Lab
node.sections01: Our research has supported some CRC decisions about contract, protocol disclosure and service complaints mechanisms to improve the defense of consumer rights within the communication services in Colombia. In addition, over the past seven years the research group in consumer psychology has developed a line of training for other regulatory Colombian agencies (such as SIC- Superintendence of Industry and Commerce) underlying marketing and advertising, unfair competition, protection, and consumer rights. We have been developing research in different fields related to our academic programs. Thus, in psychology, we are developing research projects in, for example, protocols for increasing verbal communication in children with autism; and in identifying the learning potential of highly gifted children that come from a low socio-economic background, as well as third generation therapies, (particularly the acceptance and commitment therapy) to treat emotional disorders. Research is carried out by doctors focused on these specific areas. In mathematics, we are working on a highly promising project involving the modeling and simulation of porous materials for industrial and biomedical sectors.
node.sections11: our flagship programs each have a research unit. For example, in Economics, we have a research unit for Macroeconomics, Microeconomics, Regional Economics, Health Economics and Applied Economics. In Management, we have research units specializing in business, such as the Organizational Management unit, the GIFI unit dealing with Finance, a Human Resources unit, and another promising unit in the field of Marketing. In the area of Accounting, we address several thematic areas in the GICCO group, a research unit for Accounting Studies. Each area has its own consolidated research units, which are also ranked. One of the strengths of the faculty is its rich history of research. In fact, economic research in Colombia saw early development at our university in the 1960's, and was instrumental in the planning of public policies in Colombia in the 1970s and 1980s. We also have an important presence at the regional level. For example, in Antioquia we are heading up key projects with the local government on projects of strategic importance for the Department. We are involved in a project for education indicators, one on regional GDP metrics, and another on the economic impact of prosperity.
node.sections21: Our university provides seed capital to some of the best business projects that our students develop. For example, we now provide financial and technical support to 60 student entrepreneurs. We tend to prioritize social sustainability projects in terms of fund allocation. In fact, socioeconomic and environmental sustainability is another of our values at EAN. We also promote innovation and intend for projects to be of maximum social application. In doing so, we leverage our links to national agencies that promote entrepreneurship nationwide; for example, we belong to the National Industrial Association and participate in all round tables and meetings in order to better capture the needs and trends of the sector and translate them into the classroom. We also have close ties with the public sector and other institutions and social agents in the country, as well as organizations that boost innovation nationwide. I could cite the Food and Agriculture Organization, for example, although we have signed partnerships with all of them at one time or another.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Changing regulations, market conditions, and an evolving economic climate are forcing Real Estate companies to change strategies on a yearly basis; especially since each of the country's cities have their own nuances.
node.subject: Real Estate
node.title: It’s in the Details
node.sections01: We continue to work for energy and oil entities, as well as consumer goods companies. In addition, our clients include advertising agencies and marketing services agencies, as well as pharmaceuticals companies. This diversity of clients represents a major transition from the past, and over the past year we have undertaken three large projects for state entities. As you may know, our government has been ready to channel more tax revenues—themselves on the rise in a more vibrant economy—to state investment. Most of our work remains in Bogota, catering to foreign investors requiring office space upon entry to the country. Meanwhile, local companies are expanding because business is brisk. These companies need either more space, or else to optimize existing space.
node.sections11: In Colombia, companies located within free zones take out insurance with European or American companies, which demand strict precautions against the risk of fire. Fire safety regulations did not always exist, and the requirements initially came from insurance companies, rather than through regulations. Then in 2010, with the NSR-10, the government required all installations and buildings in Colombia to have fire protection. Hydrocarbon services are our second biggest market. We have worked with main players in the Oil & Gas industry installing fire protection systems for crude oil storage facilities. We are now trying to expand our business in the free zones where we have a pronounced advantage as industrial users of such zones. This allows us to favorably import most of our items (fire pumps, accessories, pipes, and other items) from the US, Spain, or China.
node.sections21: The free trade zones have had an impact on the real estate market, especially with regard to warehouses. Flex warehouses, which can be used as an office and a warehouse have become popular. In 2013, three or four office buildings became LEED-certified. Now we have many buildings that hold this certification. This makes Colombia more competitive within the wider Latin American region. The resources being used in those buildings make them more efficient. They do not use that much energy, and we obviously do not use heating, just air conditioning. Now we have less space so rents are rising again. We have so many offices that I thought rents would be stabilizing, but this is not the case. We are looking at office spaces that are $32 to $48/sqm a month. In terms of retail properties, we have numerous shopping malls where rents can be around $100 to $300/sqm each month.
node.sections31: The world and the global economy have changed significantly, and you have to swiftly adapt to things. Our success is going to lie in adapting to changes in the global economy, adapting to the world buyer, and staying ahead of the curve. The most obvious investors would be from the US and Spain, solely due to their knowledge of the Colombian market. Currently, we are working with American investors and for subsequent phases we will be looking towards Europe as well. Colombia is enjoying greater international prominence because of its openness to investment. Tourism is the most rapidly growing industry in Colombia, with new hotels having opened in Cartagena such as the Four Seasons or the Marriott. Investors are ever seeking fresh opportunities and markets, and especially when considering Cartagena's proximity to the US it becomes an obvious choice as an investment address.
node.sections41: Pension funds are a source of equity, which we use to buy long-term land, which we develop for them. I believe we are the only fund in Colombia buying land with pension fund capital, and we have done well thus far. Other funds in Colombia mostly operate with foreign or private equity. This has been a complicated process, but we are happy with the outcome, and are launching another fund this year. We have already invested the $25 million generated from the first fund, and want to increase the volume of the new one. In Barranquilla and Cartagena, we are currently in the planning stages for four projects. We anticipate these areas accounting for a significant proportion of our business within five years. New land will be bought with the fund, which allows us to co-invest. Our company equity goes into funding the land, and we leverage the fund for the actual purchase.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Demand in the national real estate market is growing increasingly sophisticated, and Colombian firms are responding with targeted projects and investments.
node.subject: Property Investment
node.title: Full Spectrum
node.sections01: Aslew of large infrastructure projects in the region are attracting foreign investors to Colombia. Five years ago, 80% of the attendees at local construction and infrastructure conventions were from Colombia. In stark contrast, these days, around 60% are from abroad. This reflects a surge in interest from foreign investors, be they contractors or builders, seeking opportunities in Colombia. The Caribbean region in general is growing. For example, net sales of new properties last year in Barranquilla grew by about 25% over the previous year. The influx of internal investment started with infrastructure, but lately investors have been moving into real estate as well. There has been a change in their risk perception. Initially, they had been looking for constructed buildings already generating rental income. But now, we have seen that these investors are approaching companies such as ours looking for off-plan projects, where the selling process has not even begun. They are beginning to see the risk as worthwhile, which is logical because with higher risk comes higher return.
node.sections11: We have properties in Bogotá, Barranquilla, Cartagena, Cali, and Medelln, those are the main cities in Colombia. And as you would expect, the challenges are different for each city and for each segment. Office space in Bogotá is set to see a large supply come through. Part of that supply has been created by the changes of the zoning code, which prompted landowners to license and build in order to secure their existing building rights. In the hotel space, we had an income tax exemption for projects that would be up and running by 2017, so everyone is trying to get into that window. It is set to create additional supply ahead of demand, but I foresee that being a temporary scenario. It will take two or three years to readjust, but once that exemption expires in 2017, I forecast a long period of silence and very few developments being realized. In that respect, yes, we are going to experience somewhat of a crunch over the next two or three years, but conditions will ultimately improve and become notably more robust than what we are seeing today.
node.sections21: Most investors are still national; there isn't significant foreign investment, although it has slightly increased. We are seeing around 10-15% of foreign investment. We have fiduciary rights in smaller projects, around 30-40 thousand billion pesos each. So these investments are more appealing to individuals than big funds. In the future, we will be looking to creating cities within a city, meaning that housing projects will have integral utilities provision. To elaborate, these are projects of a certain magnitude, that would include housing, but also commercial establishments, supermarkets, schools, transportation, and so on. In summary, they would be a kind of city where people enjoy a full spectrum of services. This is what we are planning for the future. In fact we are starting a sizeable micro-city project in Cajica, which will include a mall and over 1,000 housing properties in one project, which allows this micro-city model. This is the largest project OIKOS is set to develop in its history on an investment of over 1.4 billion pesos.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Senior Vice-President & Regional Manager Latin America
node.previewsummary: Large infrastrure projects and a national effort to upgrade Colombia's energy capacity are translating into ambitous projects for both local and international contruction companies.
node.subject: Construction Companies
node.title: Going All The Way
node.sections01: Local companies are capable up to a certain point, but the real question is whether Colombia is ready to leap forward in terms of infrastructure development. At present, there is not really the capacity in terms of scale, since this is a highly ambitous program. The adequacy of the scale and the scope of the contracts will be the final test in upcoming financial closings. The government has to make a choice on whether to introduce 4G over longer periods, or whether it intends to concentrate its investment efforts on individual areas. It is clear that there is insufficient local capacity, and the idea of foreign companies is not to cannibalize local markets, but to develop them. The government wants foreign banks to invest $400 million here, and they will demand a premium price. Traditionally the success of alliances between local and foreign companies has been much higher in Colombian sectors such as energy and O&G, rather than in the transport sector.
node.sections11: Our main investments are in the plant itself. However, we consider all projects and try to sell a diverse range. We could undertake this across Colombia, although all facilities are established here. We have been trying to bring our production systems in line with other developed countries. Free zones such as Zonas Francas can be regarded as either a threat or an opportunity. From one perspective they can threaten as companies from other countries are able to compete through satellite bases. Sometimes the conditions are even better for them than for us. It also means that there is a lot of construction required and this it is an opportunity. In our case we have the capacity and are closer to customers and sites. So while free zones can be seen in both ways, we see it as an opportunity. Beyond that, we know from past experiences that we will be competitive in these cases. We have already completed a number of projects in these areas. And while we do not have permanent strategies to do business in other countries, we have ventured abroad.
node.sections21: Many Western companies, from US or Europe, have not seen Latin America as a real opportunity in our sector. It is seen as having only tier 2 or tier 3 markets. Yet it is surprising how Mexico, being the largest trading country with the US, receives relatively little attention from US firms compared to the Middle East, Asia, or Europe. We entered Latin America to try to understand what was being done and to do something different by holding the decision-making process here. Still today, our decisions are 99% focused on the region. In terms of these multi-billon dollar investments in Mexico or the US, you would be amazed by the percentage of projects that deviate over 10% to 15%. If this is multiplied by $5 billion, there is significant revenue at stake. We started working on a large infrastructure project on the west coast of Colombia, in Buenaventura. José Amarante has been present in the country ever since we started talks with the national infrastructure agency and local agencies such as the IDU for the metro rail.
node.sections31: Renewables will increase the country's total energy production and allow the country to sell any excess. At the local level, small energy producers that benefit from renewables can sell their excess to the national network. On a larger scale, it will increase Colombia's revenues from sales of energy to countries such as Venezuela, Peru, and even the US. In terms of installed power, Colombia has the potential to generate a surplus within the next five years, as supply is so much greater than existing demand. Recently Panama and Colombia have had problems with the agreement to the electrical interconnection between the countries, but the connection will be up and running by the close of 2018 at the latest, which will allow us to sell our energy surplus to Central America. When it comes to the stability of the system, for low and medium power connections, such as houses and small businesses, the grid is not expanding at a fast enough pace to catch up with future demand.
node.sections41: The Mulaló-Loboguerrero Project has a high strategic value as it places our company in the current outlook of the Colombian infrastructures. This project means becoming part of the limited group of companies that are developing designs for so-called 4G highways, the country's new central routes, which are under PPPs. Besides, this project is a big technical challenge because of its structural difficulty since it involves building nine tunnels. Ayesa boasts the best expert collaboration in this area. All this, along with the experience and references related to similar previous work, is essential to properly carrying out such projects in Colombia. Therefore, the knowledge we have acquired in this field and our financial strength enable us to manage important projects such as this one. We are currently developing two geographic information systems; one for the National Agency for Environmental Licenses and another for the Bicentennial Pipeline. In the latter project, we also perform integrations with the SAP system.
node.intervieweelist4name: Luis Marí­a Ruiz del Portal Lázaro

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: For outsourcing companies, success is contingent upon their ability to leverage Colombia's unique economic conditions and human capital to provide better cheaper services for multinationals.
node.subject: Outsourcing
node.title: Relative Advantage
node.sections01: We work with multinationals such as Citibank, which was a client back when the company started, but which unfortunately decided to withdraw its account after my father died. After 14 years it placed a call for collection agencies and we received the highest rank according to several internal indicators provided by Citibank, receiving the account. One of the factors that gave us an advantage was that the bank highly regarded robust cyber-security. As we perform a specialized service, our strategy to acquire new customers is to invest in targeted scenarios such as events by the National Collection Association. The collection sector has evolved in the past few years, and clients are now looking for agencies that have a strong client base, robust technologic support and highly qualified human labor.
node.sections11: We see BPO services as the main tool to building bridges with the US. For example, Everis' largest BPO center in the world is located in Colombia. We expect that the merge with NTT DATA will give us even more opportunities to build those bridges. On top of that, the human resources in this country are above average. Costs are also competitive. This means that Colombia is ready to provide services to European countries and the US, for example. Meanwhile, India is falling behind in BPO services and Colombia is taking over, benefiting, too, from the virtually non-existing time difference from the US. Additionally, the government is focused on boosting BPO services and activities.
node.sections21: We began providing services to the Spanish companies that moved to Colombia. These were high potential Contact Centers that believed in offshoring as a means for growth. We assisted them with technology but also with the human support they needed, high-qualified local people with local knowledge. In the second phase, the strategy was to grow with new clients from different industries like collections, finance or education. Presence has specific solutions for different industries and that helped us reach new clients. Now we are addressing corporate clients, helping them in their quality improvement strategies and making human resources profitable. We also have a social initiative for blind people in Contact Centers in which the Colombian government supports us, motivated by our social integration programs.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: As Colombian companies automate more of their operations, the demand for these services is being met with an array of offerings and an uptick in investment.
node.subject: WIRING
node.title: Wired for Success
node.sections01: We had been present in Brazil for 40 years—our second largest investment on the continent was a large fiber optic in Argentina. In terms of market and size, our third most important market, in close competition with Argentina, is the Colombia. Economic growth prospects, combined with legal stability for investors were both key factors. Our timeline for investment of $5 million was 2013-2016, and our investment plan includes equipment, capital, and premises. Many multinationals spend more money on land and location, but we opted to lease the best available technology and equipment for our operations. Our next investment began in January 2015, when we developed our connectivity factory, to facilitate the connection of our cables, and is effectively a separate plant and investment.
node.sections11: While Anixter's core business has always been cabling, we have evolved into data center experts. We entered the security business because it was highly complimentary to our core activity, in that installing cameras requires cabling. Moreover, today security is gaining significance in light of new products such as Smart CDs or Safe CDs, and we are playing a central role in the segment. Security in broad terms is seeing notable annual growth of around 20-25%, which is in turn driving growth. Cabling solutions are also growing, albeit modestly in recent years, as today communication is driving growth. In Colombia, at 50 million, we have more mobile phones than people. The government's aggressive approach to providing internet combined with the arrival of global companies is obliging local companies to compete with inferior technology. If we compare the volume of local companies' investment in ICT today to 10, or even a few years ago, the difference is vast.
node.sections21: Initially, the banks and financial systems were the more demanding industries requiring data centers, and traditionally had their own IT department and data centers. Then the authorities noted that it was not secure to have computers and storage systems in one location, and the telecom industry saw the opportunity to offer an alternative. This expanded beyond the banks to all types of business. Today each ministry has its own data center and there is a shift toward centralized information areas. This has created an important need for data centers, and third parties or call centers are supplying many solutions that used to be done in-house by the companies themselves 10 to 15 years ago. Now they have greater opportunities to provide better services to customers if they work with a PPO (preferred provider organization) that can provide an online website for their customers, although again, this needs infrastructure to ensure it remains online.
node.sections31: Traditionally, our activity has been in the residential and commercial construction segment. However, through a series of products, such as power transformers and MV switchboards, we are making an incursion into new sectors. In recent years we have been the first to introduce a new concept in the residential segment of the Colombian market, which has already been present in other countries with more mature economies, like the US and Europe. We can say that the automation sector is well developed in the residential sector of Colombia. In many of the new sectors we are covering, screenings of the specific necessities of the sector are not our only objective, but rather, proposing innovative solutions to the market. This is the kind of process we are investing in, whether at a local or wider level.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Colombian producers of handicrafts and garments export freely thanks to trade agreements with many markets, and their reputation for quality is becoming known worldwide.
node.subject: Made in Colombia
node.title: Sew the Way
node.sections01: We stage Expoartesaní­as, which is the largest fair in Latin America lasting two weeks and attended by more than 1,000 artisans. We attract international buyers and the international press, and it is also an attractive fair for the tourism sector which is why we work with travel agencies. Over 20 countries participate in the fair, and we see over 100,000 visitors annually. In terms of intellectual property, we first ensure that the communities or the techniques being considered for this status comply with traditional methods of production. We are determined to protect our handicrafts, as in recent times we have experienced certain problems with European designers working with Colombian handicrafts but not crediting the producers or the country. Colombia is a major textiles producer, and we are expanding, and not in terms of technology alone, but with added value products, which is what attracts our buyers. We try to maintain this handmade quality, while increasing manufacturing efficiency. Around one million people work in Colombia's handicraft sector, and many have products that could be commercialized at various retail outlets, which we are keen to facilitate.
node.sections11: We have become the most important shoe company in the country in the medium-high and high segments. Today, with 140 stores, we reach the adult market with the BOSI brand, the youth segment with ADDICT by BOSI, and the Bambino brand, which is geared toward juniors. Our entire product range is made of leather. We are anticipating challenges in 2015 because of the increased price of raw materials and imported leather. However, over the next two years I anticipate growth of between 15% and 20%, as we will have a larger store network. Here inventory turnover is excellent, and few products become obsolete. We are highly skilled in terms of inventory management, which renders the whole commercial dimension of business more efficient. We run a traditional promotional campaign to tie in with our anniversary, between March and April, and also have minor promotions in late December. That being said, motivating our customers is the priority rather than exhausting the inventory. Last year we also launched a range of accessories, which has received a spectacular reaction.
node.sections21: The company was created in 1993, and at that time was completely different to the company in 2015. When we began, the market was highly competitive in terms of labor costs and the exchange rate. There was not the same level of innovation, flexibility, and sustainability. Once we moved to Medellí­n, we changed the way we thought and the way we produced. We used to make only basic products, what we call commodities in this industry, but we then expanded our portfolio. We were originally a three-product company, but made the decision to start producing up to 12 different products, and began to utilize innovation as part of this expansionary process. Our main business is the export business. We export 92% of our output, and of that, 90% is exported to the US. Our main customers in that market are Levis, Polo, Ralph Lauren, and we are working with Michael Kors and Adam Levine for Kmart, and during the past 25 years we have produced for a number of name customers including GAP and Tommy Hilfiger.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Construction firms and their suppliers are looking to an increasingly diverse range of projects as the market matures.
node.subject: Diversifying Construction
node.title: Follow the Lead
node.sections01: We won a number of public contracts, which often had non-conventional architecture, and required a wider range of machinery and equipment. This included high-rise buildings, where our original equipment was no longer useful, and we had to expand our portfolio and capital according to the growth and demands of the construction sector in Barranquilla. We have completed a considerable body of work in Barranquilla and the region in institutional construction projects, universities, and have worked comprehensively with the public health and EPS institutions. At that stage, private construction was rather inactive, and had we been entirely dependent on residential construction we would have faced bankruptcy. Today our ratio is divided approximately 50-50% between public and private contracts.
node.sections11: Our headquarters is in Barranquilla, and handles all imports, external commerce, and relations with our providers. About 95% of our products are imported, and 90% of that comes through Barranquilla, and 10% through Cartagena. When we began to grow we expanded into Bogotá, Medellí­n, Calí­, Bucaramanga, Periera, Manizales, Santa Marta, and most recently Barrancabermeja, the epicentre of the petroleum industry in Colombia. Today petrol, gas, and mining represent the bulk of our trade. The other industries we cover include paper, alimentation, and sugar cane. For the petrol industry, we have specialised parts, tubes and valves for replacement when industries require them, which can be at very short notice. We are all also in the business of maintaining products for these industries in compliance with all international norms. And with regards to the construction industry, clients request that all buildings and structures have fireproof tubes and valve networks, which today is obligatory.
node.sections21: We have undertaken the wiring and electrical engineering for several huge projects including the Unidad de Planeación Minero Energética (UPME). There, we undertook power system studies for the interconnection between mining and energy projects in Central and South American Countries. We also undertook an analysis of the FACTS implementation to link Central and South American countries via a DC link between Panama and Colombia. We have also done jobs as far away as Iraq, at the Doura Thermal Plant, where we installed a start-up electrical protection system. We also undertook a project at the Minera Escondida in Chile were we were engaged in the testing of equipment, associated protection and control devices.
node.sections31: Our main expectations in the region are the oil pipeline to the Pacific, which is under study. This pipeline will transport oil from Llanos Orientales to the Pacific shore and a gas pipeline will transport from Camisea to the South in Peru, which is probably the most important project to be built in the near future in South America. It is a gas pipeline of more than 1,000km in length, together with a shorter condensate line. That is worth around $4 billion. The Bicentenario Oil Pipeline is still the largest project that has been carried out by SICIM. In Mexico, our first project was the Manzanillo-Guadalajara gas pipeline, and followed by: the Chihuahua Natural Gas Transmission Pipeline; the TAMAZUNCHALE Gas Pipeline phase 2; the Sonora Pipeline Corridor; and the Los Ramones Phase II South - Sections I and II. We are also promoting business in Bolivia and Chile.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0position: MSSI Vice President & Territory Director North of Latin America
node.previewsummary: Telecommunications companies in Colombia are making the most of a large domestic market to roll out new technologies and expand penetration and coverage.
node.subject: Telecoms
node.title: It’s Your Call
node.sections01: After developing a portfolio with a wide range of solutions, including mobile devices, wireless broadband, connected-home solutions, and mobile solutions for government and enterprise customers, Motorola Solutions separated from Motorola Mobility in 2011 and underwent a transformation process and is now totally focused on mission-critical solutions for governments and commercial markets. Our focus has been the public safety market, because of the unique situation that exists in Colombia. The police, the army, and the navy required specialized telecommunications solutions and they informed us of their requirements. All our efforts have gone into this. However, we have also had some resources allocated to oil and gas and utilities companies. Due to the fact that the situation is changing and that we are close to signing a peace deal, we have been creating market solutions based on demand. We now have people focused on public safety, oil and gas, carriers, and utilities. We have been trying to allocate people to the various vertical markets present in the country. We continue to provide tailor-made solutions for the educational sector, with a strong emphasis on addressing underlying security needs.
node.sections11: The main challenge in our market is the major players, but the good thing is that there are numerous operators. There are at least six to seven operators taking into account Virgin and other companies. Having numerous options is conducive to innovation, but with the major operator, it is a challenge for the regulator to ensure market fairness. Right now we have a less dominated field, and our interest lies in data services concentration because it is to close to voice concentration. If there is only one device for voice and data, it is likely that customers will have the same operator for both. The concentration in voice is evolving quickly towards data, which is a major concern for the market, and the regulators. Perhaps three years ago, we started to invest in security on all levels, from connectivity to hacking. In any telecommunications company, you have the traditional services, which are 60-70% of the current revenue. But for us, around 30% of revenues are coming from the digital services like security, health and insurance, and other such areas.
node.sections21: Building the right cultural approach is a key consideration for us, because UNE is a state entity, and Tigo, on the other hand, is a rapidly moving, multinational telecommunications company. We have been supplying the government successfully, especially in the spheres of education and health. A key responsibility of ours is bringing services to people who cannot otherwise access them, which amounts to the democratization of telecommunications. I think that in terms of apps, and of entire digital world, once you understand what people want it becomes easier to deliver it to them. When you look at the company profile, especially Tigo, 65% of our customers are less than 30 years old. The data business is growing by 30% in the post pay segment here in Colombia on the mobile side. The prepaid data business mobile segment is growing by 40%. People may state that in Colombia mobile penetration is at 100%, but in fact what happens is that people have two handsets. Hence, there is an excellent opportunity to keep selling phones and connecting people.
node.sections31: From the start of our operations here we found interesting opportunities; there are many Colombians living abroad and communication between those people and their relatives back home was not fully exploited on the mobile network. Calls in this segment were being made through the fixed mobile network. We brought the best rates for international calls in mobile telephony and saw rapid growth in this segment. This led to new opportunities, too, as foreigners coming to Colombia also saw us as the network to reach. All in all, we are a Colombian company and want to contribute to national development. We have been growing swiftly in Colombia as an MVNO company and this has represented continuity to the global company's development; we have been the fastest growing MVNO since 1999. Moreover, we continually explore fresh possibilities for business activity. Some two years ago, we looked into developing closer relations with a strong partner and approach Bancolombia, the largest player in the local banking sector, and an institution keen to engage with people-friendly systems and technology.
node.sections41: This is a crucial period for ETB, a year after formation, a year when we celebrate 130 years of operations, and a year in which we launched a fiber optic service into homes, our own IPTV service, and our own mobile service, ETB Mobile. We started deploying fiber less than a year ago, and at this point we have more than 600,000 home passes and about 10,000 connections. We expected to close 2014 with about 800,000 home passes and about 20 to 25,000 home connections, which is a successful deployment for the first year of fiber. If you compare us to Telefónica in Brazil and Spain and several parts of Europe, and Verizon in the US, none of these companies reached 10,000 connections in their first year, and we will probably have doubled that number by the end of 2014. The idea is to end next year with about 80% of homes in Bogotá passed with fiber optics and to create our rate of connections significantly in 2015, and we hope to reach 130,000-140,000 connections, which is a major jump from the 20,000 we expected to close 2014 with.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Low mineral prices globally are affecting the bottom lines of many companies as they look to new ways to add value to their products, while awaiting recovery.
node.subject: Chemical Companies
node.title: A Chain Reaction
node.sections01: We do not expect a full recovery, but ultimately the mineral business is cyclical. Experts agree that recovery in prices will begin after 2017, but not before. On the other side, global coal demand is expected to grow by an average of 2.1% from the actual figures until 2019, from 5,690 Mtpa to 6,462 Mtpa. In such a situation, you can try to take advantage of the lull, as a new entrant to the business, to make your name known and provide alternative services to customers, as well as develop capabilities and infrastructure in readiness for a busier future. Meanwhile, we have acquired an important network of coal laboratories in South Africa and Western Europe in anticipation of future improvement. It is difficult to define a timeframe.
node.sections11: Sustainability is indeed a key issue for CHT in Germany, and thus, for all CHT companies and branches worldwide, with Colombia no exception to the rule. We have to meet various targets in terms of sustainability and environmental issues. For our local production and the goods we import from Germany, we exclusively utilize water-based, rather than solvent-based products. We also place emphasis on creating new employment, and using domestic products whenever possible. Ultimately, by making more efficient our use of water and energy, we will increase our domestic revenues and capabilities. CHT Colombiana has incorporated certain special new products and ideas in the construction sector, while in textiles having begun to implement water and energy conservation systems.
node.sections21: One of our key segments is oil and gas, wherein much has occurred in the intervening period. The other sectors where we are thriving are industrial sectors for packaging, food, construction, painting, and coatings. Colombia remains an attractive market for companies keen to establish a local presence. That being said, the market is quite fragmented, which does not help. And yet the main sector to have suffered is oil and gas. We are compensating for the heat on our upstream business, given that companies are not drilling extensively this year, and are focused on chemicals for production. We plan to remain an important player in the oil and gas business.
node.sections31: We decided to exclusively sell products manufactured in Colombia; today these products account for 65% of our sales—a notable ratio. The rest we import from Europe, Asia, or the US. We have continuously sold only Colombian products for around 20 years. We then started working to develop more specialist products, and formed a partnership with BASF to do so. In line with the growth in agriculture and industry, we began adding related products. Today, we are involved in many industries—the chemical industry, plastics, rubber, and metals, among others. We have around 47 chemical engineers working with us. We also have a vertical integration system, and our own transportation for efficient delivery to clients. Our objective is 24 hour delivery; yet in many cases the product can be delivered to the client within 12 hours.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: The car market in Colombian is performing relatively well; however, the need to assemble more cars locally is a pressing if the country is to remain competitive amid rising foreign imports.
node.subject: Car Importers
node.title: Driving Force
node.sections01: We still see a long way to go in the Colombian market to reach our long-term targets. Our success was mainly possible due to several factors, the first being numerous product launches. Secondly, the depreciation of the Japanese yen meant that products could be priced more competitively; and thirdly, we have maintained our dealer network, and in 2014 made the decision to expand it. Most of our dealers are owned by Motorysa; however, we also have a number of external dealers in small- to medium-sized cities, whereby we cover about 95% of the Colombian market. Motorysa concentrates on developing vehicle distributions in the automotive industry. Currently, we are focused on Mitsubishi, but we are also developing several Daimler dealerships that will start early in 2015. There are other brands we will shortly develop as distributors. The automotive market is growing by around 8% per annum, and our sales are doubling. We ended 2014 on growth of 80%, and in 2015 we expect to grow by a further 50%. Our strategy for this is well grounded; however, we will need to observe developments in the general market. We expect to achieve our target as long as the market grows by 5% in 2015, which however, is uncertain due to the direction of oil prices and depreciation of the peso.
node.sections11: Daimler has gained a leadership role in different sectors of the market. This includes premium vehicles, the luxury segment, and in a historic first, we became the leaders of the bus segment. We were also leaders in the larger vans segment and dramatically increased our market share in the truck business. Last year was successful in terms of market share and volume. However, our operations were impeded by a 2013 law that amended the process of licensing new trucks. As of April 2013, you could only register a new truck once you had scrapped an old one. This made it difficult to sell the volume of vehicles we had. The truck market in 2013 fell by more than 60%. Even though market shares were good, certain areas of business were difficult. We had a pipeline of orders and sales plans, but when the game changes, the factories still deliver placed orders. We ended up with an oversupply that we had not planned for. With surplus stocks, dealers must sell off vehicles at large discounts, and we assumed the costs. At the same time, in 2014, we saw a fantastic performance from passenger cars and luxury vehicles. The vehicle market in Colombia has recovered, and is growing at around 5% per annum. The premium/luxury segment, however, is growing above that rate at around 20% and we are growing by around 40%.
node.sections21: The more protectionism you afford to the local industry, the more you are telling member companies that they are uncompetitive. In the future, Colombia could become highly competitive. We have two options: if we build an assembly plant in the Pacific or Caribbean it could provide an export solution, although it requires deep-rooted government understanding. The industry estimates that by 2020 the automotive sector will be less than 10% local assembly based. Moreover, with the free trade agreements (FTAs) that we signed with the US and Europe have been gradually reducing import tax such that by 2020 all cars arriving from Europe will have zero import tax. In order to draw wider attention to the importance of the sector for the government, the first automotive sector study to be conducted in Colombia was undertaken. The findings are set for imminent public release, and tell quite an interesting story about how much the automotive market contributes to GDP. Over 76,000 people work in the sector, and we argue that it is time the government propelled it to international standards. Taxes in Colombia are ridiculous. Here, for example, a Q7, the Audi SUV, costs around $100,000; you can almost buy an R8 in US for $110,000. Even the low-entry models are expensive. The cheapest assembly car here in Colombia costs around $12,000. Colombia has expensive cars, low fuel quality, and traffic jams because of the quality of the road network. This is the result of the government not taking our importance into account.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Domestic Expansion
node.title: Home Improvement
node.sections01: We develop the business by listening so that we can fully meet client needs, at which point the product essentially sells itself. Despite the usual YoY shift between brokers common among clients, those who work with us tend to stay for the long-term. Our efficient service ensures a minimal rate of rotation, enabling us to maintain a close relationship. Our client base expands through word of mouth. Today, boat insurance services have a very low market presence in Cartagena. We are one of the leaders in nautical insurance, but the cost is high as few people are currently insured. On the other hand, the cost of the insurance is low in comparison to the value of the property. The Ministry of the Environment has declared that all boat owners require insurance of COP2 million against damage or contamination. No one has liability insurance for their boats because people consider it prohibitively expensive. We have targeted our marketing operations at yacht clubs to get members to insure their vessels, but with limited success thus far. It would be logical for everyone in the club to be insured against an accident, such as a fire that could spread. We have many expensive boats here in Cartagena, but people remain reluctant to insure them. Overall, however, the country is doing well from my perspective. Other areas of the economy may be fluctuating, but the insurance sector is actually experiencing growth.
node.sections11: The restructuring resulted from an alignment with QBE's worldwide risk appetite. We had a Group CEO that was in office until mid-2012, and he opted for inorganic growth by acquisition. That led to over 130 acquisitions in a 30-year period, which is why we have the global footprint that we do. Given our change of strategy and the need to integrate the acquisitions that were made over the past 30 years, some were not compatible with our current risk appetite or the classes of business that we were working on. From an IT and even a cultural standpoint, some of them were so different that they simply clashed with our structure. Since 2012 we have sought a new integration that aligns our strategy implementation. We are moving away from our concentration in mandatory third party liability vehicle insurance (SOAT), which has been our flagship line of business for the past few years, and is responsible for at least 60% of our business. In a ten-year period, we went from newcomers to the driving force and the number one company in SOAT in 2010, with a 35% market share at the time.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2company: Business Development, Integral de Servicios Técnicos
node.previewsummary: Downstream energy companies are showing that a soft energy market is not an impediment to growth and diversification.
node.subject: Downstream Companies
node.title: End Results
node.sections01: The company had two lines of business, the first of which was the construction of gas plants and the second the operation of oil facilities and well testing. The business of the construction of gas plants was what triggered crisis at the company, whereby it discontinued that line of business and is dedicated exclusively to oil facility operations and well testing. Unless we make a strategic alliance with a major company, we are not interested in resuming that activity. We have clients like GeoPark, Pacific Rubiales, Parex Resources, Perenco, and Mansarovar today. These clients are only focused on well-testing activities given the problems we faced between September and November 2012. Right now the oil sector is not growing as it should be, due to several government policies that are not being enforced properly, such as environmental licenses, which currently take too much time. If they do not have environmental licensing, then companies cannot drill.
node.sections11: The energy sector will be highly important for us next year with the tanks and oil fields projects we have planned. Furthermore, the sector will have some circumstances that aren't good such as the low price per barrel, the changes to the tax environment, the reduction of the investment plan of Ecopetrol, the higher cost of production and transportation, among others, but we have a strategic plan where all these situations will be overcome the best we can and also with partners and highly qualified employees. For Equipem Atlas Oil this will be a period of important growth. With automated mechanics it is about selling the whole package. At the moment, project management is our focus. We also have a company in Venezuela called Petrosema and our aim is to continue bringing new services into the oil sector. You cannot stay still and continue to sell the same products that every other company is offering; we have to evolve.
node.sections21: We were focused on drilling services, including the acquisition of new technologies and tools to maximize efficiency and security. We also included high capacity lifting equipment in our inventory. Our company was successful in winning a major oil transportation contract with Ecopetrol with a bid of $40 million to transport their entire production throughout the country. We have an 85-truck fleet transporting oil throughout the country, and are entering a venture with Transporte Sánchez Polo, a major company located in Barranquilla. Ecopetrol awarded 30 contracts to 75 companies, and we will be combining our fleet with its own one to provide more than 100 trucks in total. We are also entering a venture to move coal to the ports in the north of the country from the north of Santander.
node.sections31: We have not been affected by the falling price of oil, as we are in an industry that is able to directly pass increased cost on to our clients, whereby they who have felt the knock-on effect. Today, due to limitation of exports for groups such as EcoPetrol, there is a great effort to assist those industries that work with hydrocarbon derivatives to ensure that their products are competitive in the international market. Paints, adhesives, household products and agrochemicals are the segments that we supply the most. They have been impacted by inflation in the price of hydrocarbon derivatives, but the industry as a whole, following the crises of 1999, and again in 2008, became structurally prepared to deal with shocks such as the fall in the price of petrol. We are used to the international market having more experience, but we have improved substantially in terms of quality, and in some products are highly competitive today.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Under current market conditions, upstream energy firms in Colombia walk a fine line between cost cutting and investing in future projects and exploration.
node.subject: Upstream Sector
node.title: Times Like These
node.sections01: In Colombia, oil production is mostly generated by the government, and in such a scenario it is important to have industrial agreements that reflect those industries' interests and not only those of the government. Oil is a global business, and we are oil producers, but we are not an oil country. Today, the oil countries are the US, Canada, Mexico, Venezuela and so on, we produce and export oil, which is an important commodity, basic and important to our national economy in fact, and contributing 29% of overall tax revenues. Last year, we exported more than the 50% of the nation's total.
node.sections11: Stratigraphic oil wells are special test wells where the ANH uncovers options in new areas, or limited areas, which are areas where the industry does not have enough information about the geology, the formations, and so when oil companies try to obtain blocks to drill, they need specific information, because without that information their risk in the investment is increased. The sooner they have more information, it is easier to make the decision to invest, and in these areas, the information available in Colombia is close to zero. The role of the ANH is to discover geological or total geological information to guide companies, to enable speculative drilling for hydrocarbons. The ANH has five projects, in Tolima, Cauca, Buenaventura, Antioquia, and Magdalena.
node.sections21: We are in a moment of uncertainty due to certain trends in the oil industry across the globe. However, I see that the sector is set to reorganize strategies and priorities. We have left the panic behind of the early days when de oil price dropped. We are looking ahead to develop new drilling activities. Colombia has numerous social particularities as a country, including the peace process, and the oil industry overlaps many of those scenarios. Therefore, we must be careful and responsible at all time. In other words, being Colombian in this industry with the nation's current level of openness and the number of foreign companies is a major plus as we are deeply familiar our country. Also, we have proved that we are here to serve the country for mutual development.
node.sections31: We have reduced our drilling activity over the last few months, as we believe we need to be more conservative regarding investments, especially in a context in which sales volumes have dropped from year to year. We wait for service companies to adapt their needs and strategy to the current situation, and I have to say that we have already seen a change in this area—we have better offers than those we had by the end of 2014. This encourages us to already rethink certain drilling projects we had postponed (CPO-4, Llanos 32, Llanos 34, etc.). We anticipate ending 2015 with 10 million barrels, and so far are fully on track to achieve this.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Investment Banks
node.title: Money Talks
node.sections01: We have become the advisor for the government on numerous infrastructure projects, having decided to play this role in every PPP program undertaken. We have undertaken particularly interesting projects such as the only urban concession project in Colombia for entry to the port in Barranquilla. It featured a toll road, the only one built within a city leading to the port. Bonus took on all the projects of Autopistas para la prosperidad. These projects ended up being so extensive that we had to split them into nine separate tranches. We took on Conexion Norte, Conexion al Rio Magdalena2, Pacifico 1, Pacifico 2, and Pacifico 3—these are the concessions that were awarded last year, constituting the first wave. We are currently in a bidding process for these last two projects valued at $7.5 billion. This is the largest 4G program to date. 4G is worth $21 billion in total, and these schemes alone are valued at $7 billion.
node.sections11: Ocensa is Colombia's most important oil pipeline, and the backbone for oil exports. The pipeline transports 65% of oil produced in the country from the Los Llanos Basin to the port of Coveñas in the Caribbean. Ocensa is over-demanded, being the most convenient and cost-effective means of export oil. In mid-2013, 27% of the company was for sale, owned by a number of E&P players, including Pacific Rubiales. Our value proposition to Pacific Rubiales was acquiring both the 5% equity and 5% of the transportation rights in the pipeline for a combined $385 million. To finance the acquisition we raised acquisition finance from local and international banks. From equity co-investors we raised more than twice our fund's ticket size.
node.sections21: The European market was not growing, and the fact that companies that had weathered the crisis, but faced slim growth prospects, has rendered Latin America an interesting investment proposition for a number of reasons. The country boasts legal stability, market scale, and corporate formality. We now also have security and the long-awaited peace process in place. Colombia's economy has been well managed. And even this year, while the country will not grow by the targeted 4.8%, due to oil depreciation, the forecast 3.5% growth rate is in itself respectable. Growth will be largely determined by Colombia's much-needed investment in 4G and infrastructure, without which it will be hard pressed to be competitive.
node.sections31: The most important consideration is the match between assets and liabilities. The long-term income from PPP projects will allow organizations to make payments. We expect to see the structuring of financing over the shorter term coming from banks, and long term from pension funds. With the new Basel III regulations adopted by the banking sector, banks will find it expensive, in terms of cost of capital, to extend long-term loans. Thus, over the coming years we will see banks trying to work on shorter term loans, and we expect pension funds and insurance companies to be on the longer side of the debt curve. If we fail to involve the pension funds, such long-term loans would not be available. When long-term credit is unavailable, two possibilities arise. Either you increase equity and become a lower risk, lower return entity, which is not the norm, or else the developers assume the risk, which is clearly a less secure prospect.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Across the economy, international firms are taking advantage of Colombia's hub-like nature to increase their regional footprint.
node.subject: Why Colombia?
node.title: On Fire
node.sections01: The Colombian market has brought positive surprises, and despite our focus on multinationals, local companies have also turned to our services and products. For example, we now work with Terpeland Banco Agrario. In the finance sector we have offered high levels of security, excellent products and services, and also our vast expertise at the international level. We have many references from our international customers. Our international expertise, puts us one step ahead of our competitors. At the same time, we have international partnerships that make our portfolio of services unique. For example, we have partnerships with Cisco, HP, IBM, and Microsoft. We have been aided by the openness of the Colombian economy that has led to the arrival of many multinationals and investors. Our portfolio of products has also evolved thanks to these circumstances. Colombia is a leading market in the region when it comes to attracting investors. Our vision is to grow alongside our customers.
node.sections11: Colombia is a land of opportunities, and we intend to participate in its success. There is a considerable dynamism in the sectors in which we work and DuPont day to day puts science to work creating sustainable solutions essential to a better, safer and healthier life for people everywhere. Our real challenge is bringing this innovation to Colombian locals, specifically to the Andean region. Ultimately, innovation is only as good as our capacity for it to serve local needs. One successful example of this is in our work with small farmers and milk producers in Colombia. Through the latest technology we have introduced, in addition to knowledge and support, we have helped small artisan producers increase the yield of their cheese production and be more competitive in the market.
node.sections21: The pipeline that we are building will make Colombia more competitive and allow the country to directly export crude to Asia. This particular pipeline is designed to transport heavy oil that has been transported in Colombia. Colombia imports probably 80,000 bpd of naphtha and diluents to mix with the heavy oil so that it is transportable, which is an additional cost. Our pipeline design will minimize the need for diluent, making the transport costs competitive. In addition, having a terminal on the Pacific coast will provide direct access to Asia. The actual markets and the contracts will depend on the exporters and the traders and whoever buys and sells that oil. Enbridge is exclusively a transporter. We do not own the oil and nor do we pump it. Our role has been to provide a market advantage, whereupon then it is up to other firms to sell the oil, be it China, India, or even the US Gulf Coast.
node.sections31: In every municipality in the country we have a police station, a justice office, and hospitals, even in urban areas of less than 20,000 people. In the past, all purchases had to be coordinated centrally, and they would often sell large products to smaller cities, whereby the cost of printing became prohibitively high for municipalities of more limited resources. We have closed two deals: one with the National Police Force, for hospitals, and another with the Notary Association. For the former, laser printers are now forbidden because the toner produces dust which can be dispersed in hospitals and create health issues; ink is more environmentally friendly. In 2013 we won the largest bid in Colombia for document scanners, which was worth $2 million, for the Colombian judiciary, which purchased 1,200 scanners. Our manufacturing plant produces 150 units per month for worldwide consumption.
node.sections41: The IT market is growing, and our demand for professionals is growing, too. Demand exceeds supply, and we are working with universities and schools to capture new talent that will become the industry's next generation. We work with universities, and the government, among other agencies, to find the best way to enhance our position as a country. Bogotá is important for our numbers; however, we have other cities around the country that are also economically significant, and therefore, also in terms of our presence and clients. Medellí­n, Cali, Barranquilla, and Santander are among those areas. We have teams dedicated to comprehending the different customers and required solutions, which is tied to our channel program. We approach our customers with solutions and our partners have the capability to cover products that we do not carry in our portfolio, for example, specific application for mining or designing applications.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0company: Cámara de Usuarios de Zonas Francas
node.previewsummary: Free Trade Zones are taking advantage of cluster economics and tax incentives to attract and promote some of the most exiting developments in the national economy.
node.subject: Advantages of FTZs
node.title: Push the Button
node.sections01: For each peso that the government gives the free zones, it receives COP18 or COP20 in taxes. The scheme of lowering taxes is interesting, because the country still ends up generating more tax returns. People think that these are fiscal holes, but in reality they pay the percentages over a far greater quantity. In the end, the companies pay less tax, yet the state receives more. The companies end up having more business, taxed at a lower amount. The idea is to present companies that are not in the free zones with what is happening, including the advantages not just for Colombian but foreign companies as well, as it is an opportunity to gain backing from the government on the legislative side.
