This is important to the sector's overall strategy, but I agree in terms of relating both to Islamic finance, for example, and values on a more global ethical scale. To me the challenge on one side is saying we want to develop products for everyone, not only for Muslims, but when it comes to workplace standards I think there is room for improvement to include similar requirements. Take for example principles of responsible investing (PRI); how many Islamic finance institutes have signed up to that? There is only one globally that has signed up. Why is this the case? If the principles and values are similar then we should see more. A lot of people would be attracted, I think, to standard setting through the International Sharia'a Board or others, and also standards that require companies to report on, for example CSR activities. If these standards are in line as much as possible, than Islamic products will increase in number

JAMAL BIN GHALAITA This is the point we are trying to reach; if you want to eat halal products, or alternatively you want to eat just any product that is available on the market, you will know the difference in terms of the ethics and the production conditions, and so forth. The same thing applies to sukuks and bonds. We should not copy what is being done today with bonds; we should bring a different financial product to the market to differentiate ourselves, and that is what we are trying to do together with the Dubai government initiative and Abdullah's team.

Can you foresee innovation being part of this, in terms of new instruments?

JAMAL BIN GHALAITA Yes, we have been working with NASDAQ, and hopefully we will be working with a commodity market as well to offer different products that will provide liquidity in a halal way. With NASDAQ we have launched a certificate that is similar to the London Metal Exchange certificate. We intend to have a joint workshop in the future to share these ideas about how we can develop the NASDAQ product and certificate further. In fact, it was actually NASDAQ that took on the idea and developed it. This is where we see the future; we need to be innovative and more flexible in our products. I do not think that halal certificates should be the same standard; they should be different and provide a different quality. And I think that halal should be closer to organic rather than genetically engineered.

ABDULLAH AL AWAR These will all be part of the standards developed by the UAE, the Emirates authorities, and the Saudi Arabian authorities who took the view, as Mr Ghalaita said, that halal certified products are not just categorized based on the process. Halal also goes beyond just the issues of faith, safety, and the treatment of the animals that are being slaughtered. Everything tie in, such as certification and logistics.

RANDA BESSISO I think we need to educate the public here, and we also need to give them information about the benefits of halal products and continue to build that Islamic brand. But we also need to look at how we can translate it into a more universally acceptable and familiar term. Global ethics and government are already being taught as part of business degrees, including those at Manchester Business School, and I think that we just need to continue to look for avenues to promote the sound ethics that underpin that halal brand.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2company: Turkey and Middle East, GE Healthcare
node.intervieweelist3company: Middle East, Africa, and Turkey, Bombardier
node.previewsummary: The range of international firms based in Dubai bespeaks an attractive business environment, with solid infrastructure and guarantees for investors from abroad.
node.subject: Why Dubai?
node.title: Stands to Reason
node.sections01: MENA, with all its population, still only represents around 2% of the total global pharmaceutical market and it is very fragmented. This has put pressure on some of the smaller companies to not be physically present here, but rather look for partners who can become an extension to their values, their best practices and their compliance to market their products. That's where NewBridge comes in, we have the expertise, network, and the distribution channels, to drive innovative pharmaceutical products to the market and be the one-stop solution to these companies across multiple geographies. Innovation in the pharmaceutical industry comes from two sources, big pharma, and small or midsize companies such as those in the biotech segment. When these small or mid-size companies want to reach the world, their initial focus is usually the US, Europe, and Japan. As for the rest of the world, they usually prefer a partnering model, and depending on the country or the region in question they usually prefer a regional partner and this was the niche we found for ourselves. These innovative companies usually want to access emerging markets, get a piece of the action and the growth, but at the same time they don't want to establish structures themselves in each country or region. They have a very focused strategy and also finite resources, hence the partnering model.
node.sections11: There are some exciting things with cash. Cash is important here. The amount of cash that changes hands versus electronic methods is much greater than many other parts of the world. We have a great technology for cash called Retail 360. It allows clients to be able to deposit their back office cash much quicker, and they can put it on their balance sheet, which is better for their cash flow and security. This is different from the traditional methodology, which will take away some of our traditional business but we believe investing in it now will help in the long term. Some of the electronic security that we are working on with major construction companies for the UAE, from an access control and a video analytics point of view, is also interesting. We are looking to help retailers understand what their footfall is doing, which direction they are walking, and what they are looking for. We can analyze that very quickly and offer them detailed metrics to improve the offering, traffic flow for their customers, which is something we do very well in other countries. Being able to bring that to the UAE is an exciting development for us.
node.sections21: The MENA territory is one of the few markets worldwide where there is a significant growth in this sector, of 9-10%. Our products have a great potential in the region because there is limited competition due to the innovative approach that we take. Our aim for the coming years is to become a category leader in those therapeutic areas. Previously, the MENA region was managed by one of our affiliates in the Netherlands.However as a pharmaceutical company, proximity to our stakeholders is key. We cannot really be a true partner unless we are there on the ground. Close to our patients, doctors and the medical community, close to our business associates and, of course, close to the healthcare providers and authorities in the region. We had to recruit local talent who have a long-standing experience in the MENA region, understand the culture and speak the same language as our stakeholder. We currently have around 170 people in the region working for Astellas having almost doubled our presence versus the previous year.
node.sections31: Investment in healthcare is high here, mainly because this is a rapidly-growing market. There is a need for more technology. This will position the Gulf or the Middle East as a unique market. At a time when we see the European and US markets more or less growing by 2-3%, the Middle East is growing at a rate of 8%-10%. In the UAE in 2009, there was a population of 3.4 million. Now it is 9 million with a projected jump to 14 million in a few years. This will create a need for more hospital beds and more quality of care. This aside, lifestyle diseases are a problem. Obesity is causing diabetes and diabetes causes heart problems. Also, we see cancer becoming really widespread. We now have the means to diagnose, so we are seeing it more, but also because the disease is spreading because of lifestyle. All this is a burden to the Ministry of Health and it needs to tackle this. In 2014 we equipped the Ministry of Health in the UAE with 11 new CTs. It wanted the latest technology, and the best for its patients. We went together to Chicago where we had launched our best technology. There has been lots of discussion around sustainability of growth in this part of the world. Like it or not, we are all talking about oil prices dropping. We are an oil price-sensitive market and the bulk of the GDP is oil dependent, but in most of these markets the official plan is that healthcare investment will remain as is.
node.sections41: One of Bombardier's main objectives in the region is targeting aircraft sales, but we have other goals to increase our customer services and presence. Bombardier has significantly increased its presence in the region over the years. Most of the sales force is now based in the UAE. The office we are in presently has expanded from eight people to 24 now, and we are still expanding. We chose the UAE obviously for the basic elements it provides us with, such as businesses in the city and airlines including Emirates, which provide us with connections between the Middle East, Africa, and our home in Montreal, Canada. It is easy to fly from here, and it is an easy center to use. That is really why we decided on Dubai, and we have been here since 1998. Dubai International Airport is very crowded and busy, and there is probably no more room for business aircraft there. We feel that this is something that is going to work against users of business aircraft. Otherwise, we don't have problems in Dubai.
node.intervieweelist4company: Dubai Branch, Head of MEA Asset Servicing, BNY Mellon

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: MICE and business tourism remain key segments within the industry, while the development of the leisure segment will rely on considerable investment.
node.subject: GROWTH STRATEGIES
node.title: Bem-vindo!
node.sections01: People haven't given up completely on leisure tourism, but the timeframes have differed. Obviously, business tourism is more of a short- to mid-term investment and leisure tourism is a longer-term investment. With the opening of the Nacala Airport, we are going to be in a position to be able to compete with other global destinations. Obviously, we need the infrastructure, but I think the most important thing is to be able to compete with global destinations in terms of times of flights. Also, the opening of new airports and the bringing in of new airlines, which has been happening in the last few years, is also going to open up the. We depend a lot on Europe, but when Nacala Airport opens up, I believe Emirates is going to fly to Nacala. That opens up a huge market, so not only Europe, but also the Middle East and Far East. That is something that we need to maximize and exploit. We work with closely with INATUR in terms of marketing. The issue is that it is expensive to market Mozambique because the country is an expensive destination to reach.
node.sections11: We are promoting Mozambique as a destination in itself, rather than merely an add-on. Mozambique has enough to occupy the visitor for two to three weeks without adding it to a tour to Botswana, Namibia, or South Africa. Mozambique has so much to offer that is refreshingly different. Our safaris offer an excursion into Gorongosa National Park where the visitor will not see more than 20 other game vehicles, as the territory is wholly untouched, and therefore provides a new way of seeing Africa. Tanzania and Botswana are established destinations that we can never compete with, so instead we aim for the unique. We are looking to expand our offerings in beach and island areas, because people here on business occasionally stay for up to three weeks, and want to leave Maputo without having to deal with visas to Kruger National Park, or taking expensive flights north. There is enough to do around here over a weekend, and we are trying to develop these products and packages to cater to that potential.
node.sections21: Predominately the profile of an average tourist is business people looking for investment opportunities, then families who spend two to four weeks at the beach or island resorts, and adventure travelers. These visitors are generally between 28 to 50 years of age. Most of our visitors are budget orientated and self-catering, particularly South Africans, who visit Mozambique during holiday seasons. The country needs to be more introspective in assessing areas in which we are still lacking. As our leisure tourism is too seasonal, and as we have great potential we look to develop domestic tourism. Often some hotels and resorts shut down in between these periods. Mozambicans could visit during low season, but this requires strong tour operators with a large capacity, without which it is difficult to offer lower prices even in the low season. If you empower the tour operators to have this capacity beyond the high season, it would make sense for them to direct their bus fleets to promote domestic tourism excursions.
node.sections31: Tourism remains expensive and we lack the competition among multiple airlines required to handle domestic flights. Most events in Maputo are conferences, meetings, and business tourism, which is why hotels are at 95% capacity booking. Thus, while we do have considerable potential for leisure tourism, the MICE and business travel segments currently dominate the sector. The government must take up the challenge of promoting the image of the country, and we will certainly assist with whatever steps are considered necessary. Mostly though, we need to invest in infrastructure, roads, and health issues, without which investors are reluctant to make a commitment. Normally, tour operators in Mozambique do not have more than six or seven employees, but we have 30 people working at our current head office alone, and furthermore in our other offices. We are also finalizing our new premises in the city's premium destination, Kenneth Kaunda Avenue. Currently, the quality of human resources in Mozambique's hospitality industry is lacking. We have to invest heavily in training to address these problems.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: Instituto Superior de Transportes e Comunicaçíµes (ISUTC)
node.previewsummary: Private higher education institutions play a key role in educating the country's workforce and are increasingly attracting international students.
node.subject: Private Universities
node.title: Linked In
node.sections01: Last year we approved a new vision and a new mission for the university, which is to have a greater focus on research. That means that research will be the basis of all our activities in terms of training our students. We expect that our research results will be used to improve our lectures. In order to build a research university, it requires a lot of investment, particularly for the training of lecturers. We expect to train people as much as possible to the Master's and PhD level so they can participate more in the university's growth and development. Our university has the most international students in the country. They want to come here because we are among the best in Africa. Because of our ranking in the region and the world, we are getting many foreign students, traditionally from lusophone nations, but also increasingly from other source countries. We are working on developing our relationships with the private sector, but not enough people recognize how we can help private business. The examples that we have with petroleum companies like Anadarko show that this can be fruitful. Maputo Port is also an impressive example.
node.sections11: We decided from the outset that ISUTC (Instituto Superior de Transportes e Comunicaçíµes) would begin by concentrating on engineering and technology. Of course that was a problem because most high school graduates do not tend to favor physics and mathematics, which is why after ten years we still did not have more than 400 students. We decided to be a more aggressive in organizing a range of training sessions in these areas. And once the post-graduate degree courses began, our school's name became more well-known to the extent that over the past four years, we have more than doubled the student body. The relationship with the private sector is excellent, and we are already on the second of our courses with Vale due to the success of the first. I know that Vale is keen to increase the professional training of its workers, and even if professional training is not our core activity, we are pleased at the prospect of entering this area. Meanwhile, we work extensively with the National Roads Administration (ANE). I organized the city's courses in the field of maintenance two years ago, and welcomed around 100 participants from the ANE.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: The evolution of health insurance has allowed more access to better treatment, offering diverse opportunities to clinics across the country.
node.subject: Accessing Healthcare
node.title: Healthy Profit
node.sections01: Clinicare has been growing over the past two years and our aim is to continue that growth. The intention is to expand our clinic in Maputo by a further ten treatment rooms because our work has been positively received by both the local and expatriate sectors. In 2015 we will also be expanding into the provinces, specifically to Nampula in 1Q2015, and then to Nacala. We are currently finalizing details, such as human resource requirements, in order to move into northern Mozambique. Health insurance is becoming a significant market for us because a number of larger companies are coming here to serve their expatriate clientele. Thanks to the environment that we provide and the people that we have, they don't need to go to other places for certain surgeries and other procedures—they can have them carried out here. Over the past three or four years, even the public sector has been investing in new equipment and resources which has been beneficial for the population, as is competition. The number of private clinics in Maputo has increased over the past three years.
node.sections11: Maputo Private Hospital is a member of the Lenmed Group of hospitals, South Africa. The Lenmed Group was established more than 30 years ago, and owns seven hospitals in South Africa, as well as two international facilities namely Bokamoso Private Hospital in Botswana and Maputo Private Hospital. This is a 105-bed institution, that provides all the major clinical disciplines, supported by state-of-the-art technology. Some of these disciplines include internal medicine, general surgery, anesthesiology, orthopedic surgery, obstetrics and gynecology, pediatrics, radiology featuring MRI, CT scans, nursing, ICU, NICU, casualty (24/7) and four well-equipped operating rooms. Supporting the above functions, we have a modern pharmacy service. These services are provided by 16 full-time specialists, 122 nursing staff and a further 100 specialist consultants that make use of our facilities to see private patients. The proliferation of health insurance in Mozambique has resulted in more individuals being able to be treated at our facility. Private patients (not covered by a medical care provider) have to pay significant amounts toward admission deposits, which in certain instances result in delays during admission to the hospital.
node.sections21: The clinic was established in 1993 and has seen growth since then. We began with a building in Maputo that we have increased in size with several new consultation rooms. In the near future we will construct a new building. The sector is improving. In the beginning, only Cruz Azul and our own company were offering good quality private health services, but today competition is on the rise, which is a healthy development. Having new private clinics in the region is good because if you need a specific service, let's say a scan, several clinics now offer that service. Also, we have an excellent relationship between the clinics, and where needed, we utilize each other's services and technologies. Besides, many doctors are present in several clinics at different times whereby we are effectively an extended family. Our business goal, naturally enough, is to provide patients the best possible treatment. Our staff has been at the clinic with me for around 20 years and is extremely adept at doing this. At this point in time we have 140 employees (up from 75 in 1993) and 20 beds where we offer the best healthcare.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: The proliferation of megaprojects in the energy and transportation sectors is providing ample opportunities for construction and consultancy firms.
node.subject: Engineering
node.title: Opportunities To Build On
node.sections01: Two years ago we were a 90% public service provider, and only 10% private. We worked for banks, for example, to provide new branches and related evaluations. Now our business is 60% public and 40% private, and we want the ratio to level out at 50:50 ultimately, with projects involving both large corporations and smaller enterprises. We have ranked among the top three in Mozambique in terms of consultancy services over the past five years. I think in less than five years we will be number one, and we look to double our business within five to seven years. Today we design tailored solutions for our clients, and over the next few years we will launch the second phase of our project to build supply water systems in rural areas.
node.sections11: The combination of Kentz and SNC-Lavalin is part of building a global Tier-1 engineering and construction (E&C) company. This created a group with approximately 45,000 employees, annual revenues of about approximately $10 billion, and a backlog of roughly $13 billion as per 2013 figures. Our new capability to take the full EPCM scope on projects will provide further value to our clients, while our focus on providing our specialist and responsive services will mean our execution for clients, who have supported us for many years, will only be strengthened. In respect of prospects on the African continent, we see opportunities that will see us providing technical services and delivering more complex, turnkey projects in remote locations. We are now able to meet our clients' needs by offering SNC-Lavalin's strong Front-end Engineering and Design (FEED) capabilities, full EPC projects, as well as Kentz's leading construction expertise in Structural, Mechanical, Electrical, Instrumentation, and Piping (SMEIP).
node.sections21: Our main objectives include becoming a reliable partner for the Mozambique government for the country's infrastructure development, which is our core business. We believe that we can play a major role in assisting in that growth, which we can do through our ability to attract private investment for the construction of infrastructure at competitive conditions, delivering EPPM and turnkey projects; all of this of course with our long term experience and knowhow of working in Africa. We are proud to be part of the Maputo Catembe bridge project. This will be the largest suspension bridge in Africa and among the top 50 in the world. GAUFF has been contracted to act as consultant for the quality control of the construction of the bridge and link roads.
node.sections31: Bechtel is the largest engineering and construction company in the US, employing about 53,000 people. We have annual revenues of approximately $40 billion. We currently operate in Angola, Rwanda, Mozambique, and Gabon, but also have a presence in Egypt. What attracted us to Mozambique initially was the LNG project, which was our flagship scheme through the middle of last year. Today, three of our four business groups are looking at all sectors in Mozambique. Mozambique has vast potential, and equally vast needs, which is widely acknowledged. The newly discovered wealth in the form of coal and gas reserves, as well as important mineral discoveries in recent years, have created a possibility for Mozambique to begin tackling some of its difficulties. There is some interesting work going on with respect to Coal-To-Liquids (CTL), and we are poised to sign a contract to support one of those contracts with early engineering work. We have been approached about a fertilizer plant project, too. Infrastructure is our short-term focus, as it is for the government.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: A number of accomplished firms offer construction support in both the public and private sectors.
node.subject: Local Construction
node.title: Building Support
node.sections01: MMD is a family company established in 2005. Our first project simultaneously involved a demolition at the British High Commission and construction of a six-floor building on Av. Karl Marx. Since then we have continued to grow and we have reached the fortunate stage where, after only six months, we have projects and clients in excess of our capacity. With the need to expand came the decision to purchase another Mozambican company that had already been operating for a number of years called JR Construçoes, a move that provided the additional capacity required to undertake our projects. In 2008, we faced the same problem on a larger scale and purchased another company called PRUMO. The new scale this provided allowed us to bid for jobs that were previously only awarded to foreign firms, with whom we are able to compete today. We now have 550 employees and are a major player in the market, competing with other large-scale companies. Yet we are not involved in infrastructure projects, such as roads and bridges, but focus solely on buildings. Clearly the oil and gas project locations are significant prospects. We are looking forward to going to Pemba and Palma, to which I would add, Nacala, Tete, and obviously Maputo.
node.sections11: Lis is a small 100% Mozambican company, and one of our largest clients since 2010 has been Cidadela da Matola. We developed the environmental project of that area, and today we are beginning to build the first phase of the infrastructure project, while supervising the construction. This project includes a mall, residential buildings, a hotel and conference center, and a building for the provincial government, as well as office buildings, a cultural center, and museum. In construction, we also undertake work for Henan Gou Ji, a Chinese company engaged on a landmark project called “5,000 houses.“ The project is a joint venture with the Mozambican government's Housing Promotion Fund (FFH), which is the agency overseeing affordable public housing. We are interested in working for the government in all areas related to construction of buildings, infrastructure, and civil engineering projects, among others. Our first goal from Lis Construction is to be able to support the LNG-related construction projects taking place in the north of the country. We are trying to become a sub-construction company of the large players operating there. We want to support all the industries in the north of the country, in the first phase of construction of their bases, and so on.
node.sections21: Fertha Construçíµes is a Mozambican-owned company that we purchased in 2010. The company was founded in 2005. Since then we have been working to bring the company to the next level. We have secured some tenders and we are growing slowly on the same path of the national economy. We are a small company that indirectly employs 110 people. We are looking to take advantage of all opportunities emerging in the country, while gaining scale to a extent to seek potential partners of greater financial and technical clout. We tend to join up with bigger companies so that we can actually cover the country in different fields, including building roads, bridges, water sanitation, dams, electrical power plants, and so forth. We have been working mostly in the rehabilitation of existing infrastructure, of buildings, roads, and some other private projects. Today we are predominantly focused on rehabilitating infrastructure such as the central hospital, or local municipality roads, mostly for institutions. Most of the work we undertake is public sector related, in the education sector, the health sector, and on a municipal level. At this time the building sector for us represents about 70% of our work.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Mozambique's access to the Indian Ocean makes it an important regional shipping center, but the capacity of its ports must be developed to take full advantage of its location.
node.subject: Shipping Companies
node.title: All Aboard
node.sections01: Since it started its first service in Africa in 2001, the CMA CGM Group has increased its presence and become a major player on the continent. It has continuously reinforced its presence and its services, and is now pursuing its maritime and inland development in Africa. The Group is present in 43 Sub-Saharan countries, with its 72-branch network and 1,300 employees. As the second shipping company operating in Mozambique, the CMA CGM Group operates at all five main ports—Maputo, Beira, Quelimane, Nacala, and Pemba—where it is also physically represented by its own agencies. Currently, refrigerated cargo and exports of certain dry commodities are our strategic focus areas. This includes a diversity of products such as timber, tobacco, cotton, grains, and nuts. Our group offers its customers weekly calls to Mozambique. Our three different shipping services to and from the country allow us to accommodate customer needs by offering personalized service with tailor-made solutions. On top of that, our innovative inland solutions provide safe cargo transportation from the port to ramp, or door-to-door delivery to any of the hinterland countries in the region.
node.sections11: Besides Maputo, Beira, Quelimane, Moma, Angoche, Nacala, and Pemba, LBH is also present in Mocí­mboa da Praia port, which is a small, but strategically positioned facility at the heart of the gas field. We hope to service the larger players from it. We have also launched a service called LBH Xpress. We operate a weekly service from Johannesburg and Durban all the way through Maputo in the north. There is no doubt that the north is the destination of future development. The closest sophisticated engineering systems are in South Africa, we have warehouses in Johannesburg, Durban, Maputo, and Nacala to service the LBH Xpress trucks and the customers. As shipping agents, we now handle almost any type of cargo, from small boxes to cape-sized vessels, nationwide. Our services have extended considerably and we can do a complete logistics management service. We have a joint venture with Barloworld in a highly sophisticated transport management system for bulk commodities. Tonnage-wise, we probably handled 2 million tons in Beira last year, 8 million tons in Maputo, and 13 million tons nationally.
node.sections21: We arrived in 1998 and first opened the office in Beira. A couple of years later we moved to Maputo but then in 2013 we returned. Beira is the business center in terms of trade and is also a gateway to Zimbabwe, Zambia, and Malawi. More than 50% of our overall business moves through Beira. From a business point of view it is much easier to connect to other countries and optimize the cargo we ship. Therefore, the relocation was done with business optimization in mind. We are operating at the four ports of Nacala, Quelimane, Beira, and Maputo. Quelimane is a small port for us, with a bi-weekly call. Nacala has a weekly call and Beira and Maputo twice a week. The biggest challenge for us in terms of expanding that is Beira because it has yet to develop into an international port, so in terms of us optimizing and enhancing our business even further, Beira is the bottleneck. We want to continue the journey begun in 2014 with an optimization of the value of the business that we have and the activities that we do.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: As the government expands infrastructure in light of a changing reality, boosting reliance on local production for raw input promises to reduce prices for local consumers, while propelling the wider economy.
node.subject: Manufacturing
node.title: Quite A Production
node.sections01: With current and future investments to come, as well as job creation, training the local workforce, support for social activities, and adding value to raw materials we import to produce our own output, we are already contributing to national development. We also believe that in the future we could locally source some of the raw materials we currently import and produce more products locally. And meanwhile, we forecast double-digit annual growth supported by innovation and investments. Looking ahead, the manner in which the government chooses to allocate revenues generated from the exploitation of Mozambique's natural resources will determine the national business environment and broader national development.
node.sections11:
Maí«va's first investment was in the Sabino soap factory, and growth in 2004 brought with it the opportunity to build a second plant to manufacture oils, a complementary product. We then pursued greater synergies by packaging our products ourselves, and today produce the plastic bottles in which our own products are sold. Maí«va Plast, created in 2006, produces plastic packaging. Both oil and plastic factories are located in Matola. In total we have five factories in the Maputo province, one under construction, and another in construction in Sofala.

And meanwhile, we have plantations in the province of Inhambane. We work to empower farmers through sunflower and soya production contracts, to supply the provinces of Manica and Sofala. Our goal is to reduce our raw material imports. If the agricultural industry is able to use locally sourced raw materials, we will be able to decrease the final consumer price. The future lies in agriculture.
node.sections21: Our strategy is to ensure that our products have the right nutrients to meet Mozambican necessities widely among the population. Accordingly, we have introduced a range of products that respond to the economic reality of Mozambican families. We play an active role in helping the country, and being a leading nutrition, health and wellness company is precisely where we can add value. We want to be part of the socioeconomic development process and part of the solution is providing the right products to promote national health. Our intention is to support a better quality of life based on our products. We play an informative role on good nutrition, for example through our “Healthy Kids Program.“ We work with the Ministry of Education and teachers to provide modules, tools, and materials to teach good nutrition to foster healthy living.
node.sections31: Tropigalia is a nationwide distribution company, mainly for food and beverage products. We started 10 years ago with a vision of bringing market leader brands from Portugal to the Mozambican consumers. Over the years we have also expanded for into certain leading world brands. Meanwhile, our strategic priorities for the next five years include sustaining our market leadership in formal distribution. Added to this, we intend to expand and export our “Gourmet" brand, currently our 2nd biggest turnover generator with 272 select SKU's, from groceries, to refrigerated and frozen products. It is also a registered Tropigalia trademark in Mozambique.Meanwhile, in pursuit of investment resources for expansion, our company is going public in 2015. We must also invest in local production for the domestic and Southern African Development Community (SADC) market, which provides potential access to around 250 million consumers of products made in Mozambique for which no duties are paid. Today we are in the process of opening an industrial cluster with five agro-businesses to replicate earlier successes.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Chairwoman of the Board of Directors
node.previewsummary: The national telephone and communications infrastructure has expanded exponentially as a consequence of the growing economy.
node.subject: Telecoms Companies
node.title: Communication Breakout
node.sections01: Our priority is to sustain our investment, not just in terms of coverage, but also on quality. This includes services on voice, data, and image, because today we also have image services like mobile television. Our investment plan will exceed $200 million. Our market share is at around 28% to 30%. Maintaining this position requires the provision of excellent services to our clients, and also enlarging coverage area not just with voice services, but also data and image. Nowadays, smartphones have become ubiquitous and people demand image communication. First there was an increase in data services. For the voice services we introduced new packages, and subsequently we introduced TV services on the phone. We also pioneered mobile banking in Mozambique through the Mkesh service.
node.sections11: Our main focus remains serving the country and expanding communications to everyone in Mozambique, to all social groups and to the remotest areas. We understand that by giving people access to telecommunications, we are opening their horizons and possibilities for growth, thus contributing to the development of the country. We started our implementation in rural areas by serving the un-served or underserved. About 30% of our clients had access to communications services for the first time with Movitel. We have not yet fulfilled our objective of total coverage, but we are almost there. For the present year the company tends to focus on the medium and high-income segment as well as corporate sector. It is time to address other segments of the market, for which creative services and solutions must be developed. The ICT sector provides many opportunities to better serve medium- and high-income clients, and it is an important component in corporate development. Access to good quality communication services is crucial.
node.sections21: Vodacom Moçambique is an integral part of Vodacom Group in southern Africa. Sharing borders with South Africa and Tanzania, which is connected to the Congo, allows us to serve as a link between the whole international group in southern Africa in physical terms, making us an important part of the picture. We have been gaining market share over the last year, primarily driven on the back of significant growth in our network. In 2013, we expanded our network by 70% with our largest-ever investment. In 2014, we have so far increased our network by 50%. I think that will make us the second-largest network in the whole country. We certainly cover all the major populated areas, and we are merging into the rural areas where people live.
node.sections31: There has been significant economic growth due to the recent discovery of important resources, and a subsequent rise in demand for telecommunications services is evident. TDM is the main provider of infrastructure in Mozambique for landlines, mobile telephone services, and the internet. As such, TDM is an important player in terms of overall economic development, and is currently the sole player in terms of fixed-telecommunications services. Until 2010, TDM's network was by far the largest telecoms infrastructure in Mozambique; in 2008, all provincial capitals were linked through a national backbone transmission network using fiber-optic cables. This infrastructure allowed TDM to satisfy existing demand. In addition, TDM also provides an ADSL network for internet services on copper cable and a CDMA network for both voice and internet services in areas not covered by copper cables.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: BHR Country Manager and Director MML, Minas Moatize Lda
node.previewsummary: Mining has been bearing the brunt of depressed prices and markets, but prudent strategies are enabling it to see a light at the end of the tunnel.
node.subject: MINING companies
node.title: Digging a Little Deeper
node.sections01: We are looking to leverage our unique access to captive iron ore (our global resource inventory stands at three-quarters of a billion tons) and the locally-produced thermal coal to establish a vertically integrated, mine-mouth smelting operation producing iron and steel products. By-products of vanadium and possibly titanium will also be produced. Against a backdrop of slowing global economies and the flattening of Chinese development, Mozambique and the SADC region continue to enjoy strong growth rates of more than 7%. The demand for construction steel in Mozambique is growing very fast, driven by the commissioning of large-scale infrastructure, mining, LNG, and power projects. However, the country is entirely dependent on imports.
node.sections11: I foresee the sector developing steadily. And despite the low price environment and logistics shortfalls the fact remains that the quality of the coal in Moatize is good. What is more, it is easy to extract, being at a shallow depth, unlike some deposits in, say, Queensland. Another point to consider is our proximity to the Asian market. In an international context, our geographical location renders us are closer to India, and it is that proximity that makes the Mozambican coal important. So I think business will develop, even if not to the extent we anticipate, and there will definitely be major growth over the next five years. Vale has already started doubling its capacity, and we are set to do so, too, as is Jindal; so while prices are indeed low, this means it is time to either optimize the scale of operations, or else pull out.
node.sections21: We completed the expansion works at the Moma mine in 2013 and have all but ramped up to full, expanded capacity, having invested approximately $400 million. With this expansion we have seen a significant QoQ rise in production since mid-2013. Overall expansion increased our capacity from 800,000 tons per year of ilmenite to 1.2 million tons. We export to around 35 countries, but the main ones are the US for ilmenite, Europe for zircon, and China for ilmenite and zircon. We will be renewing our mine concession in 2029, and have 100+ years of mine life. We would expect prices to recover quite strongly in 2015. We have a large deposit with considerable opportunities for further production.
node.sections31: The initial production plan is for 3 million tons per annum, yet in the international coal market over the past one and a half years prices have declined by 50%. Unless the market improves we cannot increase production. Having now decelerated we await improved market conditions. Among measures to adapt to prevailing conditions we recently terminated outsourced mining contracts. There are three aspects that we are still considering; one is the mining itself, another is processing, and the third is logistics. We have removed contractors from the mining component, in processing we have negotiated lower costs with our contractors, although not sufficiently. And meanwhile, logistics currently poses the greatest challenge, as our costs reflect the high volume of handling and re-handling, whereby around 45% of our cost structure is accounted for by logistics. We are discussing steps with the government to address these excess charges. It has adopted a highly sympathetic view, and a committee is in the process of studying the issue with a cost structure and comparing it to other countries such as South Africa. This will hopefully lead to lower logistics costs.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: With only 2% penetration, the insurance industry has no shortage of room for growth, and economic developments indicate that this is a safe bet.
node.subject: Expanding The Insurance Market
node.title: Let’s Roll
node.sections01: The main insurance companies in the market are in process of evaluating the new legal framework recently approved known as Special Regime of insurance and reinsurance for the Rovuma Basin, which appears to us at first glance, that isn't very clear and somehow contradictory. We as a whole consider important that the competent authorities must clarify of what in fact wants to be achieved with this specific legislation recently approved and seem to us that a strong message should be passed to the international investors about the importance for the country to have local insurers effectively involved in all insurances of the big projects particularly in the Rovuma Basin.
node.sections11: I've been in insurance for 20 years, and about 12 or 13 of those years were in South Africa. What makes insurance in Mozambique so complicated is that although it is a country that is growing quickly, we are still struggling to keep up with what has happened in the past in other countries. Looking at the occupational diseases act and injuries at work, over here it is still underwritten by insurers in the form of worker's compensation insurance. It is definitely a different approach to insurance than what we have in South Africa. Mozambique is an exceptionally large country to live and work in, and to get something from the North to the South with the road networks not as good as they should be takes a massive amount of time. We do not have set offices, and that is definitely something different. We do not have a network of repairers, tow vehicles, and spare parts distributors. I think the absence of a settled service provider network is the key issue. You need to be able to source our things and get them to the client whenever they are needed.
node.sections21: The government has a regulatory and supervisory role. It has a new and dynamic approach and is bringing in a vision as to how companies must develop this industry. It is more aware of the insurance industry now. In the past, the government was much more concerned about the banking sector than the insurance sector. However, while the government authority is more active than before, there is still a long way to go. Along with the insurance companies, brokers and other players in the sector, the government should ensure that it promotes the industry. Most people know very little about insurance products, besides motor insurance and workers' compensation. We have numerous large-scale projects where huge international companies are coming to Mozambique under specific agreements with the government, and insurance is a part of that. We have the capacity and a good insurance offering in the country. It is essential that our insurance regulator and the association lobby such that the majority of the business stays in Mozambique.
node.sections31: Sometimes in these environments it is up to the government to negotiate and attract big investors and the results will depend on the concessions they give. The jury is still out in terms of what is going to happen in the north with regards to the emerging oil and gas industry. We as the insurance industry received an urgent letter from the Ministry of Finance through the insurance association requesting our comments on the possible concession that the government was considering for the exploration area of oil and gas in the Rovuma basin. There was a proposal for these operators to be exempted from having to comply with local insurance legislation like all other companies that are locally based. Naturally, the insurance association was concerned about this trend and what it could trigger in other economic sectors. Furthermore, such a policy would be in contradiction to the official policy of the government of supporting local retention, in alignment with policies of other countries with major extractive industries.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: The largest companies in Mozambique have a wealth of information about the economy at large, maintaining activities across multiple and diverse sectors.
node.subject: Holding Companies
node.title: Holding All the Cards
node.sections01: Our first priority lies in infrastructure. We want to improve our railway capacity, either through construction or maintenance of the existing infrastructure. Our intention is to widen the diversity of our cable TV products in TVCABO, offering optimum solutions and moving forward by paying close attention to market trends. We ensure that we are always able to offer the latest communications technologies available. Our main centers for real estate operations are in Maputo, Nampula, and Beira. We are engaged in both business and housing, and are in partnership with the Bank of Mozambique and Emose. This means that we manage the housing owned by both and, of course, we also try to introduce new land to the market. When it comes to tourism, we want hotels to attain higher standards in the key touristic areas of the country, and to improve our operations in Gorongosa. There is enormous potential for Mozambique to produce a diversity of goods in the textile industry for example, as well as in the furniture industry, although it is so important that the right technology and skills are available. For that reason it is necessary for people to be adequately trained in this type of work.
node.sections11: Everything is available here for investors, from infrastructure to fast-paced education and better roads. We also have manpower available to work, so if a company brings technology and training they can maximize their use of Mozambican workers. We also have fertile lands and water, as well as a strategic location on the western shore of the Indian Ocean. Mozambique has been growing for the past 15 years at a rate of 7% or 8% per annum, which clearly demonstrates a stable economy. Meanwhile, our strong democratic institutions are also an incentive to long term investors. Mozambique will succeed in developing a more diversified economy. The oil and gas segment should add value to the diversification processes of our economy, and will offer Intelec Holdings strong opportunities for sustained growth, in turn creating a sustainable corporation that able to contribute to employment, while adding value to the nation in broader terms. Intelec Holding's focus is on creating and exploring local opportunities. Agriculture was not our main focus at the outset, but we recognized that the country has fertile land and plentiful water supply, as well as the required non-skilled manpower.
node.sections21: The company was created by my great-great grandfather 117 years ago, and remains a 100% family-owned enterprise, with a 50% stake each held by my brother and I. We forecast 40% to 50% more revenue in 2015 given the numerous large-scale projects on our books, especially those in real estate. We are currently working on 20,000sqm of offices and a shopping center in central Maputo, which will be completed by the end of 2016. In the residential area in Maputo we started a 10-floor building featuring 11 luxury apartments. In the energy sector, we have a partnership with Petromoc wherein we sell petrol. We have three stations and we are building a fourth here in Maputo. And in the communications sector we are present through the newspaper Noticias, in which we are shareholders. We have a presence in the automotive business in nine of the 10 provinces, importing Mitsubishi and Fuso trucks, and Alfa Romeo and Fiat automobiles, as well as specialized vehicles for mining and other industries. In addition, our agricultural operations make us the largest taxpayer in the Niassa province. Mozambique is an extremely difficult market that does not promise rapid returns on investment. In order to enjoy these, a business must be prepared to invest in the country for at least five years.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Local banks are not only riding the success of booming sectors of the economy such as real estate, construction, and SMEs, but also their services are ensuring that these trends play out in the long-term.
node.subject: Local Banks
node.title: Balancing Act
node.sections01: We have two products specifically directed at the construction and real estate sector. One is aimed at construction activities where risk is characteristically high. When firms decide to build in Mozambique using the bank's money, the cost of the apartments or the building itself rises, making it difficult to compete in the market. They are more cost efficient when they utilizing their own money, so we try to assist them in the short term by supporting their financial base and, at the same time, making them more efficient. The other product we offer relates to mortgages. Our operations are also linked to the national growth of SMEs. We signed an agreement with the African Guarantee Fund, the African Development Bank, USAID and IFC, and are sharing our clients' risk with these multilateral entities. In doing so, we reduce our lending rates offered to clients, the ultimate beneficiaries of these credit lines.
node.sections11: The construction and real estate sector is among the many sectors we support. We have a full package designed with property developers, whom we support right from the construction phase up until sale to the end-buyer. The country is vast, and you cannot compare the real estate market in Maputo with that in the north of the country or the midlands. I would say there are three basic markets in terms of real estate in Mozambique. You have Maputo, which is the main city and also a mature market. Then you have what I call the second segment, comprising emerging cities including Beira, Nacala, Nampula, Tete, and Pemba. Those five cities are today under pressure to grow, which presents a huge opportunity for investors. Then there is the third segment, namely the remaining cities, which is not yet a particularly exciting prospect. As a result, diverse packages need to be designed to support activity in these segments. At the retail banking level, we forecast GDP growth of around 8% over the coming years, which promise much opportunity for the financial system. Less than 18% of the population is banked, so we have to find ways to bring that population into the system, and to service them. We also need to devise means of assisting domestic SMEs to grow, and to make sure that the populated rural areas are covered.
node.sections21: Mozambique is not only seeing investment in residential property, but also commercial and infrastructure as a whole to include roads, bridges, schools, and hospitals. This is positive, and banks have a role to play in terms of financing the construction itself, or else in the purchase of residential properties. BancABC is quite active in this, and in dealing with numerous construction companies in mortgage financing. We recently launched a mortgage product for retail customers, which was innovative in that it could potentially provide more people access to housing. Competition among the banks is forcing us to innovate new products to find fresh avenues for income and customer service. We definitely need new players, and a diversification of the financial sector, with insurance and pension funds being a good example.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Leading international conglomerates see an opportunity in Mozambique for considerable growth, given the market's relative immaturity.
node.subject: Why Mozambique?
node.title: Bantu You Know
node.sections01: We are part of Coca-Cola, which is a franchise bottler, and we have seven franchises across Africa. In Mozambique we have the franchise for the entire country. In terms of volume, it is on par with our business in Tanzania, Kenya, and Uganda, and the returns enable us to invest in the market and develop infrastructure. Per capita consumption across the country is at 25 liters per capita, but as the country becomes richer, higher disposable incomes will lead to greater consumption of beverages. In 2014, we launched our water, Bonaqua, and have plans to launch into other beverage segments. We will continue to drive our range as well as continuing to innovate in terms of flavors and packs. Certainly, with the capacity that we are set to have in Maputo, the capacity we introduced in 2013 in Chimoio, and our plans for Nampula, we are excited about the huge potential of this market.
node.sections11: On a global basis we have operations in 180+ countries. What makes Mozambique unique to British American Tobacco (BAT) is its classification as a high growth potential market. This is driven by several environmental factors within the country. The first is that Mozambique has a population base of over 24 million people, and when we look at ongoing developments in the country, we see the economic circumstances of citizens are improving rapidly. As consumers' disposable income improves, there is an improvement not just in total sales volumes, but also in the brand mix that consumers decide to purchase, with notable growth envisaged for the premium offers. The second unique area within Mozambique is that there is a significant population below the age of 18, which means we'll have a significant number of consumers coming of age, while the consumer business is envisaged to increase as people start having better livelihoods. Last year we contributed in excess of $35 million to the government as a combination of all taxes.
node.sections21: With our operations starting in Zambia and eventually moving on to the headquarters in South Africa, Mozambique was considered a gateway for growth in Africa for Tata. We started with the representation of Tata Motors Limited (TML) and also sell vehicles manufactured by TML in Mozambique. As a strategy it was a sound decision to start off with the vehicles, although now we represent other companies of the Tata group. Given the challenges inherent to the Mozambican market, we opted for an incremental growth strategy where the first step was to build brand visibility. What we want to do from now on is secure a larger presence through representation of other group companies and to take the Tata brand forward in Mozambique. Having said that, we have now diversified into other businesses in Mozambique such as pharmaceuticals, steel trading, consumer durables, and chemicals. We have also developed a relationship with Vale through group company Voltas Engineering Services, which has contracts to maintain and service mining equipment owned by the company.
node.sections31: Our footprint in Mozambique dates back more than 60 years. Since 1951, it has included major reference projects such as Africa's first operational control center for the railway connection between the capital Maputo and Ressano Garcia. This is why we believe there is a legacy that binds us together and creates an environment favorable to do business in Mozambique, while we keep supporting the country development has done so far. In the past, we have partnered work on the prominent Cahora Bassa project. And as in the past we are ready to work on new projects and challenges in the energy sector and keep writing a page in the country's history. The production of gas discovered off the coast of Mozambique will emerge as an important area for innovation. Siemens possesses the know-how, products, solutions, and services necessary to help its customers to extract these resources safely and efficiently. Our gas turbines are the most efficient in the world.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Chairman of the Board and General Director
node.intervieweelist2company: Association of International Pharmaceutical Manufacturers (AIPM) & General Manager Kazakhstan, Central Asia & Caucasus IPSEN PHARMA
node.previewsummary: The growth of both pharmaceutical production and manufacturing in the country is creating both new opportunities and new challenges for the sector, and both local and global industry leaders are interested in the market.
node.subject: Pharmaceuticals
node.title: Cure for your Ills
node.sections01: Kazakhstan has the most stable political and investment favorable climate in the region. Around 4% of the country's GDP is spent on healthcare, and there is a growing pace of state investment in the healthcare sector. The overall vision for the health system is reflected in the State Health Care Development Program for 2011—2015 and the Strategic development plan of the Republic of Kazakhstan till 2020. One of the targets of the 2020 development program is to raise life expectancy from 62-63 to 73: this is a good target and could be achieved given certain special health care reforms, which should concentrate on the prophylaxis of disease, which includes immunization of the population.
node.sections11: Our main business lies in the distribution of medical supplies. We have reached certain success in this area and can call ourselves the number one distributor on Kazakhstan market. At the moment we are working on a vertically integrated structure for our company, aimed at our presence on all the sectors of pharmaceutical business, from manufacturing to retail. Our project for manufacturing of medical supplies is in the process of its realization, and we hope to start the validation of a manufacturing system next year. Our structure also includes a retail company. In two years, we are planning to double the number of our pharmacies and complete the project of a national retail network. At the moment we boast the largest branch network in Kazakhstan.
node.sections21: Kazakhstan has become attractive to the pharmaceutical industry companies that decided to start manufacturing here. There is real support from the government for local producers of pharmaceutical products, meaning that they do not have to pay certain taxes. If you export your products to another country, there may be some problems, as the firms are strongly encouraged to sell their products to the state. SK Pharmacy is the sole distributor for the Ministry of Health, and has signed a contract with local producers, which will last seven years. Several major international companies were established in Shymkent and Almaty, and there are Russian producers working out of Karaganda. This segment will continue to expand as Kazakhstan has committed serious investment to pharmaceutical manufacturing and the pharmaceutical business. For us, and for other pharmaceutical companies, Kazakhstan has become attractive. In all of Central Asia, only Kazakhstan has a comprehensive reimbursement program. We have a number of high-tech products in pharmaceuticals, oncology, and other areas.
node.sections31: Getz Pharma's mission is to develop, produce, and market safe, effective, and quality medicines that will improve the health and quality of life of men, women, and children. As a new company, we registered only 11 products in Kazakhstan. Now, our business is worth more than $2 million per year in Kazakhstan. Our tender business has been growing from year-to-year, but last year's devaluation has influenced our business, of course. Moreover the government is also giving priority to local manufacturers for tenders which is understandable, but our strategy is to deliver more and more modern and effective medications to a Kazakhstan reimbursement system with reasonable prices. We offer products for diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, bronchitis, asthma, allergy, and obesity. We also have antibiotics. The retail market is oriented towards American and Western European companies. The culture is that whatever is manufactured in Europe is estimated as the top-class. Now, according to changing situations, people cannot afford to buy only innovator's brands, and people prefer to buy generics from Eastern Europe, Russia, and Belarus.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Trucks are big business in Kazakhstan, with many clients in it for the long haul. The providers themselves are also concerned with maintaining safety standards and developing a qualified workforce.
node.subject: Trucking
node.title: Rollin’ Rollin’
node.sections01: All the products that we offer are compliant with European safety standards. Our vehicles also have numerous safety systems, such as advanced breaking, or a system that helps control the truck and wakes the driver if the truck veers out of its lane. Environmental safety is another side of the story when it comes to the trucks that we sell, and our oil and used parts must be disposed of in an environmentally friendly manner. Whenever possible, the waste that is being produced is recycled. MAN also mandates the professional training of our staff. Our mechanics are continuously trained, and the company makes this investment so that our clients have complete peace of mind when it comes to their own investments and safety. Like any healthy company, we have our ambitions. The company wants to grow and maintain our leading position in the national market. MAN has everything necessary to achieve this goal; a good team, a high-quality product, and the transfer of knowledge and services to our clients. In concrete terms, we want to increase our sales volume, as well as the amount of vehicles being produced, and we want to expand our service capacity in the country.
node.sections11: The biggest share of our sales in Kazakhstan is the long haul business, basically long-distance transportation. In the long term, we're also targeting the construction and mining business. These two segments will expand in parallel and also with the overall growth of Kazakhstan's economy. The long haul segment will continue to grow because of Kazakhstan's importance and position as a transit country between China, Russia, and Europe. We expect that segment to grow, especially with the completion of new roads. The roads on the Chinese and Russian sides are not fully completed and the roads in Kazakhstan will require even more time. But the potential and current entrepreneurs here know that once that connection is made and once that transportation infrastructure is in place, they will start transporting goods in large volume, and there will be a keen need for good long-haul vehicles. Furthermore, Kazakhstan will solidify its status as the main transportation and logistical hub of this region. From Volvo's perspective, it's all about uptime. Our vehicles are advanced, and we know through our high-tech capabilities how to avoid truck breakdowns, by constantly monitoring the condition of the vehicle, which gives us a significant edge.
node.sections21: President Nazarbayev said that developing a qualified workforce is a high priority for the country. There are more and more ambitious young people with good basic knowledge available on the market but the Scania-specific knowledge we have transferred ourselves. We provide, our colleagues with all kinds of training using Scania's global training program. The training is partly organized in Kazakhstan, and partly at Scania's training-facilities in Russia, Sweden, or the Netherlands. Additionally, we bring knowledge to the country. We have some experienced Scania colleagues working with us here in Kazakhstan that we brought in from abroad to help us implement local standards, to teach and develop the existing human capital. Training for Scania is fundamental, and it is as important as personnel. Scania opened its first office in Kazakhstan in 2005, but the real operations started in 2007. Kazakhstan's geographic location is excellent, and we believe that the road transport between China and Russia and Europe will leverage this situation. The Silk Road is the backbone of the transport business, and, moreover, the country is economically and politically stable. The confluence of these factors makes Kazakhstan one of the most important players in Central Asia.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: More complex consumption patterns go hand-in-hand with integration into the global economy. In Kazakhstan, this is especially apparent in construction and manufacturing where firms are growing increasingly sophisticated.
node.subject: Construction
node.title: Pile it On
node.sections01: All our products are certified according to international standards. At this stage there are two types of cement that are used—dry and the wet cement. Most of our production capacity is of the wet method. However, all the new production capacities that we are adding is for dry method concrete, because those are more energy efficient, and more economical in terms of volume. All the local producers are colleagues, but also competitors in some sense. In this regard, the modernization and optimization of our production capacity is to keep up with the high level of competition. We continually invest in updating and modernizing our production capacities. We have recently invested a lot into improving our technology, which improves the technological process of manufacturing. This allows us to be at the forefront of the industry, and keeps us competitive.
node.sections11: Half of all the cars produced worldwide contain Sika products. Considering that automobile manufacturing in the heart of Central Asia is growing at remarkable rate, we expect the size and sophistication of our operations here to expand. We are in contact with Asia Auto, as they are building new factories at the moment and we are currently negotiating with them. Our company plans to develop the automotive segment in the future. We are in touch with production chains and locomotive factories in Astana. Sika provided them samples last year, however they still have to activate production this year. We are expecting great capacities from Asia Auto's new factories, but it will be at the end of this year, or the start of 2016. We will sell them silicon, mastics, and fixing materials. The construction sector is our real bread and butter. From foundation to roofing, we can supply most of the materials. For construction, we can start from the beginning to the end. Our clients are both private and public, and we work with the whole industry. Perhaps 80% of our business is in construction. Last year, 20-25% of our sales were in Astana, but in the next two years we expect it will reach 50-60% because of Expo.
node.sections21: The real estate and construction market in Kazakhstan is currently booming. As far as the construction sector is concerned, by 2020 Kazakhstan will become the second largest market in the CIS and Eastern Europe region, second only to Russia. This country is an important market, despite the hard times we faced in 2008 and 2009. Hilti is committed to establishing a sustainable business in Kazakhstan. The Energy Sector is a pillar of the national economy. The oil and gas business is of significant importance to us. Not only do we manufacture power tools, we also sell a lot of very specific products designed for the oil and gas industry. If you look at the oil and gas industry from the power tool sector, for us it is about 13% of potential volume. The rest is from specific projects that come from our engineers such as installation systems, fire stopping products, anchors and direct fastening systems. We work very closely with the key oil and gas companies in the west of the country. As for mining we are focused mainly on uranium by providing solutions to the mining industries.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: The hospitality sector in Kazakhstan is developing and expanding, and major hotel brands are positioning themselves to take advantage of increased business and leisure travel.
node.subject: Hotel Management
node.title: Stay In Comfort
node.sections01: Kazakhstan is the ninth largest country in the world, and the two leading cities in the hospitality industry here are Almaty (the former capital) and Astana (the new capital). Almaty attracts more people probably because it has a longer history than Astana. However, Astana's potential is significant. Astana has gone from nowhere to having seven international chain hotels. The Marriott only opened in August 2014, and I think the potential is significant because of the willingness of the government to capitalize on events such as Expo 2017. You cannot create an event like Expo 2017 without having a solid network of hotels. The hotels create an attraction for certain events, and economic potential. Once the visa process becomes easier, and it is more convenient to access Kazakhstan by air, this will help to make the country even more attractive. The fact that Astana is a new city has managed to generate a buzz. Kazakhstan's President has a very clear vision, and not a short-term one.
node.sections11: I have been here for the past 20 years, and when I first arrived there were no five-star hotels. I am proud of Kazakhstan; all of my department heads are local, including the chef. All of them have an international profile, they studied in Switzerland or in the UK, and they are perfectly fluent in English with excellent training. We just shape them to give them the mentality and hospitality standards of the Hilton. In the hospitality industry, especially here in Kazakhstan, human resources are the most important element. We provide around 8,000-9,000 different training courses in many languages including Mandarin, Russian, Spanish, and Turkish. The entire staff has access to, and the right to take, these training courses. There is some mandatory training of course, but there are optional courses as well if they want to develop themselves; we are investing time and money on our staff. We are investing in our human capital.
node.sections21: The hospitality industry in Kazakhstan is developing. Back in 1997 in Kazakhstan, there were only two international hotels, the Hyatt Regency and the Regent Hotel, which have now been re branded as the Inter Continental Hotel. There were no other establishments that could be viewed as international hotels, and today, there are approximately 6,000 rooms, running from two-star non-branded accommodation to five-star suites. Moreover, there are approximately 1,000 new rooms under construction that will be on the market in the next year and a half. The room supply has increased notably, and will continue to do so. The new visa regime launched by Kazakhstan last year is also helping the country to attract new investors as a developing and promising country for the hotel industry, and we are mostly receiving business travelers—the leisure sectors have yet to become relevant to the accommodation industry. If Kazakhstan invests, then its role will increase.
node.sections31: Five-star resort service is growing in Kazakhstan. In Astana, we are looking forward to the opportunities of 2017, but the government should consider what will happen after once Expo closes in September 2017. I consider Astana to be a fast-growing city with a multimillion dollar budget, and there are many opportunities for us in terms of business to expand and constantly improve our service in the atmosphere of healthy competition, especially considering Expo 2017. I believe that there is a great opportunity to continue making Astana an ideal place for events, fairs, conferences for software, and even a place for large and specific expos to take place four or five times a year in Central Asia. Currently, there is nothing like that in terms of large expositions in this part of the world.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Having moved its capital from Almaty to Astana, real estate sector executives in Kazakhstan discuss the benefits and pitfalls of each.
node.subject: The Real Estate market
node.title: Two Towers
node.sections01: Astana is a fast-growing city and is one of our target markets—it is in our strategic development plan. We have a very good understanding of how the local Almaty market works. It is essential to know the market properly to come up with a good product or service. A factor that requires consideration is the market segment we will operate in for Astana. As for Almaty, the market volume is as great as in Astana. However, given that there are 1.5 million people living in Almaty, and 800,000 to 850,000 people living in Astana, the demand is not the same in terms of quantity. Nevertheless, Almaty's market is very saturated, whereas the demand for housing and so the prices have been growing much faster in Astana.
node.sections11: The FDI level in Kazakhstan is increasing. Looking at the past six or seven years, it has grown steadily, year on year. The real estate and construction sector will surely develop and bring in many international investors thanks to the many international events and government programs, such as the 2011-20 Housing and Utilities Sector Modernization Programme, Expo 2017, or the Affordable Housing 2020 Programme. These programs provide stimulus to the real estate market not only in Astana or Almaty, but also throughout the entire region. My day-to-day operations are connected to the commercial real estate market only, so that is why preparations for the Expo seem the most interesting to me.
node.sections21: The devaluation most certainly has affected both the demand andthe offer. The real estate market reacted accordingly; we saw a minor increase in construction costs. Subsequently, the offer in the real estate market became more costly. For a certain period the buyer demand decreased, but later on returned to normal. By the end of 2014, the situation started changing again in view of another devaluation, which affected both the construction costs and the demand for real estate. In 2015 we will focus on the projects we started in 2014. We have quite a large volume of work on our table. We will certainly have new projects as well, and in the near future, we are bringing some new projects to Almaty. If we come across interesting projects in other regions we will definitely consider participating in them.
node.sections31: In terms of the trends, you have to understand that Kazakhstan is a very big country. If we compare Almaty and Astana, for example, in Almaty the seismic activity defines the market and makes it quite different than Astana. Concrete constructions are being used for buildings that can withstand earthquakes up to nine on the Richter scale, which obviously is reflected in the pricing as well. In Almaty, the pricing policy is also defined by a strong continental climate, as it is very cold in the winter and very hot in the summer. Subsequently, appreciation of construction and equipment costs takes place, which provides comfort of living in difficult climatic conditions. Almaty is a huge city. It's a megapolis. Recently, we have seen an increase in demand for real estate, especially when it comes to residential real estate. We see an increase in foreigners coming and buying apartments here.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Ensuring access to quality medical care is a challenge in a country where large distances often separate patients from the right care, and where the economy is still developing. The solution in Kazakhstan is government incentives, and the private sector's response.
node.subject: Hospitals and Clinics
node.title: Toast of the Town
node.sections01: The money the government is putting into the healthcare sector is acceptable in my opinion and it is not just going into consulting, but also into hospitals, systems, and processes. Kazakhstan has restructured its healthcare governance. What was the Ministry of Health is now the Ministry of Healthcare and Social Development. In my mind, that is a prudent transition, because the two are connected. Social development has to be a part of health care and vice versa.
