In 2015 we will be able to evaluate how the transition performed, and by all indications it is going to do well. The issue in Kazakhstan is that citizens do not do a very good job at taking care of their own health. We do not exercise enough, we do not watch what we eat, and that leads to cardiovascular disease, which is largely preventable with exercise and diet. We need to use exercise and dietary discretion as medicine instead of tablets and injections. That said, there is also progress being made in this area.
node.sections11: It is cheaper and easier, in fact, to treat diseases at an earlier stage and prevent certain diseases. In doing so, we can avoid hospitalizing the patient, a process that can end up being quite costly. To help avoid many of these expenditures, HealthCity is dedicated to the early diagnosis of disease. Our facilities have been designed for patients who are interested in monitoring their health over the long term. That is, for people who want to invest in their health. People are welcome to visit and receive a comprehensive diagnostic package. Instead of traveling to South Korea or Europe, for example, they can receive reliable medical services in Kazakhstan. Family and pediatric medicine, and diagnostics for women are our fields of specialization and cover a wide range of preventive services that can save patients time and money in the long run. The goal is to start moving away from the outdated Soviet medical approach, and adopt a proactive—rather than reactive—style of healthcare.
node.sections21: Our national program “Salamatty“ is being spread not only by the government, but also by private sector. Every single patient has the right to choose which hospital they will be treated at. The difference is that public clinics have funding from the government, which we do not receive. However, we can still bid for government tenders. For example, nowadays cardiology is very important in Kazakhstan. Also, extracorporeal fertilization—and we take part in these programs. Our hospital works to fully integrate itself into the national health program, even though we do not have access to the main budget. There is a widespread assumption these days that private healthcare is an alternative to public healthcare, but this is not the case. Like education, the private sector occupies just 10% of the overall healthcare sector. Out of this 10%, around 80% of practices are represented by dentistry. Establishments like ours, scientific institutes and medical centers, are extremely rare. Today, private hospitals are usually small enterprises with a very narrow area of focus.
node.sections31: The healthcare sector in general rates quite positively. The government spends time and attention on providing healthcare, especially in the rural regions, and not just in major cities like Almaty and Astana. There are more and more cardio centers. The number of tuberculosis cases has been decreasing over the years. There are an increasing number of programs that are related to different aspects of health. They are also integrated with international health programs. There are a number of research centers that are focusing on neurological and cardio issues for which, in the past, people had to travel abroad to receive treatment. One of the huge shortages in Kazakhstan is in oncology treatment. This is something the government is working hard to address. Kazakhstan certainly has potential, and the government is doing a lot to improve the qualifications and training for doctors, as well as introducing new technology to improve healthcare. There was a period during the 1990s when many doctors left the country or changed careers. But in the last couple of years the government has been working hard to promote training for doctors.
node.sections41: International investment is playing an important role in the development of health services here. Competition is the drive of improvement and hence, growth of the private medical sector is essential, first of all for encouraging competition and improving the quality of provided services. For example, quite a few years ago all the healthcare facilities in Turkey were state-owned, but recently the number of private medical companies have grown which resulted in higher service quality standards across the country. We are now witnessing similar changes in Kazakhstan. The private sector is more flexible in addressing the challenges, we're able to introduce new methods and solutions much faster. That's what leads to positive changes in the sector. Sema Hospital spent over $10 million on equipment for the hospital. Our hospital is using the latest American, German, Japanese and European technologies. We're also representing Fatih University, one of the top Turkish universities, which runs hospitals throughout Turkey.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Chairwoman of the Board of Directors
node.previewsummary: Kazakhstan is ripe for insurance penetration, with the sector set to grow in line with the economy.
node.subject: Insurance Companies
node.title: Under Construction
node.sections01: High economic growth opportunities and low insurance penetration in Kazakhstan point to large growth opportunities. It is important to understand who is buying insurance in Kazakhstan. The largest customer is the corporate sector; we call these legal entities such as big oil companies, banks, some producing companies, malls, and similar entities. As for individuals, only the middle class buys insurance here. The population has not accumulated any wealth or anything they could lose. People don't buy earthquake insurance because they expect the government to help them out. It will take years to develop insurance culture in order to motivate individuals to buy more insurance products or just to understand the role these products play in the success of their business. There is compulsory third-party motor vehicle liability insurance here, and everybody has to buy it. However, Eurasia is not extensively involved in this business. We prefer to work with voluntary lines of insurance such as property, property damage, business interruption, machinery failure, aviation, marine, satellite, construction risk, erection risk, and ecology. Compulsory lines of business are, unfortunately, not profitable. Eurasia benefited from its international expansion. Having a presence in such emerging markets as China and India presents an opportunity for Eurasia not just to support its performance but also to successfully withstand the soft cycle.
node.sections11: There are now many local car factories in Kazakhstan that produce vehicles for major car brands, such as Toyota. This growth in the number of cars on the road affects the growth of the insurance industry. At Kompetenz, we try to educate our customers about the advantages of choosing comprehensive insurance over the minimal compulsory insurance that only covers the driver's limited liability. Here there is great potential because Kazakhstani people love their cars. As traffic becomes more intense, accidents will increase. When you compare our road conditions with Russia, for example, they have a claims ratio of up to 90%; we still have 30%, which works to our advantage. In 2014 we pushed hard to develop our retail insurance lines, whereas in 2013 our operations were 90% corporate and 10% retail. Over the year, we increased our retail and SME representation to 40% of our portfolio, bringing our corporate representation down to 60%. In comparison, our net premiums this year have already risen by 30-40%. The harmonization of the legal system is one of my main ambitions for the next three years; the law on insurance was drawn up 15 or 20 years ago, and a rapidly changing environment requires new approaches. We want to emulate the best practices on the market and use them to build our own system here in Kazakhstan. This involves opening more capacity in the national insurance market.
node.sections21: There are about 34 companies in the market, five of which are life insurance companies, while the rest are other types of insurance companies. Within those, there are giant companies such as Eurasia, Kaspi, and BTA, which work internationally and perform reinsurance—they are not direct competitors. The direct competition is the middle segment, where you have Amanat Insurance, Almaty, and London Almaty Insurance, and their strategy is similar in terms of development; but the advantage that Standard has is its path, growth rates, and the progress that the company is making. When we acquired Standard from Astana Finance, we took a number of precautionary measures. Our investment portfolio is very liquid, and very diversified; we do not have non-liquid bonds. At the moment, about 50% of our investments are dollar investments, and our balance is in gain. Of course, the devaluation had an effect on the economy. For example, salaries and some of the other expenses had to be adjusted based on the indexes, but in general we were not negatively affected. In terms of sales, the plan is to sell over KZT5 billion worth of insurance in 2015. We are also looking forward to working with reinsurance, both locally and internationally, as well as finishing the automation process that started two years ago. Of course, we will keep working on developing new projects. The development of family insurance will be another segment to cover and we also plan to work actively on international insurance.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2company: Xerox representative office in Kazakhstan and Central Asia
node.previewsummary: Despite the devaluation causing headaches across the sector, demand remains high for new ICT technologies, both from individuals and businesses.
node.subject: IT Companies
node.title: Log Me On
node.sections01: Overall, it was challenging year. A strong start in January was followed by the event on February 11 that induced us to make new plans for the new reality. The devaluation that took place has definitely affected both the B2C and B2B sectors. Moreover, given the historically strong relations we have with Russia, the situation there has also impacted overall development. Nevertheless, thanks to corrective measures, strong relations with partners, and, first of all, the dedication of every team member, we secured our leading position in the B2C segment and realized a number of important projects in the B2B area. Here, I'd like to especially underline the positive dynamics demonstrated by the healthcare team. This year we are going to fight to win back market share, sales, and reinforce our position in the market. For instance, we suffered some headwinds in kitchen appliances. It is not possible to win all the battles, and this is why we do not prioritize.
node.sections11: Penetration rates compared to the population is in the range of 170% to 180%, but that's based on active SIM cards, which means that some people might not have mobile phones, but some people might have three or four SIM cards. The smartphone penetration rate is still growing. It's still less than 30% according to our statistics. This means that many feature phone users are still migrating to smartphones. This became a major trend last year and this migration will keep continuing, maybe for another two or three years. We are heavily focused on the smartphone market to move basic phone users to smartphones. In terms of 2015, we intend to strengthen our position in the enterprise market and continue our leadership in the Kazakhstani consumer electronics market by introducing new products that will further push the boundaries of innovation and bring new experiences to our consumers, enriching their lives. We will stay true to our commitment of bringing meaningful innovation and inspiring experiences to consumers by introducing new groundbreaking products.
node.sections21: In my opinion, the interest in ICT in Kazakhstan is quite high. Dealing with a wide range of representatives from various branches and sectors in Kazakhstan, we are convinced of this. And this is not just the interest of window shoppers. It is absolutely clear for everyone that it is impossible to organize effective management and production processes without modern ICT, and this applies to both commercial and government organizations. We, as a company that has traditionally been at the forefront of innovations, clearly feel the challenges of the market and try to meet the expectations of our existing and potential customers and partners. A feature of Kazakhstan is that the local market craves innovation. Acquisition and continuous updating of knowledge, including ICT, is a priority for the representatives of the market. In turn, we, as the representatives of one of the largest technological corporations, use our experience and knowledge to make this happen.
node.sections31: The IT sector is growing quickly in the country. There is a lot of investment in IT infrastructure projects because the government and state bodies understand the importance of IT. The Ministry is also supporting a lot of initiatives, and we have had a number of talks with local institutions about the future development of the country. Nazarbayev University is playing an important part in these activities as well. Cisco initiated its presence in Kazakhstan when the first Russian office was set up. After that, the value and potential in the market became even more apparent, so the local office was set up. We have a lot of people working here and we continue to hire. There are two offices, in Almaty and Astana. We see Astana as a point of growth, so we continue to invest heavily in the capital. Our future is there. An important part of our activity here over the last 10 years has been the establishment of Cisco Academies. This is innovation in the sense of education. We teach teachers, and we support them with teaching materials. This allows universities to offer courses to students and issue Cisco certificates.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Aviation Industry
node.title: Onwards and Upwards
node.sections01: The history of our company started with a single helicopter. It was the first foreign-manufactured helicopter in Kazakhstan. Soon afterwards the shareholders decided to start an aviation company, because according to the law of Kazakhstan all helicopters, including the ones that are used in rescue missions and commercial flights, can only be put into exploitation if owned by an airline company. Today, the company owns and uses 13 helicopters and two airplanes manufactured abroad (Eurocopter, Bell, Cessna). Our aircrafts provide private (VIP transfers, tourist flights) and government-oriented services. For example, we work with the Ministry of Agriculture in their forestry department, with the Ministry of Health we provide ambulance aviation services. Our company also collaborates with large oil, gas, and energy companies, monitoring gas pipelines and powerlines, and with the Geological committee that uses our aircraft for aerogeophysical research. We also work with the Ministry of Emergency Situations and make flyovers to explore mountain lakes around the Almaty region to determine their congestion or conduct search and rescue operations. When it comes to private sector, we take our visitors to visit scenic landmarks in the Almaty region, of which we have around 20 standard routes, or we can offer individually-designed routes at the request of our customers. Quite often, clients require urgent VIP transportation for long distances, to Taldykorgan, Bishkek, Issyk-Kul, and Taraz.
node.sections11: Internally, Western Kazakhstan is promising. The Atyrau area is not well served. The European blacklist has restricted it because the flights that go from here to Atyrau also connect onto Amsterdam. The scope to develop that area has been very limited. Every so often, new operators enter the market. They try to challenge Air Astana on these routes. What I admire about Air Astana is that they hold their ground. They do what they are good at. I know from experience, from talking and working with Air Astana that safety is a very high priority for them. An increase in the number of international airlines that service Kazakhstan would invigorate the sector as well, not just to Almaty but also to Astana. Whether it is through the hub and spoke model, where airlines fly into Kazakhstan and then fly somewhere else, or just serve Europe, Asia, and the Middle East from Kazakhstan, any such developments spell good news.
node.sections21: Only recently since the financial crisis of 2008 has business aviation in Kazakhstan gradually recovered, and Jet Airlines was one of the pioneers in the segment, being established in 2004. Abdullatip Issaev (current CEO of Jet Airlines) and I worked in this company before, for different periods from 2004 to 2009. The company's key goal back in those days was to manage a fleet of the corporate jets owned by shareholders mostly for their corporate needs. The first jets that the company owned were two Tupolev-134s used in passenger aviation, but reconfigured by the manufacturer into corporate jets with luxury interiors. As we started operating those jets, we realized that the operating costs in terms of flight hours was too high due to fuel consumption. The age of the planes was something that worried our shareholders, too, as both of the jets were over 20 years old. Hence, we began developing alternative programs for our shareholders and started considering foreign jets that were a lot more economical. We were the first in Kazakhstan to acquire directly from the manufacturers and operate the Cessna Citation X, the Hawker 850XP, and the Hawker Beechcraft Premier IA jets, and that was a great a success. We are now providing consultancy services and were the first to bring in the Gulfstream G200 jet for one of the big local banks.
node.sections31: We started the business in 1998 with a focus on VIP charter flights. We focus on VIP Charters we started in 1998. Re-oriented in 2011 for scheduled regular flights. We started out with a mix of Soviet and other foreign aircraft, such as Yakovlev-40, Falcon-20, Bac1-11, and Tu-154. Starting in 2011, we began our regular flights. Our first aircraft on these routes was a Fokker 100, the perfect vehicle for this region because it has enough range and fuel space, and optimal passenger capacity, and is much cheaper than new aircraft. We started with just one aircraft in 2011, and now we have six. In March we expect to obtain one more, and by the end of this year we want to take in at least two more to increase our fleet. The goal is to make Bek Air less costly. At the moment, we are still facing some obstacles to operating a low-cost airline. The economy and mentality of Kazakhstan needs to change. For example, the passengers do not understand if we charge extra for luggage, which is central to this business model. Passengers should gradually get used to such a service.
node.sections41: There are 18 Air Charter Service (ACS) offices worldwide, and we are the youngest, although not the smallest. Before relocating here, our company had operated out of Moscow, but as the number of flights and clients from Kazakhstan increased, the need for a separate office here grew. ACS Kazakhstan works in three directions, namely business aviation, commercial aviation, and cargo charters. Business aviation and private jet flights used to be our biggest service when we opened our branch office in Kazakhstan three years ago. Now we also work in commercial jets, although they are still the smallest part of our local business. The third area, and now the fastest-growing business for us, is cargo charter. The cargo charter business that we undertake is quite complicated. Most clients go to logistics companies, which can provide similar services as us, but we deal with more complicated projects and businesses, which the other players in the market refuse to do. These are mostly oversized cargo, dangerous goods, or goods being shipped to dangerous destinations, some extraordinary cargo, and cargo that is extremely urgent. These services are needed by all sectors. We do not concentrate on any one sector per se, but most of our clients for these unconventional shipments are in telecoms and the oil and gas industries. For the moment we have only five brokers, three of whom are working on private jet charters. We have two people on the cargo side, and we're planning on hiring more brokers this year.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Chairman of the Board of Directors
node.previewsummary: Energy production and power generation are vital to the Kazakhstani national economy, and specialized support services are the veritable engine on which the sector runs.
node.subject: Ancillary Support
node.title: Power Punch
node.sections01: The large energy consuming companies, for example KazMunaiGas, are obligated to do a yearly energy audit, and we are helping them by providing these energy audits. We have received the accreditation for these audits; however, we do not want to limit ourselves to energy audits. AKEE is already developing additional complex mapping of energy consuming processes in order to find—through the use of analytical methodology—large energy saving solutions. This advanced service is not available today in Kazakhstan through any domestic entities, but available worldwide. We are now bringing these services and the associated methodology into the local market. Our current constraint is that in Kazakhstan, there is a noticeable lack of engineers that have been trained to apply this methodology, but with a two-year training process, a solution is not far off.
node.sections11: Alternative power engineering is one of the main priorities in development of the company for the next three years. Now we perform works on the construction of the solar power station, the largest in Central Asia, in Zhambyl region with projected capacity of 50 MW. Now we are negotiations with several investors for future projects with a general capacity of 180 MW. There are four projects on the construction of solar power stations, also one of the new projects is an offshore wind and solar power plant in the Caspian Sea, and another is a wind power plant in the Central Kazakhstan. We also have experience in hydro energy, but here there is little demand in Kazakhstan, therefore we aren't focused on it now. Today we work with 14 manufacturing partners in green energy. We pay great attention to training of our employees who pass regular training on production enterprises abroad. Now we have wide experience in designing and construction in this area. We are one of the few companies in Kazakhstan that has a really strong knowledge base in green energy.
node.sections21: We are actively participating in the renewable energy program. Most of such incentives are run in the Zhambyl region in southern Kazakhstan; there are a significant number of solar projects there. We are currently discussing the possibility of getting involved there with an investor from France. We have also signed the MoUs and all the necessary documentation with a Portuguese company, EFACEC. In fact, Alageum Electric is participating in the World Expo 2017 together with EFACEC. This company has huge experience in setting up solar, wind, and hydropower stations. EFACEC transfers to us their technologies and documentation and provides training for our employees, so that we are able to manufacture their products here in Kazakhstan. Thus, the local content of the products manufactured here will be 60%. The most important component of a solar power station is the inverter system. We are developing our capacities to produce inverter systems for both the domestic and international market.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: In terms of business climate, growth potential, and natural resources, Kazakhstan is fertile ground for both multi-nationals and local firms looking to expand into the region.
node.subject: Why Kazakhstan?
node.title: Steppe Up Your Expectations
node.sections01: EUROBAK was established in 1999 by a number of European companies present at the time in Kazakhstan, and was supported by the EU delegation and a number of embassies of European countries. The main objective of the association is to represent a collective voice of the business community. For now, we have over 150 members, including 30 consulates and embassies from European countries and worldwide. EUROBAK represents European, Kazakhstani, and multinational companies. We stage different types of events, such as meetings with government officials, workshops, working groups and committees, as well as networking events. EUROBAK is one platform where government, businesses, and diplomatic communities can meet. It also plays an active role in promoting Kazakhstan as an attractive investment destination. I believe that it is up to the government to make Kazakhstan more attractive, for example, the rule of law is an important factor for investors when making a decision to work in the country. We are meeting on a regular basis with the Prime Minister and the Cabinet Ministers, where we present the issues that are necessary to address to enhance investment climate and remove trade barriers. Overall, we are very happy to see that there are some extremely positive changes that the government is now introducing.
node.sections11: We have been focusing on the resource base, and also believe that vertically integrated holdings are not the right way to go. Instead, we focus on what we know, and create infrastructure around our line of work. Raimbek combines the kind of work that I do as businessman and as an advisor to the Prime Minister. This helps the company evolve, and is what we are focusing on right now. Diversification has been very important for our economy since the first day of independence, but unfortunately the problem has not been solved yet. Oil and gas is something that Kazakhstan is known for. However, we don't give up and we are still looking for the possibilities for diversification. At this point we have identified agriculture, processing, and transit potential, as well as ecotourism. Of course, it is always better to sell petrochemical products as opposed to crude oil, or heavy equipment as opposed to metal. In terms of Raimbek Group, our strategy does not revolve just around Kazakhstan. We also have facilities in China, as well as CIS countries and the Caucasus, and our products are being sold in these regions as well. Kazakhstan has potential for zonal expansion as it is politically stable, and its geographical position is also very good. Raimbek is focusing on its resource base, and concentrating on three areas.
node.sections21: It is easier to find an investor for projects starting from $10 million, and more effort is required to attract a smaller investment. However, it is still possible, and we are currently using an investment company who helps us with our search. We are confident in the success of our regional projects because mining is one of the priority industries in Kazakhstan, and it gets a lot of attention from the Government. The drilling rods that we are going to produce are a product without which drilling is impossible. Our rods will be made of high-quality steel like those currently imported from Europe, but will be offered at a much lower price as the rods will be produced locally. Success is almost guaranteed. This is an opportunity to start discussions with investors as well. Obviously, the mining industry of Kazakhstan has great potential—Kazakhstan has a large mineral resource base. Mining is a strategic sector of the national economy and therefore receives considerable investments from the state. The market is also making a comeback, following its downturn, thus providing opportunities for companies like LSH to grow with the industry and with the country as a whole.
node.sections31: Carlsberg has a brewery in Kazakhstan and distributors all around the country. In every region of Kazakhstan we have more than one distributor. Carlsberg Kazakhstan is growing, and covers all regions with a population of more than 10,000 people. We have our dedicated sales team working on more distributors. In 2003, we started the modernization of our brewery, including constructing new facilities and introducing high-technology equipment—Carlsberg Group invested a lot of money. From 2003-2010, the company invested $185 million in development, and during 2011-2013, that figure was around $37 million. Carlsberg Group research center selected a special brewing barley Null-Lox, which preserves the freshness of the beer for a long time. These new varieties of barley are highly resistant to diseases, and require less expense for the malt. Carlsberg has strict procedures regarding testing the product. Every month quality managers conduct random purchases of Carlsberg products in every country in which we have operations. Over the last year Carlsberg Kazakhstan earned the highest score for the quality of our product.
node.sections41: Bühler develops original grain processing technologies, designs and manufactures its own machines and devices. Thus, it was inevitable for the company to enter Kazakhstan's market—the country produces 15-20 million tons of grain a year. In the 1990s, when Bühler just started its operations in Kazakhstan, there was lack of mills, and those that existed needed revamping. At the time, the equipment market was highly competitive, but Bühler was the only company who could secure timely delivery of highly-efficient, high-capacity mills in large numbers. Kazakhstan managed to become a big global producers and exporter not only for grains, but also of flour. Our company operates in other sectors than grain processing. We are actively working in pressure die-casting, paints production, and nanotechnologies. On top of that, Bühler is constantly improving its services and staying close to its clients. We are opening service centers across Kazakhstan. One center is already open in Almaty, and next year we are planning to launch a new one in Kostanay. These centers will provide after-sales service, repairs, and we will use them to store spare parts.
node.intervieweelist4position: Head of the Representative Office in Kazakhstan

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Russia Country President and CIS Senior Vice-President
node.previewsummary: Kazakhstan is making serious investments in new energy technologies, and a number of key global players are providing their ideas, people, and support to realize these plans.
node.subject: ENERGY SOLUTIONS
node.title: Energetic Developments
node.sections01: Ican see an unbalance in geographical distribution of power generation, there are several coal power stations in the eastern part of Kazakhstan, but there is need for energy in the western part. There is also a disproportion of energy distribution between the north and south. There is a shortage of energy in the south and number of power stations in the north. In general, the country is heading towards a deficit of energy. There is a need for importing energy and building new power stations, as well as refurbishing the existing one. Because of the vision that is supported by the state, we see increased development of the renewable energy sources like wind or solar. ABB is supporting Kazakhstan in almost all areas mentioned before.
node.sections11: Kazakhstan is still a new market with a lot of possibilities. The country would like to manage its energy use in a better and more responsible way. This is our core business and we are here to help Kazakhstan to make the most of its energy. It is all about connecting products, software, and systems altogether. This breaks down to energy producers and energy consumers. Kazakhstan is unique because of its growing oil and gas sector, where we are one of the leaders in systems for power supply and automation, as well as the transportation of oil and gas. We are one of the main technology suppliers for pipelines, and we have wide automation capabilities. Infrastructure plays an important role in the Kazakhstan market with ports, airports, water treatment, and electricity, and basically everything that enables a better lifestyle and business for the people.
node.sections21: Expo 2017 is attracting serious investment in technologies, and Kazakhstan would like to make Astana a benchmark. Schneider Electric is currently helping 200 cities around the Globe to become more smart and connected. We would like to use our knowledge to create smarter cities in Kazakhstan. Creating a smart city of the scale of Astana from scratch is a dream, so someone needs to make it happen, and we can help in five different areas. First of all we have the electricity grid where we are able to actively connect every user. The Smart Grid makes energy work with various applications and maximizes the potential of electrical devices. We are moving to a more efficient energy solution with better distribution. The second area is water, and we are helping with water transport and safety, as we know it is as important for the people as energy is.
node.sections31: Our activity is not focused on end-user business. After the success of our thermo technology, power tools, security systems, after sales, and hydraulics units, we have decided to forge into packaging as well. We are responsible for all the neighboring countries from our base in Almaty—Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Turkmenistan. We established our regional presence in all of these countries, and we are doing well there with our components and products. We started our centralized warehouse here in Almaty last year to improve our logistics. In Kazakhstan we have implemented several projects. In 2014 we developed a 200 MW boiler house in Shymkent, in Astana we work for Akorda, which is the Residential Palace of the President, and we have developed a 20.8 MW boiler house for Nazarbayev University. We have also managed a project in Turkmenistan, where we have reconstructed 11 boiler houses.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: In such an expansive country, logistics services become crucial for any business activity. Industry leaders meet the country's unique transportation challenges through strategic regional partnerships and innovative solutions.
node.subject: Logistics
node.title: Nick of Time
node.sections01: Logistics companies face complicated structural changes in this business. Though the tenge was devalued by almost 20%—which had a negative effect on many importing businesses—the flow of goods within the Customs Union between Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, as well as China, grew. Moreover, thanks to the support we received from our coordinating office in Switzerland, we managed to maintain our market share. We also manage a Germany-based company under the Militzer & Munch umbrella called InterRail, and they have just signed a contract with the Kazakhstani Railway Authority. The agreement allows us to develop railway shipments because we will have access to a special economic zone, get special rates, and be operating in an advantageous environment. I would estimate that 50% to 60% of all our imminent business is driven by the railroad, and the rest is road, airfreight, and customs clearance. Altogether we have 50 employees for Militzer & Munch and Fedex employs 100. There are nine offices, including our head office here in Almaty.
node.sections11: For the DPD group of companies in the CIS, Kazakhstan is very important. In terms of profitability, our operations in Kazakhstan come second after Russia, and ahead of our business in Ukraine and Belarus. By revenue, of course, it is much lower than Russia, but this is an emerging market and we believe our share will be much greater in the future. Parcels are currently leading the market, but in the category of consolidated cargo, we are number one in the country. In 2013 we penetrated the business to consumer (B2C) market; a new market for us. E-commerce is also growing in Kazakhstan, which is why we were able to take on several well-known B2C projects. It is particularly easy for us to apply and develop new technologies because we have our own IT solutions, through our IT staff in Russia, who have developed our entire electronic resource management (ERM) system for all our operations in the CIS region.
node.sections21: Asia Sky Express, a Turkish company, wanted to establish a network in the former Soviet Union in Central Asia and the Caucuses region. It opened offices in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Tajikistan, and now we have a network in the Central Asian region. For the first time, we have worked with TNT as an agent for delivery to Central Asia. All the cargo that goes to neighbouring countries goes through Almaty and Kazakhstan. Now the company is also acting as a bridge to Russia. Thanks to the customs union, it has become easier to a certain extent to deliver cargo to its members, and we also see an increasing amount of cargo traveling on these routes. It is now impossible to offer high quality service without having an elaborate IT program. We have developed our own software—ASELogic—which is tailor-made for our needs. We are open to cooperation with any foreign companies that need express logistics services in our region.
node.sections31: In 2014 we had strong revenue growth and achieved an impressive gross profit. We have a unique service in Aramex called “Shop and Ship“ which we created for our clients. It is hard for clients to do online shopping and get their orders in Kazakhstan, as transit time is a major challenge for them, as well as customs clearance. There are around 20 international companies providing courier services and freight forwarding. There are more than 70 local companies, and all of these are providing good levels of service. We have more than 45 developers working on our website and technology to develop customer service. The current situation in Ukraine has transformed our business, as our trucks were coming from Europe through Ukraine, and then Russia to Kazakhstan. Now transit time is longer and documents are more complicated to obtain. The situation between China and Kazakhstan is the same. I hope that circumstances will improve over the next three to five years.
node.sections41: A business cannot grow faster or bigger than the market itself. People often ask why our operations are growing so much faster in certain countries. This is because economic drivers vary greatly by country, especially in the service sector. The transport and logistics sector in Kazakhstan is challenging due to its immense territory, low population concentration, and an imbalance between import and export of finished goods. Moreover, the Kazakh economy is quite dependent on natural resources, while the industrial manufacturing base is rather limited. Our strategy is to be closer to where our customers are and meet their turnkey transport and logistics requirements. Over the past 20 years, we have established eight locations across Kazakhstan and 20 in the rest of the CIS, which makes Globalink one of the leading full service transport and logistics providers in the market. Public sector and government active involvement in the infrastructure development is crucial. However, sometimes you need to step back and draw a line delineating the public and private sectors to avoid any conflict of interest.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Most banks in the country were able to mitigate the devaluation, and economic slowdown through a combination of rigorous financial planning and smart investment.
node.subject: Local Banks
node.title: Good Times/Bad Times
node.sections01: The National Bank took the right step to reduce the shock of possible future events as volatility of the Russian Ruble has its direct impact on Kazakhstani producers, exporting to neighboring countries. However, from the business point of view, this did not significantly affect the banking sector, as the majority of local banks do not have massive foreign currency liabilities since the last world economic crisis and thus, KZT liabilities and lending are well balanced. But ultimately, we are in the same boat as our clients. They rely upon our bank and the bank steps in when it has to, so that our clients feel safe and sound. Compared to last year, assets grew by 38%-39% and loan portfolio grew by 39%. Deposits and current accounts have grown by 33%. Capital, which is one of the most important indicators, has grown by 41% and the bank's net income grew by more than 45%. All these achievements were as per nine months of 2014, and we expect to retain this level of performance for the remainder of the year.
node.sections11: The worst effect of devaluation was a shift in our client's preferences; they moved towards US dollar deposits from tenge ones. This devaluation has undermined trust in the national currency. The retail deposit structure has also changed: before the devaluation, tenge deposits accounted for roughly 60% of the total deposits as opposed to 40% now. However, the National Bank of Kazakhstan (NBK) launched a relevant and timely initiative and started quoting swap operations. As a result of the February devaluation, March rates reached 100% overnight. Obviously, we faced liquidity problems, due to a tenge shortage. During the summer of 2014 we performed a number of swap operations, and the situation has improved. However, it is necessary for the banking system to continue to restore trust in the tenge. As an institution, we are adjusting well. : As of November 1, 2014 the bank's assets equals 307.4 billion tenge, representing a 54.6 billion tenge (21.6%) increase from the beginning of the year.
node.sections21: The growth of our assets last year increased from $100 million to $300 million. Currently, we have about $700 million in assets. The shareholders began actively investing in the bank; the bank's capital historically has been around KZT5 billion. This year it was increased to 11 and by the end of this year we plan to reach KZT20 billion. At the beginning of this year, Qazaq Bank was 28th out of the 38 banks in Kazakhstan. Currently, it is the 21st. This speaks to an aggressive growth strategy. After the financial crisis, a lot of banks here in Kazakhstan became more rigid in terms of giving loans, they became more selective with the projects and more risk averse. This was a good opportunity for Qazaq Bank to expand its loan base to acquire new creditors with a good history. We targeted creditors without toxic assets. We decided not to focus on a particular sector; we are equally present in corporate retail and SMEs. In essence, we are trying to reduce the levels of bureaucracy, have a more client-oriented approach, and speed up our loan process, all of which allows us to become more efficient and draw clients from other banks.
node.sections31: Various factors have had an impact on the financial situation in Kazakhstan. These include the devaluation of the currency, and also the political impact of what is going on in Russia and Ukraine, and the resulting uncertainty there, especially in terms of its impact on the customs union. The Russian ruble has also been devaluing and that has created certain issues for us. President Nazarbayev has laid out some guidelines that highlight the government's support for the national economy. At the moment we are clarifying our strategy for the upcoming years. Our bank had positive results in 2013, increasing our loan portfolio by more than 20%, beating the market average growth by nearly 10%. We have achieved a strong profitability in all of our business lines. In 2014, we were more focused on increasing the quality of our existing portfolio in all areas. We have been dealing with our remedial portfolio, and our work with overdue loans allowed us to achieve a NPL level of 13%, one of the lowest levels in the banking sector of the country.
node.sections41: On November 28, 2014, the bank closed its doors as “HSBC Bank Kazakhstan“ and next business day reopened as Altyn Bank. By purchasing HSBC Bank Kazakstan, Halyk Group acquired strong client base, sound business practices, highly skilled English speaking employees, and client-oriented corporate culture. Looking back it was a big leap of faith to believe that client loyalty will survive change of such magnitude, but it all paid off as clients continued to bank with us after the acquisition. On corporate banking side, we will continue to work with our existing clients—large multinational and state-owned national companies. There are very few banks in Kazakhstan that can provide same level of service to these clients, as it requires extensive international experience and deep understanding of clients' businesses and needs. In retail, we will develop new private banking offering for high net worth individuals (HNWI). Altyn Bank is uniquely positioned to take advantage of growing needs of HNWI by leveraging its client relationship model the bank used for years in the mass-affluent segment. Last but not the least, we will work on developing digital banking and other online services.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Health Insurance
node.title: The Place To Heal
node.sections01: In the past 15 years, since the moment Humana became part of the Grupo Conclina C.A., we have learned a lot and moved from being a company in the insurance sector to what we are today; an enterprise that operates in the health sector. We have implemented a successful strategy to provide high-quality health services to our clients and we now want to ensure that this relationship grows and becomes a true partnership. This means a new approach to the company's strategy, which is our main goal for the future. Also, we want to be an active part of the process to build a high-quality health system in the country through a network of clinics and hospitals. Being part of the most important health benefits group in the country, Conclina, to which Hospital Metropolitano also belongs, we know the importance of having strategic alliances with the best medical providers. Our aim is that our members receive timely medical services and are attended to with quality equipment and infrastructure.
node.sections11: Ecuador is one of our more important markets right now. Best Doctors started its Latin American operations here in Ecuador. The country has a dynamic economy. We do our third highest volume of business in Ecuador, just behind Mexico and Venezuela. If we account for sales per capita, Ecuador is our most valuable market. During our six years of operations in Ecuador, we have experienced remarkable growth. Best Doctors is a Global company. Best Doctors has enjoyed a 30% average growth rate over the years. Even though we started operations in Ecuador six years ago, we only started commercializing our products a year and a half later. We are set to reach $20 million in sales, and we have experienced growth rates of 40% every year. These numbers have earned us the reputation as one of the leading companies in the country. The insurance culture is still in its first stages of development, and Ecuadoreans are just starting to realize the importance of insurance products. Right now, only around 15% of Ecuador's population has private health insurance. This figure is low, but it shows opportunities for growth in the Ecuadorean insurance market.
node.sections21: Insurance is certainly a growing market that is becoming more sophisticated. In general, that means that there are more products. Another indicator we are seeing is market consolidation. There are too many companies for the size of the market. Companies are merging, and international companies are buying local entities and consolidating them. This pattern is set to continue over the next few years, which is positive both for the industry, and the customer. Larger, consolidated companies are able to bring better products and services to the market. About seven or eight years ago, Bupa decided to continue its growth story in Latin America. It acquired several companies working in the insurance sector, and one of them, Amedex, had offices here in Ecuador. Latin America, and Ecuador in particular, fit Bupa's profile, as a developing market. We have invested in growing our business in this market, and strategically, the company has a long-term commitment. Bupa has a very aggressive growth plan, and we want to quadruple the size of the company within five years. That is a challenging, but achievable goal, and our corporate business is a key component in our efforts to achieve this.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: A healthy real estate sector and a balanced housing market can be a key driving force behind a strong economy, something that Ecuador has its sights on.
node.subject: Residential
node.title: A Place to Stay
node.sections01: The market is evolving along similar lines to Latin American countries, such as Peru, Uruguay, Argentina, or Chile. Until 2009, the industry was quite basic. Since then, the market changed with the public becoming more exigent, more demanding in terms of design, quality, functionality, and the equipment that we fit our buildings out with. Two examples of our answer to that new demand is Ciudad del Rí­o and Karibao. Before Ciudad del Rí­o, people tended to live backward to the river. In this sense, we have followed European trends as it is to live in a river-view property, where they can enjoy the quality of life associated with the peaceful colors of the water and clear skies. Another value-added aspect is the design. We moved upscale to more aesthetically pleasing designs for our clients to enjoy. This is a strong trend that other promoters and developers are now adopting in their own products. Pronobis is proud to be one of the industry leaders, and this is one of the ways we have confirmed our commitment with our clients.
node.sections11: We have seen constant growth of the sector, especially in Quito, confirming its status as the largest market. The main reason for that is the current availability of mortgages, as in the past decade banks have been keen, because of the dollar, to extend long-term mortgages to clients at favorable rates. Formerly, it was not possible to secure a mortgage at a better interest rate than 15%, while today the 10% mark is the norm. A major growth factor in the real estate sector is the social security bank, which has started giving mortgages for 15 to 20 years at better terms in competition with the banks. The mortgage market has duly become interesting for a much wider audience, which fuels the purchase of houses, residences, and offices. As the economy has grown so too has money entering circulation. Companies are now starting up in larger number and we build a large volume of corporate property.
node.sections21: The most important challenge for the sector in the coming years is keeping the trend of financing home buying in the country, which has many benefits for the economy. The national government has knowledge that this is a key driver of the economy. Financing is the first challenge, and the second one is finding a social interest home building model. We need to find a model that is sustainable and which allows people, who are not able to get a proper home right now, to be able to do it in the future. Before 2009, if you drew a pie chart of how homes were sold in Ecuador, you would find that most of them were sold at prices above $50,000. It was 2009 when this trend changed or inverted. After 2009, most new homes are bought at prices that are under $50,000. That is a big step in being able to tend to the largest market.
node.sections31: When the company was established, it had a strong focus on large surface and high-quality housing units, because there was a demand for such properties. However, this changed over the years, and so did our strategy. We have always been a flexible firm, and as purchasing power has declined we have started developing smaller projects. The market no longer demanded high-quality finishes. The type of property we first launched to the market 15 years ago is no longer in demand at all in Quito. Some other constructors have tried to develop such schemes, but it was extremely hard for them to sell. We have always analyzed the market evolution and adapted ourselves to the types of properties that respond to saving capacity and purchasing power. In this context, recent economic and social developments in Ecuador have led to a situation in which the middle class has increased, while at the same time, the higher social class has seen its purchasing power reduced over the years. We are talking about a segmented and broad middle class in Ecuador, which is our market niche.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0company: Universidad de San Francisco de Quito (USFQ)
node.previewsummary: Ecuador's universities are increasingly using their research departments to make an international name for themselves, while also driving their respective fields forward.
node.subject: Research
node.title: A Cunning Plan
node.sections01: With the creation of Universidad de San Francisco de Quito (USFQ), the educational sector became competitive for the first time. Before then, it was a public system with no competition. Competition makes you develop, and ultimately makes your university better. Since we have started, the whole education system has been transformed, not only on a university level but also from K to 12. We are the only university in Latin America to offer a full Liberal Arts curriculum in the tradition of the UK and the US. Just by our example alone, we have changed the attitudes of students and professors, improved the quality of teaching, and emphasized the necessity of research. We are not research-oriented and do not receive state funding, although in spite of that we are the top research university in Ecuador. We have the largest number of PhDs of any institution in Ecuador by far.
node.sections11: Universidad de las Américas (UDLA) has a strong, but limited, research program. It is strong in the sense of focus, but limited in the sense of scope. Universities do not receive any funds from the government, but we have to work with the government. We will not develop a good research project as a whole if we do not collaborate. We do not receive funds from the government, and we devote most of our resources to helping our health science schools. UDLA probably has the best-developed research center in Ecuador, especially for study areas such as cancer. We have noticed that different indigenous communities in Ecuador have diverse problems of a genetic nature. As a result, we are conducting genetics studies and we have a center that is focused on diabetes. There is a traditional food from Ecuador called chocho. We are finding that certain types of chochos that we develop can fight diabetes. This is fantastic because it is natural, cheap, and people like it. We have been conducting experiments for the past three years and will shortly publish the final study. Again, the concept is: do your research in topics of significance to the country, and not just of academic orientation.
node.sections21: At the moment we are transitioning toward the new law and academic framework stipulated by the regulator. This framework has yet to be proven, but we will do our best to make it work, even if we do not completely agree with it, such as the requirement to hold a PhD to become a dean, vice-president, or president of a university. Time alone will reveal the wisdom of the new legal framework. We want to feature on the global map, and even in the international rankings. As for the next 20 years, after updating new skills and curricula, we are driven to develop the health-related component of Universidad de Especialidades Espiritu Santo (UEES): the school of medicine and related areas, such as intensive care technology, and neurosurgery. We plan to build a university hospital within the next five years. We have already approached four of the top-10 hospitals to leverage their experience and advice in what will be a greatly ambitious project. All of our efforts will be geared at establishing an agreement with one of the experienced international institutions.
node.sections31: For over 45 years Escuela Politécnica Nacional (EPN) has espoused a system to balance secondary education with the training of professionals, having offset certain deficiencies in the disciplines of physics, mathematics, and chemistry. Once students are enrolled at EPN, our staff expose them to both pure and applied scientific research. Teachers at EPN know that they have to teach, research, and work to fulfill our social responsibilities. Research must be linked to teaching, because knowledge is dynamic, and academic staff must have published 20 to 30 articles in indexed journals. Arguably, what Ecuadorean universities are missing is patentable innovation. If it is a center for engineering and sciences it should be possible to patent one's work.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Tech Banking
node.title: The Future Is Now
node.sections01: Technology is a basic issue that every bank has to deal with to operate successfully. You have to understand our target market, which is military personnel. It is like a huge company with offices all over Ecuador and in certain other countries. They need a bank with a national presence, and we are a medium-sized institution. We have dealt with this reality by joining forces with Banco Pichincha. Between 2008 and 2012 we were perfecting our financial ratios, so we were not paying much attention to IT. In mid-2012, we decided to change that. We started to invest a lot of money improving our IT, and in 2014 the vast majority of our projects are IT based. We are buying new BPM and CRM software, analyzing the core software we use to attain customers and register transactions. We improved our webpage, too, but there are still many areas to be improved. We need it to be more efficient, to save money, and to better serve our customers. They need electronic payments and other technologies to perform transactions. Improving our IT will allow us to introduce products and services that will hit our target market.
node.sections11: We want to be a multi-banking institution capable of offering integrated services and solutions, for example, we need to improve our technological processes to offer our clients alternative banking tools. My appointment was also part of the bank's strategy to diversify and expand its operating segments, while giving the institution a more pluralist character with additional products and services, as well as higher levels of technological sophistication. Technology is essential, as today we would be incapable of offering all the services and products we have, while also reaching higher banking penetration levels domestically. New technologies enable us to be faster and more efficient in our activity. I think one of the challenges facing emerging economies is the low banking penetration level, which sparks further problems. I think technology plays a key role in increasing banking penetration; nowadays it eases many processes and people can perform any process on a computer or mobile phone. Moreover, new technologies enable the faster launch and implementation of products, services and strategies, reaching clients more efficiently, too. I think this is the road to follow in Ecuador, both for us and for the other banks, as the current banking penetration in the country barely reaches 40%.
node.sections21: We operate 22 banks on three continents. Of these, six are considered the largest banks, and in Ecuador one of these is ProCredit—among the top six. I think, on the one hand, that the financial resources SMEs need in order to increase their investment pose a challenge. In addition, the human resources component can be challenging, and that in many cases their performance could be enhanced through greater technical knowledge. Our clients have many strategies for their businesses; however, they don't always have the technological knowledge to back it up. Both aspects are related to the efficiency that these enterprises need for the future. Efficiency is important because Ecuador is a relatively small market, compared with its neighbors. We need to improve efficiency and quality. Meanwhile, as a private bank, we were the first to service the agricultural sector, and also the first to launch special credit—EcoCredit—to invest in measures to protect the environment.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Ecuador is powering forward economically, and as a result, Ecuadorean companies of all sizes and varieties are making their presence felt abroad.
node.subject: Ecuadorean Companies Abroad
node.title: Have We Met?
node.sections01: Ecuador is not well known as a country that promotes design. However, we have taken this to our advantage, because our furniture and design combine the best of Ecuador—the resources, and the identity of Latin American design. Today we are well known across Latin America. We have expanded in the US, and have also been pursuing further expansion there, too. We are exporting products made in Ecuador to the US since 2001. We have around 10 active dealers and many other design firms in the US, which is currently the largest market for our brand. We also have distribution in Mexico, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Panama, and Costa Rica, and are starting to do some business in Dubai, too. We have two licenses in Venezuela, but that is slightly different. The license is more like a franchise as with here. We recently opened a showroom in Chile, and are opening one in Peru in October 2014. I would say that about 60% of our business is international.
node.sections11: We are expanding to Latin American markets and export to around 20 countries in the region. Meanwhile, we have our own operations in Peru, Colombia, and in Central America. We make products for brands like Whirlpool that are sold in Colombia, Chile, and Central America. In Ecuador, we hold a 70% market share in stoves and 65% in refrigerators. I know home appliances well, which will allow us to build on our strengths in the local market and also in Peru, where we are already in a strong position. We are also growing in Colombia and in Central America, but the ultimate goal is to have a presence throughout Latin America, where our target is do the same that we did in the Ecuadorean market. We need to establish industrial clusters linking the suppliers of the product, which will give us productivity and curb transport costs in the supply chain. We need the government to incentivize innovation to develop the national knowledge base.
node.sections21: We are an Ecuadorean brand born in Ecuador and sustained by Ecuadoreans. But what is more important for us is to emphasize that we use Ecuadorean raw materials, produced locally, to create Oriental food products using our knowledge. We want to show Ecuadoreans, Latin Americans, Europeans, and even Chinese people that Ecuadorean raw materials can be used to make healthy and delicious Oriental food. Some of our sauces are actually being exported to China now, such as our chili sauce, which is made with Ecuadorean chili. Ecuador can produce chili sauce all year round because of our equatorial location. We see this as an opportunity for export. More than 10% of our products are currently exported within the region, but also to Europe and China. You have to pursue your goals every day and adapt when needed by developing new technology and products. You also need to encourage your employees to pursue growth, adapt to change, and innovate.
node.sections31: Marbelize is the fourth largest exporter of tuna in Ecuador. We are also the first to develop new kind of products. We are innovative; we invest in research to develop new products and create new trends. We were the first company in Ecuador to package tuna in a glass container. Our largest export market is Europe. Asia is our main competitor. To compete with them is a big challenge. Their prices are very low, at around $10 per box. The challenge is to give the end consumer an excellent product, but to have them pay for it is difficult. We try not to compete on price, but rather on quality. That is why we have diversified. That is why we don't sell a lot of canned tuna, but instead pouch packs. We sell these in a catering size that is intended for hotels, hospitals, and schools because they value good quality. My biggest challenge is to open up new markets. We are working with the government to open up markets because there are customs duties everywhere.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Manabí­
node.title: Coastal Idyll
node.sections01: We are a city with a strong agricultural character and tradition. We also have a strong commercial character and over the past few years have focused on the development of services, especially education and health. Much of this city's growth was unplanned and as a result, there is a high level of informality. Our canton suffered from improper planning during its economic and industrial development, causing it to be less developed than other cantons in Ecuador. At the moment, we are planning our municipal goals for 2025. This process must involve both the public and private sectors. We have great potential as a canton, but need to unite in our efforts to address the disorganization of previous years.
node.sections11: We have developed a series of business products that suit the region and its unique characteristics. We understand the mindset of our people, and that also means that we know the needs of the enterprises here, and is why we have been able to support them throughout the disparate economic situations the country has experienced. Another way in which we play a key role in regional development, while setting ourselves apart from the competition, is through our agility in meeting the client needs. Our role here has changed over the years, too. We have provided funding channels to a wide variety of economic sectors, and that is the best example of how we have contributed to the development of the region. We have to keep in mind that the country itself has developed, and with it Manabí­. Arguably, the region has not grown to the same extent as Guayaquil, Quito, and Cuenca, but it has notably expanded.
node.sections21: We are a particularly productive province thanks to our highly skilled workforce. However, as a region we have suffered from severe climate conditions, which has affected our productivity and reduced our industrial output. Nevertheless, we have played an important part in Ecuador's development. One of our major achievements has been consolidating our long-term productive vision, as well as developing our road infrastructure plan, the latter being some of my early programs. We have improved the quality of the national roads in our province, and extended their reach to underserved rural communities. While we have already invested in over 7,000 kilometers of road infrastructure, our region requires more than 15,000 kilometers. Therefore, we have taken important steps toward developing the road infrastructure to best serve our industrial and agricultural producers.
node.sections31: The tuna industry is alive and well in Ecuador. We are currently constructing new facilities to accommodate our expansion. We also expect our production capacity to increase by 10% as a result of the new EU trade agreement. In fact, our expansion plans were based on the assumption that the trade agreement would be signed. Europe accounts for 70% of Seafman's sales, even though we do not have our own brand there. We were active before anyone thought tuna was economically viable, and have remained in operation as the industry evolved. Seafman is known in Manta, and in the industry, as a school because we put a tremendous emphasis on the training and education of our employees. If you visit other plants, you will always find people who started at Seafman. Our training programs even extend into the universities.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Why Ecuador?
node.title: Be Here Now
node.sections01: Citibank started operating in Ecuador in 1960 with a clear goal: to facilitate trade activity between Ecuador and other regional countries through our large branch network. In this context, one of our main focuses over the years has been local and multinational corporate companies in Ecuador, as well as the other markets in which we operate; we provide them with the right tools to develop their business activity, which enables them to take advantage of the synergies between Citibank branches in several countries. The government and the institutional sector is another one of our main focuses of activity. All in all, I think Citibank has contributed to the development of Ecuador from several points of view by providing finance tools to companies operating in the country, bringing in international banking practices and standards, boosting technology and know-how transfer, and playing an active role in the professionalization of the banking industry. Finally, we have also adopted an active role when it comes to social responsibility, engaging in activities to boost financial education and entrepreneurship in Ecuador.
node.sections11: Liberty has a large footprint in Latin America. We started operations in the region in 1995-1996 by entering Venezuela and Colombia. We subsequently entered Chile, Brazil, and Argentina. The intention of the group is to keep developing its footprint not only in Latin America, but in emerging markets worldwide, for example in Asia and Europe. The Ecuadorean market has been of great interest to the group for a number of years. In 2012, the regulator essentially divested the insurance business from the banking sector in Ecuador, which created an opportunity for Liberty to enter the market. Also, the market has grown significantly over the past decade, in fact exceeding GDP growth, although it is still a small market. Premiums in Ecuador border $1.7 billion today, which makes it an interesting niche market to enter. Therefore, a combination of factors was involved in our decision to enter the country. I think it is preferable to maintain our momentum and keep entering additional countries in Latin America because having a greater footprint is beneficial. Another positive about the Ecuadorean market is that the insurance penetration level remains low.
node.sections21: Ecuador is a highly attractive country for doing business; the government is keen to open the doors to foreign investors, and we are also talking about a country that needs infrastructure for its development. For Siemens, it is vital to take part in Ecuador's largest infrastructure projects, especially those related to the government's plans to shake up the national energy and electricity matrix. I believe that Siemens can play a leading role in this process, saving the country significant expense over the long term. The Pacific Refinery is another top priority for Siemens, because in the future it is set to become a key element in the broader economic development of the country. Overall, Siemens is eager to participate in Ecuador's high-tech projects of social and economic merit. Finally, the high levels of investment in education and public health committed to by the incumbent government also interest Siemens as a leading manufacturer of medical equipment and technology. Siemens is well equipped to leave its social footprint on Ecuadorean society through the strength of its leading-edge technological offering.
node.sections31: Ecuador is an important market for the company. It is a market in which the automotive sector has undergone regulatory changes and the imposition of quotas. In response, GM has ramped up investment in Ecuador over the past few years. Ecuador is a market with opportunities that warrant this increased investment. Our medium- to long-term strategy in Ecuador is proven by our commitment to industrialize the country by developing a solid auto parts supplier base. As part of our efforts to help transform the production matrix, we have increased investment in our plant to maximize its potential. In 2014, we will complete the final expansion stage, where a $70 million budget has been allocated over the past three years aimed at productivity and quality, the development of new products, and attracting new investors to the auto parts segment. By attracting new investors, we hope to increase the number of Ecuadorean parts in vehicles. Since we are a multinational company, we also boost know-how transfer by providing regular training courses to our staff, other companies of the auto industry and even other industries.
node.sections41: Ecuador is a great place for developing our global solutions. It is part of the Andean region, which is formed by Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, and Paraguay. Ecuador represents a huge opportunity for the company especially because government investment here is huge. In every segment, the government is our biggest client. The main segments that will be affected are health, domestic security, traffic, mining, and industry. The company realized that having a local person is good for the business. For countries in Latin America, 3M and similar companies tend to be more open to working with local people. Being a local allows for a better balance between what the company wants you to do, and the reality of what you can do in the country. Over the next three years, we want to break the $100 million barrier, which would be a significant milestone for the company and would position us as one of the most important of the 95 subsidiaries that 3M has across the world. This year the target is to surpass the $60 million mark. We are 75% of the way there, but need to increase our efforts.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Ecuador's agribusiness sector is looking to add value to the already strong agriculture sector through higher standards, different product lines, and advanced equipment.
node.subject: Agrifood
node.title: Food Bar
node.sections01: In Ecuador, Alpina has a 40% share of the formal cheese market and 20% of the formal dairy market. However, only 30% of cheese is sold in the formal market in Ecuador, while informal producers account for 70%. In many cases, we are working with informal producers to help them develop better safety and quality standards. One example is a small dairy cooperative in Ecuador, named Quesinor, located close to our plant in Carchi. We have been working with them to help integrate standards for technology and hygiene and generate business value to commercialize their products. We feel that we have a social responsibility to ensure that there is a harmonious environment for business. Alpina buys more than 170,000 liters of milk every day. We have been working with the Ministry of Agriculture to source much of this milk from small farmers. By guaranteeing a buyer for these farmers, we can help support the market, and by working to identify the many cooperatives and associations and agreeing to purchase milk from them under formal conditions, we are helping to bring them out of informality.
node.sections11: There are three areas that we are going to focus on for the future. The first is our people. We really work hard and will keep working in Ecuador for our people, in terms of their development and training. In 2013, we increased our investment in training and development five fold. We care about our people, and we feel that we should give the best conditions to them, meaning quality, tools, technology, facilities, and opportunities for personal development. The second area is our product and brands portfolio, which we want to expand further and faster. You will see many innovations in the coming years aimed toward improved nutrition. Also, affordable and premium products are areas where there are still plenty of opportunities. And third, I can say that we want to grow also in new and different categories, which means investing in equipment, machinery, and different lines, but also looking at mergers and acquisitions.
node.sections21: Ecuadoreans are ready to take on a challenge, and our collaborators and team members are skillful, hard working, and quick learners. In this context, many of our management positions at the production plants and commercial areas are occupied by Ecuadoreans who have previously worked for other leading companies in the food industry elsewhere in region, which is more common today. The new productive matrix adopted by the government has brought many opportunities for local producers. In this context, we search for new market niches that can help us expand our business activity. For example, in 2014 Superior's portfolio has expanded significantly in order to offer more alternatives to local consumers. I perceive many growth opportunities, and we are determined to take advantage of them to expand into new segments of the food industry. We want to double our operational size over the next five years. Today, we are on the right path and convinced that we will continue playing a major role in Ecuador's food industry.
node.sections31: Ecuador is one of the leading exporters of cacao; other markets do not currently pay at a premium for Ecuadorean cocoa, and the country needs to further invest in international brand building, as we still live off past successes. I also think that Ecuador should increase the production of fine aroma cacao and start working to generate value-added from the product through a strong brand, by promoting it and make it more competitive worldwide. We expect to reach a 20% export level within four years—we started exporting two years ago and exports currently represent 10% of our business activity. There are several lines that offer interesting business opportunities. For example, the country still has a long road ahead regarding healthy food products in order to catch up with more advanced markets. Also, Colombian companies sell products worth $150 million using technology that has yet to be introduced here. Once this is done, there is another market niche to explore there.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Vice-President of the Board of Directors
node.subject: Productive Matrix
node.title: Change Away
node.sections01: We establish assembly plants in almost every country in which we operate. The growth and development of the plant in Ecuador has been stable and consistent. The plant has manufactured innovative and top-class models that are highly acclaimed. Over the past decade we have supported the government's efforts to substitute imported products for locally produced ones. As part of our efforts to help transform the production matrix, we have increased investment in our plant to maximize its potential. In 2014, we will complete the final expansion stage, where a $70 million budget has been allocated over the last three years aimed at productivity and quality, the development of new products, and attracting new investors to the auto parts segment. By attracting new investors, we hope to increase the number of Ecuadorean parts in vehicles. Since we are a multinational company, we also boost know-how transfer by providing regular training courses to our staff, other companies of the auto industry, and even other industries.
node.sections11: Sony has 15 offices in Ecuador, and was in fact the first brand to have its own premises here, believing in the need to keep in touch with the consumer.
