node.author: TBY
node.subject: Agriculture
node.title: Till, Tomorrow Comes
node.sections01: Our primary products are meat and broiler chickens. We buy day-old chicks, grow them on the farm and process them at our plant. We also have a 420-head in milk dairy herd, and process milk on the farm. Additionally, we have a network of retail outlets throughout Zambia through which we sell our milk and chicken produce. And while we sell beef, we do not produce it ourselves. Galaunia Farms has expanded over the years, and our farming has become much more intense. Initially we were engaged in cattle ranching, which requires a large area, but have since discontinued this activity, and operate today around 3,000 hectares of land. The bulk of our production is sold directly to fast-food restaurants and institutional caterers, such as mines, universities, hotels, and other retailers. Shoprite, the largest retailer in Zambia, is one of our core customers, for example. Our sales are fairly evenly split between Shoprite, institutional customers, our own retail, and fast-food restaurants.
node.sections11: We could easily have become a warehouse like many companies, but in doing so no value is added to the country. Therefore, we have developed the dairy sector over the past 16 years and today operate 100 medium- to large-scale farms, and have 30 milk-collection centers for small-scale farmers. We support 3,500 such individuals and collect 7,500 liters solely from those milk-collection centers each year, and the volume is rising. One center is generating ZMW600,000 for the local community, adding value to the beef herd, as it is traditionally a beef producing region where crossbreeding results in better stock. Those 30 milk centers are a testimony to regional growth. Basically, we prefer to produce in the countries we are present in in order to support our brand. Moreover, all of that knowledge is transferred, whereby any talent we develop here can be used locally or else sent to our other facilities around the region. Ours is a great company to work for and considerable opportunities are available to our 400 staff.
node.sections21: We started operations in August 2013 as an important part of a German group known as CLAAS, which combines tractors, machinery, and other agricultural equipment. We import the equipment and have dealers in place that provide after-sales services. It has been difficult because people are not used to it. However, we are optimistic and we are up to the challenge. We are here to listen to the farmer, and in terms of the investment we are well rewarded. Since August we have sold ZMW10 million in equipment and machinery, and this gives us great optimism and zeal. Agriculture is the solution to the unemployment issue. Around 70% of the Zambian workforce is employed in agriculture and there is a lot of space to diversify the economy and grow in other industries. We are very optimistic about the market, because it is growing and the farmers will need new machines. Right now we have a 5% market share, but we expect it to grow up to 10% in the next years.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: Kempinski Hotel Mall of the Emirates
node.subject: Hotels
node.title: Champagne & Caviar
node.sections01: Dubai is a completely unique destination with its own brand of international and multicultural hospitality. It has international appeal as a travel and business hub, not to mention the world-class leisure attractions that continue to position Dubai as a premium and aspirational city to visit. Over the last five years, we have witnessed rapid growth and development here making Dubai a global leader in the hospitality industry, and this is due to the vision and perseverance of HH Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum and the ruling family in building this remarkable city. We also aim to be unique in the level of guest services we provide. To cater to the diversity of the international guests we host, we have employed more than 1,000 people from 70 different countries as our JW Marriott Marquis associates. This enables us to become a truly international destination, where language and cultural barriers are eliminated and every guest feels at home. We also train our associates to behave according to our brand pillar of intuitive service. Many hotels train people to simply take an order and deliver food, but the hard part is really to teach people to anticipate what a guest needs before they ask. This might mean remembering the type of coffee the guest prefers in the morning, opening a door before it's approached, or preparing special amenities for guests who are celebrating or had a difficult day. This is exceptional service and this is what we endeavor to provide.
node.sections11: We bring European luxury to Dubai and, in doing so, we provide guests with a perfect balance of European luxury and style and the rich heritage and warm hospitality of the region. We pride ourselves on the quality of services we provide to our guests, such as our limousine pick-up services from the airport, the lady in red in the lobby—a signature of the Kempinksi group—and our international cuisine, which all add to that special guest experience. You will always find a lot of Arabic ingredients, dishes, and traditions in our restaurants, as well as in the amenities we send up to the room. In this way, we are integrating local traditions. Dubai as a much sought-after destination definitely helps our brand to become even more international than before because of the diversity of the business and leisure travelers passing through. It is also a great destination for corporate customers, and we have agreements with global companies such as IBM and Siemens. Dubai is like a showroom for the rest of the world where we are not yet positioned and our presence in the UAE helps us grow in other markets such as Africa and the Middle East.
node.sections21: At Raffles Dubai, our competitive advantage consists of our caring colleagues, our high level of service, and the genuine earnest we convey toward our guests. It all comes down to the delivery and the quality. Annually, around 35% of our visitors are repeat guests, and we always find a way to exceed their expectations. There are a lot of attractive rates in the city, but I believe our guests choose to return to Raffles Dubai because of our fantastic colleagues. In a competitive market like Dubai, the people and their services are what matter the most. Consequently, the price becomes a secondary factor. Our guests are well-traveled; hence, it is important that we pay attention to their needs. People from different backgrounds and cultures have different expectations. Emotional intelligence is key to understanding your guests, and at Raffles Dubai we offer the ultimate in emotional luxury. In 2013, Raffles Dubai closed at an average occupancy rate of 80%, which is exceptionally high. This year we are anticipating that we will maintain the same figures, although many new hotels have joined the Dubai market. Our biggest yielding element is going to be our room rates. We have great strategies in place and are feeling very positive about our rate growth. Our guests are still willing to pay for a quality experience and Dubai as a city holds an alluring attraction to travelers worldwide.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Automotive
node.title: The Open Road
node.sections01: Al Nabooda Automobiles is the sole distributor of Porsche, Audi, and Volkswagen in Dubai and the Northern Emirates. In recent years, we have become the world's largest Porsche dealer and also account for more than one-third of all Audi and Volkswagen sales in the GCC. In 2012, we announced an AED900 million investment program to expand and enhance our operations in Dubai and the Northern Emirates, covering 10 individual projects. The first phase included the construction of the world's largest Audi new car sales terminal, which opened in Dubai in November 2012 at a cost of AED118.5 million. Work continues apace in delivering the 10 projects, which make up our current expansion investment program. We have recently opened the new AED85.5 million Al Nabooda Automobiles combined sales and after sales center for the Porsche, Audi, and Volkswagen brands in Fujairah and the AED120 million facility combining Porsche, Audi, and Volkswagen showrooms and workshops in Sharjah. Also pending final planning approvals, construction will commence soon on an AED300 million vehicle pre-delivery center and paint and body shop on a massive 130,000-sqm site at Jebel Ali.
node.sections11: At the end of 2013, we launched the new Toyota Corolla and the Yaris sedan. We are just reaching our first full months of sales for those new models, which comprise a large part of our passenger car range. We have also completely remodeled the 2014 model year RAV4, and we will launch a new Toyota Yaris hatchback as well and another new model in the second quarter of the year. For Lexus, we will introduce a brand new model called Lexus RC and RCF, which is the sports version of the car that debuted at the Geneva Motor Show. It is an exciting year for us in terms of new models. Toyota is the market leader in the UAE, and we expect to retain our market leadership in 2014. The business is growing and we are investing in our infrastructure to better support our customers. We are investing heavily in training our staff to enhance our customer service. As the market grows, it is important to invest in the infrastructure we already have to support our customers.
node.sections21: Renault Middle East was launched in February of 2013 to promote the brand in the region, and so is a new component of the overall Renault Group. Phase one of our strategy was to make a clear analysis of the market, and assess Renault's weaknesses and strengths in the area, and to define short-, mid-, and long-term plans. In 2013 we increased our sales in GCC markets by 19% while the market was growing only by 8%. We have also brought out a wider product range during this phase, having achieved our first-year objectives of pushing for sales and being seen to be active. We will continue to pursue growth and aim to outperform our 2013 numbers. Renault worldwide has a formidable reputation for us to build on by making full use of our expanding network coverage. The UAE, and Dubai in particular, are the most dynamic markets in the region and offer the greatest potential for the company, which is why Renault Middle East is headquartered here. And aside from competitors, there are also complementary companies present here. In terms of the Middle East overall, the primary market is Iran, although the business climate can be rather challenging. The second largest market is Saudi Arabia, and the third the UAE.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: IT Services
node.title: We Got It
node.sections01: On the topic of start-ups and how to support SMEs, I would say the most important item here is the launch of Office 365. We have built a package so that any SME that wants to start its business in Dubai—or they are already having a business in Dubai—when they go to renew their license, they will receive this package, which has a data plan. We will enable them to start their business without any major initial investment, and for SMEs that is crucial. If their business is not IT, we can simplify things for them, and that will help them grow. In 2014, we have also signed with in5, which is an incubator a start-up owned by TECOM Investments, to provide all its start-ups with free software, and we will also connect in5 with the other initiatives that we are launching with universities in the UAE.
node.sections11: A document is now physical, virtual, and digital. What the company has achieved is to apply its pedigree in knowing how documents move through organizations to develop a wide range of services around document management, and the most commonly understood is Managed Print Services. However, there are lots of applications that start with just scanning information and developed into full-blown integrated services. The document is at the heart of every single business process, and that is the set spot of our knowledge and expertise. Today, the only thing that has changed is the way we help our clients become more efficient and save money. Providing more environmentally sound technologies and services is also becoming more relevant.
node.sections21: Cities can use networks to manage services, provide citywide information, learn how citizens use managed services, and deliver business opportunities. We have seen a major impact through our support of showcase Smart City initiatives in Barcelona, Spain; Nice, France; and Hamburg, Germany. For example, Barcelona's Born District uses Cisco Smart+Connected City Wi-Fi and sensing devices to enhance livability for citizens, create a smart city blueprint, and demonstrate thought leadership. Nice's “Connected Boulevard," meanwhile, provides smart city services such as circulation (traffic), lighting, waste management, and environmental monitoring. Hamburg uses Cisco Smart+Connected City Wi-Fi to improve service delivery to mobile citizens, boost the local economy, and provide smart parking.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: Dubai has a number of companies offering a whole host of services to cater to all needs in the area.
node.subject: Maritime
node.title: All At Sea
node.sections01: The formula is basically good pricing and good service. We don't do cheap and cheerful; we cater to the high end of the market. We use technology with the boats to make them work better. We have a custom-built management system with formulated algorithms that control the pricing based on supply and demand. Depending on how busy it is, the price will fluctuate. My background is actually in IT, so I have applied IT to maritime tourism. Xclusive Yachts has a diverse fleet, meaning we have small boats for two people for a couple hours, and then we have party boats. These are event yachts, meaning they tend to go out for about four hours, typically. We have boats from 22 feet long to a new 125-foot boat, which can cater to 200 people for large corporate events. All together, there are 17 yachts and boats in the fleet.
node.sections11: Dubai Marina Yacht Club caters to a variety of customers including boat owners, renters, residents, and tourists looking to enjoy our world-class repertoire of food and beverage outlets. We see a lot of interest from visitors from the GCC and other markets that are reflective of Dubai's tourism sector. We continue to innovate our services and facilities to uphold our world-class standards. We have a number of factors that work in our favor, such as the location within the largest marina in the world. As one of the key components of the larger Dubai Marina development, we position ourselves as a lifestyle destination that provides visitors with great services, unmatched views and unprecedented hospitality experiences. In fact, most recently, our services enabled us to receive the Five Gold Anchor award, which is undoubtedly the most prestigious accolade for marinas globally.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2company: American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery Hospital
node.subject: Health Hub
node.title: Cure All
node.sections01: It is important to develop the tourism sector in general in order to found the basis of a medical tourism sector. Currently, medical tourism is benefiting the provider rather than the patient. Of course profit is important, but institutions should be purpose-orientated. Services can be offered, but in terms of cost, Dubai cannot compete with Jordan, India, Turkey, Lebanon, or Thailand simply because Dubai has to import its human resources. In that respect, the sector must grow on quality of care and diversity of offers. Aligning our day-to-day operations with Joint Commission International (JCI) standards is one of the major moves that we have done to ensure that our patient safety standards remain uncompromised. We have established different committees tasked to look after all aspects of hospital services including risk management and patient safety. We also regularly perform case studies and create committees specifically for this purpose. However, quality is not just about getting accreditation; quality is a culture. In my first clinic, I was aware that I was not in a position to compete with the other private and public medical institutions offering free services, and the key to getting ahead was quality.
node.sections11: There are many new projects coming online and the authorities are doing a very good job in terms of regulating, enhancing, and developing the public sector. From a private healthcare perspective, the e-claims system will report healthcare provider activities both to the insurance companies and the regulator, meaning the regulator will have access to high-quality information to use in planning the future development of the sector. Another important strategy area is medical tourism and Dubai is in a good position to offer high-quality care and services, along with a very desirable destination, to international patients. These are two aspects of healthcare in Dubai that Moorfields is actively promoting. Since we opened in 2007, we have treated more than 31,000 patients and around 15% of our patients come from abroad—essentially, the GCC and MENA region. The global reputation of Moorfields is a vital advantage in attracting patients to our Dubai hospital for world-class treatment in the UAE, which will also extend to our new Abu Dhabi hospital in 2014.
node.sections21: In Europe, there are many centers for people to seek treatment for heart disease, cancer, and so on, but Dubai doesn't have that reputation. Dubai is not a center for tertiary medicine. It is, however, an excellent center for what we call elective procedures, such as cosmetic surgery. For procedures that are non-life threatening, people can very comfortably come to Dubai and be operated on by some excellent doctors. Dubai has a role to play in medical tourism particularly in the GCC; however, it has a long way to go before it is able to compete with Europe and North America, but those parts of the world have had decades to develop their healthcare systems, while Dubai has achieved an enormous amount in a short period of time and will catch up with the rest of the world. Our philosophy is to always meet a patient's expectations. Therefore, the focus should be on good clinical outcomes, as good clinical outcomes develop the reputation of our brand and provide long-term business growth.
node.sections31: First of all we need to realize what medical tourism is. It is essentially people who will leave their existing country or place of residence to come to Dubai (potentially) for healthcare, and that will be because they either don't have the existing facilities in their own country, or because it would be cheaper to come to Dubai and be treated here than it would be to receive the same treatment in their own countries. Dubai is not cheap, and it cannot compare to places like India or Thailand, where there are excellent healthcare facilities for a lot cheaper. Price is determined by the cost of living in those countries, and it is obviously a lot lower in those countries than it is in Dubai. The cost of living in Dubai translates to higher salaries, which in turn translates into higher healthcare costs. Meaning, people will not come to Dubai for medical tourism because it is cheaper. Therefore, the only reason people will come to Dubai for healthcare is for quality. Dubai boasts many excellent facilities and our facilities are on par with any other facility in the world, but that being said, the perception of Dubai is one of being very new, and when people think of healthcare they like to consider older, established, well-proven places and institutions.
node.sections41: Our clinic has been designed to offer a comprehensive set of services and to be a one-stop solution for our patients, meaning that they can come and find all the services that they will need in one place. The clinic was designed not only for patients here in the UAE, but also all surrounding countries as well as patients from further afield, as we are centrally located here between Europe, Asia, and Africa. In many of those countries, patients don't have access to such services. Dubai is a hub that is very hospitable, welcoming, and easily accessible, while the quality of life here is both excellent as well as secure. It is an ideal place to deliver fast services to our patients. With regard to the outlook on our industry, the WHO states that three out of 1,000 children are born deaf. Considering this figure, the potential we have to service the region is high. I am happy to say that we have been able to attract many patients from the GCC and from Africa to come and use the services that we offer here in Dubai.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Foreign Universities
node.title: Teach Abroad
node.sections01: I think one of the most important offers we have is our MBA program. In Dubai, the norm has been to fly in lecturers and teach Bachelor's courses in blocks, be it once or twice a month. Our program has regular classes spread out over the years so that learning opportunities are stronger. We include many extra-curricular activities. We do bring in numerous professionals from the industry to add value. We have a compulsory international aspect to our programs, whereby we take students overseas to apply what they have learned in an international setting. These trips are quite heavy in terms of requirements. The work is full on from the moment they land until the moment they leave. Our student body has grown, and we can't keep going to the same three places, as it would exhaust our resources. Our program is priced correctly, representing good value for money. It has certainly attracted considerable attention, having grown from 14 students in 2008 to over 240 today, with at least 200 people having graduated.
node.sections11: Dubai's society is international. The AUD has 105 nationalities represented in its student body. This diversity reflects the state of the city itself. Indeed, Dubai is even more diverse than our student population would reflect simply because I have heard numbers as high as 150 in terms of nationalities to have been granted visas to live and work in Dubai. And as with any form of diversity, the benefit derived is a richness of perspective and approach that yields superior results. Dealing exclusively with likeminded people yields little progress, which is why I consider diversity crucial to Dubai's success. The largest student group we have is Emirati, at somewhere between 15% and 17% of the population. Obviously, they are over-represented within AUD, and that to me is our greatest contribution to Emiratization. Our relationship with the Emirati community is such that they have placed faith in the university. Our contribution is to educate the students to a level that will enable them to compete with the best and brightest anywhere in world.
node.sections31: From the first day, we decided to bridge the gap between theory and practice. We do not want to work in a way that only focuses on theory. If we look at our graduates as products, we cannot sell our products unless the people see their abilities. If you want to include someone in your organization, you will not ask them about their specializations, or their grades. The first thing you will ask is, “What do you know?" You do not ask them to define law. We focus on the practice and the skills that graduates should be equipped with to practice law. We have been to many organizations to sign MoUs in order to engage students in real-life situations and put them in real organizational contexts. For example, we have MoUs with Dubai Court, Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research, Dubai Financial Market, Dubai Chamber of Commerce, and Dubai Health Authority (in process). This is to prepare the students for the market.
node.sections41: In regard to the authorities attempting to attract investment to establish Dubai as an educational hub, it is for the government to decide at the end of the day. There are free zones for those kinds of things in order to attract people. In many instances, foreign campuses will provide their own funds to build campuses; however, for any educational system to be solid, it has to find national investors. Dubai should concentrate more on developing a strong national university in Dubai so it gets government support, funding, and backing, and everything else so that when other foreign campuses decide to come, the educational system is already solid and ready. We are maintaining our standards at the highest level. We claim to be one of the strong universities here, although we only offer graduate studies with no undergraduate degrees. We are already establishing ourselves as a strong name here in the UAE. In the next five-to-10 years, if we continue this type of approach, we will be well established in the country.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2company: Dubai Internet City (DIC) & Dubai Outsource Zone
node.subject: Smart City
node.title: The Hub Of Hubs
node.sections01: We seek to leverage our technology platforms throughout the entire Gulf region. This said, Dubai is the optimal location from which to do so. Access to Dubai allows us to use our 3M Innovation Center, located in Dubai Internet City (DIC), to expose healthcare practitioners across the Middle East to the latest product applications and practices. A common business model is to share and, where possible, replicate already proven practices. One garners knowledge, experience, and best practices from abroad and applies it locally in a way that makes sense. It is important to understand that innovation centers are an important way for 3M to show our customers locally who we are and what we do. I am always amazed by what 3M achieves as a company in terms of the sheer breadth of innovative products and solutions offered to customers around the world. What we try to do in markets like the UAE is replicate on a smaller scale the 3M Innovation Center concept in St. Paul. Moreover, at our innovation center, we also demonstrate potential customer solutions that we may bring out into the region at some future time.
node.sections11: The City Index report analyzes the level of ICT driven benefits created in 11 of the MENA region's largest cities. Dubai, Abu Dhabi, and Doha emerged as the top three cities in the ranking, and it makes a lot of sense as the maturity indicators reflect the aspirations of the government and its people. ICT deployment in the UAE has been progressively equated to socio-economic empowerment—empowerment not in terms of just providing connectivity, but in fostering entrepreneurship, and, through an extended scope, enhancing the quality of life of citizens. Qatar has a similar clear mission to the UAE, and is investing a lot in the country's infrastructure. I think all of these investments are fostering innovation and providing a great platform for any kind of business to grow. These countries are largely seen as being on the forefront of development when the vision is combined with clear plans of action.
node.sections21: Technology evolves at a tremendous rate, and establishing a long-term plan only does not always fit the industry well. This means that we are always kept on our toes. We have two principle focus areas. The first is basically to attract new companies into Dubai and the UAE, which is something we have achieved over recent years. Of course, as businesses change, we try to focus on the new industries that have the potential for growth and an appetite for the Middle East. Accordingly, the other part of the equation is to consider precisely which type of industrial activities we wish to attract. Microsoft is one of our partners and our partnership is mainly focused on start-ups. We also have a number of other partnerships and in different departments, companies, and sectors, focused on different spheres of activity. However our main partnerships, which are with numerous companies, are there to provide support to entrepreneurs. Microsoft has already gone through the process of signing an MoU to provide free software to companies within in5, the innovation hub launched in 2013.
node.sections31: In the UAE, we are absolutely at the center of the world in terms of digitalization. For the past three years, my mission has been to implement strategies to become the digital coach of companies leading this transformation, and also to work on major projects. Multinationals are working with us as partners in the development of their IT infrastructure. For the past two years, we have delivered more than 10 major projects in the UAE and Saudi Arabia. We are also connecting embassies all over the world with secure infrastructure, and security for an embassy is of course a must. We have delivered systems for one of the largest chemical producers in the Gulf, interconnecting more than 200 sites worldwide. Orange cannot be considered as just a telecoms company. We are delivering a package that integrates networks, information infrastructure, and applications. In smart cities, the application you have with our services will be around providing better interaction with the inhabitants by giving them access to the internet and services, all from a single integrated platform.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Senior Vice-President Middle East, Indian Sub-Continent & Africa
node.subject: Logistics
node.title: Move IT
node.sections01: We use three global hubs: Cincinnati, Leipzig, and Hong Kong. These are our super major hubs and make all of the connections. From there, we go into regional hubs, one in Dubai and the DHL regional hub in Bahrain. We have main streams and side streams. Dubai is more of a commercial hub, which means that it is used more for commercial flights, while Bahrain is more of our own network hub. We serve approximately 150 flights a day from here commercially, including our own aircraft and those stemming from a joint venture. We have flights coming that we shuttle to Bahrain, among many others. Our key consideration, however, is how we can get your shipment to you tomorrow morning, anywhere in the world. That is why we are always looking to improve and enhance our service levels. At the moment, we work closely with Dubai International Airport and other airports in the UAE for the commercial flights. Al Maktoum is more of a cargo hub; however, it still serves us as a group, but as the Express division we need the commercial flight connections. The Dubai hub also serves as a connection for shipments from Africa, Asia, and Middle Eastern countries flying in and out again.
node.sections11: FedEx is a major contributor to the business community. We facilitate international trade and enhance customer flexibility and speed to market through our well-established international air and intra-regional ground network, which connects over 99% of the world's GDP. Shippers from different industries turn to FedEx for its ability to provide access through innovative and customized solutions, and our business certainly benefits from that. As demand from key sectors grows, FedEx develops specific solutions that better meet its clients' logistics needs. For example, recognizing the growth of the aviation sector in the region and now specializing in shipping requirements, FedEx showcased its Aerospace Solutions during the 2013 Dubai Airshow. Companies from the aviation sector can now access an extensive range of FedEx-tailored shipping services that meet the time-sensitive demands of acquiring components to manufacture, maintain, or repair aircraft back into service. Such innovative solutions have enabled companies across different industries to reach new markets and fulfill the needs of their customers. Over the 41 years of our existence, we have constantly enhanced every aspect of customer interaction that facilitates the shipping process and enhances the overall experience.
node.sections21: The GCC logistics sector represents about $35 billion, with the major contributors from Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Oman. In the UAE, there is an air-sea concept when it comes to logistics, whereby a company that brings a product by sea can warehouse on location. In the second leg of the journey, the product is air freighted to other destinations in Europe and the rest of the world. Sea-air shipment is growing in the region at a rapid pace due to the lead time and efficiency gains and Al-Futtaim Logistics is able to contribute to this requirement with our local presence in key ports and airport locations in the UAE. There is also growing interest in Egypt and the Levant, and our facility at Jebel Ali is another factor that gives us an edge to extend our offering to Middle East, North and East Africa. There are two methods in place that provides regular customer feedback across both B2B and B2C markets and covering our clients and the end customers. This allows us to have a clear idea of what needs to be improved or changed in order to achieve our objectives. The B2B surveys are conducted independently by a third-party research services company.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: COFELY BESIX Facility Management Middle East
node.previewsummary: As Dubai's economy continues to diversify, the need for efficient and well-run facilities is key, which is where a number of local and international companies have stepped in.
node.subject: Facility Management
node.title: I Got It
node.sections01: We are the largest local, private facilities management company in the UAE. The key words here being: private and local. As far as the major players in the facility management industry are concerned, there are a few semi-government owned facility management companies. And then there are a few other players that are a part of international joint ventures. Al Shirawi FM is a purely local, private company that competes with these players and often wins. Today, our portfolio of clients is the second to none. We look after the entire Dubai Industrial City, which is the largest smart city in Dubai in terms geographical area (over 50 square kilometers). It is comprised of offices, warehouses, and labor accommodation. We look after varied services there, including the road infrastructure. We also manage what is known as the Business Village, which is where Dubai SME's headquarters is located. It is also where the Department of Economic Development (DED) is located. In addition to those, almost every AZADEA store in the Emirates is looked after by our firm. We have a significant retail portfolio. Although some of our competitors actually have the advantage of being connected to mall developers, we look after the stores in the malls. That truly is a testament to our capabilities.
node.sections11: Many people are talking about sustainability, and this is not a fancy thing—it is a reality. The concept of green is for the health of future generations and for the country's environment. We are lucky that the government supports sustainability. If we put our heads together, we will not reach the disaster scenario that some countries have experienced. If you live in a clear and nice environment, it is different than if you live with pollution; people are affected by this. In facilities management, we are dealing with sustainability by adding value to our clients. We advise them on how to reduce electricity and water consumption, for example. We are fortunate in that we maintain the majority of the mosques in Dubai. There are more than 240 mosques in Dubai. We also have many five-star hotels and many high villas in our portfolio. What I am trying to do is create an easy and effective method to maintain mosques. It is difficult to upgrade mosques to transform them into “five-star" locations. The type of carpet, the type of curtains, what type of AC we use, what types of perfumes we use inside, and the water temperature are all related to this.
node.sections21: As a facilities management operation, we look after some quite large and world-renowned buildings. We work for clients like Emaar and Aldar, with which we deliver technical expertise. Through this, we build confidence with our clients. We have built a reputation where, if there is a challenging environment, we position ourselves in a market where the service we provide supports the business specifically, rather than selling identical products to everyone. It is molded to our customer base, and we don't simply customize a package services, but deliver precisely what the customer asks for. We are mobilizing a project in Abu Dhabi, which is another iconic building, as well as the Dubai Mall. We also have infrastructure projects where we support the municipality's assets, such as pumping stations and distribution networks consisting of highly technical equipment. We expect that the market, over the coming year, will see a major push on energy efficiency. There is also going to be a push in sustainable business, not necessarily in the green sense, but functioning in a business activities sense that are sustainable for the long run. We are keen to develop solutions and models where we can support customers in the long term through building confidence in the relationship over cost and the bottom line.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Financing Outlook
node.title: Center Of Things
node.sections01: The UAE market, and indeed the Dubai market, is doing extremely well. It has gone through the fantastic experience of a major boom, a bust, and then a recovery, which is something not many cities or countries have experienced in the region. And the positive outcome is that Dubai and the UAE have learned and gained valuable experience from it. Dubai does not have the oil resources that other GCC countries have, yet it has been able to establish a very solid economy with concrete foundations. Since 2009, Dubai's economy has rebuilt itself on the fundamentals of what it used to be, which are currently the key pillars of its economy, namely trade, logistics, and tourism, and to a lesser extent real estate and financial services. One can easily see these pillars in the economy today; retail is booming, consumer spending is increasing, and there is a population influx into Dubai. On top of all that, tourism is growing at a very fast pace. Fundamentally, Dubai's growth today is much more comfortable, even though it is at a much higher pace than what we used to see during the crisis years. The Expo 2020 has already had some positive impacts on the local economy though its benefits are likely to accelerate closer to the event. The Expo will impact the same key pillars of the Dubai economy and should provide a further boost. I also do think that it will be a great way for Dubai and the UAE to showcase the achievements of this country, what it has to offer, and to highlight the future vision and economic growth that is likely to be seen in many years to come.
node.sections11: Historically, the SME sector in the UAE has been vastly underserved. There are over 200,000 SMEs accounting for nearly 86% of private sector employment in the country. At the same time, only 4% of bank lending is directed toward SMEs compared to 24% in developed economies, and probably less than 50% of SMEs have accessed banks for short and long term finance. In total, SMEs account for 40% of the workforce and contribute an estimated 43% of economic value in within the UAE. A key constraint to lending has been the lack of financial information and accurate historical data on SMEs, but we do see that this is slowly improving thanks to strong government support that has led to an increasing number of financial institutions becoming more farsighted in providing the funding that SMEs need to thrive and prosper. Today, the UAE has a strong and growing SME market with plenty of mechanisms and institutions in place to drive the sector. For instance, according to the recently published UAE report on SMEs, a total of 16,688 commercial licenses were issued in 2012, which is a vast improvement from the 11,743 licenses issued in 2009. The majority of these licenses were issued in Dubai, where events such as the rebounding property market and the strong performance of the UAE markets in 2013 have had a positive effect on liquidity and the country's SME sector.
node.sections21: We are an investment bank that has two verticals; one is the debt vertical, which is the debt capital markets, and the other is the mergers and acquisitions (M&A) vertical. On the debt side, we look to bring in innovative debt structures with better pricing for our clients to see what fits. We gather diverse solutions to provide one specific solution for each client. On the M&A side, we're able to bring much to the table because of our connectivity and physical presence in the GCC and India—we have the right connections for clients in all of these markets. Alpen Asset Advisors is a new entity that we have launched in the DIFC and it acts as an independent financial advisory and asset management firm. It has a totally different product offering from Alpen Capital. At Alpen Capital, we raise money and provide solutions, while with Alpen Asset Advisors we help manage wealth. There is no conflict or overlap between the two businesses. The aim of the new company is to provide our clients with a wider solution base.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Foreign Insurance Providers
node.title: Click, Click, Covered
node.sections01: In recent years, our focus has been more on improving the breadth and quality of the services we offer to our clients, as well as introducing new technology solutions to meet the needs of the market, rather than aiming for growth alone. We have taken our new motto, “Taking care of Healthcare," to heart and all our achievements are built around that goal. We introduced our Pharmacy Benefit Management system, which is one of only four systems accredited by URAC in Abu Dhabi. We also introduced our online automated approvals web portal, called i*Care, throughout our network of healthcare providers. This portal, which automatically responds to providers' requests for approvals on treatment, was a first for the UAE market, and we are extremely proud of the results, namely faster responses for providers, consistent decisions for insured members, and efficient processes for our clients. In addition, we recognized how many of our members travel across the region and need smooth, simple access to healthcare wherever they go; therefore, we introduced our cross-border service. With our extensive regional alliances, we can offer cashless, fast services to managed members at contracted healthcare providers throughout our group's area of operations.
node.sections11: We have always strongly believed that when operating in a country, you need a local face. Yet in truth, due to the specific situation of the UAE, where there are almost 85 insurance companies, the weight of nationals in the sector is low. We are improving and expanding our partnerships with universities in order to attract young talent and people. We basically have two different partnerships, one with the American University in Dubai and with Sorbonne University in Abu Dhabi. With a stronger presence here and a young energetic staff, we can do better than ever before. Each year, we try to raise the bar in terms of quality of services and understanding the expectations and needs of customers. We have segmented much more of our offer than in 2013 to ensure that we provide the best solution for each customer. Naturally, not all customers have the same expectations; for instance, some adopt a value-for-money approach, while on the other hand we also provide high-end solutions for those customers who require a dedicated person to provide them the best quality service. We are conducting numerous studies and getting feedback from our customers to see how we can improve on our offering. The second element, to my thinking, that makes us stand out in the business is the fact that we are able to provide nearly all the lines of business and solutions, even with some innovation, for both retail and corporate.
node.sections21: In 2014, we are planning to use direct channels where clients can access our products and services online through our website. We are also aiming to work with telecoms companies, meaning that clients can buy insurance from their smartphones, and also pay their premiums through them. We're trying to provide comprehensive solutions for our clients. We want them to be able to come to us and find a single solution to all their needs without having to go out into the market and deal with different carriers. Our SME product is a prime example of this. We are investing a lot into services in terms of ease of access to AIG services, and we ensure that all of our clients get the same level and quality of service regardless of what channel he or she uses, be it online or traditional brokerage channels. We are also investing a great deal in training people, not just restricting it to our employees but all producers, and all people who sell AIG products. In 2014, we plan to have a training academy in our organization for both our employees and producers.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Local Insurance Providers
node.title: In Any Case
node.sections01: An effective distribution channel is a must, making use of both brokers and direct sales, and relying on national representation. NGI has four branches in Dubai and is set to open another two in an area where we are little represented today. It all comes down to access to clients. In the interests of remaining conservative, I anticipate a 10% market share and gradual growth from there. The critical issue here is the performance of the new system going forward given that price is low and treatment costs and inflation in the medical sector high.
node.sections11: Insurance demand in the UAE is triggered by two major factors: demographics and the implementation of compulsory insurance benefits. Under demographics, the expanding population of expatriates in the UAE is enhancing real estate investments and large-scale infrastructure projects, both of which require insurance coverage, hence turning property insurance into a thriving business. Compulsory insurance benefits previously included motor insurance only, but recently health insurance has also been made mandatory by the UAE insurance authority. Due to high levels of car ownership and the compulsory law, the motor insurance sector will experience substantial growth.
node.sections21: Dubai National Insurance & Reinsurance is a leader in the mid-sized insurance company market in Dubai. Our strategy has been to focus on stability and to grow consistently and smoothly every year. There is still a need for more education in this country concerning insurance. Most people's perception is that insurance is only called for when some misfortune occurs, and in any case they generally only think in terms of motor vehicle or medical insurance. In fact, insurance is much broader and more important than that.
node.sections31: RAK Insurance celebrates 40 years this year. Having joined the company in January 2013, I set about repositioning RAK Insurance to put it on a different path in terms of distribution, operations, technology delivery, product innovation, and customer service. Incorporated into the strategic initiative of the organization in 2013, I planned to bring in international best practices and standards of operations, but all with a local flavor. We rebranded the company in May of 2013, and it was about positioning and understanding where we wanted to be as a company; clearly portraying that in the form of a brand.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Chairman of the Board of Directors
node.subject: Energy Outlook
node.title: Power Through
node.sections01: Lamprell has four main product lines. Our original business, which we continue to have a dominant position in the region, is the rig repair and refurbishment business. We then moved into other new build offshore construction and have recently been successful with several projects for the North Sea, both fixed platforms and lift boats. Finally, we also refurbish and build land rigs. Since our IPO in 2006, we have constructed 16 new build jack up drilling rigs, converted, upgraded, or refurbished more than 168 rigs (both jack up rigs and land rigs) and built modules for nine FPSOs. In the longer term, I would, however, like to broaden our offering and, in addition to our current products, build more FPSO topsides and turrets and other modular solutions such as onshore LNG modules. I think by doing so, we can end up with a business model that is more predictable as each of these business streams is cyclical but only rarely would they all hit a downturn concurrently. The products that we are looking to build are in essence different kinds of process modules that we have a long history of delivering.
node.sections11: Schneider Electric is one of the largest corporations in the world, and a leading company worldwide in energy management. We are in the top tier of the Fortune 500. In 2013, we achieved sales of ‚¬24 billion, and we have over 150,000 employees globally. In 1Q2014, turnover from new economies (including the Middle East), stood at 41% in global revenues, and this reflected an increase of 8% against the same period in 2013. Importantly, 5% of our turnover is devoted to R&D, which is a substantial amount for our industry. We need this level of R&D to be continuously ahead in terms of technology, and to bring more energy efficiency to our customers. Globally, Schneider Electric is a vibrant, dynamic company that has grown sustainably over the last decade. We continue to grow, both organically and through the acquisition of experts in technology. We are present in most countries in the world. In the Middle East, we have around 5,000 people—engineers, experts, and salespeople—with roughly ‚¬1 billion in turnover.
node.sections21: We recently signed a very important MoU with the Ministry of Energy, mandating Dubai Carbon to undertake three annual cycles of CO2 emissions and MRV activities across the UAE. This is important as the data-centric approach will facilitate and encourage bespoke project activities. We also signed an MoU with the World Bank and specifically with the International Bank of Reconstruction and Development launching the Dubai Green Fund, a special purpose vehicle specifically created to access capital for green projects at competitive rates. We also plan to sign with Enpark and will sign with Dubai Holding. Real estate and buildings in Dubai are growing fast and there are numerous areas where green economic knowledge adds value. We will work with them to set their strategies for greenhouse gas emissions and sustainable development. On the skills creation side, we signed with the Green Project Management Association to introduce Green PM and PMO training in the UAE, as lots of projects can take advantage of the knowledge-based approach.
node.sections31: The Supreme Council of Energy (SCE) has been carrying out extensive research on the future of energy in Dubai, looking at all aspects of energy production, distribution, and demand. On the demand side, it realized that there are things that need to be done. A study was carried out on how to reduce the demand for energy in Dubai, identifying the buildings that consumed a lot of energy and water. Then, it came up with a roadmap on how to tackle those challenges and make those buildings as energy and water efficient as possible. Almost 60%-70% of a building's energy consumption goes to cooling, which is basically air conditioning, and 10%-15% is consumed by lighting. The main task is to replace air-conditioning units with more efficient models or to connect buildings to district cooling systems. Etihad Energy Services was set up in 2013 by the Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) under the leadership of the SCE. Our role is to improve the existing buildings of Dubai so that they consume less energy, electricity, and water. We are achieving that by creating and organizing a market for energy services companies.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Expo 2020
node.title: Roll Up, Roll Up
node.sections01: With the World Expo 2020, you don't need to worry about the economy; it will grow. However, 2014 might not be the highest in growth. It is a year for optimism and planning for the future. In 2014, we will know the size of the growth expected for the coming five years; hence, we will define the gap between what we are now and what we should be in 2020. Then, based on this assessment we will work out what needs to be done in order to be ready. For example, I know Dubai needs to double the number of its hotel rooms and air passenger capacity, meaning there is a lot to be done in our hospitality activities. Every operator in Dubai is now wiser and more experienced in ensuring that whatever growth is taking place is sustainable. In our hotel, though, we are undergoing serious renovation activities we managed to keep it under control and occupancy didn't drop below 90%. Now, all the hotels are preparing for 2020. Many have started renovating or upgrading. We are no different as the pressure is on. Another challenge is to try and keep an eye on inflation, and we need to do our best to manage it. When rents move, everything starts moving—schools, hospitals, and restaurants, for example. Everything is linked.
node.sections11: I have been interviewed many times on Arabic news regarding the Expo. Public perception of the Expo is that Dubai has shifted plans to meet the objective of 2020, which is not true. Many years ago, Dubai had a strategy for 2021, and Expo 2020 is the icing on the cake. Yes, it clearly does have an impact on Dubai's strategy, but I maintain that Dubai has not diverted from its original vision and plan to realize it. There probably is an increased investment in infrastructure. And yet, I have asked myself whether 2020 had not been on the horizon, what would be the impact on Dubai? It is substantial enough to have realized its original plans regardless of World Expo 2020. The reality, however, is that the Expo is a vehicle that enables Dubai to reach its objective that bit earlier.
node.sections21: We can all safely assume growth. In the short term, I think there are probably some people who have been considering gently tapping the market here and have been lukewarm about operating in the region. What the Expo has done is given clarity to the fact that for the next seven years, Dubai is going to remain on the map. There will be infrastructure and connectivity growth. Today, no one can think of a world without Dubai. It has embedded itself, and I think that 10 years from now that will have become crystal clear. Jebel Ali will continue to rapidly develop as a port, and the connectivity with Abu Dhabi will be demonstrated. If I were all positive, I would not sound plausible, and I do have some level of concern, Dubai cannot be a regional hub if it is in the top three most expensive cities in the world. The key to Dubai's success was the fact that it was a regional hub from which to run business and employ people. The reason the whole thing blew up in 2008 was that it stopped being a low-cost hub and started being a high-cost center. Real estate, allowances, fees, and transport rose. When the city recalibrated, businesses and people returned. We have seen a further 40% increase in rent in 2014. We see increased school and food costs. If this carried on, Dubai is going to stop being a viable place for businesses to build regional hubs and they will pull out again and reduce.
node.sections31: Dubai and the UAE are growing exponentially. This event offers Dubai a long-term growth perspective, and will certainly contribute to its further rise. And as a six-month event it will also bear lasting region-wide significance. More than 20 million people visited in China when it hosted the Expo, meaning even if we target 10 million that would mean a large number of people traveling around the country and the wider region, which can only be beneficial for the entire GCC. The few negative aspects of the event, such as traffic congestion and large-scale construction, among others, are minor inconveniences when compared to the benefits that the population stands to reap, in terms of advanced infrastructure, metro and tram lines, and fresh family attractions, not to mention new educational facilities, and the internationalization of the city, through hosting the world at the Expo. We are confident in the way the local leaders will manage the event at a Dubai and national level.
node.sections41: We started with almost zero tourists, and I remember the first charter group was brought in 1991. Today, we have reached almost 11 million tourists annually, with a growth of approximately 10% to 15%. In seven years' time, we will have 20 million by default. Expo 2020 is a very important factor for development, not only for the tourism industry, but also for real estate, finance, consumer products, entertainment, and infrastructure. One day after the announcement of Dubai as the host city, the real estate developers started to look at areas to develop, with many projects tourism related, including hotels, hotel apartments, and residences, not to mention the development of Al Maktoum International Airport.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Investment Climate
node.title: Corporate Oasis
node.sections01: Dubai is leading the way because of what I call the three “s" theory of characteristics: social, systematic, and security. Dubai has a strong social network, and ideas are free to be shared. This is the social element. Furthermore, everything in Dubai undergoes regulations and organization; the regulatory environment has made Dubai an organized business oasis. In addition to this, security is the other important factor, including stability from a political and an economic perspective. Why is Dubai such an attractive destination for FDI and foreign investors? Because the Emirate has it all.
node.sections11: Ironically, although we are registered in Sharjah, we are overweight in real estate and almost all of our UAE assets are in Dubai, so that is where we interact, and where we meet people. It is a different business culture. One slight concern is that the sheer volume of property coming on to what is a fairly narrow market. If property prices start falling, it could spark a broader economic decline including share prices, a fixed income contraction, and a general squeeze on liquidity. This said, I foresee a fairly good ride for Dubai until 2020. This year looks promising for the Emirates Investment Group. We are invested in the real estate sector, and Dubai is on the way up. Experts are saying that asset values have risen significantly already, but in our case it's not an issue as we have not started any new projects.
node.sections21: The business environment in Dubai is actually, as a woman, one of the most equal playing fields that I have had the opportunity of working in. And I think that this is something that Dubai does very, very well. There are some incredibly successful Emirati businesswomen. Dubai is very much a work-hard environment, but I enjoy that. Business in Dubai works both very quickly and very slowly, so you need to be a very tenacious individual to be able to push pieces of paper around and not get beaten down by some of the processes.
node.sections31: I think that when the financial crisis arrived, everyone predicted various scenarios. I always thought that it would be seven years before the world economy got back on its feet, and it has taken a bit longer because there have been too many false starts. International governments injected funds, but these failed due to a number of reasons, amongst them there being too little too often. However, having recovered, I would like to think that Dubai will experience the steady growth that it had up until 2002. In 2002, the economy of Dubai was very stable. The quality of work and what was produced was at its highest, and that fell during the boom. I can see a recovery of that now with expectations of quality being higher.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist3company: BASF FZE & BASF Kanoo Gulf LLC, U.A.E.
node.subject: Why Dubai?
node.title: Perfect Examples
node.sections01: Dubai is the hub for the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan [MENAP] region. DuPont is well positioned for accelerated and sustainable growth in the UAE, which represents one of the fastest-growing markets for the company. DuPont is committed to supporting and participating in the new economic, industrial, and scientific developments in the UAE. The accessibility of Dubai also makes it easy to operate from. A lot of key decisions are made in Dubai. Over the last three years, we have tripled our employee count in the UAE. With a strong and diverse team in the UAE, we are continuing to expand our capabilities on the ground and that will help us better serve the local market. This is a perfect example of our ambitious plans for growth. Dubai has been a great location for us to grow and expand due to its business-friendly environment. We see strong opportunities in the UAE, and indeed throughout the GCC region. The next step for us in Dubai will be looking into the possibility of bringing DuPont science and innovation and providing localized solutions. The transfer of knowledge is an ongoing priority for years to come. We will be aggressively working on embedding our scientific knowledge.
node.sections11: Dubai is one of our larger territories in the whole of Africa and the Middle East, and also one of the key growth areas for Caterpillar. The entire region of Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and the CIS is managed from our head offices in Geneva. Given the volume and growth from the Middle East we clearly wanted to further establish ourselves in the region. We have already been operating from a marketing and sales support office in Dubai since the early 1980s. Yet with the increased volume of business, we decided to invest in a parts distribution center to better support our dealers and customers in the territory as well as in the nearer African countries. That decision was already taken prior to the crisis and temporarily suspended right after the crisis, and in 2011/2012 brought to completion. The logistics, infrastructure, and ease of doing business are all contributing factors to opt for Dubai as the location for our regional office. In addition, the safety and relatively low risk of doing business when compared to other countries in the region also plays a role.
node.sections21: Sovereign Middle East has been licensed in Dubai since 1998 and is now one of the largest corporate services providers operating in the Middle East. We are also a registered agent for the free zones of Dubai, as well as Ras Al Khaimah and Jebel Ali. We have further expanded our presence in the Gulf states by opening offices in both Bahrain and Abu Dhabi. There are no income or capital taxes in Dubai, except for oil and domestic banking, and no withholding tax. Companies in Dubai can obtain further significant advantages from the absence of foreign exchange controls, trade barriers, or quotas. The UAE also has a number of double taxation treaties with high-tax countries, giving investors an extensive choice of markets for a diverse portfolio of goods and services. When Sovereign first entered the Middle East market, our business was primarily based on providing offshore companies and management services for asset holding purposes. Now we are getting more involved with foreign firms and entrepreneurs that are coming to the Gulf to generate business here, and I think that this trend will accelerate as local markets mature and expand and particularly as we move toward Expo 2020 in Dubai.
node.sections31: BASF has been in the Middle East for almost 50 years now. Proximity to our clients is very important to BASF, as it allows us to give them the best possible service. We launched our global strategy in 2010, which we started rolling out across different parts of the world. In 2011 it was Russia, in 2012 it was Africa, and 2013 it was the Middle East. With the “We create chemistry" strategy, BASF has set itself ambitious goals in order to strengthen its position as the world's leading chemical company. BASF's Middle East strategy, formulated in 2013, is in line with the global one, which is to “create chemistry for a sustainable future". We also have four strategic principles, namely: we add value as one integrated company; we innovate to make our customers more successful; we drive sustainable solutions; and we form the best team. We are committed to the Middle East, and are working to provide the same excellent service that we offer in other parts of the world. BASF has more than 750 employees in the region. In Dubai, starting from the 1980s, we have been involved with prominent projects and megaprojects in the Emirate, such as the Dubai Creek, Ferrari World, the Burj Khalifa, and the Dubai Metro.
node.sections41: Much more than just a city itself, Dubai is a gateway to the rest of the world. Africa, for instance, is rapidly developing today. Any enterprise looking to enter this continent is advised to establish their base in Dubai. Naturally, the same goes for those businesses keen on doing business in the GCC and MENA region. The AFC codes, being common law codes, are now considered as UAE codes and the government has conceived it long back. The UAE is the safest place to run a business headquarters within the GCC trade agreement area. When viewed from the West, the UAE is a gateway to Asia, and at the end of the day, Dubai is a very safe destination and has offered solid business potential over past four decades and undoubtedly, will inspire entrepreneurs for centuries to come.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Senior Executive Officer & Head of Client Management for the MEA region,
node.subject: Foreign Banks
node.title: Bags Of Prospect
node.sections01: Dubai is benefiting from the regional infrastructure boom in Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and neighboring states. About 55% of exports into the GCC come from Dubai. We forecast trade rising by between 12% and 15% in 2014, and, thus, a strong repeat performance. In tourism, too, we saw another strong year in 2013. Occupancy in hotels was at around 81%, while tourist numbers were up 11% in the first half of last year—and we're expecting a similar increase this year. Our operative slogan is “Dubai; emerging stronger, looking forward." While 2014 has the same core drivers, we are observing changes within them. For example, in commerce, we see the emergence of new trade and investment corridors. In the region, Iraq is becoming a key trading partner, while Africa-Dubai trade relations are becoming increasingly important.
node.sections11: Our strategy is very simple; to invest in people and attract a wide array of bankers to look beyond private banking toward investment banking and asset management. And, obviously, when one brings in people, a simultaneous infrastructure investment is essential. Investment in IT, HR, general operations, and real estate has been quite substantial. We selected Dubai as the hub from which to service our other regional operations, such as those in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Lebanon, Egypt, and even South Africa. All of these markets are supported in terms of IT and shared services from here in Dubai.
node.sections21: The finance sector has improved dramatically. On the regulatory side, the central bank has applied many steps and introduced regulatory requirements to enhance the business environment in Dubai, and the UAE in general. On the financial side, the local banks have improved greatly to mitigate risks and enhance their creditability and meet capital requirements. This has been improving over the last few years. We have also witnessed the central bank introducing many requirements on real estate regulation and lending practices. These will help avoid further crises in the future. The other area where I see improvement is in compliance, as it becomes an important issue for both local and international banks. I see many additional resources on the compliance side that have been put in place by the local banks, which in turn helps international banks to cooperate with them on a more solid footing.
node.sections31: Obviously not all banks are on par when it comes to cost of funding, but given the high level of liquidity and financing needs in the region it is not so difficult to be involved in “plain vanilla" financing. When it comes to structured finance, it is different. Project finance advisory is not a given strength for all banks. Every bank has areas of specific expertise, and one of Société Générale's key expertise lies in natural resources and energy where we have a global franchise both in advising and financing projects. As a global finance, derivatives, and structuring house in many different asset classes, we have a recognized strength when it comes to structuring in general. We have the capacity to come up with tailor-made solutions for our clients, whether it is on the financing side or on the investor side.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: General Manager UAE and Global Accounts Lead
node.subject: Payment Providers
node.title: Packaging Planet
node.sections01: As a technology company in the payments industry, innovation is at the heart of everything we do at MasterCard. But what exactly is innovation? A lot of people think that innovation means coming up with a new gadget. But that's not necessarily what it is about. It can also be about changing a current process—taking something that exists and finding a way to make it more efficient or convenient for the user. The UAE is a priority market for us in the Middle East, and we are leading the way with innovative payment products and solutions that provide issuers, merchants, and corporations with better choices and channels to grow their businesses, besides also providing unique benefits, rewards, and experiences that are aligned with the cardholder's lifestyle. In the UAE, we have collaborated with several financial institutions to introduce customized payment solutions that have been appreciated by the banks' customers and have also won industry accolades.
node.sections11: Network International is primarily in the payment processing business, and we have two core verticals to our business: issuer processing and acquirer processing. To grasp what we do in terms of processing, think about getting a credit card from your bank. You must apply to the bank, it sends the credit card, you use the card, and then you receive a monthly statement to pay off. Someone needs to do all the work at the back-end, from printing the card, sending it out, monitoring the monthly statements, making sure payments are posted, and that the entire process is done efficiently, seamlessly, and in a timely manner. That is one part of our business that is called issuer processing. Acquirer processing involves what happens once a consumer receives their card and wants to use it, for instance at a retail outlet. All of the back-end processes from processing a transaction at a merchant outlet, getting money from a consumer's card, settling with the merchant, and reconciling the transaction all in a manner of seconds while a consumer is at the merchant checkout, is managed by us.
node.sections21: Dubai is a key market for Visa. We recently strengthened our operations base here in Dubai to manage 92 countries across Central and Eastern Europe and the Middle East and Africa. We are bringing many new resources and people into the country to serve our customers across the region, which will ultimately benefit the city. This move highlights our commitment to driving the electronification of payments in Dubai and confidence in the Emirate as the base of our regional operations, and reinforces the growth and increasing importance of Dubai as a regional and global player. There are a number of reasons why Dubai has been considered our headquarters. First of all, it is the hub point of our various locations, easily accessible for both our staff and clients. It is also easy to do business here because of the robust infrastructure. In addition, local legislation definitely fosters business and attracts foreign investment.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Development Outlook
node.title: Up & Outward
node.sections01: Freight forwarding is huge; however, we mostly specialize in sea and airfreight. We do very little land freight now; our number one activity is sea freight, with number two being air, and land is number three. In the area of customs clearance, we are well-enough established in the market to deal with any problems, and we have a good reputation with our customers. Customs clearance in Lebanon is not an easy business, but we are tough enough in customs clearance to handle any challenge. We also offer all other logistic services than any forwarder would do. We have door delivery, packaging, insurance, and warehousing. Lebanon is not an exporting country; it is mostly an importer. Freight forwarders that are strong and have a lot of power in exports are rare. For me, ABC Shipping is, if you want to have some sort of ranking, in the top 10 for sea freight exports in the country. We have great relationships with the major players, such as Maersk Line and CMA.
node.sections11: There is no doubt that Lebanon as a whole has been affected by the regional political environment. However, Chaddad Group hasn't been affected yet in Lebanon by these outcomes due to its strategy, which has made the whole company capable of emerging outside Lebanon. In addition to the business in Lebanon, Chaddad has other businesses abroad and development projects in Europe. We are also seriously studying several potential development projects in Lebanon. We believe that there are still opportunities to seize in the real estate sector. The demand for smaller apartments in prime locations is still very high. We are also developing a project in Algeria that is comprised of two towers of 20 floors each. The project should be delivered by end-2016.
node.sections21: Loft Construction was founded in 2005. The idea behind it is to offer something different to the local market. At that time, the real estate market was booming. Basically, we were thinking that the market would reach a point where people would become selective in their choices. All the buildings looked alike, meaning the prices would eventually fall unless you offered something different in the sense of creating a niche in the market. We have created such a niche for expatriates who mostly lived abroad in places such as New York or London and were familiar with the loft concept: industrial spaces, high ceilings, where luxury would not be simply defined by the type of bathrooms that you install, but by the design.
node.sections31: We have started many projects, and have completed maybe 150 projects in total. Currently, Beam's major project is the Rue Damas Tower, which is almost finished. Ciel et Jardin is another large project, which should finish in three years' time. It is a tower of 35 stories with three technical floors, a ground floor, and five basements. It is a purely residential building. But really, we are somewhat on hold. We are a bit hesitant to start most of our projects right now. The ones we have already started, we are still working on them, but we are on hold for the new ones because we are a bit worried about the economics of the situation. We Lebanese are a bit crazy sometimes; we jump into projects even though we are fighting, as we know things will eventually pick up. But right now, we are not worried about the Lebanese situation; we are worried about the Syrian border.
node.sections41: Real estate has always been a pillar of the economy of Lebanon; however, we have been through times when anyone could build anything and it would sell. Now, it is different. Today, you have to know the product that you are offering, because the market is tight, especially during these times, when the economy is not in the best shape. Our signature is to create a new trend in the Hazmieh region of Beirut—small units, in a trendy project, with high-quality specifications. Today, we offer 75-sqm apartments for $150,000. We believe that this is the type of property most needed in Lebanon.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Maritime
node.title: Smooth Sailing
node.sections01: Our company is around 90% imports and 10% exports. We conduct all of our exports with other companies, carrying out only the logistics. Usually, in Lebanon, the customer goes straight to the carrier for exports. About 75% of the full-container cargo at Global Freight and Logistics (GFL) goes to Africa. Perhaps only 6%-7% goes from Lebanon to the Middle East. In terms of what we import, around 50% comes from China to Lebanon, and 45% from Europe. We get some raw materials from Saudi Arabia and Dubai as well. These raw materials are to make juice, wine, dyes, and coloring for textiles. Lebanon generally imports raw materials for textiles and then exports to third countries. While freight for order is based on containers, groupage, and airfreight clearance, packing is our specialty. When you go to Africa the rate is given from the carrier to the customer, and it is better than the rate given by freight for order. The carrier needs the cargo to be exported from Beirut, which affects the rate of the import. To get a competitive rate for imports, you absolutely need export cargo.
node.sections11: In Lebanon, not many deal in dangerous cargo (hazardous material). This highlights the importance of being able to move critical cargo, like biological substances or goods that are time sensitive. For example, we had a shipment of medicine for patients and it was moved in a cryo-shipper, which is a box that no one else has in Lebanon. We buy it from suppliers in the UK, Germany, and the US. We ship blood samples packed with dry ice to laboratories in the UK that must be delivered under 24 hours. We do this basically every day. Per year, we are talking about 4,000 shipments, so that is about 10 per day.
node.sections21: We do what others don't. For example, we worked with a major courier company that can't handle dangerous cargo. It had a shipment of lithium batteries, which required special treatment and extraordinary packaging. You cannot load this kind of cargo onto passenger aircraft; you have to load it onto cargo aircraft without passengers. That service requires a special license, and we specialize in that area.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Higher Education
node.title: Set Up Campus
node.sections01: Université La Sagesse (ULS) was founded in 1875, making it 140 years old in 2014. The university has evolved from a college that taught law to introduce new faculties and disciplines, such as business administration, political science and international relations, hotel management, religious studies, canon law, and ecclesial sciences. Additionally, there are 22 Master's degree programs. Administratively speaking, previously there was one head that ran the entire university.
