I believe the city still has considerable potential in terms of construction; however, we must respect history and culture, as well as current legislation, because the city has yet to reach its full potential. In this context, tourism and construction have to go hand-in-hand to better meet the future growth potential of the city.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Key Account Manager & Country Lead for Colombia
node.intervieweelist3position: District Manager Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Peru, Central America, Caribbean
node.subject: IT Hardware
node.title: The Right Interface
node.sections01: The government is generating opportunities and increasing our coverage across the industry. The access to technology helps improve the quality of life in poorer nations, addressing key issues such as unemployment, poverty, and connectivity, and it is a major differentiator for the economy. We aim to help the population to be connected to opportunities and boost their livelihoods. We are growing across the consumer business, SME, and large corporate business segments, where each makes a positive contribution to our numbers. On the other hand, we have our tablet business. Samsung, Apple, and Lenovo lead the market. Currently, there are many players and unbranded products, but these are the top three players. Meanwhile, we now also offer cell phones, although at this point, we are not as large a player as we would like to be. Colombia was in fact the first country in Latin America offering Lenovo smartphones. We need to drive our business to the next generation, taking into consideration how we address our efficiencies and speed. We are growing our business contribution to the networking of smaller cities.
node.sections11: The growth of the IT industry has gone hand in hand with the expansion of the national economy. We should highlight the role of national authorities, and in particular of the Ministry of Telecommunications, as there has been a clear understanding of the sector's potential. We believe that by technologically educating society, we contribute to increased employability. We also have a strong focus on SMEs, which are one of the core economic engines for Colombia, and we provide the technical support they need for development and expansion. According to the latest official data on market share, Hewlett-Packard (HP) holds a 30% market share of the PC segment, being the leading company; whereas in the printers and server segments we hold around a 60% market share. Looking to the future, we see cloud services, big data, mobility, and security as being the key strategic elements of the industry. For this reason, we will focus on developing services and products within these four segments.
node.sections21: As demand grows across Colombia, new technologies will emerge to meet it in a more efficient manner. 5G will mean more capacity, better use of the resources (spectrum), better quality and more bandwidth for the end user. At the same time end-users will want more capacity and have more requirements. Machine-to-Machine will be one of the main drivers for those network requirements. For example, if you analyze the connections people require currently, you have a telephone, iPad, PC, TV, car, and home security, amongst other things. One of the government's main targets during the last three years was to close the gap we have between the different levels of society. And, the steps Colombia has taken over the past two or three years have produced positive results. During the last three years, the government has been working on its Vive Digital plan. Basically, the project was aimed at installing a broadband connection into all small villages across the country. The government's target was to have at least 1,000 small villages connected by August 2014, and it has reached, or is at least close to, that target already.
node.sections31: The ICT sector is a significant part of the Colombian economy. From a government perspective, it serves two roles: it helps to remove all possible barriers and makes it easy for the private sector and the government to acquire cutting-edge technology at affordable prices, which plays an important role in encouraging industry. We ended 2013 as Intel's only growth market in Latin America, and even more interesting was the growth in our leading-edge categories, for example Ultrabooks, 2-in-1 devices, and tablets—we lead the region by far. Ultrabooks are the technology of this decade. Right now, tablet computers and cellphones are our next step. There has been a delay in emerging markets in general, and in Colombia in particular, from the time we launched the new technology internationally. Once the barriers have disappeared, it was an invitation to invest more. We have been able to not only close that gap, but encourage the growth of cutting-edge technology in Colombia. In many cases, we have cheaper computers in Colombia than in the benchmark market, which is North America.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Local Developers
node.title: Code of Honor
node.sections01: The CCIT is the association that groups together and represents the largest players in the Colombian ICT sector. Among our associates we have operators, telecom providers, as well as large IT companies. It is interesting to see that the mobile device market, as in other parts of the world, is experiencing a steep upward trend. Thanks to efforts made by the Colombian government in previous years to bring down import tariffs, as well as VAT on personal computers, Colombia has the cheapest PCs in the region. However, this is still not the case for smartphones. The business software alliance calculates that in Colombia, 53% of the software is pirated, which is something we take seriously at CCIT, and we are working very closely with the government to resolve this. It is not only an IPR issue, but also one of lost tax revenues. The Colombian government is leaving a lot of money on the table by not legalizing each percentage point of the usage of that software. The growth potential is enormous and eventually we are going to be talking about software solutions for the mobile market as well.
node.sections11: The government of Colombia has implemented ambitious initiatives within the IT sector, such as democratizing internet access across the country and setting up an optic fiber network in its main cities and municipalities. The authorities are transforming the internet into a tool capable of improving the lives of Colombians. The only area in which we are lagging behind is content. SIESA was established over 30 years ago on the back of the innovative attitudes of its founders. We have a long and well-established tradition and relationship with other businesses in the Cauca Valley. SIESA became a leading company in the region due to its provision of software solutions for local businesses, especially large enterprises. After that, we grew both nationally and internationally; today we have over 10,000 clients in Colombia and over 100 abroad in eight countries in the region. Our main objectives are to consolidate our leading position in the national market; simultaneously, we want to further consolidate our activity abroad. Despite the fact that it took us some time, we finally offer a cloud product. It has been a process of teaching business the benefits of the cloud model, and at the moment we already have several clients using SIESA cloud services. We also have our mobile product which when first developed had a strong focus on the commercial side of companies; supplies, deliveries, money management, and related services.
node.sections21: We carry out a fully comprehensive and integrated process whereby we provide specialists in economics, communications, and marketing, among other areas. However, we base our entire activity on new technologies. In the beginning, the company used to sell software, and then we started to install networks and offer services. We also have our software production center. We like to call ourselves a shared service center that provides fully integrated solutions to businesses by generating value-added for companies by contributing to the efficiency of the processes. ADA provides a unique technological platform for over 4,000 educational centers by grouping them together under 480 educational funds, and we provide the required platform for these centers to better administrate and control their activity and development. From our early stages of developing the company, we started providing software solutions and packages to government authorities and institutions. Since then, we have understood the possibilities of that market niche, considering that most of the players have traditionally focused on the private sector. In this context, we understand that we can easily become a strong player if we focus more resources and efforts on providing services to the public sector.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Land Transportation
node.title: The Right Road
node.richbody0content:
DAVID MATTOS LACOUTURE

DARIO AMAR

JUAN GONZALO MAYA MOLINA

© The Business Year
node.sections01: There is a development plan for the national transportation sector, but there is no long-term growth structure. One of the main problems in Colombia, and not just in this industry, is the tendency for short- to medium-term planning. This means that once a project is in execution, it is already at maximum capacity. Sparta noticed that in Colombia 80% of transportation is informal; trucks are owned by and passed down through families. There are no real logistics involved, but merely the provision of a temporary solution to someone in need of transportation. We therefore have the potential to become a logistics consultant providing solutions and expertise on the trucking industry worldwide. Sparta provides the structure to fully understand the transportation industry, because without such a structure, work is inefficient. Sparta promotes being fully involved in all aspects of the business, including structural planning. There are several other companies that can offer this service, but they are too large for this market. Large consultancies are not helpful for small or medium-sized companies, but are, in contrast, our target demographic.
node.sections11: The key factor is having Colombian human resources focused on transportation. We started in the main cities of Cali and Bogotá, looking for ways to run international functions, such as analytics, and service provision to citizens using Colombian tools and resources. Secondly, some years ago we started to integrate ITS solutions, sourced from North America, Australia, Brazil, and Spain, among others. We aligned those tools to Colombian software and resources to develop local solutions. Our key offer is that we replicate and improve products we see in the market at competitive prices specifically tailored to local solutions. Our market has some unfortunate differences from Spain, as for example, road conditions, lack of infrastructure and even security, whereby we have to adapt. Colombia, for every 100 people, has around eight cars, whereas Brazil and Mexico have closer to between 20 to 25. Over the past decade, the prices of motorcycles has halved to $500 due to the importation of Chinese models. The same has happened with motor vehicles, the range of which has increased over the past five years. And of course our own sector builds on this. It is a question of digitalizing multiple transactions, such as those performed during the ownership of a vehicle, from the purchase and taxation, right through to any fines incurred during ownership, and finally the sale of the vehicle.
node.sections21: Over the years, we have expanded our portfolio of services. We started with the consolidation of logistics services to and from the ports, supporting the activity of exporters. Our company was established in, and is headquartered in, Medellí­n and is fully committed to the city. At the moment, we have a network of 32 sales points across the country. Transportes Botero Soto also offers logistics solutions for companies, which means we develop and deliver internal logistics plans for them to become more efficient. Also, we fully address the logistics demands of companies 24/7 with our own resources, and are not dependent upon third parties. Right now, our company handles an average of 70,000 cargo transport movements every year. In terms of our future plans, we are set to introduce Oracle Transportation Management (OTM) services, enabling us to bring goods and cargo from anywhere in the world to Colombia, and we are continually upgrading our systems and capabilities to continue offering a unique service.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Advisors
node.title: Prognosis: Positive
node.sections01: TINSA has developed its own strategy, which has been widely awarded in Europe. For example, the real estate exhibition in Madrid and the Bank of Spain awarded our in-house developed methodologies. We have in-depth knowledge of the real estate sector and the products that are selling in the countries in which we operate. We aim to further the professionalization of the sector. Currently, it lacks regulation and formal structure, and is open to all types of competitor. TINSA is working to introduce certain regulatory barriers and professionalism in methodology and business practices. In this context, we have received positive feedback from banking institutions, which are pleased with our methodology and the quality of the results. Today, Banco de Bogotá and BBVA are our two main clients in terms of volume, and we are also increasing our take in smaller banks, in the hope that in the future our participation in the market will grow substantially. We plan to expand our activities in the public sector, as we have highly specific products that would suit its needs.
node.sections11: Our company is focused on the corporate real estate business; the major movement in our sector comes from the amount of international companies that are arriving in Colombia. In the past five years, we have seen at least 3,000 multinationals arrive looking for offices, retail, or logistical space. Obviously, every single one of these arriving businesses has an impact on the residential market as well. We target high-end residential properties, known here as strata 5 and 6, mostly in large cities like Bogotá, Baranquilla, Medellí­n, and Cali, and this market has also been very dynamic in the past couple of years. Basically, there is a great deal of trust in the country on the part of investors. The fact that Colombia, in a certain way, was closed to the world meant that it was not part of the growth strategy of most of the retail companies and big multinationals. The crisis in Europe and the US has made Colombia attractive, and this market is one of the most favorable prospects for these companies for the next five years.
node.sections21: Bubbles are driven by oversupply and excessive debt, but I do not really see a bubble here. Instead, I see a scarcity of land due to the absence of urban renewal legislation, mainly in Bogotá. It is very difficult to find areas larger than 2,500 sqm to build interesting developments that make urban sense, and which could include complementary, mixed-use spaces. My perception is that we are making updates very rapidly, that land prices aren't in keeping with construction capacity according to the norm (residual value), and that the city needs to grow denser, vertically, rather than expanding horizontally. CREA's objective is to structure successful commercial projects, thus filling a gap in the market. We have very good builders and large funds with great provision of capital, but none is ready to develop an asset and take the commercial risk. Investors consider long-term viability and rental potential based on what they pay per square meter. In my experience, from an investor's perspective in Colombia, it's not easy to find someone to advise on such transactions. And CREA's mission is to be the best advisor in the technical, commercial, and financial segments.
node.sections31: The housing segment is clearly experiencing a boom in all echelons of society, especially in Colombia's so called strata 5 and 6, where prices are growing very rapidly. Regarding the lower strata, government-led programs are also driving housing market development. Meanwhile, the situation in the office, industrial, and logistics segments is essentially the same; the construction of infrastructure and new units in these segments is currently seeing excellent growth. For example, the stock of office space in Bogotá—1.6 million sqm—is twice what it was back in 2008, and we predict that it will grow by more than 50% over the next five years, reaching 2.5 million sqm. Bogotá needs office blocks with a single owner, as this structure is almost non-existent here. Multinational companies require an average of 700 sqm of quality office space, and Bogotá cannot meet this demand today because most buildings are condo-type properties with many different owners owning smaller office suites. Ideally, these offices should be located in strata 6, as this area represents more than 70% of the city's current quality office stock.
node.sections41: I believe that a period of price stabilization is close at hand. I do not expect there to be a housing bubble because interest rates are low and because all the assets that have been constructed are not backed by much credit. The buyers are not in leveraged positions and the interest rates are not high. I recommend that investors find opportunities in the middle class housing sector, in social strata three and four. High-end housing, from strata 5 to 6, is too small and unrepresentative. We manage and administer assets for investment funds and carry out facility management for about 66% of Bogotá's corporate buildings. The ideal way for small investors to proceed is through real estate funds, and for institutional clients we can analyze investment alternatives in Bogotá. The returns institutional clients can earn through investing in the development of projects along with local construction companies range from the 8% level with a revaluation figure of 5% to reach a target of 13% to 14%.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Outsourcing
node.title: Time Out
node.sections01: We are involved in business process outsourcing (BPO), including the outsourcing of logistic, administrative, retail, and commercial outsourcing processes. Another large area for us is BPO Voice, which basically involves a call center or contract center. We have two other areas of work, one of which is represented by our Avanza Institute. Here, we provide training for companies, including leadership coaching and specialized training for various clients. We also offer outsourcing services in the health sector, including in-call care for the elderly. We are set to end the year on ‚¬10 million in revenues. We already have 20% of the global employees here in Colombia. In our first year, we sold ‚¬200,000 and now we are going on for ‚¬10 million. In 2015 the figure should reach ‚¬50 million.
node.sections11: Thanks to government strategy, investments, and innovation in its systems, cities and education programs have demonstrated to other nations the potential and stability this country offers. In Colombia, more than 80% of new businesses disappear during the first five years and an average of 90% will not survive more than 10 years. This data clearly highlights a weakness in business management. We come in by offering products to help local businesses grow, while also fortifying our users' marketing efforts. We do this though events, courses, and content exclusive to all MyLocal users. We don't want to just sell, but also to guide and help sustain local businesses. We currently have over 75 employees worldwide, with monthly growth of around 10%. Talent is our most important consideration, right after our clients' needs.
node.sections21: We believe that our business model and development perfectly fit the ideas of innovation and creativity that the city heavily promotes. We have developed the e-office concept and through it, as well as our long list of alliances and partnerships, we have helped local companies to open premises in other areas, such as Europe, creating direct connections with almost 70 countries. We have clients from many different sectors: health, services, new technologies, and small entrepreneurs. We currently offer office spaces that go from 10 sqm to over 110 sqm, as well as all the services a company needs to start operating, even with an employee to undertake administrative tasks. We first started out with analog telephony services, delivered through IP systems, and have grown to have over 60 clients in our portfolio, including IBM and Accenture.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Air Sector Outlook
node.title: Jet Set You Bet
node.sections01: We are looking to develop connectivity through different modes of transport. The policy of this government is to improve all existing transport options, from air connections to roads. Air is the most expensive way to transport cargo or passengers, so it is important to be aware of the subsectors. Perishable goods need to be moved efficiently and quickly. In Colombia, the transport of refrigerated fresh flowers, as well as tropical fruit, is a major area of business. In addition, urgent items delivered through companies such as DHL or UPS are also crucial, particularly for items such as newspapers and magazines and other items for next-day delivery. There is also the luxury category, which requires items to be moved with minimal risk of damage during transit. I believe that Colombia, Barranquilla, and this airport can become the breadbasket for all of the Caribbean islands. That is the way forward, and it is also the reason we need to establish both an agricultural and logistics center here, in order to both produce and, ultimately, deliver.
node.sections11: In 2013, the company managed to grow at a rate of around 12% in the domestic market and 35% in the international market. LAN currently operates from 20 destinations, with 22 routes in Colombia alone. We believe that one of our best achievements has to do with our leadership in terms of on time performance over 2012 and 2013, with domestic flights achieving 88% on time performance rates. Furthermore, we increased capacity by more than 30% on several international flights, such as São Paulo and Miami, thanks to the fact that we started operating Boeing 767 double-aisle aircraft. The most important routes are those that generate the highest volume, such as Cali, Medellí­n, Cartagena, and Barranquilla. LAN Colombia represents around 5% of LATAM´s overall traffic and should continue to grow for the foreseeable future. Colombia is also the second largest cargo market in South America after Brazil, which spells considerable opportunities for us.
node.sections21: In Colombia, we are doing the same as in the rest of Latin America, and concentrating on underserved markets; in other words those cities where connectivity remains below average. We pioneered international service in Bucaramanga and Cúcuta, providing a convenient one-stop service to the Caribbean, and North, Central, and South America, which nobody else is flying to. We have the shortest connecting times in many of our flights through our Hub de las Americas making it arguably the most efficient hub in Latin America today. Basically, there is no big secret behind our success; it is a case of serving with an efficient and convenient product the underserved cities of the continent. Over the past two and a half years, we have grown by almost 55%. On top of that we are due to receive eight aircraft in 2014, all 737s with the latest Boeing generation sky interiors, and, therefore, expect to grow by around 11%. We should highlight that this is a greatly significant pace when compared with industry growth rates and we feel extremely positive about 2014.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Maritime Sector
node.title: The Boatman's Call
node.sections01: Overall, 2013 has proven to be, once again, a difficult year for the shipping industry. There has been a significant lack of growth in the container industry throughout the world since 2008. We are now beginning to understand that this is the new reality of the volume growth of the shipping business. Prior to 2008, the container industry grew at 10% per year. Since 2008, we have been seeing a different kind of trend. There are a number of reasons for this reduced growth, but principally it is due to the fact that China's global sourcing of goods has stagnated, and consequently stagnating container volumes. The FTA with Mexico, as well as those with the US and Chile, has shown that, within five years, there will be a doubling or tripling in the interchange of goods. The US is quicker at reacting and bringing in more imports, but it usually ends up that the exporters are the big winners. About 40% of global consumption is in the US, and I'm sure that Colombia is going to find some way to get a slice of that. Colombia used to export to 70 destinations in the US, but since the FTA this figure has increased to around 500.
node.sections11: Colombia has a range of multi-purpose port facilities. The draft capacity at our ports is greater, and can handle containers, grain, and coal all at one place. All port activities were privatized between 1992 and 1993. Barranquilla is labeled as the capital of the US-Colombia Free Trade Agreement (FTA), and has done an extremely good job, not only in terms of public investment, but also in bridging the gulf between the public and private sectors. The fact is that the market has changed quite considerably for us, and until 10 years ago we were basically the only port in Barranquilla. That is not the case anymore, and we have 25 concessions, eight of which are operational, while three have yet to become efficient enough to run well. The Port of Barranquilla changed hands in late 2012, and the new administration activated major investments in equipment and infrastructure, which are ongoing. We have an investment plan of $180 million, of which we have already invested $85 million.
node.sections21: Colombia has been dreaming of a new navigable river for the past 80 years, although it is clear that the country has prioritized the development of road transportation. Bearing this in mind, we have achieved much over the past two years; we have pursued studies at an international level and are now in partnership with several companies and institutions to open the tender process in 2014. Recovering the Magdalena River for navigation purposes is a huge undertaking in terms of investment and infrastructure. It will help the country to divert road traffic to the water, reducing traffic and accidents on some of the country's main roads. However, the main advantage of this project will be the rise in the competitiveness of local products, as they will be able to reach maritime ports at lower costs, in direct contrast to the high cost of transporting goods from the center of the country to Colombia's Caribbean ports for export. We will have reached our target of 908 navigable kilometers by 2019, with depth and width navigation conditions that will enable us to guarantee the year-round navigation of barge convoys of 7,200 tons.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Retail
node.title: Our House
node.sections01: By 2013, Colombia had 183 shopping centers of over 5,000 sqm of GLA (gross leasable area). We believe that the smaller cities have the most potential. Historically, in Colombia the shopping center industry has grown in the five main cities: Bogotá, Barranquilla, Cali, Medellí­n, and Cartagena. However, over the past three to four years, the real growth in the industry has been in the mid-sized cities. Approximately five years ago, a shopping center in Colombia would usually only have been constructed in a city with a minimum population of 500,000. Today, however, that threshold has dropped to 100,000 people. For this reason, we have shopping centers in 44 cities in Colombia currently. Palmira, Jamundí­, and Yumbo, all near Cali, offer a number of opportunities for investors. People from Cali, which has a population of 2.3 million, are now relocating to these other cities. In the same way, people from these cities usually work in Cali, and enjoy a healthy consumption capacity. This condition, increases household income and total spending. In Buga and Tulua, middle class consumption is growing, making them interesting markets to invest in too.
node.sections11: From my Chilean perspective, Colombia is a bigger market. Chile's population of about 17 million starkly contrasts to Colombia's of 45 million people. Furthermore, Chile has one city, namely Santiago, which alone accounts for around 70% of GDP. In Colombia there are different cities over which GDP is more evenly spread. Bogotá for example represents about 30%-35% of national GDP, and other centers also have significant representation in the country. Medellí­n has about three and a half million people, Cali has about 3 million people, while Barranquilla has about 1.5 million inhabitants. Additionally, there are more than fifteen cities with over three hundred thousand inhabitants. These are all highly interesting markets for a Chilean company. Moreover, the rising purchasing power of Colombia's middle class is another magnet for investment. Traditionally, in Colombia, the developer sells the stores. In contrast, our model involves keeping and maintaining 100% of the property, and managing it, along with the tenant mix. If you are an investor, you only care about who pays you the most. There are even examples in Colombia of shopping malls that feature adult entertainment or casinos, which is not an appropriate family ambience. Such venues simply target revenues, whereas we are interested in the nature of the venue itself.
node.sections21: Income levels in Barranquilla are lower than the national average, though the city has a lot of land available. Although development has been increasing, the land remains inexpensive compared to other Colombian cities. Still, there has been a level of speculation as the city has been booming over the past three or four years. However, there is a lot on offer, and perhaps we have seen demand decline in the luxury market. I believe the city is seeing strength in the office segment, though there are many projects being realized. There is also a lot on offer in the warehousing segment. I surmise that prices will stabilize over the short to medium term. Constructora Rumié is involved with developing PriceSmart's wholesale infrastructure in Colombia, and is looking to complete at least some of its local facilities. I am also collaborating with industrial groups from Bogotá. TLC Industrial Park in Cartagena is another project we are working on. Finally, we have a few residential projects that we are looking to launch, though are trying to put together a package that will appeal to investors.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Construction Sector Opportunities
node.title: Riding The Wave
node.sections01: Our company started off as a family business 21 years ago. Since then, we have specialized mainly in upscale office and residential construction projects in the northeastern part of Bogotá. This specialized focus over the past two decades has earned us a reputation for excellent quality and design in the projects we carry out. We want to diversify our business and move more toward institutional and office projects. Our biggest ongoing projects right now are office schemes, because there is significant demand for office space considering the foreign players that have been entering the Colombian market in recent years. Construction financing in Colombia is very well structured. The economic crisis in 1998 created a robust fiduciary system that enables investors, developers, and end-buyers to operate in a much safer, more secure, and less risky market. Previously, a constructor had to build a whole building and sell it off like that, but the fiduciary system today enables both the buyer and the project promoter to base the financing and completion of the building on a guaranteed volume of sales, supported by mortgages, so they don't begin construction until those guarantees are in place.
node.sections11: Thanks to the growth trends the country enjoys, the sector foresees a similar expansion over the next few years to that it experienced in the past three to five years. We could divide the main driving forces in the sector into two; the housing segment and the public infrastructure segment. I think the four power generation projects will capitalize on the growth of the sector in the near future, especially within the framework of the free trade agreements (FTAs) signed with the US and South Korea, for example. Regarding the real estate segment, we have recently seen fluctuations that are normal in the sector, and I expect these growth trends to continue for quite some time. There is still great potential for development in the entire country—since we are located on the coast, there is great potential in the second house market. As the purchasing power of society continues growing, I expect this particular segment to also expand in the near future.
node.sections21: Construction is definitely the key instrument of economic growth, and the government's social policy builds 280,000 homes a year. President Santos' government has established a set of economic drivers, the most productive of which, especially since his second year, has been construction. According to the National Administrative Department of Statistics (DANE), construction has two branches, namely civil works and infrastructure, and buildings. Put together, these categories account for 7% of GDP. But if you added to that all industrial and services activities related to construction, the number could reach 20%. That is why construction is so important as a generator of employment and economic growth. So how do we arrive at the 20% figure? Whenever a bar of steel, a brick, an item of furniture, or a piece of pottery is made in Colombia, it is added to the industrial sector category in calculating GDP. And when a mortgage or insurance policy is provided, or when the wages on a trust are paid, it is added to the financial services subsector. Were you to take everything related to construction and real estate from the services, industrial, and commercial sector categories and add them to the construction activities category, you could easily reach 18% or 20% of GDP. That is why this sector is so important, not least as a massive generator of employment.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Palm Oil
node.title: Slick Look
node.sections01: By our calculations, around 40 million hectares are available for agricultural activities nationwide. Yet currently, production is notably below the potential yield due in part to extensive livestock activity, which offers low returns. Regarding the eastern plains, I think that any government efforts to boost agricultural activity in that area require a logistics infrastructure plan. For example, river navigability and railway connections are crucial, as is a comprehensive land improvement program with special emphasis on irrigation and drainage. These issues are difficult to tackle for the private sector alone, which is why the government must implement a public sector-led, strategic plan to contribute to the development of the area. We started producing bio-diesel eight years ago, and today we have an installed capacity of 500,000 tons per year. There are two types of oil extracted from palm trees, and over the past two decades the country has positioned itself as a leading regional exporter of these two oils. We also produce palm kernel cake, a high-fiber, medium-grade protein feed that is best suited for ruminants.
node.sections11: Colombia is currently the largest palm-oil producer in Latin America. In 2013, we produced 1 million tons of crude palm oil. Producing such quantities requires palm plantations, which is a highly labor-intensive business. A hectare of palm should yield about four tons of crude palm oil, and should require about one worker per seven hectares. Therefore, to produce one million tons would require 300,000 hectares of cultivated palm land. Refineries are then required to process the product into palm oil. This is also labor-intensive work because it is not a heavily automated process. Specifically in Magdalena, we are responsible for 150,000 hectares of plantations, which directly generate around 25,000 jobs in the palm oil sector. The oleochemical industry is a sub-activity within the palm plantation involving palm kernel oil, a sub-product of crude palm oil (CPO). The crude palm kernel oil (CPKO) derived is an excellent raw oil component of the palm oil industry. It is used throughout the personal health and care (PHC) industries. Companies such as Johnson & Johnson and Proctor & Gamble are researching its applications, and it is the main raw product of surfactants.
node.sections21: Unipalma was founded by the Unilever group between 1981 and 1982. Growing in this region is difficult, demanding a creative approach. After the period of President Uribe, investment in the rural sector caused the price of land to increase, such that today it is prohibitively expensive to grow palms profitably. Today, we have 4,500 hectares, and are processing more. If we compare our business to 15 years ago, certain structural and economic differences should be taken into consideration. We are doing the same as 15 years ago, but 30% of our costs are accounted for by labor, which has more than doubled over that time, while the price we get for the oil is essentially unchanged. Thus, margins are shrinking due to various factors, such as the microeconomics of dollar fluctuation, and Colombia's lack of infrastructure.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0company: Hospital Pablo Tobón Uribe de Medellí­n
node.subject: Hospitals
node.title: Treat Them Well
node.sections01: The Hospital Pablo Tobón Uribe began operating in 1970, but its history dates back to 1946, when the ANDI Foundation signed an act establishing a hospital that would later bear this name. In 1954, Don Pablo Tobón Uribe, a well-known philanthropist from the city of Medellí­n, upon his death, left as a legacy the construction of the hospital, which would merge with the ANDI Foundation in 1957. We have become a leading healthcare institution in terms of quality, services, and innovation, particularly in highly complex treatments. We have also become a leading institution in terms of administrative practices, and host many visits every year from people interested in better understanding our operational activities. Today, we are the 10th best Latin American health center, and we are the first in Antioquia. This has been made possible by our incredible staff and the professional team we have formed over the years; we also invest around $2 million every year in advanced training for our employees. Moreover, our facility has the latest technology in the industry and our high-quality services are nationally certified and recognized.
node.sections11: Colombia has one of the most progressive health systems in the world, meaning that all Colombians who have enough financial resources cover the health costs for those with no financial power through a budgeted national system. This is done through tax charges on salaries that go directly to fund access to the health system for those who cannot afford care. Private clinics within the sector have the latest and most advanced technologies available as well as highly qualified doctors and specialists who obtained their qualifications abroad. On top of that, demand has been increasing over the past few years, and this has brought prices down considerably. Bucaramanga has become one of the prime movers in the industry. There are also some other high-quality centers in Bogotá and Medellí­n. Barranquilla had no clinic meeting high international health standards before the incorporation of Clí­nica Portoazul. The city had qualified and skilled human resources in the sector, but no center that offered services at the highest international standards. Doctors, insurers, local and regional authorities, and some other agents came together to make this project a reality. The government was also a key player, and that's why we now enjoy the legal status of an FTZ.
node.sections21: We have reached universal healthcare through social insurance, and I would say that people in Colombia have learned to claim and demand health as one of their social rights. One of the most important achievements has been the fact that health access has become an essential right. One of the latest advancements in this field has to do with the monoclonal antibodies treatment, which is also included within the system. The latest radiotherapy surgery is also available within the Colombian health system, which overall operates to international standards. One of the main strengths of the health system is that despite the current per capita payment level, we provide a full range of services; we have developed a highly efficient health system from an economic perspective. The hospital was established through a common effort from the Pontifica Universidad Javeriana and a number of private sector doctors back in 1942. Over the years, the center maintained its university character and today employs 2,250 staff. We work 24/7 and 365 days a year, while the average number of patients treated per day currently stands at 2,000.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2company: School of Finance, Government & IR at UEC
node.intervieweelist3company: School of Law of the Universidad Santo Tomás
node.subject: University Sector
node.title: Open Minds
node.sections01: Colombia's higher education system has many institutions offering high quality courses. The country has the potential to become a leading player in the regional education field and the world, because the sector today is undergoing a transformation, of which innovation and research are the main two drivers. Colombia offers many interesting programs within business management and administration. It is a country of contrasts, creative and unique, meaning that while studying these programs, students have the opportunity to complement their studies, as well as benefit from unique work experience. One of the main concerns in the sector today is the extremely high dropout level of around 50%. Our dropout rate is at 18%. We have promoted a progressive message about the benefits of debating social and public issues to the advantage of the country. We have built a unique brand over the years, one based on pluralism, austerity, and ethics.
node.sections11: The university system in Colombia has been developing over the past decade and a half. This has brought about a huge effort on the part of the government and a good number of universities to improve the quality of teaching and education. This has taken precedence over improving the quality and volume of research. That has been a bottleneck for growth, and has particularly hurt the status of Colombian universities in the international rankings, which are usually only measured in terms of research and perceptions of the country. The vision of the founders of ICESI was to create an excellent business school in Cali. It was in fact founded by local industry and is still supported by it. During the late 1990s and early 2000s, we transformed the mission of the institution to become a fully-fledged university on condition that the business school remained a highly competitive, excellent institution. We now offer social sciences, natural sciences, engineering, law, design, medicine, pharmacy, and other disciplines.
node.sections21: Colombia has a centuries-old tradition of education. However, while there are around 300 universities or institutions in Colombia, only 30 are accredited by the Ministry of Education, and of those 30 only 10 have been accredited for just under a decade. Although in actuality infrastructure in Colombia is short of what it could be, the study of design and engineering is solid. There is extensive research into biodiversity as well, as a result of the country's naturally diverse environment. Our degrees are well received in both the private and public sectors. There is also high demand from other countries in Latin America, and we have students in Europe, Asia, Japan, and India. There is a difference between political science and government, and ours was the first school that groomed the professionals who would go on to govern the various institutions of Colombia and other nations, as opposed to being confined to providing an education in political theory. We also offered studies in economy, business management, and international relations.
node.sections31: Over the past few years, we have seen increased cooperation between the public and private segments of the industry to raise the level of higher education in the country. We still need to improve the output and quality of our research activity as a sector. Many highly recognized public personalities graduated from our university and I have to say that, in particular, the School of Law has been one of the most reputable institutions of its kind in the country for the quality of our graduates and highly recognized lawyers. The university plans to achieve the so-called multisite accreditation; if we get it, then we will be able to establish university extensions and courses in any part of the country without specific certification. We are also in the process of obtaining international accreditation as a university to expand our profile overseas.
node.sections41: INALDE is a business school established by a group of businessmen in 1985. Since ours are all executive-oriented programs, it is difficult to have foreign students. However, we do offer the possibility for our students to visit Mexico, the US, or China. Our first program, Advanced Management Program (PADE) had around 50 participants. A year later, we developed our second program, the PDD (Management Development Program). These programs aim at providing the right tools to understand the needs of large companies from the perspectives of HR, management, training, and more. Our Executive MBA program has over 22 years of experience; it is a very well structured program. Today, we have 16 full-time professors and every semester we invite around 25 professors from abroad. Educational institutions and authorities have lately strengthened research, making it compulsory at many levels, and we allocate 10% of our income to R&D.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Clubs & Organizations
node.title: Members Only
node.sections01: We have been the leader in the development of residential and sports infrastructure projects in the area. It is my observation that the local area, due to its proximity to Bogotá and the lack of space in the capital, has become a regional point for capitalizing on the development of such projects. We formally set up the project in June 1996 through real estate developer Potosí­ La Pradera SA. However, some of the security issues that the country faced back then delayed the realization of the project. At the moment, we have around 660 members. The main concept behind our project is to provide entertaining alternatives for families. We have a type of membership called our “diplomatic visitor" package, and also offer temporary membership plans for foreign visitors. After all these years, we have seen a highly dynamic development of the area—at the moment, there are 65 urban development projects in the zones neighboring La Pradera, and they have matched our high standards to develop their projects.
node.sections11: Colombia has many golf players today, and with such events we support the development of professional golf players in our country. We have a golf course for senior players and another one for children. There is also a practice golf course for training purposes. One of our strong points is that we combine facilities for both professional and amateur practitioners, meaning everybody can enjoy their sport regardless of their level and purpose. Undoubtedly, the biggest change in our history was relocating the club headquarters from the grounds of the La Colina to the grounds of Los Arrayanes, which was made possible thanks to the acquisition of the latter in 1972 under the direction of Pedro Gomez Barrero. We are open to expanding our international profile in the near future, as we know the importance of such agreements in offering added value to our members when traveling abroad.
node.sections21: Our association's management know-how significantly contributes to our growing golfing sector. You can find golf courses in locations of warmer weather, and other courses along the coast. All of the best courses in Colombia have been laid out by world-renowned designers. And what's more, it is relatively inexpensive to play golf at San Andrés Golf Club when compared with other top courses around the world, including Latin America. Until recently the club directors only thought about golf. However, they noticed an important change; not only did older people want to play golf, but also their children and grandchildren enjoyed the game as well. Member families have grown, and we have to give them the scope to do other activities. We needed to develop children's facilities, a pool, a nursery, and a complete infrastructure that provides activities and care to the children who don't play golf. The philosophy of the club is be committed to the community; we have a social responsibility for the Funza region, and purchase produce from it.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Operators
node.title: Dial G For Growth
node.richbody0content:
ESTEBAN IRIARTE

SAíšL KATTAN COHEN

MARC EICHMANN PERRET

© The Business Year
node.sections01: We strive to bring the latest phones to our customers, or to provide timely customer service for repairs, and we were also the first to sell unlocked phones. The industry over the past two or three quarters has grown by 17%. It is a highly concentrated market; in fact, the second most concentrated in the world. And while there are challenges, I think that, over time, we will succeed in bringing in more competition. We will achieve this through a greater focus on the customer. During the past year, customers have made it clear that they want better services. Data traffic accounts for about 60%-70% of our revenue, and I think that it has to be the focus for the future. However, we need to bring more affordable smart phones to the market. I expect the sector to grow by between 5% and 8% in 2014.
node.sections11: ETB has 129 years of history and has always been a highly innovative company—we have been evolving ever since our first day, and the best example of our success in such a competitive industry is that we are one of the leading companies in Colombia. We should keep in mind the importance of Bogotá for Colombia; it represents 25% of GDP. As part of our strategic plan for the next five years, we are pushing innovation and investment to the forefront and plan to replace all our lines in Bogotá with fiber-optic infrastructure. Today, more than 200,000 households in Bogotá already benefit. And by the end of the year, we will have covered between 800,000 and 1 million households. We have received awards both nationally and internationally, which I believe boosts our already established credentials. However, the greatest accolade we have received is the current condition of our company; whereas two years ago it was up for sale and virtually at its end, today we proudly observe its solid development. This is a company that pioneers technologies and we see a bright future ahead of us.
node.sections21: We launched a 4G LTE network where we have about a 70% market share of LTE users in Latin America. We have also increased our ranking in brand awareness from fourth in the market to second. Were we to describe Colombian customers, we would first take into account disposable income; it's much lower than in many other countries. I believe that Colombia still has a problem in the telecommunications sector, which is concentrated in the mobile voice sector. Ultimately, telecommunications will split into two different sectors. On one hand you have one massive segment, the residential market, where growth is limited by GDP and the adoption of technology, which cannot have very high growth rates. And on the other you have the corporate segment in which the modernization of the state and private industry is lagging compared to other countries.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Free Trade Zones
node.title: No Limits
node.sections01: Our FTZ belongs to Funza and Cota, two towns located in the Metropolitan Area of Bogotá in the Western Savanna Province, in respective ratios of 10% and 90%. In this context, we can rate the development of our FTZ in parallel to the development of Funza and Cota themselves, which has been both active and positive. Over the past few years, we have seen an increase in the activity of both local and foreign companies. We should keep in mind that Bogotá represents around 65% of the local market and that FTZs are usually established around the main logistics and consumption regions. We have also seen a decrease in the importance of agriculture in local economies, resulting from the fact that Bogotá has already absorbed us as it expands. FTZs have brought great dynamism to Colombia and its economy, especially after the amendment to Law 7 back in 2005, which brought a new regulatory framework to FTZs, making them much more attractive and efficient.
node.sections11: Four years ago, Mosquera had barely 100,000 inhabitants and lacked efficient drainage and water infrastructure. The Zona Franca de Occidente, along with a number of private companies, has provided over 50% of the funds to build the infrastructure. We also built the drinking water storage infrastructure—now the city has a 1,000 cubic meter infrastructure, when before it could only store 80 cubic meters. Furthermore, over the next couple of years, we will be building two further storage facilities and developing local infrastructure further. Our goal is to secure the drinking water supply for the entire population of Mosquera. Our arrival in the city has also transformed it into a driving economic force, and we have seen the establishment of other FTZs nearby. We are also part of several projects to develop as many as 18,000 housing units, because the population of Mosquera has considerably increased over the past couple of years. We have around 240,000 sqm available for future developments. So far, we have built infrastructure on around 40% of the area and we expect to close 2014 with that figure reaching 60%. Our aim is to continue offering integral services for those companies that want to establish operations in our FTZ. Since the beginning of our operations, we aimed at attracting companies with a very low environmental impact, meaning the absence of heavy industry.
node.sections21: I believe that construction, and free trade zones (FTZs) will grow in importance in Bogotá. The city represents around 30% of total GDP, and there alone lies a reason for a presence here. Colombia, historically, has had a centralized economy, which is why so many companies want to stay in Bogotá, or develop their businesses from here. We are directing our strategy toward the business process outsourcing (BPO), knowledge process outsourcing (KPO), and IT outsourcing (ITO) sectors, as these have seen annual growth of around 15%. To date, 65,000 jobs have been created by the FTZs in Colombia. Worldwide, an average of 1% of a country's population works in FTZs, meaning a global total of around 70 million people. Today, approximately 38 million sqm have been approved as FTZs, and over two-thirds of that space is available for use. We expect that by 2018 or 2020, around 1,700 companies will be established as residents of Colombia FTZs. We also foresee between 300,000 and 400,000 people working in FTZs.
node.sections31: Private management of this free trade zone (FTZ) began in 1994, although it had already been operative within another framework prior to that. All companies that set up operations in our FTZ enjoy a variety of commercial advantages, including numerous tax benefits. Furthermore, because the FTZ has been a leading force in the development of Cali for over two decades, we can provide a comprehensive range of services that a company needs to expand its activities. One main advantage is our location, as we are close to the Buenaventura Maritime Terminal and Port. The region has a dynamic and demanding internal market, which makes our FTZ extremely attractive too. We handle around $3 billion per annum in terms of foreign markets. According to official data, we are the third largest in Colombia in terms of foreign trade volume. And we handled around 20% of the country's foreign trade as at 2013.
node.sections41: Our free trade zone, the Zona Franca Brisa, was approved in August 2010, and has a port and an FTZ for the mining and oil and gas sector. Its primary focuses are the petrochemical industry, the coal industry, and power generation. It is a free zone with a well-defined market, which is boosted by the port and its location 74 kilometers from Riohacha and 94 kilometers from Santa Marta at the Caribbean coast. In the south of the Guajira, we have a deepwater port that can service deep-draft vessels that few ports in Colombia can currently service. The benefits are mostly tax related, as a company in the zone pays no more than 15% income tax, whereas were it not in the free zone it would pay 36%. In customs terms, it is an extraterritorial area and thus not part of Colombia.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Private Equity
node.title: Smart Moves
node.sections01: One of Colombia's most attractive features for investors is the development of the internal market, where many are improving their social conditions in a climate of greater social security. This said, there are some areas where Colombia still needs to register improvement, such as the ease of opening a new business and/or bank accounts, as well as its tax regime and general bureaucracy. Our Latin American headquarters are located in Colombia, and we see Bogotá as the perfect location to manage our operations in the region. We know Bogotá as a major driver of Colombia's economy; however, we see a great potential in cities like Medellí­n, Cartagena, Cali, and Barranquilla. We fully anticipate infrastructure and other building projects in those cities. Our project, Cargo City Bogotá, is located on 19 hectares of land and features 75,000 sqm of modern air cargo warehousing and office facilities. Currently, occupancy rates are at 99%, and we are pleased at how it has evolved over time, bearing in mind that we have been present since 2010.
node.sections11: Abacus Real Estate's founding principle was that if you want to be a player in Colombia by owning a building or real estate development, you have to build it yourself. The nature of the country's ownership structure means that the potential for developing funds capable of acquiring existing properties was limited. There were few possibilities for consolidating good properties due to fragmentation and the use of strata-title. We recently closed our first fund—the OXO-Sustainable Properties Fund. Currently, we work with Skandia, Colfondos, Fondo Inversor, and Mundial de Seguros as our institutional capital providers. We are in the process of launching our next fund, which will be primarily focused on logistics and industrial properties. This fund will, hopefully, be in the $200 to $300 million range. Our first project is in the pipeline is in Barranquilla and should be closed within the next four or five months. A follow on project will be targeting the Pacific coast.
node.sections21: Private equity plays a minor role amongst the various investment alternatives in the market. Investments in private equity funds have reached around $1.5 billion, with commitments to reach approximately $3.4 billion. Colombian pension funds have approximately $70 billion under management. Approximately half of the assets under management (AUM) are in fixed-income instruments, whilst the remainder is divided between assets such as real estate or equities. US treasury bills have been at historically low levels, as have Colombian fixed-deposit rates, which means that investors have to design new strategies in order to compensate for the lack of return they had been obtaining from their traditional investments. Equities have been highly volatile both in emerging and developed markets. If infrastructure developments are executed correctly in Colombia, I believe we could grow by around 6% as the country has sufficiently strong internal demand to fuel such growth. In addition, Colombia has been developing a very interesting productive sector that may underpin future growth.
node.sections31: Terranum was born of the idea of creating an integrated real estate platform based on what we had seen abroad in the US and Europe. We opted for the real estate investment trust (REIT) model. Pension funds were starting to grow and we had begun to look at alternatives to fixed-income instruments. Corporates had, until then, owned major real estate holdings and were starting to compete on a more global basis, which naturally required capital. The legal framework took us a couple of years to put in place, but since then we have seen that an integrated platform for the development of corporate real estate services encompassing the investment dimension has allowed us to offer clients a one-stop shop. We have Ps1.5 billion under management, and are currently present in Bogotá, Medellí­n, Cali, Barranquilla, and Manizales. Roughly 63% of the portfolio is located in the capital. Terranum Capital is our low-income housing initiative. The fund was closed in June of 2013 with $235 million through a wide pool of investors. The target has been the housing deficit that we have in the region, which amounts to 20 million homes.
node.sections41: Exact was founded in 2005 by a Danish investment banker to provide capital for real estate projects, originally in Denmark. However, in 2007, due to market conditions in Europe, we decided to relocate to Latin America. Specifically, we saw in Colombia what we had seen in Brazil seven years before, namely the growing middle class, access to finance for property buyers, and a growing retail market. We want to be present in medium-sized cities to create a foothold and presence there, positioning us as a leader for the next two decades. Developers have traditionally financed projects by pre-selling units, just as they do in the residential sector. The fiduciary system creates the opportunity for developers to construct and sell relatively large projects with relatively little equity. That then generates the smaller stratified offices, and now because there is a lack of larger office space, funds are going in and financing projects to meet that need.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: Chubb de Colombia Compañí­a de Seguros S.A
node.subject: Insurance Providers
node.title: Plan Ahead
node.sections01: The main insurance opportunities are in the various infrastructure developments. Demand is rising and consequently the growth of the middle class impacts that of the economy, and naturally our sector expands. Of course, if unemployment declines, and more people find jobs, that means more sales for us. The competition in the consumer segment of the market is totally different and that is where we see real growth. In the past two years, we have increased the penetration rate up to 2.7% of GNP, which is positive because have grown from 2% in previous years, so we can say that we have penetrated a little bit more into the economy, although there is still room to grow. We need to keep moving in that direction. We have done everything to be ready for the coming years. In terms of premiums, in 2013 we closed on a figure close to ‚¬431 million.
node.sections11: The insurance sector is experiencing a boom. The economy itself has been doing well over the past 3 to 4 years. This has prompted many international players and some local ones to note the potential for growth of the insurance sector in emerging markets. Colombia, compared to its neighboring countries, has the lowest insurance penetration. Recently a major European insurer acquired 51% of Colpatria, which is one of the largest insurance financial groups in Colombia. Other European insurers are looking to buy or establish local companies, and we have seen American companies establishing here. We have seen smaller groups buying niche companies, specifically for bonds, for example. There is considerable appetite for new business and prices are declining in what has become a highly competitive market. Chubb is generating more than $12 billion in written premiums; the international zones alone represent 25% of the business.
node.sections21: It has been a sound year for the insurance industry in Colombia. This was mainly due to the fact that the life insurance segment of the business saw strong growth supported by a pension commutation carried out by a government-owned company, Positiva, and a utilities company client, ETB, allowing for life insurance growth of 20% in 2013. When you look at the industry as a whole, it grew by about 14%. In the property and casualty segments, we grew 7%. As of year-end 2013, we are still at 2.3% penetration of GDP. QBE entered the Colombian market in 2005 when it acquired Compañí­a Central de Seguros, a local company that was bought at that time. Since this acquisition in 2005, almost 10 years on, QBE's presence in the country has been effectively passive. Since 2012, we have a new group CEO in place and are now working as a fully integrated, synergized multinational company.
node.sections31: The national insurance sector is growing, but I think the general population needs to be better educated about the benefits of insurance coverage. Insurance needs to be promoted from a quality-of-life perspective. If society were more unified and people worked together more, then I think they would naturally prepare for earthquakes, floods, fires, accidents, and death. Automobile insurance, while traditionally the most important segment, only has a 30% to 35% penetration rate in the market. Approximately 60% to 65% of our business is generated by business clients and about 35% to 40% comes from the consumer segment. Property insurance will contribute to our growth. We attend to over 3,400 commercial or business clients and over 200,000 consumer clients and users of our infrastructure.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist3position: Andean and Venezuela Geomarket - Managing Director & Vice President
node.subject: Energy Sector Leaders
node.title: Full Power
node.sections01: In 2014, we will increase the capacity of our pipelines to over 140,000 barrels per day, which will make Ecopetrol more competitive and reduce costs. Secondly, we had a profitable operation with an integrated EBITDA of over Ps2 trillion in the first nine months of 2013. And thirdly, we are a secure vehicle for future investments. We have excellent results, but also pursue advances, especially in project development. Today, we have a transportation capacity of 110,000 barrels of oil per day (bbl/d) through the Bicentenario pipeline from the plains to the coast. Cenit's project portfolio is looking at $4 billion for the next four years. For 2014, we are talking about as much as a $1.5 billion investment focused on four large areas. The first area is the extension of OCENSA from 600,000 to 770,000 barrels, which represents around $1 billion between 2014 and 2015; the environmental license is already in place, allowing engineering and construction to commence. This project is highly important for being the one that will make transportation entirely viable.
node.sections11: Colombia has become a strong example for the production of clean energies and the implementation of schemes for their consumption at the retail level. However, we have to keep in mind that current production figures aim to cover current market demand, and no more. The government needs to expedite the process of adopting a new regulatory framework for offshore and shale gas (the two main areas the authorities are keen to develop), in order to boost investment in these areas. In sum, we need more dynamism in the industry to boost its development, and subsequently national consumption trends. The country's goal is to continue producing at least 1 million bbl/d. This poses a challenge in itself, as there are social, economic, and security aspects associated with sustaining production figures. Government changes also affect the production rhythm, and the presidential elections just passed. I personally expect 2014 to close on growth of between 4.5% and 6%. Current reserves are good for 6.8 years and the government has already stated its intention to raise this number to 10 years.
node.sections21: We have also been expanding our coverage; we are leaders in aviation with a 68% market share. We also hold 46% of GMV, which supplies natural gas for vehicles, as well as 44% in liquid fuels. Meanwhile, we hold a 38% stake in diesel and gasoline for industrial use, and 21% of the lubricants market, the only area where we are not the market leaders. Our operations feature 29 storage plants and over 2,000 gas stations located beyond cities. Our main shareholders are made up of the third largest company in Chile, Empresas Copec, which has more than a 60% local market share. We are committed to being in alliance not just with the government, but also with the country at large. Everything we do must have social significance, and sustainability is our watchword. The foundations of life are crucial because we believe that education can bring about meaningful change for the country. For the future we need an educated population aware of how to manage Colombia's natural resources.
node.sections31: Today there is a conflict in the industry between operators, service companies, and national oil companies regarding who is who and who does what. To my thinking, operators need to be the owners of reserves. When I say the operators, the national oil companies are mostly the owners of reserves, and a glance at local history reveals that operators transfer technological know-how to the service companies, but still have concessions on the reserves when used by national oil companies. Today, these firms are unwilling to relinquish these reserves, whereby the operators, which are not service companies, but the Exxons and the Shells of the world, wonder what precisely they are left with. Meanwhile, the national oil companies have tried to impose service contracts on operators, which is economically flawed. Baker Hughes wants to become the technology partner of the reserve owner, and provide the technological assistance needed to develop reserves and maximize their economical utilization, without seeking ownership of the reserves or operating them, but rather by focusing squarely on the core activities that we do best.
node.sections41: Colombia is an interesting success story, having reached peak production in 1999 after the momentous discovery of Cusiana. When the country realized that it could lose its self-sufficiency, the National Hydrocarbons Agency (ANH) was created in 2003. In fact, this attracted all of the investment to have entered the oil and gas sector between 2003 and 2007, leading to a production increase of 500,000 to 1 million bbl/d. Colombia's oil production statistics rank in around the top 20 countries in the world. Colombia would require oil discoveries of approximately 360 million bbl/d to maintain the current annual production rate. Determining where it is going to come from is where Colombia's prospects come into play. Certain key regulatory changes coming emerging in 2014 are set to be critical for the country, influencing short-term and medium-term production. We have yet to run upstream services in Colombia, although we do have a lubricant business that has been active for around 75 years, which remains quite attractive.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Cauca Valley
node.title: How Green is Cauca?
node.sections01: The Port of Buenaventura requires social development and logistics infrastructure. It also needs an excellent airport to facilitate increased arrivals of people wishing to benefit from Cali's health cluster. Cali conducts 3% of all plastic surgery in the world, which is clearly potential to be exploited. Meanwhile, the Port of Buenaventura, situated on the Pacific coast, and facing Asia, has incredible potential. With improved port, road, and airport infrastructure, we could become the most successful region in the country. The geographical location provides access to various markets: North America, Central America, and on the Atlantic coast Europe and Africa. It allows us, with two cities of such great importance as Buenaventura and Barranquilla, to be the point of entry and exit for Colombian production to the world. We are not actually producers, but rather, we commercialize elements of medical technology. We have important world-class representation, and our success lies in having quality products, great service, and an excellent work ethic.
node.sections11: Survival requires us to be competitive and innovative, to work with the talent present in the Cauca Valley region, and to train human capital in different corporate aspects for the development of our suppliers. Without good suppliers, it is impossible to make a good product. The major companies in the Cauca Valley are competitive and have the will to survive. Moreover, they are keen to become international players and move beyond the frontier, first to South America and thence beyond. Approximately 600 people work with us, and our intention is to retain them for the long term to be trained and transformed into a highly skilled workforce. By law, we are obliged to train people from universities. In this region we boast major names: Johnson & Johnson has a manufacturing plant here, as do Palmolive and Unilever, which have a huge factory near the airport and a brand new facility. We have the best culture in the country for cosmetics because we host the main alcohol producers in the valley in the sugar cane industry, and are also the major carton-packaging producer.
node.sections21: Since the 1950s and 1960s, this region has been characterized by its many entrepreneurs looking to develop industry. The city then experienced a boom, which lasted until the early 1970s, when Cali was transformed into the foremost entrepreneurial and industrial zone of Colombia, due to its closeness to the Pacific and to the Port of Buenaventura. In the 1970s and 1980s, many multinational companies settled in the valley. We experienced stagnation during the 1990s, but for the past four to five years this has been changing and becoming yet more dynamic. Foreign investment, and that from other regions of the country, is always well received here, as local businesses see that they can form part of larger productive chains. Between 10 and 15 years ago, we were a regional company, but after commencing a national expansion process, we now have distribution centers in 10 cities across the country. In 2013 we had turnover of over $50 million, with utility of around $2 million. Production is confined to the Cauca Valley. Yet, through these distribution centers I believe we can reach around 170 to 200 municipalities.
node.sections31: The Cauca Valley is an excellent platform on which the nation can recover its leadership and attract FDI and foreign companies. We must bear one thing in mind, however, which is that this region is not rich in the typical investment operations, such as mining and oil. It is more attractive in terms of opportunities to invest in industry, due to its well-trained labor force. Growing the company allows us to grant opportunities to the people around us, which will result in a higher standard of living and more opportunities for people. We have doubled production for the last five years on over 10% annual growth. And that is because of the relationship between the cost of manufacturing excellence, and how we deal with customers and international expansion. In the region, we are the largest company, and are working on growing more into this part of the region. The technological differences between our company and our competitors in the area are significant. Today, we operate with state-of-the-art technology compared to regional manufacturers.
node.sections41: I believe that the most important infrastructure development the Cauca Valley needs in order to become more competitive is the completion of the dual carriageway to the Pacific port of Buenaventura, which has long been under construction, while we also need to increase the depth of the access canal to the port of Buenaventura to receive the larger ships that will be passing through the new Panama Canal when completed. Although the geographical conditions are difficult, it would also be an ideal complement to the port's airport to have a longer landing strip to accommodate large cargo aircraft. Besides, of great importance is the construction of the La Lí­nea highway tunnel, which will cross beneath the central range of the Andes Mountains, easing traffic on one of Colombia's most important east-west connections. Unfortunately, it is being built in only one direction, for export cargo only, and ideally it should operate in both directions.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Electricity
node.title: Colombia’s Bright Sparks
node.sections01: Nowadays, we cover 36 municipalities and 130 towns in the Cauca Valley. In other words, our penetration level reaches 95% in terms of services. We also have around 40,000 users connected through Buenaventura Maritime Port, infrastructure that does not have supplying gas pipes—we transport the gas by trucks. Apart from that, we have also developed other products during this period of time, such as Brilla, a non-banking product to finance bills, and we can proudly say that more than 190,000 families in the region have already benefited from this product. We have almost a 100% rate in terms of clients keeping abreast of bill payment. That means that we have high levels of liquidity as a company. Additionally, our tariffs are competitive and all types of client, regardless of their social status, can afford them. Our Brilla business model was highlighted by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) as an attractive non-bank financing option that helps reduce poverty. The program has been regionally praised for being a highly inclusive initiative; nowadays, over 300,000 families benefit from our services thanks to the scheme. It is, without a shadow of a doubt, one of our main successes as a company; we provided credit lines to those clients who purchased their gas installations from us, and those were clients that other companies often did not want to grant such credit lines to. It is a way to reward our clients' trust by providing them with financing opportunities to acquire other equipment for their households.
