A recent study showed that families from the Brilla program saved up to 6% more on a year-to-year basis than other families.
node.sections11: Barranquilla has experienced positive and dynamic urban, social, economic, and industrial development over the past few years. We can feel this development through the electric energy consumption patterns, not only in the city, but in the region in general, as Electricaribe distributes electric energy to the seven coastal departments. For example, electric consumption in Colombia grows at an average rate of 2% to 3% per annum, whereas on the coast the figure reaches almost 7%. The signature of free trade agreements (FTAs) in the past couple of years has boosted the role of the area in the national economy, and its economic and industrial development. This alone is already a key driver in the increased consumption of electric energy. Cities like Santa Marta, Barranquilla, and Cartagena have developed remarkably over the past few years. In this context, certain economic sectors have taken the lead in this growth; in Santa Marta and Cartagena, port and logistics services have been the drivers of expansion; also, there has been an increase in urban infrastructure projects led by the development of the tourism industry. Industrial and tourism developments are driving up the consumption of electric energy, and at the same time we have seen an increasing number of people accessing the electricity network thanks to their social and economic development. Over 2013 we carried out some capacity expanding projects at power stations in order to meet the increasing demand for electric energy. These projects will contribute to the industrial and economic development of the remote areas we cover within the seven coastal departments of Colombia. Currently, we have around 2.4 million clients and 80% of them come from strata 1 and 2, as well as the above-mentioned settlements and special zones. The main objectives of our company are to reduce losses, achieve better bill payment, help our clients become regular and solid payers, and improve service quality. We managed to curtail losses in 2013 by up to 17%, we reduced service blackouts, and we managed to meet the increasing energy demands of the market.
node.sections21: EMCALI is an energy provider and distributor, and one of the major energy providers in the country. We aim to add innovation to our energy operations as well, and also to move into renewables. We aim for every house to be able to contribute to their own energy needs through solar power; we want our citizens to be energy generators, and to achieve this within three years. Our vision is for every roof in Cali to be generating energy, with EMCALI paying households for surplus energy. Cali has one of the foremost infrastructure networks in Colombia. And in our telecommunications company, we aim to bring value-added to our internet services and connectivity offering, becoming a comprehensive, high-quality platform. We want to improve our follow-up and after-sales services, and place technology, innovation, and quality in the hands of the community. We're also inaugurating entrepreneurship centers for young people, to encourage the development of apps. EMCALI works closely with Empresa de Energia del Pacifico (EPSA). We are both shareholders and clients of the company, and carry out innovation projects for clients together with EPSA. We're set to become partners in the Solar Decathlon; the US Department of Energy Solar Decathlon is an international competition that challenges 20 college teams to design, build, and operate the most effective, and energy-efficient solar-powered house. We have a diversity of plants and a well-developed infrastructure that offers many opportunities for foreign companies wanting to invest in Cali and in the energy sector in particular.
node.sections31: We have been in the market since 1997, and over the past few years have prioritized winning public confidence. We were the first company in the country to trade energy. We aim to continue strengthening trust and reliability through qualitative services, competitive prices, post-sales services, and professional and well-qualified human resources. We currently work on new energy generation opportunities, as well as broadening our service portfolio. For example, we believe we can develop interesting projects within the solar energy field. However, we are still dependent on official approval of the new law for renewable energy. The government would do well to subsidize several fields in the industry, specifically those related to solar energy. Our tariffs are today one of our most competitive advantages. This is possible thanks to the current tariff structures. We have larger and more concentrated clients than most other companies, which allows us to offer more competitive prices. We also offer more personalized services. One of our strongest features is that we have a long-term strategy and purchase energy well in advance. For example, three years ago we bought supplies to cover 2015, which comes at a cheaper cost. Meanwhile, our commitment to the environment is represented through our increasing efforts to educate society on how to conserve energy, preserve river basins, and other important considerations.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Asset Management
node.title: Nice Assets
node.sections01: Since the Association was established, the sector's growth has been exponential. By June 2013, the sector managed assets worth Ps250 billion, representing 37% of GDP. The Financial Superintendency of Colombia (SFC) grants two types of licenses to the trust sector: trust management licenses and collective investment fund licenses. The 27 trust companies currently operating in Colombia manage 126 types of funds amounting to Ps30 billion. In terms of regulation, Colombia has made important advances in different areas. Over the past few years, changes in the tax framework and strict control over the sector by the SFC have enabled it to strengthen. Moreover, in June 2013, the government introduced a new regulatory framework, adjusting the collective investment funds industry to international standards. Trust companies possess extensive knowledge of the country and its regulatory framework, as well as experience in how to conduct business in a flexible and transparent way. This allows foreign investors to minimize risks and have an easier approach to a new market.
node.sections11: The sector has enjoyed continued growth and expansion at all levels; we closed the year with around Ps275 trillion in assets under management. Overall, the trust industry continues to be an attractive option for the management of state assets and resources, along with real estate developments and family-related issues, and 2013 was a good year not only in terms of managed assets, but also in the total number of trusts. The industry generates much added value, as it manages resources from the state by pushing transparency to the forefront, and by generating more efficient processes when it comes to the management of these resources. Regarding real estate developments, we are a sector that provides security to all segments, ensuring the sound management of family assets and resources. We currently manage around 180 trusts, $300 million in assets, and a mutual fund that has an estimated value of $80 million and with average growth rates of around 400% across all segments.
node.sections21: We have risen fourfold from Ps500,000 million in 2009 to where we are today, at almost Ps2 billion. We had operated in four key segments: retail, companies, institutional, and the corporate segment. Yet in 2013, we entered a new segment; what we call the Premium Segment (private banking), which caters to our top clients, including personal and premium banking services. Our portfolio in investment funds is heavily concentrated in fixed income, both short and medium term. About 98% of our portfolio is fixed income; the rest is variable income (stocks). The average Colombian investor is quite conservative when it comes to risk. In general, the allocation in the fund industry in Colombia is 95% fixed-income and 5% variable-income; therefore, there is a long way to go in our market in terms of innovation. Assets given to the industry for management, by June 2013, represent approximately 35% of GDP. If we add in assets under the management of investment funds, the figure is at around 40%. This indicates that the perception is good and the numbers are increasing.
node.sections31: When one uses assets under management (AUM) to assess the development of the sector, one must understand that it is possible to have a high volume of AUM with a very low turnover. For this reason, it is better to talk about commissions, the number of operations you manage, and the volume. The trustee sector experienced an interesting trend in 2013; the volume of operations rose, but at the same time income volume fell. That was due to a loss in the net asset value (NAV) of funds experienced last March, after which many people retrieved their investments. The asset management industry is mainly a fixed-income market, as the country has historically suffered from high levels of inflation. At the same time, other markets, such as derivatives, are only in their infancy. The evolution of this industry will be linked to large investors.
node.sections41: Fiduciaries can engage in any branch of business. In our case, we deal with asset management and custodial services. Also, we support our bank with trust structures that help to strengthen relationships with existing customers in the bank. On the other hand, for the market perspective, we believe that the role of fiduciary institutions at the present time is more related to deepening the capital markets. In this sense, we have taken the initiative to find the best scenarios for growth in the asset management business and custodial services. The asset management business line is the mutual fund business and discretionary portfolios, and the main service is global custody whose principle clients are foreign. In mutual funds and asset management, our clients are retailers, small businesses, and universities, which consider our fund to be a good alternative for investing and generating savings. Also, we have corporate clients that consider it to be a good option for cash management and mutual funds.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Key Account Manager & Country Lead for Colombia
node.subject: Why Colombia?
node.title: Opportunity Knocking
node.sections01: Colombia is a large Latin American country, in which we are not yet present, but look forward to having operations in soon. It is a country of enormous potential in terms of population and economic growth, and also one with huge infrastructure needs. The current expansion in power production should be sufficient to provide energy to Panama and Central America and increase flows to Ecuador and Venezuela, and possibly even further south to Peru and Chile. Given its wealth of resources, Colombia is better off looking into hydro (which is renewable), but not the more unconventional sources. I think solar, thermal, and wind power have a long way to go before they can prove economically efficient in the country. We also believe LNG to be a promising opportunity, for the country as a whole, and for our company. It will give a new shape to the energy matrix and make it more competitive, solving some of the problems the country has today, such as the El Niño effect.
node.sections11: The decision to enter Colombia was made three years ago; however, it was not until the beginning of 2013 with prequalification in the 4G-concession program that the group plan started to get off the ground. Currently, the focus is on continued participate in the 4G program, plus at some point, the development of an alliance with a company in Colombia. Our targets are infrastructure projects in which we can invest, as well as construct, and operate. Our other focus is on entering the oil and gas industry. We are active in Peru, where we operate small fields, pipelines, storage facilities, and gas facilities. We are looking at the oil and gas sector as a sector to invest in construction or operation, or else are considering operation services for the major E&P companies. Graña has had a clear strategy for entering new markets shunning entry as a new player. In Chile, the company entered as a local outfit pursuing acquisitions. Our strategy here is the same, namely to identify the right partner to work with.
node.sections21: We have generally seen growth in Colombia across a broad range of economic sectors, including agriculture, healthcare, and education. However, if you compare our growth over the past two or three years in the ICT industry with that of GDP, you note that the ICT sector has grown at least four percentage points more than GDP, and in 2013 the figure was around six percentage points more. During the past three years, the government has been working on its Vive Digital plan. Basically, that project was aimed at installing a broadband connection into all the small villages in the country. The government's target was to have at least 1,000 small villages connected by August 2014, and they have reached, or are at least close to, that target already. The next step is deciding what kind of applications we will have, in order to maximize the use of the cables. Education is first, then e-government, agriculture, minerals, and then all the industries.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Industrial Exports
node.title: Send It On
node.sections01: We have been extremely active in the adoption of international standards from the UK and the US. We have taken more control over quality and have implemented strict production processes for Colombian industry. This has led to an increase in total exports for demanding markets. These exports comprise not only goods and products, but also engineering, technology, design, and consultation. Currently, the country is facing some problems in terms of its level of industrial competitiveness; we have problems regarding infrastructure and logistics costs, so it is still expensive to move cargo and goods within the country. However, we have seen many construction-related companies expand their operations to other Latin American countries. At PAVCO, we expect to close 2014 on growth of 10% in our activity and 40% growth in exports, keeping in step with sector development.
node.sections11: We must build closer links between the agricultural and industrial sectors, so we can shift from exporting commodities to exporting finished products of greater value. Grupo Nutresa recently acquired Chilean company Tresmontes Luchetti, the second largest food outfit in that country. We utilize Tresmontes Luchetti's activity and infrastructure in Mexico to expand our activities there, as well as introduce its products in Peru and our products in Chile, and benefit from the free trade agreements (FTAs) Chile has with a number of Asian countries, which Colombia currently lacks. All in all, our current business activity focuses on the Andean community of countries, Central America and the Caribbean, and the US. We have also signed an agreement with the Mitsubishi Corporation, which has a food division that can open up the coffee market in Asia to Colombian coffee. We foresee further future acquisitions as well, as this will be one of our main growth strategies in the region.
node.sections21: Nowadays, our direct export activity is focused on seats and chairs for cinemas and auditoria destined for four continents. We constantly innovate in partnership with the film industry, which is our major client. In addition, we work on new ideas for furniture design. Cali has an interesting future ahead of it, revolving around its proximity to the Pacific coast. Much of the economic future of the world is focused on the Pacific, and we in the Cauca Valley are Colombia's gateway to that region. The truth is that for the Pacific Alliance to generate benefits in the industrial sector, the national government in particular, and to a lesser extent the regional governments, must consolidate their industrial policy, which is one of the aspects that a foreign investor interested in the industrial sector looks for.
node.sections31: The Cauca Valley is the best location in Colombia. We are in a privileged geographical location, close to the Port of Buenaventura and the country's main cities. Besides that, we can easily import and export from here. FOGEL Andina can produce up to 5,000 units a month. For 2014, we are set to export 60% to 65% of our production to South American countries like Ecuador, Peru, Paraguay, and Bolivia. We are located close to the Port of Buenaventura, from where we can export back to countries like Ecuador and Peru. From here, we can also ship our goods to all cities in Colombia. Moreover, the labor force in Cali is skilled and we have good people trained for the mechanical industry. The industry is still not growing as we would like, but as Cali is a good place to live in and offers competitive prices, the next boom in Colombia is destined to happen here.
node.sections41: The word INDUMIL is a portmanteau of the Spanish words Industria Militar, which means Military Industry. Today, the bulk of our business activity comes from the mining industry; we provide the sector nationwide with the explosives it needs to operate. Additionally, we provide weaponry and ammunition to our armed forces, as well as to the police, security bodies, and similar institutions. We also have several agreements with other companies for know-how and technology exchange, as well as import capacities for our defense industry. Colombia enjoys a privileged geographical position and sits in the middle of a very dynamic continent. In addition to that, we are close to the Panama Canal, and have access to two oceans. In this context, we believe there is a huge potential for us to import equipment and technology. We also have the production capabilities to become a leading exporter in the region.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Mining
node.title: Meet The Flintstones
node.sections01: The mining sector is highly important and has much potential in Colombia. The government is trying to develop the sector with all the right incentives in order to realize this potential. The government should try to expedite permits and authorizations, while facilitating the development of projects, as long as these are undertaken in full legality, and as long as they are to the benefit to the country. The lack of infrastructure is a problem for small and medium-sized companies. In partnership with other coal companies, we are the owners of FENOCO, the railroad concession company. We have essentially completed the construction of the double line, with the exception of a stretch of 45 kilometers. Once this is completed, the capacity of the railroad will be huge, at around 80 million tons per year. Right now we are focusing on the expansion of the port, which is an investment of nearly $350 million. We are expecting a production level of 30 to 32 million tons for 2014.
node.sections11: The government has taken strong measures in other segments of the mining industry such as copper or gold, but not in the emerald segment. Esmeracol has over 40 years of experience in the industry and we currently have an exploration and extraction area of 40 hectares. The mines we operate were previously state-owned, and we exclusively carry out underground mining activities, out of environmental concerns. Illegal mining in our country still represents a high percentage of the industry's activity, however, people operating illegal mines do not have the resources to better exploit them and generally are subsistence operations. In this context, public policies have been aimed at formalizing activity in the sector. Current studies show that today just 10% of the available mines in Colombia are operative. Several foreign companies have conducted studies here and established that Colombian mines remain in a virgin state. The great biodiversity and geographic landscape of Colombia hides many minerals underground, and to reach them we need the most advanced technologies in the mining industry, only available to industry giants.
node.sections21: My most important aim in 2012-2013 was to continue enhancing the Muzo name and emerald mining throughout the world. We have had the opportunity to meet different companies that engage in mining on a broader scale worldwide. For example, Gemfields manages 20% of the colored stones in the world and has the largest emerald mine in the world today in Zambia. The Muzo Mine is legendary and has been around for a couple of centuries, since the colonial era. The emeralds traded around the world were thought to come from Mexico and other countries, but in actual fact all originate from Muzo, and were smuggled out of Colombia and sold in other countries. We need greater investment and more mining companies employing diverse exploration methods and leading edge technologies to discover more emeralds. While the emerald belt is huge, the actual exploitation of the mines is small in scale. If you put Coexminas and Santa Rosa together we only operate on 200 hectares, even though the emerald belt runs to over 100,000 hectares.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Peace Process
node.title: Come Together
node.sections01: Colombia is in a period of such considerable economic growth that plenty of work is being generated for the local population. Colombia welcomes professionals who are leaving their home countries, and we recognize that these people are extremely educated and possess vast professional experience. The increasing number of multinationals coming to Colombia has boosted the demand for fluently bilingual people, which has contributed to an influx of people from Spain and other neighboring countries. Colombia has a long road ahead, and peace would expedite its development. I hope the peace talks bring the country closer to stability, as I am convinced that it would boost the arrival of private investment and position Colombia's economy at the same level as that of Mexico.
node.sections11: Companies have to assume a leading role. When the peace agreement is signed, this will only be the beginning. Many people will be “unemployed" as a result, and in general will adopt a lifestyle more formalized that the one they had known while at arms, and that is where the private sector comes into its own. Naturally, this has to be accompanied by government policies, and there has to be some incentive for businesses, as they may be cautious about the implications of taking on former combatants. We will have to create jobs that match their experience and knowledge and will also have to teach and train them to be competitive. Construction companies can offer unskilled labor to people entering the workforce for the first time, as an industry of many knowledge levels. This offers the prospect of career advancement for those keen to advance themselves.
node.sections21: The first thing to remember is that this is not the first peace process that we have undertaken. I think the business community was at first wholly skeptical. Yet we have been having these conversations for a year now, and feel this is the moment for peace. Then again, many people prepared for the post-conflict era question whether they are prepared to employ ex-combatants. We have been working with the reintegration agency because this is a long-term project. And it is not just a question of signing a peace treaty, as there need to be alternatives for all people. This process is estimated to require at least six years; hence, we have much to learn in the period ahead. At the Chamber of Commerce, we have been working with the Colombian Reintegration Agency and hiring ex-combatants in subsidiaries, such as at Corferias, or at our university. So far, we have generated around 73 positions.
node.sections31: The Colombian Agency for Reintegration (ACR) is part of the Presidency of the Republic of Colombia and is integrating into civil society people who have demobilized from illegal armed groups such as the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), the National Liberation Army (ELN), the paramilitary umbrella group AUC, and other smaller groups. This process takes, on average, seven years per person. During that time, we offer them psychological attention, academic and vocational training. We also help people in transitioning back into legal economic activities with the purpose of fully integrating them into society. Currently, there are over 30,000 ex-combatants participating in the reintegration process nationwide.

node.author: TBY
node.previewsummary: A number of successful branding and promotion companies work to improve Colombia's international reputation and encourage investment.
node.subject: Trade Promotion
node.title: Word Is Out
node.sections01: Depending on each area, we pursue a different type of strategy in order to get Colombian products to the international market, and to attract tourists and investment into Colombia. As a private company, we have the flexibility to change strategies when we need to, and this allows us to be more proactive and efficient for our exporters. We are proud to have been able to attract over 25 countries to invest in Colombia, generating more than 60,000 jobs, and bringing 197 projects to 20 departments. That is one of Proexport's greatest achievements. We have increased the base of exporters that are going to the US by 41%. There are 1,609 new companies exporting to the US today. Proexport's success is partly due to the fact that, if you are coming to Colombia to invest, we provide you with all the information you require, organize meetings, and help you with other investment requirements here. We help to solve the problems investors encounter along the way. The cost for this service is zero—it is confidential and free.
node.sections11: Our role includes involving social and private agents in boosting investment in the city, while maintaining a methodology that allows us to establish the strategic value-added sectors for the development of the city. Sectors evolve and Bogotá is currently seeking its true vocation as a city; we put much emphasis on the services industry, which, along with commerce, represents 75% of the city's GDP—without commerce the percentage is about 62%. Bogotá has the largest number of higher education institutions (115) in Colombia, and approximately 100,000 people become part of the qualified workforce every year in this city. Additionally, 55% of the country's PhDs are earned in Bogotá, and 30% of those 100,000 people graduate here. Therefore, Bogotá is a highly attractive city for new companies in any sector that requires qualified employees. Bogotá is a clear example of how the country evolves; there are an increasing number of tourists arriving, investment in the hospitality sector is growing, and the number of SMEs is rapidly expanding (today, there are above 300,000 companies in the city), as is that of multinationals with a presence in Bogotá (1,500).
node.sections21: The current positive economic trends Colombia is experiencing, coupled with the idea of seeing them continuing over coming years, brought us to the conclusion that we needed to set up a common communication strategy to help the world learn about Colombia as an attractive destination that can meet the prerequisites that many investors and tourists seek. We changed the visual identity of the brand. Before, we had hearts as the main trademark of Colombia; as we were appealing to the emotions such an image seemed essential. When rethinking our campaign and strategies, we came to understand that we needed another visual identity for the brand; our main aim was to create an image that would adapt to the different campaigns we launch every year. There is one major difference; when selling the image of a product, you are usually in total control of that product, meaning you can modify it. However, when dealing with a country, we are dealing with an active and dynamic subject; therefore, the challenge has to do with our capability to be flexible and to grab those opportunities to better promote it.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2company: Ferrocarril y Terminal del Valle de México
node.subject: Rail Network
node.title: Changing Signals
node.sections01: Today, we can proudly say that 75% of the passenger trains sold in Mexico during the last 21 years are CAF trains. Our main goal after becoming the leading player in the sector is to maintain this position, because the competition is tough. I would say that innovation and flexibility have been the key elements in our success, and we always try to understand the needs and circumstances of our clients at all levels, including the financial ones. CAF exported its first full passenger train to Mexico in the early 1990s, therefore it became the first country to which CAF started to fully export production. CAF has developed full projects in Mexico, meaning production, export, operation, and maintenance. CAF has found stability and security in Mexico, including security in our investments; we believe the government of Mexico is highly committed to foreign investors.
node.sections11: Kansas City Southern of Mexico (KCSM) is committed to the country, and has been present here for 17 years. This year we will be investing $143 million in Mexico in infrastructure and the maintenance of our network, as well as the acquisition of new equipment. We foresee a highly positive future for Mexico and growing volumes for our business. In intermodal freight transport anything can be moved by container. We have 4,200 kilometers of tracks in Mexico out of a total of around 20,000 kilometers, so that's around 25% of the total. That doesn't mean we have 25% of the market, however. I would say we're moving about 30% of the market on our trains. Almost all our freight either starts or ends at the Port of Lázaro Cárdenas. Most of the materials we transport either come through Lázaro Cárdenas or go through there. The port of Tampico and the port of Veracruz are also very important for us. In Nuevo Laredo we're now building what we call a secure corridor, and we're also changing the whole track from Nuevo Laredo to Monterrey, converting it into a high-speed track that can also transport a greater volume of freight, or at least more weight.
node.sections21: Normally 46% of our operations comprise whatever the railroads deliver, while 30% is intermodal and 24% is local freight. That means that 54% of the business of Ferrovalle is promoted by us, though we expect a ratio of 50:50 in the near future. There has been exceptional growth of warehousing in 2014, which has increased the percentage of income generated by Ferrovalle. As an industry, we are a technologically advanced modern freight railroad. Our market share today is at around 26%, vs. truck transportation, but should exceed 30% over the coming five or six years as we offer a safe, clean, long-distance, and cost-effective service. Also, we contribute to a reduction of congestion on the roads. Even though we are constricted with space in central Mexico City, we are developing additional space to offer better services. We have already built a yard for empty containers where we do not charge storage fees, up to a certain volume of containers, but were able to grow through the increased handling of empties. Most of our customers with containers are shipping companies.
node.sections31: Since the privatization of railway transportation 15 years ago, we have improved the country's infrastructure significantly. Ferromex in particular has been active in this area. Though there were some corridors with good infrastructure, there were others that were not in good condition because of the volumes and the weight of the cars. Ferromex has been investing heavily in state-of-the-art locomotives with more horsepower and the capacity to reduce fuel consumption, and on the infrastructure side, we have been renewing many of the lines, the ties, and the rail infrastructure and improving and enlarging the sidings. The longest trains demand sidings. If two trains want to cross on the same line, one has to pull over. Currently we can accommodate trains of more than 2.5 kilometers in length in such situations, and in general we are striving to increase our capacity and performance. About 81% of all the Mexican foreign trade is with the US, and the US economy is growing; it has overcome its recession.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: IT Services
node.title: I Know IT
node.sections01: We are innovating in terms of services, for instance we are launching here in Mexico our services based on satellite images (Predial, infrastructure image services for the oil and gas and telecomm industries), but we are also innovating to improve delivery. We are keen to innovate with revenue sharing models, for example, where we assist clients in reducing their IT-related operational costs. We are a company that takes risks and usually do so jointly with our clients. We help them to implement new ways of saving, which enables us to access new markets through the revenue-sharing selling model. We operate in many different ways, and opt for the one-on-one approach with our customers; our executives meet and talk about new ways of innovating and selling, and demonstrate how we can help our retailer, bank, or telecommunications company to innovate. For example, we help telecommunications companies provide new services for smart phones. We have developed several new ideas abroad, which we subsequently exported. Meanwhile, our alliances and partnerships also determine the market.
node.sections11: As our world and industry change, we must keep up with the times. Our offering of solutions and services is constantly evolving and driving the marketplace forward. For example, before the advent of mobile telephony, we were primarily a telephone card manufacturer. When mobile technology emerged, Gemalto realized the enormous opportunity and evolved to become the leader in SIM card production, a completely different venture with numerous additional solutions and value added services. As the market for SIM cards becomes saturated, we are again moving into exciting new directions. Today, most people around the world have a mobile telephone, which opens the door to offering a new realm of services. For example, six years ago, we were among the first to offer secure mobile banking services; now we are offering secure mobile payment and mobile wallet solutions. Innovation underpins our business at every turn. As a global technology leader, we are able to leverage our success abroad and be the first to bring leading edge solutions and services into the country.
node.sections21: Retail is really exploding in Mexico. Even though the economy is not moving as fast as we would like, stores are still opening every day. If you look around, many chains from the US are arriving in Mexico. The energy sector is also going to grow within the next three to five years once reforms are passed and laws are published. Many telecoms companies are also coming to Mexico to develop that sector. We need more competition in telecoms, and I expect it within the next two to three years. Mexico is divided into two parts: one is where the economy is growing and modernized. The other part is where mid-sized companies are not as competitive, lacking access to technology; this is where companies like AVNET can really make an impact. With solutions such as the cloud, we can provide technology inexpensively. Bandwidth is still expensive in Mexico, but once the competition starts to take place and bandwidth prices start to fall, companies are really going to have to buy the pipelines and the services behind them, which is going to be cheap to do.
node.sections31: BMC's solutions reduce costs, strengthen security, increase efficiency, and improve service delivery, while addressing federal IT policies. Mexico's culture is different in many ways to other parts in the world. Our customers have specific needs, but sometimes there is complexity on how they organize their IT departments. Creative solutions to problems are part of our culture, and many IT organizations adopt best practices and seek other frameworks/tools to use. Some are early adopters and others like the idea of a expert vendor that guides them. We, as a high-tech company, try to innovate and bring to our customers the better technology and professional services to solve their problems, always adapting our technology to their needs and guide them on best practices. Our focus is on reducing customer costs, generating value with our solutions, and providing technical support for our products. We expect the government to start investing in dependency management for major projects. It was announced that in 2014 Mexico will allocate the largest budget for an infrastructure project in its entire history.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Pharma
node.title: Pill-Power
node.sections01: The Mexican market is crucial for Apotex; it marked the company's first excursion abroad, and today we are the second largest subsidiary outside of the Canadian market. Apotex Mexico is the headquarters for Latin America, and from here we supply the rest of Latin America with both Mexican-made and Canadian products. We package them here in different formats for the Central American market, and in the very near future also for the Argentinian market. Currently, we have operations in four countries in Latin America, and distributors in Guatemala, Honduras, and Ecuador. We make 35% of our net sales to government institutions. Of our local production, 70% is destined for the state sector due to the high unit volume involved. Our competitive advantages are primarily quality, and secondly price. We are not a low-price company, as we need to maintain the quality proposition that underpins our reputation in the sector.
node.sections11: Boehringer Mexico has grown strongly and rapidly because it has a powerful pipeline, the trust of the medical community and patients, and a stronger market position than any other affiliate in the Boehringer Ingelheim universe. In Mexico, we are the sixth largest company in the pharmaceutical sector, and rank at around 17th in the world. Doctors in Mexico believe in our products' quality, efficacy and safety, and are confident in the business ethics of Boehringer Ingelheim. We have been in operation for almost 130 years, and have been present in Mexico for over 65. While other companies are losing patents in key product lines, we have close to 10 products set for launch in the market between 2010 and 2017 in our strongly innovative pipeline. Mexico has now been nominated to manufacture diabetes products for the rest of the world, including the Americas, and soon to the US if the FDA confirms our strategy. Independently from the diabetes products, we currently manufacture cardiovascular products for the US and are set to manufacture over the counter products for the rest of the world, which will result in a much larger local facility.
node.sections21: Cí­rculo de la Salud is one of Nadro's strategic programs as the content it carries provides a mechanism of professionalizing independent retailers, thereby enhancing their ability to compete with the larger pharmacy chains. Cí­rculo de la Salud deals effectively with the ethical issues involved in prescription substitution, supporting the doctor-patient relationship, while at the same time promoting the development of over 7,000 Nadro clients that are currently benefiting from this program. There is a second stage to this ecosystem called Cí­rculo de la Salud Oro, where retailers are effectively connected to our CRM (or Customer Relationship Management) platform, giving patients access to a number of loyalty programs provided by the pharmaceutical industry. While we now have over 450 retailers using our CRM, we expect this number to increase significantly in the short term. The National Institute of Genome Medicine is generating breakthroughs, and is one of the most important scientific institutions in Mexico. This area of medicine is a slow-burn endeavor as we are still very much learning the genetics of pathology.
node.sections31: Mexico represents the main business in Latin America. We started in Mexico in 2011, thanks to regulatory changes. Historically we have seen a regulated market, and the increased regulatory environment has rebuilt confidence in the country and in our line of business. Mexico is the reference country for certain Latin American markets, such as Colombia, Peru, and Chile. For us, Mexico is strategically the head of the business for the rest of Latin America and our presence here will grow year by year. We have reached ambitious targets thanks to new market regulations. This market offers many opportunities to companies such as ours that are vertically integrated. We have invested $150 million, and the main impact of this will be in bio-similarities, and are launching a line of products focused on HIV too. We aim to nurture an environment in which this research is respected by the authorities. I think ours is one of the few companies to have invested in clinical trials here in Mexico, and we are planning to set up a production plant as well.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: The Local Scene
node.title: Regional Tourism Development
node.sections01: We are working very closely with the Federal Secretary of Tourism and FONATUR to boost support for Hidalgo. They are now working on four projects that are going to impact the position of Hidalgo State as a tourism destination. One of them is the project of the archeological zone of Tula, one of the most important cultures of ancient Mexico. The other is a convention center that we are planning to build that we hope to call “The City of Knowledge and Culture." It will be in the city of Pachuca. This project will help to improve the economy. Companies come to Hidalgo because it is more cost effective than other destinations, as well as the sensational food that is on offer here. There is a third project concerning a new center for festivals and events, with the San Francisco Fair being the most popular and important, which is held in October. The final project has to do with central downtown Pachuca. There is a plan to create a cultural center for music, dance, and performance artists, not just from Hidalgo, but for the entire nation and other countries, too. That is one of the goals of Governor Francisco Olvera Ruiz. However, we still need support from the federal government to make it possible.
node.sections11: Jalisco is Mexico, because all the climates and geographies that our country offers are also present in the state. In Jalisco, we have mountain resorts, colonial cities, magical towns, beautiful beaches, archaeological sites, and important religious destinations of national and international significance, not to mention our indigenous cultures, such as the Nahuas and Huichol, southern and northern, respectively, of our federal entity. We host the Guadalajara metropolitan area, one of the main destinations for MICE tourism nationwide, which has experienced a notable increase in the number of visitors arriving by air and by land. Elsewhere, Puerto Vallarta and Costalegre, where important beach destinations such as Barra de Navidad, Melaque, La Manzanilla, and Punta Pérula are located, among others, are some of the gems that nature gifted Jalisco along its 300 kilometers of coastline on the Pacific Ocean. Jalisco also offers a wealth of paths and landscapes for ecotourism, with extensive forested areas. It has the Nevado Volcano, and most of the Colima Volcano extension is located within its territory. There is also a strong gastronomic tradition and variety, due in part to the extensive territory and diverse habits and customs of the citizens that populate the state's 125 municipalities. To talk about Jalisco is to talk about Mexican culture, specifically mariachi and tequila, which are two internationally renowned symbols of our country. These are gifts from Jalisco to Mexico, and to the entire world.
node.sections21: We focus on the diversification of the sector, as that will help us improve our product and diversify the source of income in the industry, too. At the moment, every tourist spends an average of Ps700 when staying in Sinaloa and we compete against other destinations like Cancun, where tourists spend between $200 and $300 in one day. That has to be our focus too; target the quality of the visitor rather than the quantity. Therefore, we need the quality of service in order to be able to better sell the product. In addition, we need to further work on showing the world the many wonderful locations and elements we have in our state; we have around 1 million hectares of agricultural crops and the national sector moves around 200 million visitors per year. However, a small portion of it reaches us, and we have to build infrastructure to attract more of this type of tourism. On top of that, we have many natural spaces in the state, for example the northern ravines, which receives very few visitors, and this is something we have to change. I think, for example, hunting and fishing are two of the tourism segments we can better exploit in the near future, too.
node.sections31: One of our main strengths is the combination of business and entertainment, and we have been considerably successful in this field. Guanajuato's tourism industry has experienced stronger growth than other regions of the same size. In addition, it has benefited from increasing investment not only in the tourism industry, but also in other economic sectors such as the automotive industry. Over the past few years, several assembly and production plants have established operations in our state, which has enabled us to become a Mexican automotive cluster. This development attracted interesting growth in the corporate segment of the tourism industry in Guanajuato and that has also helped us to achieve a high level of specialization and diversification in our tourism industry compared with other states. This has impacted the improvement of other segments such as gastronomy and adventure tourism. Guanajuato also had the two fastest growing cities in the country in terms of population in 2013. Such development has boosted confidence among private sector investors, and today, for example, we are looking at the construction of 22 new hotels in the state. No other state can boast such a large number of ongoing construction projects. In 2014, we have seen a significant rise in the number of visitors and their expenditure per visit.
node.sections41: Medical tourism is a huge opportunity for Baja California. The quality of our staff and medical professionals is top notch. Most of our doctors are bilingual, and many are bicultural, holding degrees from universities in the US. Aside from that, the film industry has great potential, and we could bring a competitive edge to California through companies filming in Baja California, where, incidentally, we also have a film school. We have a great history in film, and the number of awards that local cinema has received is evidence of this. San Diego just closed its film commission, and I believe we could work together to rejuvenate it. We are also developing the rest of the state to feature renewable energy, and have a self-sustaining development 68 kilometers south of San Felipe. Tourism is another area of great potential, and we have just recently signed new contracts with cruise lines. Ensenada will be the second most-visited port in Mexico in 2014, and we are poised to build a new port between Ensenada and Los Cabos, which should help the cruise industry in the near future. We are working hard at these projects to make Baja California a world-class destination.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Realtors
node.title: Wheeling and Dealing
node.sections01: Real estate is a capital-intensive business. Without equity capital and debt, you cannot grow your business. Equity Capital is most important. We started in Mexico in 1996 investing capital provided by friends and family, and built a respectable platform to attract Prudential to establish its first co-investment program in Latin America. We started with one build-to-suit with Mattel in Northern Mexico City, and over five years we developed and managed around 77 buildings, ground-up speculative construction with Prudential, which sourced capital and organized various syndicated loans to maximize and leverage our capital for maximum returns. Today, the Mexican real estate market is quite mature as International funds, domestic pension funds, publicly traded global funds REITs, and domestic publicly traded funds FIBRAS provide a deep source of capital for speculative development and acquisitions that has compressed capitalization rates and values in line risk adjusted values. Around 30% of our activity is in the northern Mexico City region, 40% in the central region, 27% in Bají­o, 17% in the northeast region, and 16% in the northwest region. Recently, we won a national bidding process to develop Audi's Just-in-Time, Just-in-Sequence Supplier Park in Puebla. It is a two-phase $110 million project. Going forward most of our development will be in the central region and Bají­o with value-add acquisitions in the north.
node.sections11: We have been growing, not only geographically, but also in terms of service lines. We still perform considerable brokerage, but now offer more specialized services. We offer more than just a transaction, and advise our clients on the best real estate decisions for their business. We also provide real estate management services that feature property management, facility management, lease administration, and project management. We have a strong valuation and advisory division. We have also opened another division related to capital flow and investors. Finally, we also offer full-service corporate solutions to multinational companies interested in real estate. This business line has been highly successful because the number of Multilatinas has been growing, and they feel comfortable working with an international brand that has the local knowledge and flavor of the Latin people. Capital flows toward the real estate markets in Mexico are increasing because of the economy and low country risk. Additionally, the legal framework has evolved to create special ways to invest like the FIBRAS. After putting this instrument in the Mexican legislation, the market is capturing a tremendous amount of investment for real estate.
node.sections21: CBRE is following what is happening in the Mexican market. The Mexican market has become institutionalized, meaning that companies, funds, and banks predominantly own real estate, rather than families and individuals having ownership. As the market has changed and transformed, CBRE has grown and added more facets to the company's operations, adjusting to what is now an institutionalized global market. The market is different in that it is a young and energetic, and we are experiencing a boom. Of course, that feeds a great deal of energy into what we are doing, and adds to the growth CBRE is already experiencing due to global expansion. We are already seeing many energy players coming into market and looking for new space, or extra space, generating additional business. One of several hub cities for energy around the world is Houston, Texas, and we work closely with our office there to assist our clients and investors advising them about what they need to do before they come to Mexico. Having those relationships, and being part of a larger network, works well in this regard. The fact is that what we are doing is trending toward the practices that you see more in the US and in parts of Europe. That is the natural evolution of the business.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Materials
node.title: Material World
node.sections01: This building materials group was formed four or five years ago, and the company's shareholders decided to go into one of the primary materials in construction, namely cement. We started with an investment of $315 million in a plant in Hidalgo State. Mexico is a good market for cement as there is still considerable infrastructure and housing to build. At the same time, all of the world's major cement players are present here, with CEMEX being the giant. It controls an approximate 45% market share, having once controlled two-thirds. Holcim is another major player in this industry, and has been operating in Mexico for many years. Mexico sells more concrete in bags than in bulk, which is a significant difference compared to the US or Europe where most sales are carried out in bulk. In Mexico, most sales are of 50-kilogram bags, most frequently bought by small-scale builders. We currently operate with an installed capacity of 1 million tons. Demand in Mexico is as high as 36 million tons, however, and so we represent just one 36th of the market. Lafarge entered Mexico in 2002 with a white cement plant in Hidalgo, and then built another small plant adjacent to this installation with a capacity of 700,000 tons.
node.sections11: We have one production plant for tiles and two for toilets. In 2013, we managed to produce six million square meters of tiles. We have five warehouses located in Tijuana, Guadalajara, Monterrey, Mexico City, and in Cancun, which are our distribution centers, and we are located in strategic points of the country. Our main market is retail; however, we also have a division that caters to major projects in the construction. Customers appear to favor Italian style. In the mid-to- high-end price range, they prefer larger sizes of 80x80 cm or 60x120 cm. The preference for larger tile sizes is growing, as these have the effect of making spaces appear larger. We also offer eco-products that sell around 20,000 units per month. This kind of product consumes less than five liters per flush, and we even feature a dual flush of five or three liters. We have estimated that a single eco-toilet can save as much as half a million liters in its lifetime. Our company ended 2013 with a 12% rise in growth, despite the broader economy not echoing this performance. Our strategy relies on the ability to make quick changes, and on adaptability. Around four years ago, 45% of our sales were made on economic tiles; however, today that segment represents just 15% of our sales.
node.sections21: ARZYZ was founded in 1980 to produce materials such as aluminum and zinc. In 1991, we became distributors for Grupo Mexico, and began to significantly increase our production, revolutionizing the market with induction furnaces. From there, we started to grow and export. In 1998, we associated ourselves with Union Minere, our first international association. It is a world leader in the treatment of special metals. In 2010, the company began its transformation. After painstaking analysis we identified an opportunity in the aluminum industry. Mexico did not produce aluminum at that time, and so we started a strategy to take advantage of the potential in recycling in terms of sustainability and the legal framework. Currently, we are in the process of finishing our strategic plan covering the 2014 to 2020 period to create an integrated organization that gathers, produces, transports, and sells scrap. This is a business model that we learned from the Spanish, Germans, and French, who are world leaders in the aluminum sector. Now, we are consolidating the organization, which is already an institution. Technology is vital, too, and we have state-of-the-art equipment of the most sophisticated technology. Over the next few years, we hope to increase our production to 500,000 tons per year from its current 250,000 tons. We want to be the best at what we do; the most ecological and sustainable, and the best quality providers.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: International Players
node.title: Open For Business
node.sections01: If you consider insurance in general, I would say that the products are rather international in nature, but that personal lines can differ notably from country to country. There is a difference in terms of the products you have for auto or home when you compare the Latin American market to its US or European counterparts. In auto insurance, for example, one has to adapt products to the specific regulations of the country even though in broad brushstrokes the concept behind the products does not vary. In the Mexican market, we try to differentiate our products and de-commoditize them. The first point of concern was for the adjuster to arrive at the scene of an accident in as short a time as possible. The second consideration was the availability of a replacement vehicle during the repair period, which is a pioneering move we introduced. Now, according to independent surveys, we are seen in the market as the best service company in the country.
node.sections11: AIG LAC has a presence in 15 countries in the region, of which Mexico boasts within the two largest top and bottom lines. As part of AIG's strategic business expansion initiatives, nine countries have been selected globally, and Mexico is one of them. AIG is the world's largest insurance organization with more than 64,000 employees across the globe. We serve more than 88 million customers in more than 130 countries. We are extremely enthusiastic about the near future, and I am confident that Mexico's time is here. The new reforms have triggered substantial demand. We have already seen the infrastructure plan, and billions of dollars are set to enter the broader economy. I'm positive that the economy will grow probably by a fraction more than estimated, and this will largely depend on secondary laws. We boast robust macroeconomic data, strong government, and private sector initiative. There is a substantial volume of money entering the country, and we lack a fiscal deficit. And so with general improvement foreseen, the insurance sector, too, stands to benefit.
node.sections21: I think we have good products and a strong understanding of our market. We also benefit from being part of the BBVA group. We try to complement the bank's product and services, offering insurance products that are aligned to client needs. In most countries, the major insurance companies have a strong presence, but in Mexico there are strong local players too, which are very competitive and efficient. In any country, each player has its own history. Some of the companies that now belong to international groups were originally local companies. International groups have the acquisition power that a local player probably does not. But in the end, the success of the company lies in the people in the organization and the methodologies they have operating in Mexico. There are benefits from being part of an international group, but I would not say that Mexican companies are at a disadvantage; they know the market, they have talented people and good processes, and they are efficient.
node.sections31: We are the second strongest company in Mexico, and financially speaking, our goal is to become the strongest. New York Life is a mutuality, meaning we have a need for financial strength, rather than for earnings. New York Life purchased us 14 years ago and in those years, our revenue never went to the US as 100% of the money generated in Mexico remained in our country to bolster and enlarge the company. Also our earnings are reinvested annually in Mexico to create more jobs and strengthen the economy. Over the next five years, we aiming for double-digit growth; this requires an effective structure and strategy to be achievable. We need the best sales force, the best employees, the best partners, and the best brokers in Mexico. Seguros Monterrey New York Life is comfortable growing in line with, or in excess of national growth. In fact, we have been growing at five or six times Mexico's annual GDP growth 13% during 2013. And we are set to hire 2,000 new agents in 2014.
node.sections41: I think the Mexican insurance sector offers the highest opportunity in Latin America and perhaps the world in terms of progression. Only 25% of drivers have car insurance, and only 5% of citizens have home insurance. What's more, less than 10% of companies have insurances out of the 5 million SMEs that exist in Mexico. Just 8 million Mexicans have insurance coverage. If you look at the dimensions of our business for the long term, this marks a great opportunity because the middle class in Mexico will grow and the average age of Mexicans will rise, and both of these are trends that make people wealthier. If you look at the long-term perspective, the fundamentals are good and the regulations are going the right way. It is a healthy country in terms of financials. It will grow over time. We need a bit of help from the government. Third-party liability is important for the country. We hope that, as in many other countries, the government uses insurance to safeguard its economy and citizens.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: GSM SEGURIDAD Grupo Schutz de México
node.subject: Security
node.title: Safe Hands
node.sections01: We employ 11,000 people in the country. Our contribution to private security in the country has been the specialized human resources that we have introduced at different levels. Our employees are specialized in high defense systems (HDS). Our personnel are able to handle crisis situations under different circumstances. Their training involves learning how to handle stress situations and act on instinct. Then, when they face a real situation, such as a kidnapping, they are able to handle it. Our employees can also use firearms, as authorized by the Secretary of Defense. They are able to use them in a quick and effective way in order to protect the workers and goods of different companies. However, all of this human capital would be useless if we didn't use the proper technology. In 1999, we implemented a new division, MSI 2000, and we have an international emergency center that works 24 hours, seven days a week. We have 52 offices in the country so, if any client has an emergency, the alarm rings and we send support within five minutes.
node.sections11: Ours is a difficult market because there are no barriers to entry. Anyone can create a company, legal or illegal. There are perhaps 10,000 companies, but many are not legal or registered. They do not even have official permits or certificates to provide security services. Perhaps less than 200 of those 10,000 companies satisfy international certifications like ISO, or certifications like ASIS, BASC, and C-TPAT, all of which we have. When people and companies come to us, they know they can rely on us. Therefore, we decided to develop a technological platform to connect more efficiently and effectively with the federal police, sending our information instantly and simultaneously to officers close to the incident at hand. After all, we do not have the authority to carry out security measures, as that authority rests with the state, the police and the other security forces. Therefore, we have to work closely and effectively with the government to provide the security that our clients need. On this new technological platform, we can coordinate these efforts at optimum capacity.
node.sections21: Our consultancy work focuses on three areas of risk management: political risk, security risk, and integrity risk. We seek to work with our clients to evaluate and assess these risks as they relate to their geographical location and industry; and then work with them to manage and mitigate those risks. The security risk element attracts more attention, in large part due to domestic and international media attention. However, our perspective has always been that companies that are prepared to invest in assessing and managing these risks are able to operate very successfully here. From a political perspective, we categorize Mexico as medium risk, but if you put that in the context of what is happening in other markets in the region, such as Venezuela, Mexico is significantly more stable at the macro level. One of the risks that often gets highlighted is the security situation, and that is a core part of our business; analyzing those risks and how they could potentially impact or affect a company that is already operating here or a company that is looking to move into this market.
node.sections31: Over the past two years, the energy sector has seen a great turnaround in terms of security, thanks to collaboration among many companies initiated by the Labor Secretariat. The idea was to increase the level of risk assessment of work places and to provide a way to ascertain the optimum solution to mitigate that risk. In order to enforce compliance with standards, a number of inspectors were trained in what to look for and how to look for it. Kidde was invited to assist with training in relation to these new safety regulations. The new standard calls for equipment to suppress fires without human intervention, and also increased fire alarm use. We continue to offer a portfolio of products addressing very specific risks. For instance, we have many open mines in this country that require strong, heavy and large trucks—during mining operations their tires face risk of burning. We offer specific solutions designed to protect the tires, which in turn will reduce the risk to the driver.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Local Oil and Gas Services
node.title: Keep It Flowing
node.sections01: The energy sector reform will allow the Mexican State to retain full ownership of hydrocarbon reserves and of the former state monopolies, PEMEX and the Federal Electricity Commission (CFE). The government will charge royalties for the exploitation of these reserves, and a sovereign Mexican oil fund will be incorporated in order to create transparency in the management of the economic rent generated by their exploitation. The main component foresees PEMEX and CFE transforming from a monopoly to a dominant state-owned entity. They will become productive enterprises competing on equal terms with private companies, but still as state-owned entities. There will be at least four organizations regulating the oil and gas industry. Oil service companies, whom I represent through AMESPAC, are counting on PEMEX becoming a dominant player and trusting in its strength to face the new competition. Some of the companies that belong to AMESPAC have most of the capabilities required to become independent operators of oil and gas fields. We are counting on some of these Mexican-owned corporations being able to transform themselves from oil service entities into fully independent operators in new areas, such as shale gas and oil, and developing mature oil fields that in many cases PEMEX has abandoned.
node.sections11: The Group is divided into four main business niches. The first one is Blue Marine Cargo, with which we ship clean and dirty products, mainly for PEMEX, on the west and east coasts. We offer this service with mid-range tankers of around 47,000 deadweight tons (dwt). The demand from PEMEX has been very stable for the past 20 years. We also provide for the transportation of people and materials to offshore fields. The oil companies require a lot of logistical support, and if a company is expanding its fields and promoting more activity, their need for transporting people, equipment, and goods is sustainable. I believe that this market will grow with the reforms because more companies are going to arrive in the coming years to carry out exploration and then develop fields. Our second niche is Blue Marine Oil and Gas. In this regard, we provide technological solutions for offshore oil well situations. These activities help oil companies to monetize their production earlier, which means a direct impact on their profitability. The third business unit is Blue Marine Offshore, which provides services related to maintenance and construction vessels. We accommodate about 200-250 people on board, and they perform maintenance and construction activities on the platforms. We currently have four vessels operating in the Gulf of Mexico.
node.sections21: The role that Navix plays in the industry is quite significant, as we cover 90% of the financial needs of our clients. With Navix's funding, our clients have tripled their revenues and doubled their equity. Navix will also offer syndicated loans where our funding capacity is exceeded, capital raisings when our clients require equity rather than debt, and strategic advisory when our clients demand either bringing in a strategic partner or would like to consolidate their sector. Currently, our loan portfolio is concentrated in Pemex contractors. Close to 95% of our loan book is in this sector and it resembles the mix that Pemex has in terms of what type of goods and services it demands: close to 60% of our clients are constructors, 30% of them provide a wide range of services and the remaining procure goods for Pemex. We are amending our business model as a result of changes to the sector itself, and will be set to provide other services where clients demanding loans that exceed our balance sheet capacity would be facilitated through syndicated loans. We have tested the idea with both local and international investors, and as long as Navix is involved in the process, they are eager to participate in the risk for such loans.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1position: Vice-President of Corporate Affairs in Latin America
node.subject: Electricity Service Providers
node.title: Current Affairs
node.sections01: Our project, Etileno XXI, will be very important for the economy and for the petrochemical industry of Mexico. The project is going to replace most of the imports of polyethylene; meaning around 70% of the existing market will be supplied by local production. We believe that our participation in the Mexican market is going to add a lot of innovation to the polyethylene market in the country. Based on our existing experience, we believe that we have innovative products. We will make a lot of differentiation in the services we offer, as well as in innovation and technology. All these things together add value to our Mexican customers and to the local economy. It is the largest industrial project in Mexico, and it has been the largest investment in petrochemicals in the Americas. The whole investment for the project is worth some $4.5 billion. International lenders have a 70% participation rate in the project, with the IFC being one of the most important lenders. Its participation is based on the belief that it is a very important project for the Mexican economy and for the relationship between Mexico and Brazil.
node.sections11: Our company produces a wide range of car batteries including lithium-ion batteries, for electric and hybrid cars, and AGM batteries for start-stop vehicles. We are global leaders in lead-acid batteries supported by our facilities in Mexico. There is also potential growth in sectors such as construction and real estate. In 2012, the construction sector did not experience significant growth; nonetheless, since 2013, we have been observing a considerable growth in the construction of large scale buildings. Our air conditioning and automation systems are widely used in Mexico. Wherever you see a new building, there is a high possibility that we have supplied them with air conditioning, controls, and energy saving systems. In Mexico, we are generating close to $5.5 billion out of a $42 billion total in global operations; it represents around 13% of the company's total revenue. Mexico has the benefits of proximity to the US, cost effectiveness, high-quality production, and the availability of good human capital.
node.sections21: The Mexican market is key to the company both in terms of sales and manufacturing. We have a solid presence here, over 9,000 collaborators, 10 manufacturing facilities, one R&D Center and over 25 commercial offices, plus the corporate offices, and we only expect our footprint to increase. Just like in any other economy, we target specific segments based on their growth expectation and investment levels, some of the ones we are leading are utilities & infrastructure, industries & machines manufacturers, non-residential buildings, data centers & networks and the residential market, and this has allowed us to strengthen our position as a leading energy management firm. We have invested $65 million in our new R&D center in Monterrey, and plan to establish new manufacturing and generation plants in the country. We expect the market demand to rise due to the announced investments in infrastructure, and Mexico has been a good manufacturing base for the company since NAFTA was signed. We expect a significant growth in the oil and gas, and utilities market, not just for Schneider Electric, but also for the entire sector, as a result of the energy reform.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Renewables
node.title: Blowing in the Wind
node.sections01: The Asociación Mexicana Energí­a Eólica (AMDEE) was established in 2005 by seven businessmen who had the common goal of establishing a new industry in Mexico. The Association aims at promoting and developing projects within the wind energy industry in Mexico, as well as representing the interests of the companies in the industry before the authorities and other economic sectors in the country. The first large wind energy project that we implemented in Mexico took place in 2007. And since then, we have seen the installation of 2,000 MW in capacity. At the moment, the Association has 52 members and among them there are developers, constructors, manufacturers, and consulting and service-related companies. They represent all the most relevant segments within the wind energy industry. The sector offers plenty of attractive opportunities with great future returns to investors; therefore, I do not see the need to set up a subsidy scheme to boost the development of projects in the sector. Wind energy is competitive enough not to depend on subsidies.
node.sections11: Our projects overall will generate around 366 MW, which is actually equivalent to 22.2% of the installed capacity. The first phase is at around 65 MW and will be located in the state of Puebla. We have strong support not only from the International Energy Commission, but also from the government of Puebla, as this will put the state at the forefront in eolic energy. Puebla has wind, land, and infrastructure. We are investing close to $130 million for the first park and are keen to leverage as many companies and as much manpower as possible from Puebla. Mexico has already signed various international agreements with other organizations in order to accomplish certain renewable energy goals. The energy reform will improve the work environment for wind energy companies in Mexico. In this context, we expect to grow by over 3% in 2014. Our exports are growing not only because the US is growing, but also because Mexico is the country with the most free trade agreements in the world.
node.sections21: We started working in Mexico in 2005, providing consultancy and assistance to private wind developers. In 2008 we opened our first office in Monterrey, relocating to Querétaro in 2010. In 2009, Garrad Hassan became part of GL, I joined the company in the final stage of this process, and most recently in 2012 GL merged with DNV, creating DNV GL which is our current name. DNV GL Renewables Advisory provides consultancy project services to banks, developers, investment funds, NGOs, and government without owning assets. There is already a lot of money invested in the wind sector, but there will probably be more following the energy reform. An Asociación Mexicana de Energí­a Eólica study into the potential of wind energy in Mexico points to a conservative potential of 12 GW of installed capacity by 2020. Mexico is the second largest wind energy market in Latin America after Brazil, and will probably remain so. I envisage Mexico adding between 700 MW and 900 MW per year in the near future.
node.sections31: Currently, the energy division is the main activity of Acciona in Mexico, because we have 556 MW of installed capacity through four operating projects. One of these projects supports self-sufficiency, and the remaining three are associated with the CFE as an independent power producer (IPP). Additionally, we have two projects totaling 300 MW under construction. At the end of 2014, we will have 900 MW of installed capacity. Therefore, Acciona Energí­a is the main area of activity of Acciona in Mexico and even in the Mesoamerican region. Acciona Energí­a in Mexico is focusing on two technologies: wind and solar. Technology transfer will occur when industrial plans are linked to the development of renewable energies, something that currently does not exist. Meeting the goal of 35% clean energy is another boost for renewables. Finally, the energy reform will open investment to the private sector, while the tax reform will bring in the new carbon tax, which penalizes fossil generation and indirectly benefits the renewable energy segment, too.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist1company: Henkel Mexico, Central America & the Caribbean
node.subject: Why Mexico?
node.title: Be Here Now
node.sections01: The role of the Mexican team is crucial as it sustains the bulk of the business. Manufacturing-wise, about 60% of our revenues are from products that are physically produced here. The core business is predominantly performed in Tijuana, where logistics center is also located. The orders placed by NASA are produced in Tijuana. We also produce here all hardware for tower controls, our call center, and any project that requires wireless products. We were also able to relocate critical operations to Mexico, and our technical assistance operation is located in Tijuana. We have a team of over 60 people fielding calls from all over the world and resolving technical issues. Meanwhile, our science center today employs 120 people engaged in product development. Plantronics Mexico, therefore, contributes diversely to the success of Plantronics International. I think that Tijuana will remain a very important player for the electronics sector. I also foresee the company entering new sectors, especially healthcare.
node.sections11: Mexico ranks among our top 10 countries. This means that we give it a high priority for investment. And as we enlarge our production capacity we also expand our R&D facility. Mexico is one of the 10 main hubs worldwide and is an emerging market, which is precisely where the company is looking. There are not that many differences from other markets in terms of demand. The difference is of course that Mexico is an emerging market and Henkel, which fits the profile of its focus of attention. In our strategy for 2016, we intend to realize 50% of our sales in emerging and 50% in developed markets. Already, 55% of our employees are located in emerging markets and Mexico is a big part of this; it is now consolidating itself as one of the largest production hubs in Latin America. Many of the companies operating here have confirmed investments in the country. We have covered all the industrial components that have been developing over recent years.
