node.sections21: At PepsiCo, performance with purpose is our philosophy. We have to deliver the numbers, but we also have to make sure the company is sustainable for the future. We are hopeful and our outlook for Mexico remains good. This market caters to a highly demanding consumer who has been used to these products for many years. For Mexicans, tortillas have been consumed since the time of the Aztecs, so to satisfy the consumer we have to offer the best tortilla products. The Mexican consumer loves repertoire, meaning they want to change from one product to another and eat many different brands. Also, the Mexican consumer is very sensitive to price points, which means they want to buy a product by size and weight, and they want options. The Mexican consumer is much more sensitive to certain tastes than other markets; therefore, we have a process to determine the shelf life of the product and make daily taste quality checks.
node.sections31: I remain excited by everything I observe in Mexico. We have close to 7,000 employees in Mexico. We expect the next five years to be much more like the five years leading up to 2013, and foresee double-digit growth. Wherever we are present our objective is always to outperform the economy, which is precisely what we did in 2013, although in effect the economy was not particularly strong. In 2012, we posted double-digit sales growth, which led to growth of more then $50 million. Looking at the next five years, there is no doubt that we will be able to double those sales figures. And over the next three to five years, we are planning to continue investing in commercialization, marketing, and presence. We also plan to double our investment in R&D over the next five years.
node.sections41: Mexico is roughly the 15th largest operation we have around the world. The figure varies considerably due to exchange rate fluctuations, but it is in that ballpark, and hence a significant operation. We have a strong commitment with Mexico. In 2011, for example we opened our most advanced aerosols plant, which was designed to include the most advanced energy consumption and environmental protection technologies. This site has its own solar energy production, as well as water collection and recycling systems. We see it as a model of sustainable practices for future plants built elsewhere. We opened a new manufacturing plant in 2011 on a ‚¬60 million investment, and it is one of the most advanced we operate in the world. We have also committed to capital expenditure of $500 million until 2015 in new capacity, new plants, and new equipment, with a substantial volume being dedicated to the Mexican market. We want to be a part of Mexican growth.

node.author: TBY

node.sections01: Air Liquide is in 80 countries around the world. Mexico is one of the world's largest economies, and it was always a challenge to enter because the market had been dominated by other major players. Other competitors have tried to come into the country before and failed. We made a strong entrance into Mexico, with a strategy of building a solid foundation with a long-term approach. Our relationship with Altos Hornos de México has been a key example of this. In April 2013, we inaugurated the largest Air Separation Plant in the country, which produces more than 1,600 metric tons of oxygen per day. We supply large volumes of oxygen, nitrogen, and argon from this plant, but in addition, we produce significant quantities of liquid oxygen, nitrogen, and argon to sell to other customers in Mexico. Since entering the Mexican market in 2011, Air Liquide has invested over $250 million dollars into production facilities, distribution assets and other supply chain infrastructure in Mexico. We are always looking for new growth opportunities and would be excited to have the potential to continue investing in Mexico as we have been able to do thus far.
node.sections11: We started in Mexico in 1964, creating products for the local market. At the time, we were focusing on the textile, leather, paper and construction markets. We had been growing and also acquiring businesses up until the start of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), 20 years ago, when we had to face a new challenge. Mexico was opening to the global market, so we also had to compete with external market; there were a lot of opportunities for us. With the trade agreement at that time it was necessary to restructure because if you are competing with the rest of the world you need to make your productive sites much more efficient. Since then, we have continued to acquire companies. BASF LAN is now a company with a $2.5 billion turnover and more than 2,000 local employees. In the past 20 years, demand has been growing by around 7% a year. This growth was due to global production, and was mainly import driven. The new energy reform will offer the opportunity to address this situation. The contribution of the chemical industry to GDP is 1.5%, and in a country like Mexico with oil and gas in the market, it should be between 3% and 5%.
node.sections21: For Lanxess, the Mexican market is key because it is a growing market with a strategic position related to the four macro trends that we are involved in. We are focused on mobility, urbanization, agriculture, and water, and our largest markets are the automotive and construction sectors. We offer high-performance plastics, and many synthetic types of rubber. Mexico is the eighth largest producer of cars in the world, and the fourth largest exporter. Our products are oriented to the manufacturers and assemblers of cars in Mexico, especially in relation to the materials needed to produce green tires, which means tires with better rolling enforcement that reduce CO2 emissions. We aim to reduce fuel consumption and we offer high-performance plastics in order to produce lighter vehicles. The industry in the country is facing big challenges because, in some aspects, we are linked to the past. Mexico, now, imports almost 70% of the raw materials that are consumed. For this reason, the chemical sector in Mexico has decreased its contribution to GDP over the last 10 years from 10% in 1987 to 1.2% in the last year. This is the real challenge for the chemical sector in Mexico; we need to improve production in order to fulfill demand.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Specialized & Ready
node.title: Tailor Made
node.sections01: Given that Mexico is a young country and has an evolving economy, the oil and gas industries are future markets for us. We were selected by Shell as its preferred instrument provider worldwide. We also work with PEMEX, where our instruments and solutions are used in a number of different processes from exploration and production, to refinery and terminal management. We are focused, too, on key industries such as food and beverages, chemicals, life sciences, water and wastewater, and mining, and each of these has bright prospects in Mexico. The Swiss are normally associated with precision and reliability; however, it is also a very global country. We want our global customers to feel at home everywhere by giving them reliable and global solutions. We sell safety, reliability, environmental compatibility, and cost efficiency. When measuring flow in a pipe, the level of a storage tank, pressure in a steam generator, or temperature in a reactor, our customers know that they can trust E + H. Companies need to be more efficient, and have better measurements in their processes.
node.sections11: Our main strength is development, which is based in the skilled and qualified staff we have here. We also have the most advanced technologies. TC Technologies is committed to providing its customers with quality services. We take care of the design, development, production, and commercialization processes of many products. TC Technologies is the leading company in integral technological development. We provide fully integrated IT solutions for a wide range of clients from all the economic sectors. We also have our own interfaces and products. However, we also purchase technologies from other countries. This combination puts us at the forefront of the industry and we have, as one of our main missions, to make technology available to everybody. We have an electric car project with a long-term vision, which we are developing with a Spanish partner and a national university. We envisage a vehicle with batteries of 56 kW and have plans to finish that first model by July 2015. We have already developed an electric motorbike, and it is already out and available.
node.sections21: The range of products that we bottle in Mexico is crucial for company growth. The company's strategy that took shape in the early 2000s gravitated toward global customers active in Mexico. We started serving the main brands, such as Coca-Cola, Danone, and Nestlé as some of the focus customers that we serve globally. Yet we subsequently came to appreciate the huge opportunity to serve local customers who operated within the huge economy of Mexico itself. We have three business divisions: food and beverages, household and personal care products, and a third division dedicated to specific products for the food industry. Graham produces products for a specific niche, which differentiates us from our competitors. It is certainly clear that Mexico has a technology shortfall, and is heavily reliant on imports. It is also weak in sectors such as plastics. Therefore, I perceive huge opportunity for the country to support such markets not only in terms of plastic bottles, but also regarding the technology that could be developed locally. We develop through cooperation with the government.
node.sections31: ERICO has been present in Mexico since 1970 having focused on a set of products, the oldest of which is CADWELD, which is used in grounding systems, and permanent electrical connections. We began developing operations for ERICO Latin America in Mexico, investigated open markets and opportunities for products, but also made sure to emphasize that ERICO was a provider of solutions. Our largest market is Mexico followed by Brazil, but we are currently developing our presence in Colombia. We pursue different strategies in each country, given the specifics of government entities, prevailing laws, and tender specifications, which ultimately requires us to adapt on a case-by-case basis. In Mexico we employ approximately 20 people, yet we compete with large players. We are in fact their benchmark mainly because of the manner by which we approach the market and our knowledge base. ERICO, for example, developed exothermic welding technology, designed by Dr. Cadwell, hence the name CADWELD. No one else has been as successful in rail work as we have.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Auto Scene
node.title: Exhausting Work
node.sections01: We export them our engines separately, as they are mainly used in our trucks, specifically the V6 and V8 engines. We export to our assembly plants in the US and Canada. We have two engine plants here, one producing the 3.6-liter V-6 Pentastar Engine and another producing the 5.7-liter, 6.4-liter V-8 HEMI® Engine. It is a high-performance engine, which is used in certain trucks. Additionally, we are adding a production line to assemble the TigerShark engine. Right now, we produce one engine every 17 seconds, and we are aiming at making that one every 12 seconds, or five per minute. Mexico is becoming a major production hub for Chrysler. From my perspective, Mexico is a market with a great potential, but we need to make that potential happen. We have always thought that Mexico should be a $2 billion vehicle market. We talk with different governments and administrations on what we can do to take Mexico to that level, but we haven't found the solution yet. In 2013, it was almost $1.1 billion, so still $900 million short.
node.sections11: We have been present in Mexico for close to 90 years, and have become one of its largest exporters. I would describe the performance of Ford in Mexico as outstanding. Naturally, that has much to do with the massive investments made over the course of recent years, such as the expansion of the production plant in Hermosillo, which grew from 56 vehicles per hour to 62 vehicles per hour—that means an annual capacity of 380,000 units. We have also invested in the launch of the new Fusion model, the opening of a new engine plant in Chihuahua, and the refurbishment of the Cuautitlán assembly plant for the launch of the new model Fiesta. We have been growing our engineering capacity in Mexico by expanding the Product Development Center headcount from 50 to almost 1,000 engineers by the end of 2013. The new investments provided such scale that, in 2013, we became the country's second largest exporter. We remain committed to Mexico, and therefore plan to sustain our prominent role in the sector within export and local markets.
node.sections21: We have an overall sales volume of 7,000 units right now in a market reaching 1 million units. This means we hold around 0.7% of the market. We should keep in mind that here we are in the first stages of business development. Right now, our main priority is to build a robust image of the Peugeot brand in Mexico; we retain our European brand persona unlike certain other firms in this market, as Mexico is an open country with influences from the US as well as important European traditions. The market today is at a complex juncture; the country has set up the process to introduce key reforms, but many have yet to come into force. On top of that, many people remain unsure as to which path the country will take. This is generating a lack of confidence among consumers, and society in general. This climate leads many people to postpone new vehicle purchases. Also, I think there are too many bureaucratic steps involved in purchasing new vehicles. Our priority is to revise the old stereotype of “European car, fragile vehicle."

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Chairman of the Board and CEO
node.subject: Auto Parts
node.title: Piece By Piece
node.sections01: I was born in Mexicali, and studied engineering in the US, specializing in the automotive business, which proved greatly influential for me. When I graduated I started working in the automotive sector for the family business. It took us six years to shed the fallout of the crisis in the early 1980s. At that time, Michelin bought Uniroyal and entered the Mexican market. This was a huge opportunity for us as the company offered us the opportunity to start the business in Sonora, where there was no competition from the US. It took us 10 years to succeed in Baja California, and three years to achieve success in Sonora, where I send all of my employees who had braved the tough days of the company. This was our best formula for success, because our people absolutely loved their jobs. The other key to our success involved key changes to our showrooms 30 years ago when I made them appealing to both sexes, employing both male and female staff, where it had been traditional to employ men in our business. These changes have made us into what we are today.
node.sections11: It a global level, Pirelli has always had a strategy of diversification regarding its manufacturing locations. The NAFTA market has been one of the great opportunities for the company. When we made the decision to build another plant to serve the NAFTA region, we selected Mexico for a number of reasons. Geographically, it is very well situated to serve markets to the north and south. At our plant in Silao, we have a research and development group of 22 engineers, 20 of whom are Mexican, and we continue to provide our compatriots with employment in their home country. At this plant, we made an initial investment of $200 million, and we are now in the process of investing an identical sum. This is a large plant of 135,000 sqm under one roof. In 2017, when it becomes fully operational, it will employ 1,400 direct and 400 indirect employees with a total of 1,800 jobs created. Our managerial staff comprises expatriates and Mexicans, although our goal is to be managed only by Mexicans.
node.sections21: Rassini continues to drive top and bottom line growth and focus on leveraging opportunities in the US, Mexico, and Brazil. Our consistent focus on technology and engineering development has enabled us to secure new contracts; more than 40 new platforms since 2012. More specifically, North America represents 71% of our sales, so we are very optimistic about this market. The vehicle production projections for 2014 in the region are above 16.8 million units, which is an increase of 8% over 2013. Mexico is increasing its production in an accelerated manner, and we are poised to leverage this growth as our headquarters, production plants, and operations facilities are strategically located throughout Mexico. Rassini has a close relationship with the University of Ontario, the University of Michigan, and the UNAM, among others, and we are continuously working with the academic centers in the US and Mexico, such as the Tecnológico de Monterrey, which produces excellent engineers. Mexico is producing better people with greater skills every year.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Heavy Auto
node.title: Big Wheels
node.sections01: New generations of entrepreneurs will face different challenges to those we faced in our early days; globalization and new technologies have definitely changed the way we do business. If we want to be competitive, we have to adapt international standards and working practices. Therefore, the level of readiness has to be higher than the one we had, because the market is now the whole world, rather than just one country. They have the right tools to make sure they become competitive players in their sectors. Buses are one of the primary modes of transport in Mexico, and I am sure this will continue to be the case over the medium term. We are committed to continue developing the sector, while also assessing business opportunities abroad. We are seeing foreign brands coming into Mexico, and that is a strong signal to everybody that the market holds opportunity and potential. The increasing arrival of foreign brands will increase competition, further encouraging us to achieve international standards to become more competitive and achieve a leading position in the market. We must be flexible enough to adapt ourselves to market changes.
node.sections11: The market in Mexico is controlled by large players. What we have developed for them is a “fit for use" concept, and in-house implementation, such as in-sourcing to service the buses, which is completely tailor made. Today, we are managing more than 35 customer workshops. In those cases, we are doing everything for their fleets, including multi-branding. It has been a great advantage for us because, as the concept was so successful, our clients have subsequently asked us to take care of their other brands. So we are inside, charging per kilometer. If the buses are running, we charge, and if they do not run, we do not charge anything. It is a win-win situation, and we are true partners with those companies. With input from our customers, Scania has changed the bus transport philosophy in Mexico. Scania has a market share of well over half of the long-distance coach market in Mexico—there is no other country in the world where Scania has this level of market share participation.
node.sections21: Kenworth Mexicana has about 2,000 employees. This includes manufacturing facilities as well as the commercial and financing arm of the company. We used to produce 62 tractors per day at this plant, but we now have a figure of 50 per day as a result of a slowdown in some of the export markets that we serve, specifically Colombia. Right now the tractor market is undergoing several changes in terms of the regulations and requirements for the registration of a new tractor. The result of these changes has been a slowdown of vehicle imports. We have been experiencing high demand for heavy-duty trucks. The demand for those was 24,000 in 2012; that is close to the historic best year for Mexico. We were shooting for 12% growth in demand in 2013, but that did not happen. We are cautious about 2014, and projections are set at a 1% or 2% increase. We think that 2015 will be really interesting and that it will start to see the impact of the reforms. We hope that 2016 and onward will be all-time record breakers, with about 27,000 units sold.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Services
node.title: With a Smile
node.sections01: We view Kazakhstan as a growth market for our company based on its geographic positioning between the two superpowers of China and Russia. It's an emerging market with rich natural resources, mainly oil and gas, and also an attractive mining sector. That's on the energy side of our business. Meanwhile, on our supply chain side, we view Kazakhstan and the greater Central Asia region as a whole as a growth sector for us supporting our government business in Afghanistan. In order to shorten the supply chain and provide best value sourcing and delivery options to our customers, we source a wide range or product categories out of Central Asia for our customers in Afghanistan. Over the years, we have seen quite a dynamic range of products, including steel, power cables, generators, consumables supplies, construction supplies, and also various ship food products for the US in Afghanistan.
node.sections11: To date, the vast majority of our investment has been in Atyrau as the majority of our revenues are generated by our assets there. Recently, we have been focused very much on improving the quality of our assets and the lives of our guests and tenants in Atyrau and by doing so the lives of people living there in general. With our current development plans for quality apartments, leisure, and recreational facilities I think we will more than accomplish our goals there. In Aktau, our business today is not significantly related the oil and gas business. We do, however, believe that Aktau will experience significant growth once the offshore oil industry does begin to expand and those that are properly invested locally will reap the benefits of that investment.
node.sections21: Training, recruitment, out staffing, and consulting are our standard services, like all other companies that work in the field of human resource consulting. We offer standard training programs, such as soft skills, technical oil and gas training, and programs in the uranium-processing industry. We also came across certain trainers who wanted to implement a new product in the market, with whom we now cooperate. They develop a certain program that we in turn offer to our clients. This is something new for the Kazakhstani market. Education is problematic and is undergoing a transformation in Kazakhstan. College and university graduates often do not meet companies' requirements. This is why our agency's services are still in demand; the fact is that we offer tailored training services.
node.sections31: WorleyParsons is a leading provider of project delivery and engineering services to the resources and energy sectors and complex process industries. Safety is our number one priority—we are committed to creating inherently safer workplaces and sustainability in our operations. In our 16-year operation in Kazakhstan, we have consistently achieved a world-class safety record. And over the past three years, we have worked almost 6.5 million man-hours, with just four recordable injuries, achieving a total recordable case frequency rate of just 0.12 per 200,000 hours. However, our vision is zero harm to people, assets, and the environment.
node.sections41: Lloyd's Register Kazakhstan opened in 2006. Our intention here was the same as it is in every other market, namely to help our clients manage their technical and operational risks by using our global regulatory knowledge, technical expertise, and ability to create bespoke, innovative solutions. In Kazakhstan, we provide independent verification services. In addition, we deliver independent technical assurance services to the drilling and manufacturing sectors. Our clients in Kazakhstan are typically quality focused; they are companies that understand that you cannot compromise or cut corners when investing in safety, environmental stewardship, and the operational efficiency of high-value assets.

node.author: TBY
node.subject: Banking Outlook
node.title: A Deposit in Time
node.sections01: The weakness of the Kazakhstani banking system is that it has been in crisis for too long, for various reasons. The banking sector has also lagged behind the general Kazakhstani economy, which has long recovered and is now due to expand. The good news is that the government has taken the right steps by privatizing three nationalized banks, namely Alliance, BTA, and Temirbank, which is a sign that the banking system is entering recovery. After all, the economy cannot really recover; there is much less growth without a well functioning banking system. I foresee the recovery beginning in 2014.
node.sections11: We are trying to build one of the most client-orientated banks in the country. To do this, we focus on improving all processes within the bank to make sure our clients receive the highest-quality services swiftly and efficiently. We focus on fostering close relations with our clients, as in many former-Soviet countries there is at best a limited notion of service-orientation. As we work with the SME segment, many of the products we provide are highly custom-built to cater to its needs, such as the “Forte NoLimit" product we launched in 2013. Our approach is to offer solid, well-priced products, of the best quality, and delivered with the best service.
node.sections21: To help solve the problem with non-performing loans (NPLs), we need to give banks the opportunity to earn more. After all, the higher a bank's profit, the easier it is to form the necessary provisions. And the greater the level of provisions, the easier it is for a bank to make a decision to write off debts. However, any restriction on a bank's activities, which, at first glance, means reducing risks, ultimately reduces profit and postpones any decision on writing off debts. Secondly, the government might consider changing tax payment terms for collection companies. Currently, the corporate income tax (20%) is due once discounted debts are transferred to the collection companies. In my opinion, these companies should not be paying taxes upfront, but only after receiving profits.
node.sections31: Our main aim is to be a successful Islamic commercial bank. The second is to find opportunities for UAE-based investors to invest in Kazakhstan and to thereby promote diversification, as well as see if there are Kazakh investors who can find opportunities in the UAE. An equally important objective is to raise the profile of Islamic finance in Kazakhstan and CIS countries. We held a session for about 150 imams from the Almaty area as part of a new strategy of educating communities. It is highly important that we explain that Islamic finance does not mean free banking. It is true that we do not charge interest in the true sense of the word, but there is a cost involved in any type of financing, of course.
node.sections41: Public confidence in Russian banks is high in the Kazakh market. Our main advantage in working with the corporate sector is being able to serve Kazakh business entities, which could not be served by local banks during the financial crisis of 2007-2009. There were reduced limits on Kazakhstan's banks from the Western partners, which impacted trade and financial services. We represent a universal bank, engaged in investment transactions and corporate business. We are interested both in small- and medium-sized businesses and in working with retail clients, providing a comprehensive range of services.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist2position: Chairman of the Executive Board & CEO
node.subject: Insurers
node.title: Safe Hands
node.sections01: The necessity for the development of draft legislation for obligatory insurance of real estate against catastrophic risks brewed long ago. For example, Kazakhstan is a sufficiently large territory in a zone of seismic activity. Currently, the state bears responsibility for the cover of losses; however, in a large accident it can become an intolerable burden for the state. In this case, it is necessary to form a special fund of insurance against catastrophic risks. Therein, Kazakhstan could use the experience of Turkey as an example. The introduction of this type of insurance will be the impulse for the development of voluntary insurance. People will realize the risks associated with loss or damage to real estate. The establishment of such a fund is not possible without the participation of the state; however, insurers should not be excluded from the insurance process. They shall act not only as agents, but also as operators, professional participants in risk pooling, influencing the successful functioning of the fund and the development of this class of insurance. In addition, there is currently an interest in the introduction of obligatory medical insurance in Kazakhstan.
node.sections11: The insurance market is challenging and requires a comprehensive approach. First of all, it is necessary to design the market development strategy. Second, we should apply good practices and international experience in the sector. As global practice suggests, an insurance market regulator should be a separate entity, unlike in Kazakhstan, where the regulator is the National Bank. This may result in positive changes to the industry. As for the financial culture, there is no silver bullet, and it will take time to build trust in the insurance sector. Perceptions of the need for insurance and purchasing habits will change with the emergence of a new generation. Premiums need to be paid promptly and the market needs to deal with the risks. It is impossible to underestimate the importance of a regulator in the developments. Therefore, GAK is not meant to intensify the competition in the industry. We represent an experimental platform and a bridge between the state and citizens. Given that GAK is a public company with 100% of its shares owned by the state, we are very conservative when estimating risks, and are a role model for the insurance industry.
node.sections21: Success is really about the delivery of a quality service. For example, we already have all our client's documents, which are required in case of loss, in our database and do not bother clients for new copies. Our company policy is not to penalize our employees if they make omissions in their work, rather we make sure they know their problems and have instruments to address them. This importantly allows our staff to feel their own responsibility and grow professionally. Ours is a very interesting and rather unique operation system. Generally, our staff don't consult top management unless they need to know how to tackle a particularly sensitive situation. Another reality of the London-Almaty workplace is that happy and confident employees being proud of their work transfer this feeling to the clients. Many employers in Kazakhstan simply fail to grasp this. The state regulation of the insurance industry is very efficient in Kazakhstan, and we are well ahead of the other CIS markets. For example, an insurance agent is not allowed to take cash from clients; this eliminates a scope of risk for the client and the insurer. Insurance companies have, therefore, taken greater precautions with their agents.
